<phrase_Q=0.591>An overview</phrase> is presented of the use of <phrase_Q=0.852>spatial data</phrase> structures in <phrase_Q=0.893>spatial databases</phrase>. The focus is on <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> structures, including a number of variants of <phrase_Q=0.866>quadtrees</phrase>, which <phrase_Q=0.842>sort</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> with respect to the space occupied by it. Such techniques are known as <phrase_Q=0.897>spatial indexing</phrase> methods. <phrase_Q=0.850>Hierarchical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> structures are based on the principle of <phrase_Q=0.855>recursive</phrase> decomposition. They are attractive because they are <phrase_Q=0.829>compact</phrase> and depending on the <phrase_Q=1.000>nature</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> they save space as well as time and also facilitate operations such as search. Specifying Systems, The <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Language</phrase> and Tools for Hardware and <phrase_Q=1.000>Software</phrase> Engineers
From the <phrase_Q=1.000>Book</phrase>: This <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> will teach you how to write specifications of <phrase_Q=0.518>computer systems</phrase>, using the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.814>It's</phrase> rather <phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase>, but most people will <phrase_Q=0.588>read only</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.567>Part I</phrase>, which comprises the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> 83 pages. That part contains all that most engineers need to know about <phrase_Q=0.515>writing specifications</phrase>; it assumes only the <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> background in <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase> expected of an <phrase_Q=1.000>undergraduate</phrase> studying <phrase_Q=1.000>engineering</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.705>computer science</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.691>Part II</phrase> contains more <phrase_Q=0.803>advanced</phrase> material for more sophisticated readers. The remainder of the <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> is a <phrase_Q=0.923>reference manual</phrase><phrase_Q=0.657>Part III</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase> tools and <phrase_Q=0.653>Part IV</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> itself. The <phrase_Q=0.866>TLA</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>World Wide Web</phrase> page contains material to accompany the <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase>, including the <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase> tools, exercises, references to the <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase>, and a list of corrections. There is a link to the <phrase_Q=0.866>TLA</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>Web</phrase> page on <phrase_Q=0.827>http</phrase>://lamport.org.What Is a Specification?Writing is <phrase_Q=0.886>nature's</phrase> way of letting you know how sloppy your <phrase_Q=0.805>thinking</phrase> is.-GuindonA specification is a written description of what a system is supposed to do. Specifying a system helps us understand it. <phrase_Q=0.814>It's</phrase> a good idea to understand a system before <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> it, so <phrase_Q=0.814>it's</phrase> a good idea to write a specification of a system before implementing it.This <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> is about specifying the <phrase_Q=0.843>behavioral</phrase> properties of a systemalso called its <phrase_Q=0.811>functional</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.810>logical</phrase> properties. These are the properties that specify what the system is supposed to do. There are other important kinds of properties that we don't consider, including <phrase_Q=0.533>performance properties</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.933>Worst-case</phrase> performance can often be expressed as a <phrase_Q=0.843>behavioral</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>property</phrase>forexample, <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 9 explains how to specify that a system must react within a certain length of time. However, specifying <phrase_Q=1.000>average</phrase> performance is beyond the scope of the methods described here.Our <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> tool for <phrase_Q=0.515>writing specifications</phrase> is <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Mathematics</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.886>nature's</phrase> way of letting you know how sloppy your writing is. <phrase_Q=0.814>It's</phrase> hard to be precise in an imprecise <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> like <phrase_Q=1.000>English</phrase> or <phrase_Q=1.000>Chinese</phrase>. In <phrase_Q=1.000>engineering</phrase>, imprecision can <phrase_Q=1.000>lead</phrase> to errors. To avoid errors, <phrase_Q=1.000>science</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>engineering</phrase> have adopted <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase> as their language.The <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase> we use is more formal than the <phrase_Q=1.000>math</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.849>you've</phrase> grown up with. <phrase_Q=0.782>Formal mathematics</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.886>nature's</phrase> way of letting you know how sloppy your <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase> is. The <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase> written by most <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematicians</phrase> and scientists is not really precise. <phrase_Q=0.814>It's</phrase> precise in the small, but imprecise in the large. Each equation is a precise <phrase_Q=0.827>assertion</phrase>, but you have to read the accompanying words to understand how the equations relate to one another and exactly what the theorems mean. Logicians have developed ways of eliminating those words and making the <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase> completely formal, and hence completely precise.Most <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematicians</phrase> and scientists think that <phrase_Q=0.782>formal mathematics</phrase>, without words, is <phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase> and tiresome. They're wrong. Ordinary <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase> can be expressed compactly in a precise, completely <phrase_Q=1.000>formal language</phrase>. It takes only about two dozen lines to define the <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> to an arbitrary <phrase_Q=1.000>differential equation</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>Differential Equations</phrase> module of <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 11. But few specifications need such sophisticated <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase>. Most require only simple application of a few standard <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematical</phrase> concepts.Why <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase>?We specify a system by describing its allowed behaviorswhat it may do in the course of an execution. In 1977, <phrase_Q=1.000>Amir Pnueli</phrase> introduced the use of <phrase_Q=1.000>temporal logic</phrase> for describing system behaviors. In principle, a system could be described by a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>temporal logic</phrase> formula. In practice, it couldn't. Pnueli's <phrase_Q=1.000>temporal logic</phrase> was ideal for describing some properties of systems, but awkward for others. So, it was usually combined with a more traditional way of describing systems.In the <phrase_Q=0.582>late 1980s</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> invented <phrase_Q=0.866>TLA</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>Temporal Logic</phrase> of Actionsa simple variant of Pnueli's original <phrase_Q=1.000>logic</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.866>TLA</phrase> makes it <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> to describe a system by a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> formula. Most of a <phrase_Q=0.866>TLA</phrase> specification consists of ordinary, nontemporal <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Temporal logic</phrase> plays a significant role only in describing those properties that <phrase_Q=0.814>it's</phrase> good at describing. <phrase_Q=0.866>TLA</phrase> also provides a <phrase_Q=1.000>nice</phrase> way to formalize the style of <phrase_Q=0.577>reasoning about</phrase> systems that has proved to be most effective in practicea style known as <phrase_Q=0.894>assertional reasoning</phrase>. However, this <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> is about specification; it says almost nothing about proofs.Temporal <phrase_Q=1.000>logic</phrase> assumes an underlying <phrase_Q=1.000>logic</phrase> for expressing ordinary <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase>. There are many ways to formalize ordinary <phrase_Q=1.000>math</phrase>. Most <phrase_Q=0.607>computer scientists</phrase> prefer one that resembles their favorite <phrase_Q=1.000>programming language</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> chose instead the one that most <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematicians</phrase> preferthe one logicians call <phrase_Q=1.000>first-order logic</phrase> and set theory.TLA provides a <phrase_Q=0.880>mathematical foundation</phrase> for describing systems. To write specifications, we need a complete <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.753>built atop</phrase> that <phrase_Q=0.839>foundation</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> initially thought that this <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> should be some <phrase_Q=0.842>sort</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.834>abstract</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>programming language</phrase> whose <phrase_Q=1.000>semantics</phrase> would be based on <phrase_Q=0.866>TLA</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.531>didn't know</phrase> what kind of <phrase_Q=1.000>programming language</phrase> constructs would be best, so <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> decided to start <phrase_Q=0.515>writing specifications</phrase> directly in <phrase_Q=0.866>TLA</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> intended to introduce <phrase_Q=1.000>programming</phrase> constructs as <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> needed them. To my surprise, <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> discovered that <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> didn't need them. What <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> needed was a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> for writing mathematics.Although <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematicians</phrase> have developed the <phrase_Q=1.000>science</phrase> of writing formulas, they haven't turned that <phrase_Q=1.000>science</phrase> into an <phrase_Q=1.000>engineering</phrase> discipline. They have developed notations for <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase> in the small, but not for <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase> in the large. The specification of a real system can be dozens or even hundreds of pages <phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Mathematicians</phrase> know how to write 20-line formulas, not 20-page formulas. So, <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> had to introduce notations for writing <phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase> formulas. What <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> took from <phrase_Q=1.000>programming languages</phrase> were ideas for <phrase_Q=0.865>modularizing</phrase> large specifications.The <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> came up with is called <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> refined <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase> in the course of <phrase_Q=0.515>writing specifications</phrase> of disparate systems. But it has changed little in the <phrase_Q=0.828>last</phrase> few years. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> have found <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase> to be quite good for specifying a wide class of systemsfrom program interfaces (<phrase_Q=0.859>APIs</phrase>) to <phrase_Q=1.000>distributed systems</phrase>. It can be used to write a precise, <phrase_Q=0.858>formal description</phrase> of almost any <phrase_Q=0.842>sort</phrase> of discrete system. <phrase_Q=0.814>It's</phrase> especially <phrase_Q=0.524>well suited</phrase> to describing <phrase_Q=0.838>asynchronous</phrase> systemsthat is, systems with components that do not operate in strict <phrase_Q=0.826>lock</phrase>-step.About This BookPart <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase>, consisting of Chapters 1 through 7, is the core of the <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> and is meant to be read from beginning to end. It explains how to specify the class of properties known as <phrase_Q=1.000>safety</phrase> properties. These properties, which can be specified with almost no <phrase_Q=1.000>temporal logic</phrase>, are all that most engineers need to know about. After <phrase_Q=1.000>reading</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.567>Part I</phrase>, you can read as much of <phrase_Q=0.691>Part II</phrase> as you like. Each of its chapters is <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> of the others. <phrase_Q=1.000>Temporal logic</phrase> comes to the <phrase_Q=0.832>fore</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 8, where it is used to specify the additional class of properties known as <phrase_Q=0.918>liveness properties</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 9 describes how to specify <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> properties, and <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 10 describes how to write specifications as compositions. <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 11 contains more <phrase_Q=0.803>advanced</phrase> examples. The three chapters in <phrase_Q=0.657>Part III</phrase> serve as the <phrase_Q=0.923>reference manual</phrase> for three <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase> tools: the <phrase_Q=1.000>Syntactic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.838>Analyzer</phrase>, the TLATEX <phrase_Q=1.000>typesetting</phrase> program, and the <phrase_Q=0.886>TLC model checker</phrase>. If <phrase_Q=0.501>you want</phrase> to use <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase>, then you probably want to use these tools. They are available from the <phrase_Q=0.866>TLA</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>Web</phrase> page. <phrase_Q=0.852>TLC</phrase> is the most sophisticated of them. The examples on the <phrase_Q=0.835>Web</phrase> can get you started using it, but you'll have to read <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 14 to learn to use <phrase_Q=0.852>TLC</phrase> effectively.Part <phrase_Q=0.812>IV</phrase> is a <phrase_Q=0.923>reference manual</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.567>Part I</phrase> provides a <phrase_Q=0.614>good enough</phrase> working <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> for most purposes. You need look at <phrase_Q=0.653>Part IV</phrase> only if you have questions about the <phrase_Q=0.818>fine</phrase> points of the <phrase_Q=1.000>syntax</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>semantics</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 15 gives the <phrase_Q=1.000>syntax</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 16 describes the precise meanings and the <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> forms of all the built-in operators of <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase>; <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 17 describes the <phrase_Q=0.616>precise meaning</phrase> of all the <phrase_Q=0.827>higher-level</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase> constructs such as definitions. Together, these two chapters specify the <phrase_Q=1.000>semantics</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 18 describes the standard modulesexcept for module <phrase_Q=0.802>RealTime</phrase>, described in <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 9, and module <phrase_Q=0.852>TLC</phrase>, described in <phrase_Q=0.865>Chapter</phrase> 14. You might want to look at this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> if <phrase_Q=0.845>you're</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.831>curious</phrase> about how standard <phrase_Q=1.000>elementary</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematics</phrase> can be formalized in <phrase_Q=0.597>TLA+</phrase>.<phrase_Q=0.653>Part IV</phrase> does have something you may want to refer to often: a <phrase_Q=1.000>mini</phrase>-manual that compactly presents lots of useful <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.837>Toolkit</phrase>
From the Book:Tcl was <phrase_Q=0.814>born</phrase> of frustration. In the <phrase_Q=0.798>early 1980s</phrase> my students and <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> developed a number of <phrase_Q=0.822>interactive</phrase> tools at the <phrase_Q=1.000>University</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>California</phrase> at <phrase_Q=1.000>Berkeley</phrase>, mostly for <phrase_Q=1.000>integrated circuit design</phrase>, and we found ourselves spending a <phrase_Q=0.823>lot</phrase> of time <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> bad <phrase_Q=0.812>command languages</phrase>. Each tool needed to have a <phrase_Q=0.940>command language</phrase> of some <phrase_Q=0.842>sort</phrase>, but our main interest was in the tool rather than its <phrase_Q=0.940>command language</phrase>. We spent as little time as possible on the <phrase_Q=0.940>command language</phrase> and always ended up with a <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> that was weak and quirky. Furthermore, the <phrase_Q=0.940>command language</phrase> for one tool was never quite right for the <phrase_Q=0.822>next</phrase> tool, so we ended up <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> a new bad <phrase_Q=0.940>command language</phrase> for each tool. This became increasingly frustrating.In the <phrase_Q=0.802>fall</phrase> of 1987 it occurred to <phrase_Q=0.821>me</phrase> that the <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> was to build a reusable <phrase_Q=0.940>command language</phrase>. If a <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase>-purpose <phrase_Q=1.000>scripting language</phrase> could be built as a <phrase_Q=0.839>C</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>library</phrase> package, then perhaps it could be reused for many different purposes in many different applications. Of course, the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> would need to be <phrase_Q=0.814>extensible</phrase> so that each application could add its own <phrase_Q=0.666>specific features</phrase> to the core provided by the <phrase_Q=1.000>library</phrase>. In the <phrase_Q=0.865>spring</phrase> of 1988 <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> decided to implement such a <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase>, and the result was <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> was also <phrase_Q=0.814>born</phrase> of frustration. The <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> idea for <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> arose in response to <phrase_Q=0.801>Apple's</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.874>announcement</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>HyperCard</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.802>fall</phrase> of 1987. <phrase_Q=1.000>HyperCard</phrase> generated tremendous excitement because of the power of the system and the way in which it allowed many different <phrase_Q=0.822>interactive</phrase> elements to be scripted and work together. However, <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> was discouraged. The <phrase_Q=1.000>HyperCard</phrase> system had obviously taken a large <phrase_Q=0.831>development effort</phrase>, and it seemed unlikely to <phrase_Q=0.821>me</phrase> that a <phrase_Q=0.815>small group</phrase> such as a <phrase_Q=1.000>university</phrase> researchproject could ever <phrase_Q=1.000>mount</phrase> such a <phrase_Q=0.809>massive</phrase> effort. This suggested that we would not be able to participate in the development of new forms of <phrase_Q=0.822>interactive</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> in the future.I concluded that the only hope for us was a component approach. Rather than <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> a new application as a <phrase_Q=0.810>self</phrase>-contained <phrase_Q=1.000>monolith</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.510>hundreds of thousands</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.577>lines of code</phrase>, we needed to find a way to divide applications into many smaller <phrase_Q=0.940>reusable components</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.842>Ideally</phrase> each component would be small enough to be implemented by a <phrase_Q=0.815>small group</phrase>, and interesting applications could be created by <phrase_Q=0.824>assembling</phrase> components. In this environment it should be possible to create an exciting new application by developing one new component and then combining it with existing components.The <phrase_Q=0.866>component-based</phrase> approach requires a powerful and <phrase_Q=0.821>flexible</phrase> "<phrase_Q=0.862>glue</phrase>"for <phrase_Q=0.824>assembling</phrase> the components, and it occurred to <phrase_Q=0.821>me</phrase> that perhaps a shared <phrase_Q=1.000>scripting language</phrase> could provide that <phrase_Q=0.862>glue</phrase>. Out of this <phrase_Q=0.805>thinking</phrase> grew <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase>, an <phrase_Q=1.000>X11</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.837>toolkit</phrase> based on <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> allows components to be either <phrase_Q=0.696>individual user</phrase>-interface controls or entire applications; in either case components can be <phrase_Q=0.516>developed independently</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> can be used to assemble the components and communicate between them.I started writing <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> as a hobby in my spare time. As other people began to use the systems <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> found myself spending more and more time on them, to the point where today they occupy almost all of my waking hours and many of my <phrase_Q=0.840>sleeping</phrase> ones.Tcl and <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> have succeeded beyond my wildest <phrase_Q=0.818>dreams</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.948>Tcl/Tk</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.746>developer community</phrase> now numbers in the <phrase_Q=0.642>tens of thousands</phrase> and there are thousands of <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> applications in existence or under development. The <phrase_Q=0.724>application areas</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>cover</phrase> virtually the entire <phrase_Q=1.000>spectrum</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>graphical</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>engineering</phrase> applications, including <phrase_Q=1.000>computer-aided design</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>software development</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.821>testing</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.698>instrument control</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>scientific visualization</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>multimedia</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> is used by itself in many applications, and <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> are used together in many others. <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> are being used by hundreds of companies, large and small, as well as <phrase_Q=1.000>universities</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> laboratories.One benefit that came as a surprise to <phrase_Q=0.821>me</phrase> is that it is possible to create interesting <phrase_Q=1.000>graphical user interfaces</phrase> (GUIs) entirely as <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> scripts. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> had always assumed that every <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> application would contain some new <phrase_Q=0.839>C</phrase> code that implements new <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> commands, plus some <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> scripts that combine the new commands with the built-in facilities provided by <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase>. However, once a simple <phrase_Q=0.948>Tcl/Tk</phrase> application called wish became available, many people began creating <phrase_Q=1.000>user interfaces</phrase> by writing <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> scripts for it, without writing any <phrase_Q=0.839>C</phrase> code at all! It turned out that the <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> commands provide a <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-level interface to <phrase_Q=1.000>GUI</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>programming</phrase> that hides many of the details faced by a <phrase_Q=0.839>C</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>programmer</phrase>. As a result, it is <phrase_Q=0.551>much easier</phrase> to learn how to use wish than a <phrase_Q=0.839>C</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=0.837>toolkit</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>user interfaces</phrase> can be written with much less code. Most <phrase_Q=0.948>Tcl/Tk</phrase> users never write any <phrase_Q=0.839>C</phrase> code at all and most of the <phrase_Q=0.948>Tcl/Tk</phrase> applications consist solely of <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> scripts.This <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> is intended as an <phrase_Q=0.822>introduction</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> for programmers who plan to write or modify <phrase_Q=0.948>Tcl/Tk</phrase> applications. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> assume that readers have programmed in <phrase_Q=0.839>C</phrase> and have at least passing familiarity with a <phrase_Q=0.833>shell</phrase> such as <phrase_Q=0.884>sh</phrase> or csh or ksh. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> also assume that readers have used the <phrase_Q=0.814>X</phrase> Window System and are familiar with <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> ideas such as using the <phrase_Q=1.000>mouse</phrase>, resizing <phrase_Q=1.000>windows</phrase>, etc. No <phrase_Q=0.768>prior experience</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> is needed in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to read this <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase>, and you need not have written <phrase_Q=0.814>X</phrase> applications using other toolkits such as Motif.The <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> is organized so that you can learn <phrase_Q=1.000>Tcl</phrase> without <phrase_Q=0.807>learning</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.882>Tk</phrase> if you wish. Traditional <phrase_Q=1.000>Software Design</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Virtual Memory</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Virtual memory</phrase> is the <phrase_Q=1.000>simulation</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.768>storage space</phrase> so large that programmers do not need to reprogram or recompile their works when the capacity of a <phrase_Q=0.765>local memory</phrase> or the configuration of a network changes. The name, borrowed from <phrase_Q=1.000>optics</phrase>, recalls the <phrase_Q=0.805>virtual</phrase> images formed by mirrors and <phrase_Q=0.801>lenses</phrase>--images that are not there but behave as if they are. The designers of the <phrase_Q=0.885>Atlas</phrase> Computer at the <phrase_Q=1.000>University</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Manchester</phrase> invented <phrase_Q=1.000>virtual memory</phrase> in the 1950s to eliminate a <phrase_Q=0.805>looming</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>programming</phrase> problem: <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.814>scheduling</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> transfers between main and <phrase_Q=1.000>secondary</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>memory</phrase> and recompiling programs for each change of size of <phrase_Q=0.925>main memory</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Virtual memory</phrase> is even more useful in the <phrase_Q=1.000>computers</phrase> of the 1990s, which have more things to hide-<phrase_Q=0.532>on-chip</phrase> caches, separate <phrase_Q=1.000>RAM</phrase> chips, <phrase_Q=0.751>local disk</phrase> storage, network <phrase_Q=0.871>file servers</phrase> (q.v.), <phrase_Q=0.639>large numbers</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.858>separately compiled</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.769>program modules</phrase>, other <phrase_Q=1.000>computers</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=0.584>local bus</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.628>local network</phrase>, or the <phrase_Q=1.000>Internet</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.826>story</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>virtual memory</phrase> from then to now is a <phrase_Q=0.826>story</phrase> about machines <phrase_Q=0.618>helping programmers</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.560>solve problems</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.911>storage allocation</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.801>protection</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>, sharing and reuse of objects, and <phrase_Q=0.812>linking</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.528>program components</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Virtual memory</phrase>, common in all <phrase_Q=1.000>computers</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>operating systems</phrase> from the smallest <phrase_Q=1.000>microprocessor</phrase> to the largest <phrase_Q=1.000>supercomputer</phrase>, is now invading the <phrase_Q=1.000>Internet</phrase>.

Elements of <phrase_Q=1.000>Relational Database</phrase> Theory.
The goal of this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> is to provide a <phrase_Q=0.810>systematic</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.832>unifying</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>introduction</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>relational database</phrase> theory, including some of the <phrase_Q=0.938>recent developments</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>logic programming</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> part of the presentation covers the two <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> components of the <phrase_Q=1.000>relational</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data model</phrase>: its specification component, that is the <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> scheme with dependencies, and its operational component, that is the <phrase_Q=1.000>relational algebra</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>query language</phrase>. The choice of <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> constructs for specifying the <phrase_Q=0.896>semantically meaningful</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase> and for querying them is justified through an in-depth investigation of their properties. Some important <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> themes are reviewed in this context: the analysis of the <phrase_Q=1.000>hypergraph</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>syntax</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> scheme and the extensions of the <phrase_Q=1.000>query language</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.854>deduction</phrase> or <phrase_Q=1.000>universal</phrase> relation assumptions. The subsequent parts of the presentation are <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> around the two <phrase_Q=0.864>fundamental concepts</phrase> illustrated in the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> part, dependencies and queries. The <phrase_Q=0.657>main themes</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>dependency theory</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.586>implication problems</phrase> and applications to <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> scheme <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase>. Queries are classified in a <phrase_Q=1.000>variety</phrase> of ways, with emphasis on the connections between the <phrase_Q=0.828>expressibility</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.927>query languages</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.870>finite model theory</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>logic programming</phrase>. The theory of queries is very much related to <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> on <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>logic</phrase> programs, which are an elegant formalism for the study of the principles of <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge base</phrase> systems. The optimization of such programs involves both techniques developed for the <phrase_Q=1.000>relational</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data model</phrase> and new methods for <phrase_Q=0.803>analyzing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.855>recursive</phrase> definitions. The <phrase_Q=0.836>exposition</phrase> closes with a discussion of how <phrase_Q=1.000>relational database</phrase> theory deals with the problems of <phrase_Q=0.888>complex objects</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.944>incomplete information</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> updates.

<phrase_Q=0.843>Decidability</phrase> Questions for <phrase_Q=1.000>Petri Nets</phrase>
An <phrase_Q=0.816>understanding</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematical</phrase> properties of <phrase_Q=1.000>Petri Nets</phrase> is essential when one wishes to use <phrase_Q=1.000>Petri Nets</phrase> as an <phrase_Q=0.834>abstract</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.827>concurrent</phrase> systems. The <phrase_Q=0.843>decidability</phrase> of various problems which arise in this context is an important <phrase_Q=1.000>aspect</phrase> of this question. The <phrase_Q=0.814>fact</phrase> that these problems also arise in the context of other <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematical</phrase> theories, such as <phrase_Q=0.929>commutative semigroups</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.805>closure</phrase> under <phrase_Q=0.616>linear relations</phrase>, Matrix <phrase_Q=0.902>Context-Free grammars</phrase>, or Weak <phrase_Q=0.905>Counter Automata</phrase>, provides further <phrase_Q=1.000>motivation</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>Reachability</phrase> Problem for <phrase_Q=1.000>Vector</phrase> Addition Systems - whose <phrase_Q=0.843>decidability</phrase> is still an <phrase_Q=0.822>open</phrase> question - is of central importance. We show that a number of <phrase_Q=1.000>Petri Net</phrase> problems are recursively equivalent to this problem. These include the <phrase_Q=0.810>Liveness</phrase> Problem (e.g. can a system reach a deadlocked <phrase_Q=1.000>state</phrase>?), the <phrase_Q=0.814>persistence</phrase> problem (can a given transition ever be disabled by the firing of another transition?), and the membership and emptiness problems for certain classes of languages generated by <phrase_Q=1.000>Petri Nets</phrase>. The power of the unrestricted <phrase_Q=1.000>Petri Net</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is illustrated by various <phrase_Q=1.000>undecidable</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>equivalence</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase>. In particular, we show that the <phrase_Q=0.819>equality</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Reachability</phrase> Sets and the <phrase_Q=0.818>equivalence</phrase> of two <phrase_Q=1.000>Petri Nets</phrase> in terms of their <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase>-generating capability are <phrase_Q=0.855>recursive</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>undecidable</phrase>. It is hoped that the constructions used to prove our <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> will shed some <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> on the source of the complexities of the unrestricted <phrase_Q=1.000>Petri Net</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, and may eventually <phrase_Q=1.000>permit</phrase> us to achieve an <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase> balance between representational transparency and analytical power of the <phrase_Q=1.000>Petri Net</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.597>Axiomatic Proof</phrase> Techniques for <phrase_Q=0.831>Parallel</phrase> Programs
This <phrase_Q=1.000>thesis</phrase> presents an <phrase_Q=0.845>axiomatic</phrase> method for proving certain <phrase_Q=0.721>correctness properties</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.831>parallel</phrase> programs. <phrase_Q=1.000>Axioms</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.818>inference</phrase> rules for <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> correctness are given for two <phrase_Q=1.000>parallel programming</phrase> languages: The <phrase_Q=1.000>General</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.831>Parallel</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Language</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=0.808>Restricted</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.831>Parallel</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Language</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>General</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Language</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.821>flexible</phrase> enough to represent most standard <phrase_Q=0.810>synchronizers</phrase> (e.g. semaphores, events), so that programs using these <phrase_Q=0.810>synchronizers</phrase> may be verified using the <phrase_Q=1.000>GPL</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>deductive</phrase> system. However, proofs for <phrase_Q=1.000>GPL</phrase> programs are in <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> quite complex. The <phrase_Q=0.808>Restricted</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Language</phrase> reduces this complexity by requiring <phrase_Q=0.859>shared variables</phrase> to be <phrase_Q=1.000>protected</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.916>critical sections</phrase>, so that only one process at a time has access to them. This discipline does not <phrase_Q=0.739>significantly reduce</phrase> the power of the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase>, and it <phrase_Q=0.818>greatly simplifies</phrase> the process of <phrase_Q=0.936>program verification</phrase>. Although the <phrase_Q=1.000>axioms</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.818>inference</phrase> rules are <phrase_Q=0.555>primarily intended</phrase> for proofs of <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> correctness, there are a number of other important properties of <phrase_Q=0.831>parallel</phrase> programs. We give some <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> techniques which use <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> obtained from a <phrase_Q=0.939>partial correctness</phrase> proof to derive other <phrase_Q=0.721>correctness properties</phrase>, including <phrase_Q=0.885>program termination</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>mutual exclusion</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.565>freedom from deadlock</phrase>. A number of examples of such proofs are given. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>axioms</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.818>inference</phrase> rules are shown to be consistent and complete (in a special sense) with respect to an interpretive <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.831>parallel</phrase> execution. Thus the <phrase_Q=1.000>deductive</phrase> system gives an accurate description of <phrase_Q=0.918>program execution</phrase> and is powerful enough to yield a proof of any true <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> correctness formula.

<phrase_Q=1.000>Sketchpad</phrase>, A <phrase_Q=0.860>Man</phrase>-Machine <phrase_Q=1.000>Graphical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Communication</phrase> System
The <phrase_Q=1.000>Sketchpad</phrase> system makes it possible for a <phrase_Q=0.860>man</phrase> and a computer to <phrase_Q=0.855>converse</phrase> rapidly through the medium of <phrase_Q=0.970>line drawings</phrase>. Heretofore, most interaction between <phrase_Q=0.860>man</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>computers</phrase> has been <phrase_Q=0.643>slowed down</phrase> by the need to reduce all <phrase_Q=1.000>communication</phrase> to written statements that can be <phrase_Q=0.824>typed</phrase>; in the past, we have been writing <phrase_Q=0.828>letters</phrase> to rather than conferring with our <phrase_Q=1.000>computers</phrase>. For many types of <phrase_Q=1.000>communication</phrase>, such as describing the shape of a mechanical part or the connections of an <phrase_Q=1.000>electrical circuit</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.824>typed</phrase> statements can prove cumbersome. The <phrase_Q=1.000>Sketchpad</phrase> system, by eliminating <phrase_Q=0.824>typed</phrase> statements (except for <phrase_Q=0.824>legends</phrase>) in favor of <phrase_Q=0.970>line drawings</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.556>opens up</phrase> a new <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.850>man-machine communication</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> Verification of Programs with <phrase_Q=0.664>Complex Data Structures</phrase>

This study, compared with actual approaches, proposes a <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> based on <phrase_Q=0.823>active</phrase> functionalities.
Novel <phrase_Q=0.818>Indexing</phrase> Method of Relations Between <phrase_Q=0.900>Salient Objects</phrase>.

On the Computation of <phrase_Q=1.000>Recursion</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>Relational Databases</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=0.852>composite</phrase> object represented as a <phrase_Q=1.000>directed graph</phrase> is an important <phrase_Q=1.000>data structure</phrase> which requires <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> support in <phrase_Q=0.973>CAD/CAM</phrase>, CASE, <phrase_Q=0.858>office</phrase> systems, <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>management</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.835>Web</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.831>document databases</phrase>. It is cumbersome to handle such an object in <phrase_Q=1.000>relational database</phrase> systems when it involves <phrase_Q=0.855>recursive</phrase> relationships. In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase>, we present a new <phrase_Q=0.681>encoding method</phrase> to support the <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> computation of <phrase_Q=1.000>recursion</phrase>. In addition, we devise a <phrase_Q=0.606>linear time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to identify a <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> of reachable <phrase_Q=1.000>trees</phrase> (w.r.t.) a <phrase_Q=1.000>directed acyclic graph</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.861>DAG</phrase>), which covers all the edges of the <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase>. Together with the new <phrase_Q=0.681>encoding method</phrase>, this <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> enables us to compute <phrase_Q=1.000>recursion</phrase> w.r.t, a <phrase_Q=0.861>DAG</phrase> in time <phrase_Q=0.839>O</phrase>(<phrase_Q=1.000>e</phrase>), where <phrase_Q=1.000>e</phrase> represents the number of edges of the <phrase_Q=0.861>DAG</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.516>More importantly</phrase>, this method is especially suitable for a <phrase_Q=1.000>relational</phrase> environment.
<phrase_Q=0.810>Building</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.659>Signature-Trees</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.546>Path Signatures</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.831>Document Databases</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Java</phrase> is a prevailing implementation platform for <phrase_Q=0.884>XML-based</phrase> systems. In addition, we propose a new <phrase_Q=0.818>indexing</phrase> technique: <phrase_Q=0.546>path signatures</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.555>speed up</phrase> the evaluation of <phrase_Q=0.746>path-oriented</phrase> queries against document object sets, which is further <phrase_Q=0.819>enhanced</phrase> by combining the technique of <phrase_Q=0.659>signature-trees</phrase> with it to expedite scanning of signatures stored in a physical file.

<phrase_Q=0.822>Interactive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>Indexing</phrase> of Documents with a <phrase_Q=0.834>Multilingual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Thesaurus</phrase>.

The <phrase_Q=0.834>abstract</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>thesaurus</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.675>updated incrementally</phrase> by new <phrase_Q=0.601>indexed documents</phrase> and is used to search for documents using adequate terms.
<phrase_Q=0.816>Understanding</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.941>Functional Dependency</phrase>.
In <phrase_Q=0.815>explaining</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.941>functional dependency</phrase> to students, <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> have noticed in texts a <phrase_Q=0.801>mixture</phrase> of two types of elements: <phrase_Q=0.867>intensional</phrase> (or <phrase_Q=1.000>psychological</phrase> or meaning) and <phrase_Q=1.000>extensional</phrase> (patterns of <phrase_Q=0.823>repetition</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>). In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> examine whether it is possible to consider <phrase_Q=0.941>functional dependency</phrase>, in particular, in <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.806>third</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.940>normal forms</phrase>, solely on an <phrase_Q=1.000>extensional</phrase> basis. The <phrase_Q=1.000>Microsoft Access</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.838>Analyzer</phrase> utility seems to do so. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> illustrate the <phrase_Q=0.862>mix</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.867>intensional</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>extensional</phrase> elements in <phrase_Q=1.000>textbook</phrase> definitions of <phrase_Q=0.941>functional dependency</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> conclude that although in principle <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.569>third normal form</phrase> can be done solely by <phrase_Q=1.000>extensional</phrase> means, in practice <phrase_Q=0.867>intensional</phrase> considerations are indispensable. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> discuss these questions with respect to the "<phrase_Q=0.946>higher order</phrase>" <phrase_Q=0.940>normal forms</phrase>, namely <phrase_Q=0.845>Boyce-Codd</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.848>fourth</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.832>fifth</phrase> and Domain/Key <phrase_Q=0.962>normal form</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.860>Keyword-Based</phrase> Queries Over <phrase_Q=0.835>Web</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Databases</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase>, we propose an approach to using keywords (as in a <phrase_Q=1.000>Web search engine</phrase>) for <phrase_Q=0.781>querying databases</phrase> over the <phrase_Q=0.835>Web</phrase>. The approach is based on a <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian network</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> and provides a suitable <phrase_Q=1.000>alternative</phrase> to the use of interfaces based on multiple forms with several fields. Two <phrase_Q=1.000>major</phrase> steps are involved when querying a <phrase_Q=0.835>Web</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> using this approach. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>-like) queries are derived from a query composed only of the keywords specified by the user. <phrase_Q=0.822>Next</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> queries are submitted to a <phrase_Q=0.835>Web</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>, and the <phrase_Q=0.565>retrieved results</phrase> are presented to the user as <phrase_Q=0.611>ranked answers</phrase>. To demonstrate the feasibility of the approach, a simple <phrase_Q=1.000>prototype</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Web search</phrase> system based on the approach is presented. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> obtained with this system indicate that the approach allows for accurately <phrase_Q=0.821>structuring</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.766>user queries</phrase> and retrieving appropriate answers with <phrase_Q=0.815>minimum</phrase> intervention from the user.
System of <phrase_Q=1.000>Information Retrieval</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>XML</phrase> Documents.
This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> introduces the process to retrieve units (or subdocuments) of <phrase_Q=0.728>relevant information</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>XML</phrase> documents. For this, we use the <phrase_Q=1.000>Extensible Markup Language</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>XML</phrase>) which is considered as a new standard for <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> representation and exchange on the <phrase_Q=0.835>Web</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>XML</phrase> opens opportunities to develop a new <phrase_Q=0.801>generation</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Information Retrieval</phrase> System (<phrase_Q=1.000>IRS</phrase>) to improve the <phrase_Q=0.845>interrogation</phrase> process of <phrase_Q=0.669>document bases</phrase> on the Web.Our work focuses instead on <phrase_Q=0.885>end-users</phrase> who do not have expertise in the domain (like a <phrase_Q=0.833>majority</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.885>end-users</phrase>). This approach supports <phrase_Q=0.860>keyword-based</phrase> searching like <phrase_Q=1.000>classical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>IRS</phrase> and integrates <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> searching with the search attributes notion. It is based on an <phrase_Q=0.818>indexing</phrase> method of document <phrase_Q=1.000>tree</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>leafs</phrase> which authorize a <phrase_Q=0.777>content-oriented</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> subdocuments are ranked according to their similarity with the <phrase_Q=0.701>user's query</phrase>. We use a <phrase_Q=0.942>similarity measure</phrase> which is a compromise between two measures: exhaustiveness and specificity.
A <phrase_Q=1.000>Taxonomy</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.888>Object-Relational</phrase> Queries.
A <phrase_Q=1.000>comprehensive</phrase> study of <phrase_Q=0.888>object-relational</phrase> queries gives not only an <phrase_Q=0.816>understanding</phrase> of full capability of <phrase_Q=0.888>object-relational</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>query language</phrase> but also a direction for <phrase_Q=0.955>query processing</phrase> and optimization. This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> classifies <phrase_Q=0.888>object-relational</phrase> queries into <phrase_Q=0.815>REF</phrase> queries, <phrase_Q=0.921>aggregate queries</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>inheritance</phrase> queries. <phrase_Q=0.815>REF</phrase> queries are <phrase_Q=0.687>queries involving</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.815>REF</phrase> pointers, whereas <phrase_Q=0.814>aggregation</phrase> queries use either <phrase_Q=0.844>nested</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.505>table structures</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.801>index</phrase> on clusters. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>inheritance</phrase> queries are queries on <phrase_Q=0.942>inheritance hierarchies</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.652>Re-Engineering</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Automation</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Business Processes</phrase>: Criteria for Selecting <phrase_Q=0.658>Supporting Tools</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.652>Re-engineering</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>business processes</phrase> and their <phrase_Q=1.000>automation</phrase> is an activity very common in most organizations in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to keep or create a <phrase_Q=0.529>competitive business</phrase> advantage in the <phrase_Q=0.630>changing business environment</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Business Process Modeling</phrase> Tools (BPMTs) and <phrase_Q=1.000>Workflow</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Management</phrase> Systems (WFMSs) are the most popular tools used for <phrase_Q=1.000>business process</phrase> transformation and <phrase_Q=1.000>automation</phrase> of the redesigned <phrase_Q=1.000>business processes</phrase> within and outside organization's boundaries. This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> describes a set of criteria for selecting appropriate BPMTs and WFMSs among the <phrase_Q=0.803>diversity</phrase> of the tools offered in the market in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to assist the interested <phrase_Q=1.000>manager</phrase> or <phrase_Q=1.000>business process</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>engineer</phrase> to more successfully manage the <phrase_Q=1.000>business process</phrase> transformation. While establishing the proposed criteria, we considered currently available <phrase_Q=1.000>technology</phrase> and standards for <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>enterprise</phrase> support and <phrase_Q=0.920>inter-organizational</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>business process modeling</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>automation</phrase>.
Metrics for <phrase_Q=1.000>Data Warehouse</phrase> Quality.
This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> proposes a set of metrics to assess <phrase_Q=1.000>data warehouse</phrase> quality. A set of <phrase_Q=1.000>data warehouse</phrase> metrics is presented, and the formal and empirical validations that have been done with them. As we consider that <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> is the main organizational <phrase_Q=0.830>asset</phrase>, one of our primary duties should be <phrase_Q=0.809>assuring</phrase> its quality. Although some interesting guidelines have been proposed for <phrase_Q=0.801>designing</phrase> "good" <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> models for <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> warehouses, more <phrase_Q=0.502>objective indicators</phrase> are needed. Metrics are a useful objective mechanism for <phrase_Q=0.802>improving</phrase> the quality of <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>products</phrase> and also for <phrase_Q=0.801>determining</phrase> the best ways to help professionals and researchers. In this way, our goal is to elaborate a set of metrics for <phrase_Q=0.802>measuring</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data warehouse</phrase> quality which can help designers in choosing the best option among more than one <phrase_Q=1.000>alternative</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.968>Integrity Constraints</phrase> in an <phrase_Q=0.823>Active</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Database</phrase> Environment.

This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> describes a <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>narrowband</phrase> lowpass <phrase_Q=1.000>finite impulse response</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>FIR</phrase>) filter using a small number of multipliers per output sample (<phrase_Q=0.870>MPS</phrase>). The method is based on the use of a <phrase_Q=1.000>frequency</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.804>improved</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.855>recursive</phrase> running <phrase_Q=0.840>sum</phrase> (RRS), called the <phrase_Q=0.838>sharpening</phrase> RRS filter, and the interpolated <phrase_Q=1.000>finite impulse response</phrase> (IFIR) structure. The filter <phrase_Q=0.838>sharpening</phrase> technique uses <phrase_Q=0.654>multiple copies</phrase> of the same filter according to an <phrase_Q=1.000>amplitude</phrase> change <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> (ACF), which maps a <phrase_Q=1.000>transfer function</phrase> before <phrase_Q=0.838>sharpening</phrase> to a desired form after <phrase_Q=0.838>sharpening</phrase>. Querying <phrase_Q=0.894>Multidimensional Data</phrase>.
A powerful and easy-to-use querying environment is certainly one of the most important components in a <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>, and its effectiveness is influenced by many other aspects, both <phrase_Q=0.810>logical</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>data model</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase>, policy of <phrase_Q=0.960>view materialization</phrase>, etc.) and physical (<phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> or <phrase_Q=1.000>relational</phrase> storage, indexes, etc.). As is evident, <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> querying is often based on the <phrase_Q=1.000>metaphor</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>cube</phrase> and on the concepts of facts, measures, and dimensions. In contrast to conventional <phrase_Q=0.824>transactional</phrase> environments, <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> querying is often <phrase_Q=0.556>an exploratory</phrase> process, performed by <phrase_Q=0.821>navigating</phrase> along the dimensions and measures, increasing/decreasing the <phrase_Q=0.519>level of detail</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.801>focusing</phrase> on specific subparts of the <phrase_Q=1.000>cube</phrase> that appear to be "promising" for the required information.In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> we focus on the main languages proposed in the <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase> to express <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> queries, particularly those based on: (<phrase_Q=0.820>i</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.503>an algebraic</phrase> approach, (<phrase_Q=1.000>ii</phrase>) a <phrase_Q=0.863>declarative</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>paradigm</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>calculus</phrase>), and (iii) <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> constructs and <phrase_Q=1.000>syntax</phrase>. We analyze the problem of evaluation, i.e., the issues related to the <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.819>data retrieval</phrase> and calculation, possibly (often necessarily) using some <phrase_Q=0.796>pre-computed</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, a problem known in the <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase> as the problem of <phrase_Q=0.819>rewriting</phrase> a query using views. We also illustrate the use of particular <phrase_Q=0.801>index</phrase> structures to <phrase_Q=0.555>speed up</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.947>query evaluation</phrase> process.

<phrase_Q=0.624>Source Integration</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>Data Warehousing</phrase>.
While the <phrase_Q=0.717>main goal</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>data warehouse</phrase> is to provide support for <phrase_Q=1.000>data analysis</phrase> and management's decisions, a fundamental <phrase_Q=1.000>aspect</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>data warehouse</phrase> system is the process of <phrase_Q=0.803>acquiring</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.845>raw data</phrase> from a set of <phrase_Q=0.728>relevant information</phrase> sources. We will call <phrase_Q=0.624>source integration</phrase> system the component of a <phrase_Q=1.000>data warehouse</phrase> system dealing with this process. The <phrase_Q=0.717>main goal</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.624>source integration</phrase> system is to deal with the transfer of <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from the set of sources constituting the <phrase_Q=0.822>application-oriented</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.692>operational environment</phrase>, to the <phrase_Q=1.000>data warehouse</phrase>. Since sources are typically <phrase_Q=0.834>autonomous</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.812>distributed</phrase>, and heterogeneous, this task has to deal with the problem of <phrase_Q=0.807>cleaning</phrase>, reconciling, and integrating <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> coming from the sources. The <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.624>source integration</phrase> system is a very <phrase_Q=0.658>complex task</phrase>, which comprises several different issues. The purpose of this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> is to discuss the most important <phrase_Q=0.652>problems arising</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.624>source integration</phrase> system, with <phrase_Q=0.783>special emphasis</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.922>schema integration</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.638>processing queries</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>data integration</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.928>data cleaning</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.854>reconciliation</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.944>Incomplete Information</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.903>Multidimensional Databases</phrase>.
While <phrase_Q=0.944>incomplete information</phrase> is <phrase_Q=1.000>endemic</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.639>real-world data</phrase>, current <phrase_Q=0.894>multidimensional data</phrase> models are not engineered to manage <phrase_Q=0.944>incomplete information</phrase> in base <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.597>derived data</phrase>, and dimensions. This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> presents several strategies for managing <phrase_Q=0.944>incomplete information</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.903>multidimensional databases</phrase>. Which strategy to use is dependent on the kind of <phrase_Q=0.944>incomplete information</phrase> present, and also on where it occurs in the <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>. A relatively simple strategy is to replace <phrase_Q=0.944>incomplete information</phrase> with appropriate, <phrase_Q=0.597>complete information</phrase>. The advantage of this strategy is that all <phrase_Q=0.903>multidimensional databases</phrase> can manage <phrase_Q=0.597>complete information</phrase>. Other strategies require more substantial changes to the <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>. One strategy is to reflect the <phrase_Q=0.807>incompleteness</phrase> in computed aggregates, which is possible only if the <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> allows incomplete values in its <phrase_Q=0.817>hierarchies</phrase>. Another strategy is to measure the amount of <phrase_Q=0.807>incompleteness</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.549>aggregated values</phrase> by tallying how much <phrase_Q=0.857>uncertain information</phrase> went into their <phrase_Q=1.000>production</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Privacy</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.903>Multidimensional Databases</phrase>.
When <phrase_Q=0.912>answering queries</phrase> that <phrase_Q=0.830>ask</phrase> for, <phrase_Q=0.842>summary statistics</phrase>, the query-system of a <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> should <phrase_Q=1.000>guard</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.855>confidential data</phrase>, that is, it should avoid revealing (<phrase_Q=0.660>directly or indirectly</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.501>individual data</phrase>, which could be exactly calculated or <phrase_Q=0.652>accurately estimated</phrase> from the values of <phrase_Q=0.580>answered queries</phrase>. In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to prevent the <phrase_Q=0.556>disclosure of confidential</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, the query-system should be provided with an <phrase_Q=0.814>auditing</phrase> procedure which, each time a new query is processed, checks that its answer does not allow a (knowledgeable) user to disclose any <phrase_Q=0.723>sensitive data</phrase>. A promising approach consists in keeping <phrase_Q=1.000>track</phrase> of (or <phrase_Q=0.814>auditing</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.580>answered queries</phrase> by means a <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>graphical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> structure, here called the answer <phrase_Q=0.835>map</phrase>, whose <phrase_Q=0.632>size increases</phrase> with the number of <phrase_Q=0.580>answered queries</phrase> and with the number of dimensions of the <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>, so that the problem of the existence of <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>auditing</phrase> procedure <phrase_Q=0.737>naturally arises</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> reviews <phrase_Q=0.756>recent results</phrase> on this problem for "<phrase_Q=0.811>additive</phrase>" queries (such as <phrase_Q=1.000>COUNT</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.840>SUM</phrase> queries) by <phrase_Q=0.801>listing</phrase> some <phrase_Q=0.903>polynomially solvable</phrase> problems as well as some <phrase_Q=0.880>hard problems</phrase>, and suggests directions for future work.
Time in <phrase_Q=0.903>Multidimensional Databases</phrase>.
In spite of the obvious importance of time in <phrase_Q=1.000>data warehousing</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase>, current <phrase_Q=0.601>commercial systems</phrase> do not support <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>history</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>data warehouse</phrase>, either at the <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.880>instance level</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> we address this issue, <phrase_Q=0.804>introducing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.817>Temporal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>Multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> and a <phrase_Q=1.000>query language</phrase>, denoted TOLAP, allowing expressing <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase> queries at a <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> level of <phrase_Q=0.808>abstraction</phrase>. Further, we show that previous work in <phrase_Q=0.909>temporal databases</phrase> needs to be <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to handle <phrase_Q=1.000>evolution</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.832>versioning</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, we present an implementation, along with <phrase_Q=0.700>preliminary experimental results</phrase>.
Materialized Viewsin <phrase_Q=0.903>Multidimensional Databases</phrase>.
Cooperation with <phrase_Q=0.901>Geographic Databases</phrase>.
The purpose of this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> is to create cooperation between <phrase_Q=0.901>geographic databases</phrase> (GDBs) and <phrase_Q=0.903>multidimensional databases</phrase> (MDDBs), which are considered as the most promising and <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> technologies for supporting <phrase_Q=0.935>decision making</phrase>. We focus on the common <phrase_Q=0.744>key elements</phrase> between <phrase_Q=0.835>geographic</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.894>multidimensional data</phrase> which allow effective support in <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.819>cooperating</phrase>. These elements are basically time and space, which are present <phrase_Q=0.647>implicitly or explicitly</phrase> in MDDB and are modeled on the dimensions, Time and Location. Thus, because GDBs are primarily concerned with <phrase_Q=0.895>geographic data</phrase>, we will focus on space as a <phrase_Q=1.000>bridge</phrase> element for <phrase_Q=0.819>cooperating</phrase> MDDBs and GDBs. We propose an approach that extends the <phrase_Q=0.895>geographic data</phrase> structure through special attributes, called binding attributes, in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to describe all phenomena represented by MDDBs. This extension will make it possible to answer more specific "<phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase>-based" queries within GDBs without modifying the <phrase_Q=0.535>physical organization</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> in both environments.
<phrase_Q=0.817>Hierarchies</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> we will focus on the rules of <phrase_Q=0.772>aggregation hierarchies</phrase> in analysis dimensions of a <phrase_Q=1.000>cube</phrase>. We give <phrase_Q=0.591>an overview</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.727>related works</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> concepts of the different types of <phrase_Q=0.772>aggregation hierarchies</phrase>. We then discuss the <phrase_Q=0.817>hierarchies</phrase> from two different <phrase_Q=0.502>points of view</phrase>: <phrase_Q=0.828>mapping</phrase> between domain values and <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> structures. In relation to them, we introduce the <phrase_Q=0.808>characterization</phrase> of some <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase> operators on <phrase_Q=0.817>hierarchies</phrase> and give a set of operators that concern the change in the hierarchy structure. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, we propose an enlargement of the operator set concerning <phrase_Q=0.817>hierarchies</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Basic</phrase> Notions.
This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> presents the <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> notions regarding <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> (aggregate) <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase> by referring to different definitions given for them in the <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase>. It illustrates the <phrase_Q=0.564>important concepts</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.860>micro</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.852>macro</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>metadata</phrase>; presents a <phrase_Q=0.869>formal definition</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.814>aggregation</phrase> process, discussing the concepts of <phrase_Q=1.000>dimension</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>dimension</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>hierarchies</phrase>; describes the <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>aggregate data</phrase> structure, <phrase_Q=0.818>distinguishing</phrase> between simple, complex, and <phrase_Q=0.852>composite</phrase> structure; illustrates the different types of <phrase_Q=0.836>null</phrase> values; and discusses <phrase_Q=0.518>differences and similarities</phrase> which exist between <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>aggregate data</phrase> (generally called <phrase_Q=0.775>statistical data</phrase> because they are used mainly by statisticians) and the <phrase_Q=0.580>On-Line</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.808>Analytic</phrase> Processing (<phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase>) of <phrase_Q=0.894>multidimensional data</phrase> represented by different <phrase_Q=0.928>data cubes</phrase>, also discussing the different (<phrase_Q=0.581>symmetric and nonsymmetric</phrase>) treatment of dimensions and measures required by <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase> and aggregate <phrase_Q=0.903>multidimensional databases</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase> it discusses a <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> and a <phrase_Q=0.836>tabular</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> for this kind of <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, and gives a set of definitions regarding the <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.802>terminology</phrase>.
Operators for <phrase_Q=0.836>Multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Aggregate Data</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>author</phrase> proposes the different approaches for defining operators able to manipulate this <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> structure. In particular, he initially considers operators for <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>aggregate data</phrase> which extend <phrase_Q=1.000>relational algebra</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>relational</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>calculus</phrase> (the so-called enlarged <phrase_Q=1.000>relational model</phrase>). Then he discusses operators for <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>aggregate data</phrase> defined in a <phrase_Q=0.836>tabular</phrase> environment. In both the cases the <phrase_Q=1.000>author</phrase> defines such <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> as <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> (aggregate) <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.823>Subsequently</phrase> he introduces the operators for <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase> applications, giving a <phrase_Q=0.802>terminology</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> between the <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> aggregate (<phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase> areas. Then he defines the fundamental operators deduced from the previous ones, which form the <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algebra</phrase> for the manipulation of <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>aggregate data</phrase>, giving their <phrase_Q=0.855>formal definitions</phrase> and some explanatory examples.
<phrase_Q=0.833>Dynamic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.794>Multidimensional Data Cubes</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.928>Data cubes</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.817>ubiquitous</phrase> tools in <phrase_Q=1.000>data warehousing</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>online analytical processing</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.953>decision support</phrase> applications. Based on a selection of <phrase_Q=0.796>pre-computed</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.828>materialized aggregate</phrase> values, they can dramatically <phrase_Q=0.555>speed up</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>aggregation</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.818>summarization</phrase> over <phrase_Q=0.610>large data</phrase> collections. <phrase_Q=0.808>Traditionally</phrase>, the emphasis has been on lowering query costs with little regard to maintenance, i.e., <phrase_Q=0.655>update cost</phrase> issues. We argue that <phrase_Q=0.855>current trends</phrase> require <phrase_Q=0.928>data cubes</phrase> to be not only query-<phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase>, but also <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> at the same time, and we also show how this can be achieved. Several <phrase_Q=0.775>array-based</phrase> techniques with different <phrase_Q=0.513>tradeoffs between</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.527>query and update</phrase> cost are discussed in detail. We also survey selected approaches for <phrase_Q=0.785>sparse data</phrase> and the popular <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>cube</phrase> operator, <phrase_Q=1.000>CUBE</phrase>. Moreover, this work includes <phrase_Q=0.591>an overview</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.870>future trends</phrase> and their impact on <phrase_Q=0.928>data cubes</phrase>.
Multidimensionality in <phrase_Q=0.809>Statistical</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.903>Scientific Databases</phrase>.
The term "<phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> databses" refers to <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> that can be viewed conceptually in a <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> space, where each <phrase_Q=1.000>dimension</phrase> represents some attributes of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. Viewing <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> in this form is natural for many applications, yet the concepts are not treated in a uniform way in the <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase>, we show the <phrase_Q=0.813>commonality</phrase> of concepts between three <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> areas: <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.903>scientific databases</phrase>. We show that these domains have two main <phrase_Q=0.829>structural</phrase> concepts: the <phrase_Q=1.000>cross-product</phrase> space of the dimensions, and the <phrase_Q=0.646>classification hierarchy</phrase> structure associated with each <phrase_Q=1.000>dimension</phrase>. In the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> part of this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> we describe how these structures are <phrase_Q=1.000>sed</phrase> to represent <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase> and how <phrase_Q=0.818>summarization</phrase> operators can be applied to them. Further, we discuss how these structures can be <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> to represent <phrase_Q=0.657>related information</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.886>federated database</phrase> concepts. In the <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> part of the <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> we show that these concepts are common to many <phrase_Q=0.685>scientific database</phrase> application. In particular, we discuss the importance of supporting classification structures and the difficulty in representing them as tables in <phrase_Q=1.000>relational databases</phrase>. We also discuss <phrase_Q=1.000>data structures</phrase> to support <phrase_Q=0.903>multidimensional databases</phrase>, emphasizing <phrase_Q=0.611>space-time</phrase> representation, <phrase_Q=0.832>clustering</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> space, <phrase_Q=0.818>indexing</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> space, and supporting classification structures. We conclude by <phrase_Q=0.826>arguing</phrase> that the concepts of multidimensionality and classification structures as well as the operation over them should be elevated to "<phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> class" <phrase_Q=0.888>object types</phrase>. These <phrase_Q=0.888>object types</phrase> should be visible by the application user explicitly in the <phrase_Q=0.813>conceptual</phrase> schemas as well as <phrase_Q=0.817>exposing</phrase> them in the <phrase_Q=1.000>user interfaces</phrase>.
Querying <phrase_Q=0.894>Multidimensional Data</phrase>.
A powerful and easy-to-use querying environment is certainly one of the most important components in a <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>, and its effectiveness is influenced by many other aspects, both <phrase_Q=0.810>logical</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>data model</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase>, policy of <phrase_Q=0.960>view materialization</phrase>, etc.) and physical (<phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> or <phrase_Q=1.000>relational</phrase> storage, indexes, etc.). As is evident, <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> querying is often based on the <phrase_Q=1.000>metaphor</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>cube</phrase> and on the concepts of facts, measures, and dimensions. In contrast to conventional <phrase_Q=0.824>transactional</phrase> environments, <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> querying is often <phrase_Q=0.556>an exploratory</phrase> process, performed by <phrase_Q=0.821>navigating</phrase> along the dimensions and measures, increasing/decreasing the <phrase_Q=0.519>level of detail</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.801>focusing</phrase> on specific subparts of the <phrase_Q=1.000>cube</phrase> that appear to be "promising" for the required information.In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> we focus on the main languages proposed in the <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase> to express <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> queries, particularly those based on: (<phrase_Q=0.820>i</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.503>an algebraic</phrase> approach, (<phrase_Q=1.000>ii</phrase>) a <phrase_Q=0.863>declarative</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>paradigm</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>calculus</phrase>), and (iii) <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> constructs and <phrase_Q=1.000>syntax</phrase>. We analyze the problem of evaluation, i.e., the issues related to the <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.819>data retrieval</phrase> and calculation, possibly (often necessarily) using some <phrase_Q=0.796>pre-computed</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, a problem known in the <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase> as the problem of <phrase_Q=0.819>rewriting</phrase> a query using views. We also illustrate the use of particular <phrase_Q=0.801>index</phrase> structures to <phrase_Q=0.555>speed up</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.947>query evaluation</phrase> process.
<phrase_Q=0.638>Conceptual Multidimensional</phrase> Models.
A <phrase_Q=1.000>variety</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.894>multidimensional data</phrase> models have <phrase_Q=0.815>recently</phrase> been proposed by both <phrase_Q=1.000>academic</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>industry</phrase> communities. but <phrase_Q=0.859>consensus</phrase> on formalism or even a <phrase_Q=0.532>common terminology</phrase> has not yet emerged. In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase>, we <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> discuss the requirements that an ideal <phrase_Q=0.638>conceptual multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> should fulfill. These requirements are suggested by <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> system <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> principles and the <phrase_Q=0.559>specific characteristics</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>OLAP</phrase> applications. <phrase_Q=0.810>Building</phrase> on these requirements, we then present a <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.638>conceptual multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data model</phrase> and show how it can be used to describe the <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> aspects of a <phrase_Q=1.000>business</phrase> application in a way that is <phrase_Q=0.559>easy to understand</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> of the criteria for <phrase_Q=0.509>actual data</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>organization</phrase> in the various systems. Starting from the characteristics of the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> proposed, we summarize the <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> features that a <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>conceptual model</phrase> should support. We then survey various <phrase_Q=0.836>multidimensional</phrase> models proposed and relate their characteristics to these <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> features. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, we discuss the main points raised in the <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> and some problems that remain to be solved in this context.
