<phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Business</phrase> Rules for <phrase_Q=0.823>Active</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Database</phrase> Application Specification.
<phrase_Q=0.823>Active</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.837>database applications</phrase> require the classic cycle of analysis, <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.855>prototyping</phrase> and implementation. During analysis and <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> steps of the <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> system <phrase_Q=1.000>engineering</phrase> process, <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> behavior is an important task. This task is both essential and crucial when <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> system is centered on <phrase_Q=0.883>active databases</phrase>, which allow the replacement of parts of <phrase_Q=0.645>application programs</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.823>active</phrase> rules. For that reason, the specification of <phrase_Q=1.000>business</phrase> rules during analysis and <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> steps becomes an actual requirement. <phrase_Q=1.000>Business</phrase> rules ensure the well-functioning of <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> system. They are descriptive (<phrase_Q=0.968>integrity constraints</phrase>) or <phrase_Q=0.811>functional</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.811>derivation</phrase> rules and <phrase_Q=0.823>active</phrase> rules). To relieve programmers from using either traditional or <phrase_Q=1.000>ad hoc</phrase> techniques to <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.883>active databases</phrase>, it is necessary to develop new techniques to <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>business</phrase> rules. These techniques have to enhance the specification of <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>aspect</phrase> through a <phrase_Q=0.545>high-level description</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> able to express precisely and completely rule <phrase_Q=1.000>semantic</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase>, we propose a uniform approach to <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>business</phrase> rules (<phrase_Q=0.823>active</phrase> rules, <phrase_Q=0.968>integrity constraints</phrase>, etc.). To improve the <phrase_Q=0.717>behavior specification</phrase> we extend the <phrase_Q=1.000>state</phrase> diagrams that are widely used for <phrase_Q=0.614>dynamic modeling</phrase>. This extension is a transformation of <phrase_Q=1.000>state</phrase> transitions according to rule <phrase_Q=1.000>semantics</phrase>. In addition, we outline new functionalities of <phrase_Q=0.716>Computer-Aided</phrase> System <phrase_Q=1.000>Engineering</phrase> (CASE) to take into consideration the <phrase_Q=0.823>active</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> specificities. In this way, the designer can be <phrase_Q=0.815>assisted</phrase> to control, maintain and reuse a set of rules.
<phrase_Q=1.000>CMU</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.835>WEB</phrase>: A <phrase_Q=1.000>Conceptual Model</phrase> with Metrics for <phrase_Q=0.821>Testing</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.801>Designing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Usability</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>Web Applications</phrase>.
With the <phrase_Q=0.817>ubiquitous</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>availability</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>browsers</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Internet access</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.828>last</phrase> few years have seen a <phrase_Q=0.734>tremendous growth</phrase> in the number of applications being developed on <phrase_Q=0.567>the World Wide Web</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.868>WWW</phrase>). Models for <phrase_Q=0.803>analyzing</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.801>designing</phrase> these applications are only just <phrase_Q=0.543>beginning to emerge</phrase>. In this work, we propose a <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> classification space for <phrase_Q=0.868>WWW</phrase> applications, consisting of a <phrase_Q=1.000>degree</phrase> of structure of pages <phrase_Q=1.000>dimension</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=1.000>degree</phrase> of support for interrelated events <phrase_Q=1.000>dimension</phrase> and a location of processing <phrase_Q=1.000>dimension</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.822>Next</phrase>, we propose <phrase_Q=1.000>usability</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> metrics for <phrase_Q=0.868>WWW</phrase> applications along the structure of pages <phrase_Q=1.000>dimension</phrase>. To measure these, we propose <phrase_Q=1.000>CMU</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.835>WEB</phrase>-a <phrase_Q=1.000>conceptual model</phrase> that can be used to <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.868>WWW</phrase> applications, such that its <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase> provide values for the <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> metrics. This work represents the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> effort, to the best of our <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase>, to provide a <phrase_Q=1.000>conceptual model</phrase> that measures quantifiable metrics that can be used for the <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of more usable <phrase_Q=1.000>Web applications</phrase>, and that can also be used to compare the <phrase_Q=1.000>usability</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.603>existing Web applications</phrase>, without <phrase_Q=0.815>empirical testing</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.806>Enforcing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Cardinality</phrase> Constraints in the <phrase_Q=1.000>ER</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.814>Integrity</phrase> Methods.
<phrase_Q=0.947>Entity-Relationship</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>ER</phrase>) schemas include <phrase_Q=1.000>cardinality</phrase> constraints that restrict the dependencies among entities within a relationship type. The <phrase_Q=1.000>cardinality</phrase> constraints have <phrase_Q=0.811>direct</phrase> impact on application transactions, since <phrase_Q=0.687>insertions or deletions</phrase> of entities or relationships might affect <phrase_Q=0.678>related entities</phrase>. Application transactions can be strengthened to preserve the consistency of a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> with respect to the <phrase_Q=1.000>cardinality</phrase> constraints in a <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase>. Yet, once an <phrase_Q=1.000>ER</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.525>translated into</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.810>logical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database schema</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.811>direct</phrase> correlation between the <phrase_Q=1.000>cardinality</phrase> constraints and application transaction is <phrase_Q=1.000>lost</phrase>, since the components of the <phrase_Q=1.000>ER</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase> might be decomposed among those of the <phrase_Q=0.810>logical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> schema.We suggest <phrase_Q=0.813>extending</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.819>Enhanced</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>ER</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.862>EER</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>data model</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.814>integrity</phrase> methods that can enforce the <phrase_Q=1.000>cardinality</phrase> constraints. The <phrase_Q=0.814>integrity</phrase> methods can be fully defined by the <phrase_Q=1.000>cardinality</phrase> constraints, using a small number of primitive update methods, and are <phrase_Q=0.756>automatically created</phrase> for a given <phrase_Q=0.862>EER</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>diagram</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=1.000>translation</phrase> of an <phrase_Q=0.862>EER</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase> into a <phrase_Q=0.810>logical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database schema</phrase> can create <phrase_Q=0.814>integrity</phrase> routines by <phrase_Q=0.820>translating</phrase> the primitive update methods alone. These <phrase_Q=0.814>integrity</phrase> routines may be implemented as <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> procedures, if a <phrase_Q=1.000>relational</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>DBMS</phrase> is utilized, or as class methods, if <phrase_Q=0.574>an object-oriented</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>DBMS</phrase> is utilized.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Algorithm</phrase> Development, <phrase_Q=1.000>Simulation</phrase> Analysis, and <phrase_Q=0.833>Parametric</phrase> Studies for <phrase_Q=1.000>Data</phrase> Allocation in <phrase_Q=1.000>Distributed Database</phrase> Systems.
In a <phrase_Q=1.000>distributed database</phrase> system, an increase in workload typically necessitates the installation of additional <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> servers followed by the implementation of expensive <phrase_Q=0.768>data reorganization</phrase> strategies. We present the <phrase_Q=0.823>Partial</phrase> REALLOCATE and Full REALLOCATE heuristics for <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.539>data reallocation</phrase>. Complexity is controlled and cost minimized by allowing only <phrase_Q=0.845>incremental</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>introduction</phrase> of servers into the <phrase_Q=1.000>distributed database</phrase> system. Using <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.633>simple examples</phrase> and then, a <phrase_Q=0.807>simulator</phrase>, our framework for <phrase_Q=0.845>incremental</phrase> growth and <phrase_Q=0.539>data reallocation</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>distributed database</phrase> systems is shown to produce <phrase_Q=0.684>near optimal</phrase> solutions when compared with exhaustive methods.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Object-Oriented</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Database</phrase> Benchmarks.
The Role of <phrase_Q=0.603>Use Cases</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase>: A <phrase_Q=0.581>Review and Research Agenda</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=0.516>use case</phrase> is a description of a <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> of actions constituting a complete task or transaction in an application. <phrase_Q=0.603>Use cases</phrase> were <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> proposed by <phrase_Q=0.852>Jacobson</phrase> (1987) and have since been incorporated as one of the key <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> constructs in the <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase>(<phrase_Q=0.869>Booch</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.852>Jacobson</phrase>, & Rumbaugh, 1999) and the <phrase_Q=0.826>Unified</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Software Development Process</phrase>(<phrase_Q=0.852>Jacobson</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.869>Booch</phrase>, & Rumbaugh, 1999). This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> traces the development of <phrase_Q=0.603>use cases</phrase>, and identifies a number of problems with both their application and <phrase_Q=0.894>theoretical underpinnings</phrase>. From an application <phrase_Q=0.829>perspective</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.516>use-case</phrase> concept is marked by a <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>degree</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>variety</phrase> in the level of <phrase_Q=0.808>abstraction</phrase> versus implementation detail advocated by various authors. In addition, <phrase_Q=0.603>use cases</phrase> are promoted as a primary mechanism for <phrase_Q=0.805>identifying</phrase> objects in an application, even though they focus on processes rather than objects. Moreover, there is an apparent inconsistency between the so-called <phrase_Q=0.807>naturalness</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.830>object models</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=0.724>commonly held</phrase> view that <phrase_Q=0.603>use cases</phrase> should be the primary means of communicating and <phrase_Q=0.807>verifying</phrase> requirements with users. From a <phrase_Q=0.541>theoretical standpoint</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.822>introduction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.842>implementation issues</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.603>use cases</phrase> can be seen as prematurely <phrase_Q=0.830>anchoring</phrase> the analysis to particular implementation decisions. In addition, the <phrase_Q=0.805>fragmentation</phrase> of objects across <phrase_Q=0.603>use cases</phrase> creates <phrase_Q=0.813>conceptual</phrase> difficulties in developing a <phrase_Q=1.000>comprehensive</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>class diagram</phrase> from a set of <phrase_Q=0.603>use cases</phrase>. Moreover, the role of <phrase_Q=0.820>categorization</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.831>human thinking</phrase> suggests that <phrase_Q=0.946>class diagrams</phrase> may serve directly as a good mechanism for communicating and <phrase_Q=0.807>verifying</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.623>application requirements</phrase> with users. We <phrase_Q=0.570>conclude by outlining</phrase> a framework for further <phrase_Q=1.000>empirical research</phrase> to resolve <phrase_Q=0.681>issues raised</phrase> in our analysis.
<phrase_Q=0.843>Object-Process Methodology</phrase> Applied to <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Credit Card</phrase> Transactions.
<phrase_Q=0.843>Object-Process Methodology</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.842>OPM</phrase>) is a system development and specification approach that combines the <phrase_Q=1.000>major</phrase> system aspects-<phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase>, structure and behavior-within a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>graphic</phrase> and textual <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. Having applied <phrase_Q=0.842>OPM</phrase> in a <phrase_Q=1.000>variety</phrase> of domains, this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> specifies an <phrase_Q=1.000>electronic commerce</phrase> system in a <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> manner, at the <phrase_Q=0.820>top</phrase> of which are the processes of managing a <phrase_Q=0.809>generic</phrase> product <phrase_Q=1.000>supply chain</phrase> before and after the product is manufactured. <phrase_Q=0.801>Focusing</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=0.844>post</phrase>-product <phrase_Q=1.000>supply chain management</phrase>, we gradually refine the details of the fundamental, almost "<phrase_Q=1.000>classical</phrase>" <phrase_Q=1.000>electronic commerce</phrase> interaction between the retailer and the end-customer, namely payment over the <phrase_Q=1.000>Internet</phrase> using the customer's <phrase_Q=1.000>credit card</phrase>. The specification <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> in a set of Object-Process Diagrams and a corresponding equivalent set of Object-Process <phrase_Q=1.000>Language</phrase> sentences. The <phrase_Q=1.000>synergy</phrase> of combining structure and behavior within a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.700>formal model</phrase>, expressed both graphically and textually, yields a <phrase_Q=0.710>highly expressive</phrase> system <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.642>specification tool</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>comprehensive</phrase>, unambiguous treatment of this <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>electronic commerce</phrase> process is formal, yet intuitive and clear, suggesting that <phrase_Q=0.842>OPM</phrase> is a <phrase_Q=0.846>prime</phrase> candidate for becoming a common standard <phrase_Q=0.815>vehicle</phrase> for defining, specifying, and <phrase_Q=0.803>analyzing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>electronic commerce</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>supply chain management</phrase> systems.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Information</phrase> Analysis in <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>ORM</phrase>: A Comparison.
Since its <phrase_Q=1.000>adoption</phrase> by the <phrase_Q=1.000>Object Management Group</phrase> as a <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented analysis and design</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.521>the Unified Modeling Language</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase>) has become widely used for <phrase_Q=0.801>designing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented</phrase> code. However, <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> has had only <phrase_Q=0.814>minimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>adoption</phrase> among practitioners for the purposes of <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> analysis and <phrase_Q=1.000>database design</phrase>. One main reason for this is that the <phrase_Q=0.946>class diagrams</phrase> used in <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>data modeling</phrase> provide only weak, and awkward, support for the kinds of <phrase_Q=1.000>business</phrase> rules found in <phrase_Q=0.865>data-intensive applications</phrase>. Moreover, <phrase_Q=0.856>UML's</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>graphical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> does not lend itself readily to <phrase_Q=0.864>verbalization</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.519>multiple instantiation</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.812>validating</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> models with <phrase_Q=0.858>domain experts</phrase>. These defects can be remedied by using a <phrase_Q=0.641>fact-oriented</phrase> approach for <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> analysis, from which <phrase_Q=0.925>UML class diagrams</phrase> may be derived. <phrase_Q=1.000>Object-Role Modeling</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>ORM</phrase>) is currently the most popular <phrase_Q=0.679>fact-oriented modeling</phrase> approach. This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> examines the <phrase_Q=0.779>relative strengths</phrase> and weaknesses of <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>ORM</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.865>conceptual data modeling</phrase>, and indicates how models in one notation can be <phrase_Q=0.525>translated into</phrase> the other.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Cooperative</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.955>Query Processing</phrase> via <phrase_Q=1.000>Knowledge</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.808>Abstraction</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.931>Query Relaxation</phrase>.
As <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> users adopt a <phrase_Q=1.000>query language</phrase> to obtain <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> from a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>, a more <phrase_Q=0.662>intelligent query answering</phrase> system is increasingly needed that cooperates with the users to provide informative responses by <phrase_Q=0.816>understanding</phrase> the intent behind a query. The effectiveness of <phrase_Q=0.953>decision support</phrase> would improve significantly if the <phrase_Q=0.960>query answering</phrase> system returned <phrase_Q=0.836>approximate</phrase> answers rather than a <phrase_Q=0.836>null</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> response when there is no matching <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> available. Even when <phrase_Q=0.836>exact</phrase> answers are found, neighboring <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> is still useful to users if the query is intended to explore some hypothetical <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.834>abstract</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>fact</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> proposes an <phrase_Q=0.808>abstraction</phrase> hierarchy as a framework to practically derive such <phrase_Q=0.836>approximate</phrase> answers from ordinary everyday <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase>. It provides a <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.808>abstraction</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> to facilitate the <phrase_Q=0.885>approximate query answering</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.808>abstraction</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.808>specifically</phrase> adopts an <phrase_Q=0.808>abstraction</phrase> approach to extract <phrase_Q=1.000>semantic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> relationships from the underlying <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>, and uses a <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-level hierarchy for <phrase_Q=0.820>coupling</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.512>multiple levels</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.808>abstraction</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> values. In cooperation with the underlying <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.808>abstraction</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> allows the <phrase_Q=0.814>relaxation</phrase> of query conditions so that the original <phrase_Q=0.528>query scope</phrase> can be broadened and thus <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>approximate</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.836>exact</phrase> answers can be obtained. Conceptually <phrase_Q=0.834>abstract</phrase> queries can also be posed to provide a less rigid <phrase_Q=0.857>query interface</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=1.000>prototype</phrase> system has been implemented at <phrase_Q=1.000>KAIST</phrase> and is being tested with a personnel <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> system to demonstrate the usefulness and practicality of the <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.808>abstraction</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> in ordinary <phrase_Q=1.000>database systems</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Ternary</phrase> Relationships: <phrase_Q=1.000>Semantic</phrase> Requirements and <phrase_Q=0.689>Logically Correct</phrase> Alternatives.
<phrase_Q=0.588>A Case Study</phrase> of the Use of the Viable System <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>Organization</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Software Development</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> considers the usefulness of the Viable System <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.821>VSM</phrase>) in the study of <phrase_Q=0.750>organizational adaptation</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.821>VSM</phrase> is a rigorous <phrase_Q=0.617>organizational model</phrase> that was developed from the study of <phrase_Q=1.000>cybernetics</phrase> and has been given <phrase_Q=0.739>considerable attention</phrase> by <phrase_Q=1.000>management science</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> presents <phrase_Q=0.581>a longitudinal case study</phrase> that focuses upon a <phrase_Q=0.758>software development team</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.821>VSM</phrase> was useful in <phrase_Q=0.831>diagnosing</phrase> the likely consequences of different <phrase_Q=0.568>organizational designs</phrase> and in <phrase_Q=0.821>prescribing</phrase> an <phrase_Q=1.000>alternative</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase>.
Using <phrase_Q=0.823>Weakly Structured</phrase> Documents at the <phrase_Q=1.000>User-Interface</phrase> Level to Fill in a <phrase_Q=1.000>Classical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Database</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Electronic</phrase> documents have become a <phrase_Q=1.000>universal</phrase> way of <phrase_Q=1.000>communication</phrase> due to <phrase_Q=0.835>Web</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>expansion</phrase>. But using <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> stored in <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase> is still essential for <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.828>coherence</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>management</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.637>querying facilities</phrase>, etc. We thus face a <phrase_Q=1.000>classical</phrase> problem-known as "<phrase_Q=0.921>impedance mismatch</phrase>" in the <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> world; two <phrase_Q=1.000>antagonist</phrase> approaches have to collaborate. Using documents at the <phrase_Q=0.928>end-user</phrase> interface level provides simplicity and flexibility. But it is possible to take documents as <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> sources only if helped by a <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> being; <phrase_Q=0.754>automatic document</phrase> analysis systems have a significant <phrase_Q=0.899>error rate</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Databases</phrase> are an <phrase_Q=1.000>alternative</phrase> as <phrase_Q=1.000>semantics</phrase> and format of <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> are strict; queries via <phrase_Q=1.000>SQL</phrase> provide 100% <phrase_Q=0.588>correct responses</phrase>. The aim of this work is to provide a system that associates document capture freedom with <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> storage structure.The system we propose does not intend to be <phrase_Q=1.000>universal</phrase>. It can be used in specific cases where people usually work with <phrase_Q=0.881>technical documents</phrase> dedicated to a particular domain. Our examples concern <phrase_Q=1.000>medicine</phrase> and more explicitly <phrase_Q=1.000>medical</phrase> records. <phrase_Q=0.840>Computerization</phrase> has very often been rejected by <phrase_Q=1.000>physicians</phrase> because it necessitates <phrase_Q=0.532>too much</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>standardization</phrase> and form-based <phrase_Q=1.000>user interfaces</phrase> are not <phrase_Q=0.637>easily adapted</phrase> to their <phrase_Q=1.000>daily</phrase> practice. In this domain, we think that this study provides a <phrase_Q=0.633>viable alternative</phrase> approach. This system offers freedom to <phrase_Q=1.000>doctors</phrase>; they would fill in documents with the <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> they want to store, in a convenient <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> and in a freer way. We have developed a system that allows a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> to fill in <phrase_Q=0.840>quasi</phrase>-automatically from documents paragraphs.The <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> used is an already existing <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> that can be queried in a <phrase_Q=1.000>classical</phrase> way for <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> studies or <phrase_Q=1.000>epidemiological</phrase> purposes. In this system, the document <phrase_Q=0.873>fund</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> containing extractions from dccuments coexist. Queries are sent to the <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>, answers include <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from the <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> and references to <phrase_Q=0.599>source documents</phrase>.

FOOM - <phrase_Q=0.811>Functional</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Object-Oriented</phrase> Methodology for Analysis and <phrase_Q=1.000>Design</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Information</phrase> Systems.
FOOM is <phrase_Q=0.530>an integrated</phrase> methodology for analysis and <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> systems, which combines the two essential <phrase_Q=1.000>software-engineering</phrase> paradigms: the <phrase_Q=0.811>functional</phrase>- (or process-) <phrase_Q=0.744>oriented approach</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.851>OO</phrase>) approach. In FOOM, system analysis includes both <phrase_Q=0.811>functional</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>data modeling</phrase> activities, thereby producing both a <phrase_Q=0.811>functional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> and a <phrase_Q=1.000>data model</phrase>. These activities can be performed either by starting with <phrase_Q=1.000>functional analysis</phrase> and continuing with <phrase_Q=1.000>data modeling</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.557>or vice versa</phrase>. FOOM <phrase_Q=1.000>products</phrase> of the analysis phase include:a)a hierarchy of <phrase_Q=0.851>OO</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>DFDs</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.898>data flow</phrase> diagrams), and <phrase_Q=0.820>b</phrase>) an initial object <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase>, which can be created directly from the <phrase_Q=0.895>user requirements</phrase> specification or from an <phrase_Q=0.848>entity-relationship diagram</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.873>ERD</phrase>) that is mapped to that object <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase>. System <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> is performed according to the <phrase_Q=0.851>OO</phrase> approach. The <phrase_Q=1.000>products</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> phase include: a) a complete object <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase>, consisting of the classes and their relationships, attributes, and method interfaces; <phrase_Q=0.820>b</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.868>object classes</phrase> for the menus, forms and reports; and <phrase_Q=0.839>c</phrase>) a behavior <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase>, which consists of detailed descriptions of the methods and the application transactions, expressed in <phrase_Q=0.841>pseudo</phrase>-code and message diagrams. The <phrase_Q=0.846>seamless</phrase> transition from analysis to <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.825>attributed</phrase> to ADISSA methodology, which facilitates the <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of the menus, forms and reports classes, and the system behavior <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase>, from <phrase_Q=1.000>DFDs</phrase> and the application transactions.
The <phrase_Q=1.000>Psychology</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Information</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Information</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> is the <phrase_Q=1.000>cornerstone</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>systems analysis</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Information</phrase> models, the <phrase_Q=1.000>products</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase>, not only provide the abstractions required to facilitate <phrase_Q=1.000>communication</phrase> between the analysts and <phrase_Q=0.885>end-users</phrase>, but they also provide a <phrase_Q=0.503>formal basis</phrase> for developing tools and techniques used in <phrase_Q=0.892>information systems</phrase> development. The process of <phrase_Q=0.801>designing</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.808>constructing</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.800>adapting</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> methods for <phrase_Q=0.892>information systems</phrase> development is known as <phrase_Q=0.702>method engineering</phrase>. Despite the <phrase_Q=0.557>pivotal role</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> methods in successful <phrase_Q=0.892>information systems</phrase> development, most <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> methods are designed based on <phrase_Q=0.945>common sense</phrase> and intuition of the method designers with little or no <phrase_Q=0.895>theoretical foundation</phrase> or <phrase_Q=1.000>empirical evidence</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.810>Systematic</phrase> scientific approach is missing! This <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> proposes the use of <phrase_Q=1.000>cognitive psychology</phrase> as a <phrase_Q=0.778>reference discipline</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.702>method engineering</phrase>. Theories in <phrase_Q=1.000>cognitive psychology</phrase> are reviewed in this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> and their application to <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.702>method engineering</phrase> is discussed.
How Complex Is <phrase_Q=0.521>the Unified Modeling Language</phrase>?
<phrase_Q=1.000>Unified Modeling Language</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase>)has emerged as the <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.808>industry's</phrase> dominant <phrase_Q=1.000>modeling language</phrase>. It is the <phrase_Q=0.659>de facto</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>modeling language</phrase> standard for specifying, <phrase_Q=0.814>visualizing</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.808>constructing</phrase>, and documenting the components of <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> systems. Despite its <phrase_Q=0.805>prominence</phrase> and status as the standard <phrase_Q=1.000>modeling language</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> has its <phrase_Q=0.867>critics</phrase>. Opponents argue that it is complex and difficult to learn. Some question the rationale of having nine diagramming techniques in <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> and the raison d'être of those nine techniques in <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase>. Others point out that <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> lacks a <phrase_Q=1.000>comprehensive</phrase> methodology to guide its users, which makes the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> even more convoluted. A few studies on <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> can be found in the <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase>. However, no study exists to provide a <phrase_Q=0.838>quantitative</phrase> measure of <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> complexity or to compare <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> with other <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented</phrase> techniques. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase>, we evaluate the complexity of <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.817>complexity metrics</phrase>. The objective is to provide a <phrase_Q=0.814>reliable</phrase> and accurate <phrase_Q=0.838>quantitative</phrase> measure of <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> complexity. A comparison of the complexity <phrase_Q=0.860>metrical</phrase> values of <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> with other <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented</phrase> techniques was also <phrase_Q=0.501>carried out</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=0.767>findings suggest</phrase> that each <phrase_Q=0.818>diagram</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> is not distinctly more complex than techniques in other <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> methods. But as a whole, <phrase_Q=1.000>UML</phrase> is very complex-2-11 times more complex than other <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> methods.

The <phrase_Q=1.000>metadata</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>management</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> is concerned with <phrase_Q=1.000>workflow</phrase>, documents, and <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>Design</phrase> and Implementation of a <phrase_Q=0.691>Log-Structured File-System</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=0.844>dissertation</phrase> presents a new technique for <phrase_Q=1.000>disk storage</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>management</phrase> called a <phrase_Q=0.691>log-structured file system</phrase>. The technique writes all <phrase_Q=0.660>file system</phrase> changes in large <phrase_Q=0.830>sequential</phrase> transfers to a log-like structure on disk. The key benefit is a <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.729>write performance</phrase> that is <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> of the workload. The large transfers also enable the <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> use of <phrase_Q=0.518>large disk arrays</phrase> such as <phrase_Q=0.814>RAIDs</phrase>. The technique minimizes the overhead of <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> the redundancy <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> required by large <phrase_Q=0.814>RAIDs</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=0.691>log-structured file system</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.551>achieves high</phrase> write rates <phrase_Q=0.555>without sacrificing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.677>file retrieval</phrase> performance. Files are read back from the log efficiently due to the <phrase_Q=0.818>indexing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> that is maintained The log structure also permits <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> recovery from system crashes. Using a recovery system based on checkpoints and <phrase_Q=0.858>roll</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>forward</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.691>log-structured file system</phrase> can quickly restore the disk to a consistent <phrase_Q=1.000>state</phrase>. An important focus of this <phrase_Q=0.844>dissertation</phrase> is the technique used for <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase> space <phrase_Q=1.000>management</phrase> in a <phrase_Q=0.691>log-structured file system</phrase>. The approach taken was to divide the disk into large segments to which the log was written. A segment cleaner mechanism exists to compress the <phrase_Q=1.000>live</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> from heavily fragmented segments. The mechanism reads in the fragmented segments, compacts the <phrase_Q=1.000>live</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, and writes the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> back to segments on disk. The <phrase_Q=0.844>dissertation</phrase> includes a series of simulations that demonstrate the efficiency of a simple segment <phrase_Q=0.807>cleaning</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.834>policy based</phrase> on cost and benefit. The segment cleaner decides which segments to clean based on a <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> of the fraction <phrase_Q=0.821>alive</phrase> in the segment and the <phrase_Q=0.807>age</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> in the segment. <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> have implemented a <phrase_Q=1.000>prototype</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.691>log-structured file system</phrase> called <phrase_Q=0.875>Sprite</phrase> LFS; it outperforms current <phrase_Q=1.000>Unix</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>file systems</phrase> by an <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>magnitude</phrase> for small-<phrase_Q=0.657>file writes</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.560>matches or exceeds</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Unix</phrase> performance for reads and large writes. Even when the overhead for <phrase_Q=0.807>cleaning</phrase> is included, <phrase_Q=0.875>Sprite</phrase> LFS can use 70% of the <phrase_Q=0.821>disk bandwidth</phrase> for writing. <phrase_Q=1.000>Unix</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>file systems</phrase> typically can use only 5-10%.

The <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematical model</phrase> of meaning is <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> to compute specific meanings of keywords which are used for <phrase_Q=0.685>retrieving images</phrase> unambiguously and dynamically. The <phrase_Q=0.576>main feature</phrase> of this <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is that the <phrase_Q=1.000>semantic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>associative</phrase> search is performed in the <phrase_Q=0.834>orthogonal</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>semantic</phrase> space. The Type System of a <phrase_Q=1.000>Higher-Order Logic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Programming Language</phrase>.
The type system of the <phrase_Q=1.000>logic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>programming language</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.508>$\lambda</phrase>$<phrase_Q=1.000>Prolog</phrase> is discussed. The incorporation of <phrase_Q=0.946>higher-order</phrase> notions within this <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> requires the use of a typing scheme to distinguish between expressions of different <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> types. Thus <phrase_Q=0.508>$\lambda</phrase>$<phrase_Q=1.000>Prolog</phrase> is a (strongly) <phrase_Q=0.824>typed</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase>, in contrast to the typeless <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> that underlies the idea of descriptive types in <phrase_Q=1.000>logic programming</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.676>typing discipline</phrase> that is employed in the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> is based on the notion of <phrase_Q=0.532>simple types</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.508>$\lambda</phrase>$-<phrase_Q=1.000>calculus</phrase>. This form of typing enforces <phrase_Q=1.000>arity</phrase> restrictions on functions and predicates and provides a builtin <phrase_Q=0.811>functional</phrase> hierarchy over terms. The <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> contains a facility for defining new <phrase_Q=0.647>primitive types</phrase> and thus permits <phrase_Q=0.893>finer grained</phrase> distinctions to be introduced by the user. Further, the use of <phrase_Q=0.587>type variables</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.870>type constructors</phrase> provides a form of <phrase_Q=0.805>polymorphism</phrase> that is similar in certain respects to that present in the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.858>ML</phrase>. The notion of <phrase_Q=0.952>type checking</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.508>$\lambda</phrase>$<phrase_Q=1.000>Prolog</phrase> is discussed and shown to be an operation that can be performed at the time of <phrase_Q=1.000>compilation</phrase>. The value of typing distinctions in <phrase_Q=0.801>determining</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.814>clarity</phrase> of programs and their usefulness in conjunction with <phrase_Q=0.952>type checking</phrase> in preventing <phrase_Q=0.632>run-time</phrase> errors due to type violations is also discussed. In addition to their <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.952>type checking</phrase>, types also have a <phrase_Q=1.000>major</phrase> role in <phrase_Q=0.801>determining</phrase> computations in the <phrase_Q=1.000>logic programming</phrase> context. We discuss this <phrase_Q=1.000>aspect</phrase> of types that is in contrast to their behavior in other <phrase_Q=1.000>programming</phrase> paradigms and we show how this leads to a presence of types in the <phrase_Q=0.865>runtime environment</phrase>. While typing has several advantages, it is sometimes to the <phrase_Q=1.000>programmer</phrase>''<phrase_Q=0.812>s</phrase> advantage to be able to omit their mention. <phrase_Q=0.789>Type reconstruction</phrase> provides a means for filling missing <phrase_Q=0.604>type information</phrase> in and we discuss issues pertinent to this process in the context of <phrase_Q=0.508>$\lambda</phrase>$<phrase_Q=1.000>Prolog</phrase>.

The Intellectual <phrase_Q=0.839>Foundation</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Information</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Organization</phrase>
<phrase_Q=0.863>Instant</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>electronic</phrase> access to <phrase_Q=1.000>digital</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> is the <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> most <phrase_Q=0.818>distinguishing</phrase> attribute of the <phrase_Q=1.000>information age</phrase>. The elaborate <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> mechanisms that support such access are a product of <phrase_Q=1.000>technology</phrase>. But <phrase_Q=1.000>technology</phrase> is not enough. The effectiveness of a system for <phrase_Q=0.615>accessing information</phrase> is a <phrase_Q=0.811>direct</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>intelligence</phrase> put into organizing it. Just as the <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> field of <phrase_Q=1.000>engineering</phrase> has <phrase_Q=1.000>theoretical physics</phrase> as its underlying base, the <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of systems for <phrase_Q=0.616>organizing information</phrase> rests on an intellectual <phrase_Q=0.839>foundation</phrase>. The subject of this <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> is the systematized body of <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> that constitutes this foundation.Integrating the disparate disciplines of descriptive cataloging, subject cataloging, <phrase_Q=0.818>indexing</phrase>, and classification, the <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> adopts a <phrase_Q=1.000>conceptual framework</phrase> that views the process of <phrase_Q=0.616>organizing information</phrase> as the use of a special <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> of description called a <phrase_Q=0.855>bibliographic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.515>divided into</phrase> two parts. The <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> part is an <phrase_Q=0.808>analytic</phrase> discussion of the intellectual <phrase_Q=0.839>foundation</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>organization</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> part moves from generalities to particulars, presenting <phrase_Q=0.591>an overview</phrase> of three <phrase_Q=0.855>bibliographic</phrase> languages: work languages, document languages, and subject languages. It looks at these languages in terms of their <phrase_Q=1.000>vocabulary</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>semantics</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>syntax</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> is written in an exceptionally clear style, at <phrase_Q=1.000>a level</phrase> that makes it understandable to those outside the discipline of <phrase_Q=1.000>library</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> science.Digital <phrase_Q=1.000>Libraries</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Electronic Publishing</phrase> series

<phrase_Q=0.822>Journey</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>Data Quality</phrase>
All organizations today confront <phrase_Q=1.000>data quality</phrase> problems, both <phrase_Q=0.835>systemic</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.829>structural</phrase>. Neither <phrase_Q=1.000>ad hoc</phrase> approaches nor fixes at the systems levelinstalling the latest <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> or developing an expensive <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> warehousesolve the <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> problem of bad <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> quality practices. <phrase_Q=0.822>Journey</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>Data Quality</phrase> offers a <phrase_Q=0.863>roadmap</phrase> that can be used by practitioners, <phrase_Q=0.802>executives</phrase>, and students for <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase> and implementing a viable <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>quality management</phrase> program. This <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> guide, based on rigorous <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.818>informed</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.885>real-world</phrase> examples, describes the challenges of <phrase_Q=1.000>data management</phrase> and provides the principles, strategies, tools, and techniques necessary to meet them. The authors, all leaders in the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> quality field for many years, discuss how to make the economic case for <phrase_Q=1.000>data quality</phrase> and the importance of getting an organization's leaders on <phrase_Q=0.802>board</phrase>. They outline different approaches for <phrase_Q=0.808>assessing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, both subjectively (by users) and objectively (using <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> and other techniques). They describe <phrase_Q=0.506>real problems</phrase> and solutions, including efforts to find the <phrase_Q=1.000>root</phrase> causes of <phrase_Q=1.000>data quality</phrase> problems at a <phrase_Q=1.000>healthcare</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>organization</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>data quality</phrase> initiatives taken by a large <phrase_Q=1.000>teaching hospital</phrase>. They address setting <phrase_Q=1.000>company</phrase> policy on <phrase_Q=1.000>data quality</phrase> and, <phrase_Q=0.807>finally</phrase>, they consider <phrase_Q=0.833>future challenges</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=0.822>journey</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>data quality</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.848>Datenbanken</phrase>: <phrase_Q=0.839>Konzepte und</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.855>Sprachen</phrase>, 3. <phrase_Q=0.802>Auflage</phrase>
<phrase_Q=0.902>Object Identity</phrase> as a <phrase_Q=1.000>Query Language</phrase> Primitive.
We demonstrate the power of object identities (oid's) as a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>query language</phrase> primitive. We develop an <phrase_Q=0.838>object-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data model</phrase>, whose <phrase_Q=0.829>structural</phrase> part generalizes most of the known <phrase_Q=0.748>complex-object</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> models: cyclicity is allowed in both its schemas and instances. Our <phrase_Q=0.781>main contribution</phrase> is the operational part of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data model</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>query language</phrase> IQL, which uses oid's for three critical purposes: (1) to represent <phrase_Q=1.000>data-structures</phrase> with sharing and cycles, (2) to manipulate sets and (3) to express any <phrase_Q=1.000>computable</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> query. IQL can be statically <phrase_Q=0.712>type checked</phrase>, can be evaluated <phrase_Q=0.681>bottom-up</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.660>naturally generalizes</phrase> most popular <phrase_Q=0.900>rule-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> languages. The <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> can also be <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> to incorporate <phrase_Q=0.739>type inheritance</phrase>, without changes to IQL. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, we investigate an analogous value-based <phrase_Q=1.000>data model</phrase>, whose <phrase_Q=0.829>structural</phrase> part is founded on regular <phrase_Q=0.886>infinite trees</phrase> and whose operational part is IQL.
Method Schemas.
The concept of method schemas is proposed as a simple <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented programming</phrase> with features such as classes with methods and <phrase_Q=1.000>inheritance</phrase>, method name overloading, and <phrase_Q=0.928>late binding</phrase>. An <phrase_Q=0.598>important issue</phrase> is to check whether a given method <phrase_Q=0.807>schema</phrase> can possibly <phrase_Q=1.000>lead</phrase> to inconsistencies in some interpretations. The <phrase_Q=0.651>consistency problem</phrase> for method schemas is studied. The problem is shown to be <phrase_Q=1.000>undecidable</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.843>Decidability</phrase> is obtained for <phrase_Q=0.849>monadic</phrase> and/or <phrase_Q=1.000>recursion</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase> method schemas. The effect of <phrase_Q=1.000>covariance</phrase> is considered. The issues of <phrase_Q=0.845>incremental</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.961>consistency checking</phrase> and of a <phrase_Q=1.000>sound</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> case are <phrase_Q=0.760>briefly discussed</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.864>ACTA</phrase>: The <phrase_Q=1.000>SAGA</phrase> Continues
<phrase_Q=0.864>ACTA</phrase> is a <phrase_Q=1.000>comprehensive</phrase> transaction framework that permits a transaction <phrase_Q=0.873>modeler</phrase> to specify the effects of <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> transactions on each other and on objects in the <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.864>ACTA</phrase> allows the specification of (1) the interactions between transactions in terms of relationships between significant (transaction <phrase_Q=0.843>manage- ment</phrase>) events, such as begin, commit, abort, delegate, <phrase_Q=1.000>split</phrase>, and join, pertaining to different transactions and (2) transactions'' effects on objects'' <phrase_Q=1.000>state</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.878>concur</phrase>- rency status (i.e., <phrase_Q=0.808>synchronization</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>state</phrase>). Various <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> traditional models have been proposed to deal with <phrase_Q=0.842>applica- tions</phrase> that involve <phrase_Q=0.846>reactive</phrase> (endless), <phrase_Q=0.822>open</phrase>-ended (<phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase>-lived) and <phrase_Q=0.806>collaborative</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.822>interactive</phrase>) activities. One such <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.803>Sagas</phrase> [GS87] <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> (component) transactions <phrase_Q=0.865>T1</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.858>T2</phrase>,..., <phrase_Q=1.000>Tn</phrase> which can interleave in any way with component <phrase_Q=0.866>trans</phrase>- actions of other <phrase_Q=0.803>Sagas</phrase>. Components can commit even before the <phrase_Q=1.000>Saga</phrase> commits. However, if the <phrase_Q=1.000>Saga</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.823>subsequently</phrase> aborts, effects of the committed components are nullified through the <phrase_Q=1.000>invocation</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.829>compensating</phrase> transactions. After giving a brief <phrase_Q=0.822>introduction</phrase> to the <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> primitives of <phrase_Q=0.864>ACTA</phrase>, we illustrate their use by giving a complete formal <phrase_Q=0.808>characterization</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.803>Sagas</phrase>. Sub- sequently, the reasoning power of <phrase_Q=0.864>ACTA</phrase> is shown by <phrase_Q=0.526>proving properties</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.803>Sagas</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, the flexibility of <phrase_Q=0.864>ACTA</phrase> is displayed through a series of variations to the original <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.803>Sagas</phrase>, each variation coming out of changes to the formal <phrase_Q=0.808>characterization</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.803>Sagas</phrase>.

A <phrase_Q=0.821>Theorem</phrase>-Proving Approach to <phrase_Q=0.830>Database Integrity</phrase>.
Optimizing <phrase_Q=1.000>Datalog</phrase> Programs.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Datalog</phrase> programs, i.e., <phrase_Q=1.000>Prolog</phrase> programs without <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> symbols, are considered It is assumed that a <phrase_Q=1.000>variable</phrase> appearing in the <phrase_Q=0.809>head</phrase> of a rule must also appear in the body of the rule. The input of a program is a set of <phrase_Q=0.753>ground atoms</phrase> (which are given in addition to the program's rules) and, therefore, can be viewed as an assignment of relations to some of the program's predicates. Two programs are equivalent if they produce the same result for all possible assignments of relations to the <phrase_Q=1.000>extensional</phrase> predicates (i.e., the predicates that do not appear as <phrase_Q=0.809>heads</phrase> of rules). Two programs are uniformly equivalent if they produce the same result for all possible assignments of initial relations to all the predicates (i.e., both <phrase_Q=1.000>extensional</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.829>intentional</phrase>). The <phrase_Q=0.818>equivalence</phrase> problem for <phrase_Q=1.000>Datalog</phrase> programs is known to be <phrase_Q=1.000>undecidable</phrase>. It is shown that <phrase_Q=0.789>uniform equivalence</phrase> is <phrase_Q=1.000>decidable</phrase>, and an <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is given for minimizing a <phrase_Q=1.000>Datalog</phrase> program under <phrase_Q=0.789>uniform equivalence</phrase>. A technique for removing parts of a program that are redundant under <phrase_Q=0.818>equivalence</phrase> (but not under <phrase_Q=0.789>uniform equivalence</phrase>) is developed. A procedure for <phrase_Q=0.821>testing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.789>uniform equivalence</phrase> is also developed for the case in which the <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> satisfies some constraints.

The <phrase_Q=1.000>Software</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.834>Abstract</phrase> is intended to tell its <phrase_Q=0.834>reader</phrase> enough about the <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> to know where to find all the other <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> that exists about it, anywhere. A copy of the <phrase_Q=0.834>Abstract</phrase> opens every document about the <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase>. It has a fairly rigid format, so a <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.824>Abstracts</phrase> can be scanned swiftly, the same <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> always being found at the same place. The format of the <phrase_Q=1.000>Software</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.834>Abstract</phrase> is defined in <phrase_Q=0.515>Figure 1</phrase>. Although most <phrase_Q=1.000>Software</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.824>Abstracts</phrase> are written to define individual programs, the format is also an effective tool for describing any <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> entity: <phrase_Q=1.000>subroutine</phrase>, program, <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> system or subsystem, <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> file, or <phrase_Q=1.000>library</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.834>Abstract</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.818>constrained</phrase> to fit on one side of one sheet of <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>. The simplicity of this <phrase_Q=0.866>component-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, combined with the <phrase_Q=1.000>cross-platform</phrase> power of <phrase_Q=1.000>Java</phrase>, allows a <phrase_Q=1.000>web development</phrase> environment with <phrase_Q=0.680>enormous potential</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>JavaServer Pages</phrase> shows how to develop <phrase_Q=1.000>Java</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=1.000>web applications</phrase> without having to be a <phrase_Q=1.000>hardcore</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>programmer</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Java</phrase> 2D Graphics

CommonLoops: Merging <phrase_Q=1.000>Lisp</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Object-Oriented Programming</phrase>.
CommonLoops blends <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented programming</phrase> smoothly and tightly with the procedure-<phrase_Q=0.701>oriented design</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Lisp</phrase>. Functions and methods are combined in a more <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.808>abstraction</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Message passing</phrase> is invoked via normal <phrase_Q=1.000>Lisp</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> call. Methods are viewed as <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> descriptions of procedures. <phrase_Q=1.000>Lisp</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> types are integrated with <phrase_Q=0.868>object classes</phrase>. With these integrations, it is easy to incrementally move a program between the procedure and <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented</phrase> styles.One of the most important properties of CommonLoops is its extensive use of <phrase_Q=0.854>meta</phrase>-objects. We discuss three kinds of <phrase_Q=0.854>meta</phrase>-objects: objects for classes, objects for methods, and objects for discriminators. We argue that these <phrase_Q=0.854>meta</phrase>-objects make <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> both <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> implementation and <phrase_Q=0.808>experimentation</phrase> with new ideas for <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented</phrase> programming.CommonLoops' small <phrase_Q=0.820>kernel</phrase> is powerful enough to implement the <phrase_Q=1.000>major</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented</phrase> systems in use today.

A reasonably <phrase_Q=1.000>comprehensive</phrase> set of <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> accessing and <phrase_Q=0.669>manipulation operations</phrase> that should be supported by a <phrase_Q=0.840>generalized</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.844>pictorial</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database management</phrase> system (PDBMS) is proposed. A corresponding <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-level <phrase_Q=1.000>query language</phrase>, PICQUERY, is presented and illustrated through examples. PICQUERY has been designed with a flavor similar to QBE as the highly nonprocedural and conservational <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.844>pictorial</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database management</phrase> system PICDMS. PICQUERY and a <phrase_Q=1.000>relational</phrase> QBE-like <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> would form the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> by which a user could access conventional <phrase_Q=1.000>relational databases</phrase> and at the same time <phrase_Q=0.882>pictorial databases</phrase> managed by PICDMS or other <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> PDBMS. This languageinterface is part of an <phrase_Q=1.000>architecture</phrase> aimed toward <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> heterogeneity transparency over <phrase_Q=0.844>pictorial</phrase> and nonpictorial <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.692>Managing Change</phrase> in a <phrase_Q=1.000>Computer-Aided Design</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Database</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Object-oriented</phrase> concepts can make a <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> more <phrase_Q=0.846>reactive</phrase> to changes in its contents. By <phrase_Q=0.818>embedding</phrase> change <phrase_Q=1.000>semantics</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>design engineer</phrase> can be relieved of managing the detailed effects of changes. However, mechanisms are needed to limit the scope of <phrase_Q=0.911>change propagation</phrase> and to unambiguously identify the objects to which propagated changes should apply. We propose new mechanisms based on <phrase_Q=0.805>group</phrase> check-in/check-out, <phrase_Q=1.000>browser</phrase> contexts and paths, configuration constraints, and rules, to support a powerful <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> change capability within a <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>.
Integrating <phrase_Q=0.574>an Object-Oriented</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Programming</phrase> System with a <phrase_Q=1.000>Database</phrase> System.
There are two <phrase_Q=1.000>major</phrase> issues to address to achieve <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.574>an object-oriented</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>programming</phrase> system with a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> system. One is the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> issue: <phrase_Q=0.574>an object-oriented</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>programming language</phrase> must be <phrase_Q=0.846>augmented</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>semantic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data modeling</phrase> concepts to provide a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> set of <phrase_Q=1.000>data modeling</phrase> concepts to allow <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> of entities for important <phrase_Q=0.885>real-world</phrase> applications. Another is the <phrase_Q=0.782>computational-model</phrase> issue: <phrase_Q=0.676>application programmers</phrase> should be able to access and <phrase_Q=0.633>manipulate objects</phrase> as though the objects are in an <phrase_Q=0.816>infinite</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>virtual memory</phrase>; in other words, they should not have to be aware of the existence of a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> system in their computations with the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> structures the <phrase_Q=1.000>programming language</phrase> allows. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> discusses these issues and presents the solutions which we have incorporated into the <phrase_Q=0.890>ORION</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> system at <phrase_Q=1.000>MCC</phrase>.

Development of <phrase_Q=0.574>an Object-Oriented</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>DBMS</phrase>.
We describe the <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> of developing the <phrase_Q=1.000>GemStone</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database server</phrase>, which supports a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of objects similar to that of <phrase_Q=1.000>Smalltalk</phrase>-80. We begin with a <phrase_Q=0.856>summary</phrase> of the goals and requirements for the system: <phrase_Q=0.568>an extensible</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data model</phrase> that captures <phrase_Q=0.867>behavioral semantics</phrase>, no <phrase_Q=1.000>artificial</phrase> bounds on the number or size of <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> objects, <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> amenities (<phrase_Q=0.827>concurrency</phrase>, transactions, recovery, <phrase_Q=0.836>associative</phrase> access, <phrase_Q=0.812>authorization</phrase>) and an <phrase_Q=0.563>interactive development environment</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Object-oriented</phrase> languages, <phrase_Q=1.000>Smalltalk</phrase> in particular, answer some of these requirements. We discuss satisfying the remaining requirements in <phrase_Q=0.574>an object oriented</phrase> context, and <phrase_Q=1.000>report</phrase> briefly on the status of the <phrase_Q=0.702>development efforts</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> is <phrase_Q=1.000>directed</phrase> at an audience familiar with <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented</phrase> languages and their implementation, but perhaps unacquainted with the difficulties and techniques of <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> system development. It updates the original <phrase_Q=1.000>report</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=0.810>project</phrase> [<phrase_Q=0.855>CM</phrase>], and expands upon a more recent article [<phrase_Q=0.839>MDP</phrase>].

Constraining-<phrase_Q=0.860>Unification</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=1.000>Programming Language</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>UNICORN</phrase>.
Up to this point <phrase_Q=0.811>direct</phrase> implementations of <phrase_Q=0.845>axiomatic</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.852>equational</phrase> specifications have been limited because the implementation mechanisms used are incapable of capturing the full <phrase_Q=1.000>semantics</phrase> of the specifications. The <phrase_Q=1.000>programming language</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Unicorn</phrase> was designed and implemented with the <phrase_Q=0.821>intention</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.818>exploring</phrase> the full potential of <phrase_Q=1.000>programming</phrase> with equations. <phrase_Q=1.000>Unicorn</phrase> introduces a new <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> mechanism, called constraining-<phrase_Q=0.860>unification</phrase>. When <phrase_Q=0.827>coupled</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>semantic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.860>unification</phrase>, constraining-<phrase_Q=0.860>unification</phrase> closely models the <phrase_Q=1.000>semantics</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.852>equational</phrase> specifications thereby allowing for the implementation of a wider class of specifications. <phrase_Q=0.821>Unlike</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> mechanisms of <phrase_Q=0.924>rewrite-rule</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>logic programming</phrase>, constraining-<phrase_Q=0.860>unification</phrase> is <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> dependencies. The same <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are <phrase_Q=1.000>produced</phrase> regardless of the <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> in which the <phrase_Q=1.000>axioms</phrase> are stated. The use of viewpoints contributes to the flexibility of the <phrase_Q=1.000>Unicorn</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase>. Preconditions for <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> operations can be specified without added machinery.

UNIFORM - A <phrase_Q=1.000>Language</phrase> Based Upon <phrase_Q=0.860>Unification</phrase> Which Unifies (much of) <phrase_Q=1.000>LISP</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>PROLOG</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>ACT</phrase> 1.
Uniform is an <phrase_Q=1.000>AI</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>programming language</phrase> under development based upon <phrase_Q=0.846>augmented</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.860>unification</phrase>. It is an attempt to combine, in a simple coherent-framework, the most <phrase_Q=0.542>important features</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Lisp</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>actor</phrase> languages such as <phrase_Q=1.000>Act</phrase> 1 and <phrase_Q=1.000>SmallTalk</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>logic programming</phrase> languages such as <phrase_Q=1.000>Prolog</phrase>. Among the unusual abilities of the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> is its ability to use the same program as a <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase>, an <phrase_Q=1.000>inverse function</phrase>, a predicate, a pattern, or a <phrase_Q=0.810>generator</phrase>. All of these uses can be performed upon <phrase_Q=1.000>concrete</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.839>symbolic</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.846>partially instantiated</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. Uniform features <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>inheritance</phrase> from multiple <phrase_Q=0.857>super</phrase> classes, facilities for manipulation of programs, a limited ability to determine <phrase_Q=0.865>program equivalence</phrase>, and a <phrase_Q=0.860>unification</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.609>oriented database</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.819>Equality</phrase> For <phrase_Q=1.000>Prolog</phrase>.
The <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Prolog</phrase> has been <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> by allowing the inclusion of assertions about <phrase_Q=0.819>equality</phrase>. When a <phrase_Q=0.860>unification</phrase> of two terms that do not unify <phrase_Q=1.000>syntactically</phrase> is attempted, an <phrase_Q=0.819>equality</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>theorem</phrase> may be used to prove the two terms equal. If it is possible to prove that the two terms are equal the <phrase_Q=0.860>unification</phrase> succeeds with the <phrase_Q=1.000>variable</phrase> bindings introduced by the <phrase_Q=0.819>equality</phrase> proof. It is shown that this mechanism <phrase_Q=0.768>significantly improves</phrase> the power of <phrase_Q=1.000>Prolog</phrase>. Sophisticated <phrase_Q=0.897>data abstraction</phrase> with all the advantages of <phrase_Q=1.000>object-oriented programming</phrase> is available. Techniques for passing <phrase_Q=0.846>partially instantiated</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> are described that extends the "multiuse" capabilities of the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase>, improve the efficiency of some programs, and allow the implementation of <phrase_Q=1.000>arithmetic</phrase> relations that are both <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase>. The modifications to <phrase_Q=0.697>standard Prolog</phrase> are simple and straightforward and in addition the <phrase_Q=0.722>computational overhead</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.757>extra linguistic</phrase> power is not significant. <phrase_Q=0.819>Equality</phrase> theorems will probably <phrase_Q=1.000>play</phrase> an <phrase_Q=0.579>important role</phrase> in future <phrase_Q=1.000>logic programming</phrase> systems.

<phrase_Q=1.000>Concurrency Control</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.714>Performance Modeling</phrase>: Alternatives and Implications.
A number of <phrase_Q=0.735>recent studies</phrase> have examined the performance of <phrase_Q=1.000>concurrency control</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>database management systems</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> reported to date, rather than being definitive, have tended to be contradictory. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, rather than presenting &ldquo;yet another <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.590>performance study</phrase>,&rdquo; we critically investigate the assumptions made in the models used in <phrase_Q=0.647>past studies</phrase> and their implications. We employ a fairly complete <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> environment for studying the <phrase_Q=0.652>relative performance</phrase> of three different approaches to the <phrase_Q=1.000>concurrency control</phrase> problem under a <phrase_Q=1.000>variety</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> assumptions. The three approaches studied represent different extremes in how <phrase_Q=0.685>transaction conflicts</phrase> are dealt with, and the assumptions addressed pertain to the <phrase_Q=1.000>nature</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> system's resources, how <phrase_Q=0.854>transaction restarts</phrase> are modeled, and the amount of <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> available to the <phrase_Q=1.000>concurrency control</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> about transactions' <phrase_Q=0.786>reference strings</phrase>. We show that differences in the <phrase_Q=0.803>underlying assumptions</phrase> explain the <phrase_Q=0.845>seemingly contradictory</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.573>performance results</phrase>. We also address the question of how realistic the various assumptions are for actual <phrase_Q=1.000>database systems</phrase>.
On <phrase_Q=1.000>Mixing</phrase> Queries and Transactions via <phrase_Q=0.860>Multiversion</phrase> Locking.

<phrase_Q=1.000>Database</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Concurrency Control</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.869>Data Flow Graphs</phrase>.
A specialized <phrase_Q=0.860>data flow graph</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>Database</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.915>Flow Graph</phrase> (DBFG) is introduced. DBFGs may be used for <phrase_Q=0.814>scheduling</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> operations, particularly in an <phrase_Q=1.000>MIMD</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> machine environment. A DBFG explicitly maintains intertransaction and intratransaction dependencies, and is constructed from the <phrase_Q=0.547>Transaction Flow</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Graphs</phrase> (TFG) of <phrase_Q=0.823>active</phrase> transactions. A TFG, in turn, is the <phrase_Q=0.820>generalization</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.624>query tree</phrase> used, for example, in <phrase_Q=0.811>DIRECT</phrase> [15]. All DBFG schedules are serializable and <phrase_Q=1.000>deadlock</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase>. Operations needed to create and maintain the DBFG structure as transactions are <phrase_Q=0.573>added or removed</phrase> from the system are discussed. <phrase_Q=1.000>Simulation</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show that DBFG <phrase_Q=0.814>scheduling</phrase> performs as well as <phrase_Q=0.582>two-phase</phrase> locking.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Firm</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.662>Real-Time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Concurrency Control</phrase>.
Reduction in <phrase_Q=0.685>Transaction Conflicts</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=1.000>Semantics</phrase>-Based <phrase_Q=1.000>Concurrency Control</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase>, we consider <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> that <phrase_Q=1.000>permit</phrase> every site in a <phrase_Q=0.814>partitioned</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> system to perform new updates. Since this may result in <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> updates to items in different <phrase_Q=1.000>partitions</phrase>, conflicts among transactions are bound to occur. <phrase_Q=1.000>Commutative</phrase> transactions can be used to reduce the number of these conflicts. We develop a <phrase_Q=0.699>probabilistic model</phrase> to estimate the possible reduction in conflicts if we incorporate this notion of <phrase_Q=0.863>commutativity</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show that the additional efforts to recognize this <phrase_Q=0.863>commutativity</phrase> is not beneficial unless the number of transactions that commute with each other is significantly large.

<phrase_Q=0.546>Computer Networks</phrase>
From the Book:This <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> is now in its <phrase_Q=0.692>third edition</phrase>. Each <phrase_Q=0.842>edition</phrase> has corresponded to a different phase in the way <phrase_Q=0.546>computer networks</phrase> were used. When the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.842>edition</phrase> appeared in 1980, networks were an <phrase_Q=1.000>academic</phrase> curiosity. When the <phrase_Q=0.726>second edition</phrase> appeared in 1988, networks were used by <phrase_Q=1.000>universities</phrase> and large businesses. When the <phrase_Q=0.692>third edition</phrase> appeared in 1996, <phrase_Q=0.546>computer networks</phrase>, especially the worldwide <phrase_Q=1.000>Internet</phrase>, had become a <phrase_Q=1.000>daily</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reality</phrase> for millions of people. Furthermore, the <phrase_Q=0.827>networking</phrase> hardware and <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> have completely changed since the <phrase_Q=0.726>second edition</phrase> appeared In 1988, nearly all networks were based on <phrase_Q=1.000>copper</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>wire</phrase>. Now, many are based on <phrase_Q=1.000>fiber optics</phrase> or <phrase_Q=1.000>wireless communication</phrase>. Proprietary networks, such as <phrase_Q=0.812>SNA</phrase> have become far less important than <phrase_Q=1.000>public</phrase> networks, especially the <phrase_Q=1.000>Internet</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>OSI</phrase> protocols have quietly vanished,, and the <phrase_Q=0.502>TCP/IP protocol suite</phrase> has become dominant. In <phrase_Q=0.814>fact</phrase>, so much has changed, the <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> has almost been rewritten <phrase_Q=0.508>from scratch</phrase>. Although Chap. 1 has the same introductory <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> as it did in the <phrase_Q=0.726>second edition</phrase>, the contents have been completely <phrase_Q=0.805>revised</phrase> and brought up to date. For example, instead of <phrase_Q=0.822>basing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.865>hook</phrase> on the seven-layer <phrase_Q=1.000>OSI model</phrase>. a five-layer <phrase_Q=1.000>hybrid</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.548>shown in Fig</phrase>. 1-21) is now used and introduced in Chap. 1. While not exactly identical to the <phrase_Q=1.000>TCP/IP</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, it is much closer to the <phrase_Q=1.000>TCP/IP</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>spirit</phrase> than it is to the <phrase_Q=1.000>OSI model</phrase> used in the <phrase_Q=0.726>second edition</phrase>. Also, the new running examples used throughout the <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> - the <phrase_Q=1.000>Internet</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.856>Al</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>M</phrase> networks are introduced here, along with some <phrase_Q=1.000>gigabit</phrase> networks and other popular networks. In Chap. 2, the focus has moved from <phrase_Q=1.000>copper</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>wire</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>fiber optics</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>wireless communication</phrase>,since these <phrase_Q=0.851>arc</phrase> the technologies of the future. The <phrase_Q=1.000>telephone</phrase> system has become almost entirely <phrase_Q=1.000>digital</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.738>past decade</phrase>, so the material on it has been largely rewritten, with new material on <phrase_Q=1.000>broadband</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>ISDN</phrase> added. The material on <phrase_Q=0.862>cellular radio</phrase> has been <phrase_Q=0.673>greatly expanded</phrase>, and new material on low-<phrase_Q=1.000>orbit</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>satellites</phrase> has been added to the <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> of discussion of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data link layer</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=0.860>MAC</phrase> sublayer has been reversed, since experience with students shows that they understand the <phrase_Q=0.860>MAC</phrase> sublayer better after they have studied the <phrase_Q=1.000>data link layer</phrase>. The example protocols there have been kept, as they have <phrase_Q=1.000>proven</phrase> very popular, but they have been rewritten in <phrase_Q=0.839>C</phrase>. New material on the <phrase_Q=1.000>Internet</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.857>ATM</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data link</phrase> layers has been added. The <phrase_Q=0.860>MAC</phrase> sublayer principles of Chap. 4. have been <phrase_Q=0.805>revised</phrase> to reflect new protocols, including <phrase_Q=1.000>wavelength division multiplexing</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>wireless</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>LANs</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>digital radio</phrase>. The discussion of bridges has been <phrase_Q=0.805>revised</phrase>, and new material has been added on <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-speed <phrase_Q=1.000>LANs</phrase>. Most of the <phrase_Q=0.771>routing algorithms</phrase> of Chap. 5 have been replaced by more modern ones, including <phrase_Q=0.839>distance vector</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.853>link state routing</phrase>. The sections on <phrase_Q=0.961>congestion control</phrase> have been completely <phrase_Q=1.000>redone</phrase>, and material on the running examples, the <phrase_Q=1.000>Internet</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.857>ATM</phrase> is all new. Chap. 6 is still about the <phrase_Q=1.000>transport</phrase> layer, but here, too, <phrase_Q=1.000>major</phrase> changes have occurred, primarily, the addition of a large amount of new material about the <phrase_Q=1.000>Internet</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.857>ATM</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.738>network performance</phrase>. Chap. 7, on the <phrase_Q=1.000>application layer</phrase>, is now the <phrase_Q=0.820>longest</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.865>chapter</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase>. The material on <phrase_Q=0.890>network security</phrase> has been doubled in length, and new material has been added on <phrase_Q=0.861>DNS</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>SNMP</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>email</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>USENET</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.567>the World Wide Web</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>HTML</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>Java</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>multimedia</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.609>video on demand</phrase>, and the <phrase_Q=0.852>MBone</phrase>. Of the 395 figures in the <phrase_Q=0.692>third edition</phrase>, 276 (<phrase_Q=0.560>70 percent</phrase>) are completely new and some of the others have been <phrase_Q=0.805>revised</phrase>. Of the 371 references to the <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase>, 282 (76 percent) are to books and papers that have appeared since the <phrase_Q=0.726>second edition</phrase> was published. Of these, over 100 are to works published in 1995 and 1996 alone. All in all, probably 75 percent of the entire <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> is <phrase_Q=1.000>brand</phrase> new, and parts of the remaining <phrase_Q=0.540>25 percent</phrase> have been heavily <phrase_Q=0.805>revised</phrase>. Since this is effectively a new <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>cover</phrase> was redesigned to avoid confusion with the <phrase_Q=0.726>second edition</phrase>. To help instructors using this <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> as a text for course, the <phrase_Q=1.000>author</phrase> has prepared three <phrase_Q=0.826>teaching</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>aids</phrase>: A problem solutions manual. <phrase_Q=1.000>PostScript</phrase> files containing all the figures (for making overhead sheets).
