<phrase_Q=0.818>DIAGRAM</phrase>: A <phrase_Q=1.000>Grammar</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.817>Dialogues</phrase>.
An explanatory <phrase_Q=0.839>overview</phrase> is given of <phrase_Q=0.818>DIAGRAM</phrase>, a large and complex <phrase_Q=1.000>grammar</phrase> used in an <phrase_Q=1.000>artificial intelligence</phrase> system for <phrase_Q=0.814>interpreting</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>English</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.824>dialogue</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.818>DIAGRAM</phrase> is an <phrase_Q=0.846>augmented</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>phrase-structure grammar</phrase> with rule procedures that allow phrases to inherit attributes from their constituents and to acquire attributes from the larger phrases in which they themselves are constituents. These attributes are used to set <phrase_Q=0.941>context-sensitive</phrase> constraints on the acceptance of an analysis. Constraints can be imposed by conditions on <phrase_Q=0.811>dominance</phrase> as well as by conditions on <phrase_Q=1.000>constituency</phrase>. Rule procedures can also <phrase_Q=0.528>assign scores</phrase> to an analysis to rate it as probable or unlikely. Less likely analyses can be ignored by the procedures that interpret the utterance. For every expression it analyzes, <phrase_Q=0.818>DIAGRAM</phrase> provides an annotated description of the structure. The annotations supply <phrase_Q=0.523>important information</phrase> for other parts of the system that interpret the expression in the context of a <phrase_Q=0.824>dialogue</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Major</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> decisions are explained and illustrated. Some contrasts with <phrase_Q=0.896>transformational grammars</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.567>pointed out</phrase> and problems that motivate a plan to use metarules in the future are discussed. (Metarules derive new rules from a set of base rules to achieve the kind of generality <phrase_Q=0.544>previously captured</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.896>transformational grammars</phrase> but without having to perform transformations on <phrase_Q=1.000>syntactic</phrase> analyses.)

<phrase_Q=1.000>Logic</phrase>-Based <phrase_Q=1.000>Knowledge Representation</phrase>.
After a <phrase_Q=1.000>short</phrase> analysis of the requirements that a <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge representation</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> must satisfy, we introduce <phrase_Q=0.956>Description Logics</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.957>Modal Logics</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.960>Nonmonotonic Logics</phrase> as formalisms for representing <phrase_Q=0.840>terminological knowledge</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.637>time-dependent</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.569>subjective knowledge</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.876>incomplete knowledge</phrase> respectively. At the end of each section, we briefly <phrase_Q=0.817>comment</phrase> on the connection to <phrase_Q=1.000>Logic Programming</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.591>An Overview</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.812>Planning</phrase> Under <phrase_Q=0.816>Certainty</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=1.000>Taxonomy</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.821>Theorem</phrase>-Proving Strategies.
This <phrase_Q=0.637>article presents</phrase> a <phrase_Q=1.000>taxonomy</phrase> of strategies for <phrase_Q=0.910>fully-automated</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase>-purpose <phrase_Q=0.532>first-order theorem proving</phrase>. It covers <phrase_Q=1.000>forward</phrase>-reasoning ordering-based strategies and <phrase_Q=0.830>backward</phrase>-reasoning <phrase_Q=0.843>subgoal</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.862>reduction strategies</phrase>, which do not appear together often. <phrase_Q=0.821>Unlike</phrase> traditional presentations that emphasize <phrase_Q=0.810>logical</phrase> inferences, this classification strives to give <phrase_Q=0.747>equal weight</phrase> to the <phrase_Q=0.818>inference</phrase> and search components of <phrase_Q=0.821>theorem</phrase> proving, which are <phrase_Q=0.840>equally important</phrase> in practice. For this purpose, a formal notion of search plan is given and shown to apply to all classes of strategies. For each class, the form of <phrase_Q=0.811>derivation</phrase> is specified, and it is shown how <phrase_Q=0.818>inference</phrase> system and search plan cooperate to generate it.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Knowledge Representation</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>Stochastic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.866>Decision Process</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.577>Reasoning about</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stochastic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>dynamical systems</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.699>planning under uncertainty</phrase> has come to <phrase_Q=1.000>play</phrase> a fundamental role in <phrase_Q=1.000>AI</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> and applications. The representation of such systems, in particular, of actions with <phrase_Q=1.000>stochastic</phrase> effects, has <phrase_Q=0.806>accordingly</phrase> been given <phrase_Q=0.601>increasing attention</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.774>recent years</phrase>. In this article, we survey a number of techniques for representing <phrase_Q=1.000>stochastic processes</phrase> and actions with <phrase_Q=1.000>stochastic</phrase> effects using <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> networks and <phrase_Q=0.962>influence diagrams</phrase>, and briefly describe how these support effective <phrase_Q=0.818>inference</phrase> for tasks such as <phrase_Q=0.811>monitoring</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.837>forecasting</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.845>explanation</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.935>decision making</phrase>. We also compare these techniques to several <phrase_Q=1.000>action</phrase> representations adopted in the <phrase_Q=1.000>classical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.577>reasoning about</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>action</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase> communities, describing how traditional problems such as the <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.817>ramification</phrase> problems are dealt with in <phrase_Q=1.000>stochastic</phrase> settings, and how these solutions compare to <phrase_Q=0.645>recent approaches</phrase> to this problem in the <phrase_Q=1.000>classical</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.807>deterministic</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase>. We argue that while <phrase_Q=1.000>stochastic</phrase> dynamics introduce certain complications when it comes to such issues, for the most part, intuitions underlying <phrase_Q=1.000>classical</phrase> models can be <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> to the <phrase_Q=1.000>stochastic</phrase> setting.

<phrase_Q=0.849>OBDD</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=1.000>Universal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>Planning</phrase>: Specifying and <phrase_Q=0.535>Solving Planning Problems</phrase> for Synchronized Agents in <phrase_Q=0.631>Non-deterministic</phrase> Domains.
<phrase_Q=0.815>Recently</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> checking representation and <phrase_Q=0.681>search techniques</phrase> were shown to be efficiently applicable to <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase>, in particular to <phrase_Q=0.631>non-deterministic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase>. It includes the <phrase_Q=0.701>previously developed</phrase> strong and <phrase_Q=0.762>strong cyclic planning</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> [9,10]. The only known <phrase_Q=0.809>generic</phrase> method for <phrase_Q=0.899>exact inference</phrase> in DBNs is based on <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>expansion</phrase> and reduction of <phrase_Q=0.823>active</phrase> slices. It is effective when the domain evolves relatively slowly, but is reported to be "<phrase_Q=0.579>too expensive</phrase>" for <phrase_Q=0.518>fast evolving</phrase> domain where <phrase_Q=0.818>inference</phrase> is under time <phrase_Q=1.000>pressure</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.827>Concurrent</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.846>Reactive</phrase> Plans, <phrase_Q=0.820>Anticipation</phrase> and Forestalling <phrase_Q=0.600>Execution Failures</phrase>
<phrase_Q=0.960>Autonomous robots</phrase> that accomplish their jobs in partly unknown and <phrase_Q=0.867>changing environments</phrase> often learn <phrase_Q=0.523>important information</phrase> while <phrase_Q=0.553>carrying out</phrase> their jobs. To be <phrase_Q=0.814>reliable</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.884>effcient</phrase>, they have to <phrase_Q=1.000>act</phrase> appropriately in novel situations and respond immediately to unpredicted events. They also have to reconsider their intended course of <phrase_Q=1.000>action</phrase> when it is likely to have flaws. For example, whenever a <phrase_Q=1.000>robot</phrase> detects another <phrase_Q=1.000>robot</phrase>, it should predict that robot's effect on its plan and -- if necessary -- revise its plan to make it more <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase>. To accomplish these patterns of activity we equip <phrase_Q=1.000>robots</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.846>reactive</phrase> plans (SRPs), <phrase_Q=0.827>concurrent</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.584>control programs</phrase> that can not only be interpreted but also <phrase_Q=0.532>reasoned about</phrase> and manipulated. These plans specify how the <phrase_Q=1.000>robot</phrase> is to respond to <phrase_Q=0.803>sensory input</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to accomplish its jobs. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> we describe a <phrase_Q=0.782>computational model</phrase> of forestalling common flaws in <phrase_Q=1.000>autonomous robot</phrase> behavior. To this end, we develop a representation for SRPs in which <phrase_Q=0.863>declarative</phrase> statements for goals, <phrase_Q=0.818>perceptions</phrase>, and beliefs make the structure and purpose of SRPs explicit and thereby simplify and <phrase_Q=0.555>speed up</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.577>reasoning about</phrase> SRPs and their projections. We have also developed a notation for <phrase_Q=0.811>transforming</phrase> SRPs, which does not only make the <phrase_Q=0.540>physical effects</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.937>plan execution</phrase> explicit, but also the process of plan interpretation, as well as <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.852>causal</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>teleological</phrase> relationships among plan interpretation, the world, and the physical behavior of the <phrase_Q=1.000>robot</phrase>. Using this notation a <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase> system can diagnose and forestall common flaws in <phrase_Q=1.000>robot</phrase> plans that cannot be dealt with in other <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase> representations. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, we have <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> for writing SRPs with constructs that allow for a <phrase_Q=0.821>flexible</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase> and execution and thereby turned it into a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-level <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> that can handle both <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase> and execution actions. Experiments in a <phrase_Q=0.535>simulated world</phrase> show that by simultaneously forestalling flaws and executing SRPs, the <phrase_Q=1.000>robot</phrase> can perform its jobs more reliably than, and almost as effciently as, it could using fixed <phrase_Q=0.584>control programs</phrase>.

Optimization of <phrase_Q=1.000>SQL</phrase> Queries for <phrase_Q=0.831>Parallel</phrase> Machines
<phrase_Q=0.831>Parallel</phrase> execution offers a method for reducing the <phrase_Q=0.643>response time</phrase> of queries against <phrase_Q=0.871>large databases</phrase>. We address the problem of <phrase_Q=0.565>parallel query optimization</phrase>: Given a <phrase_Q=0.863>declarative</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>SQL</phrase> query, find a <phrase_Q=0.822>procedural</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.831>parallel</phrase> plan that delivers the <phrase_Q=0.776>query result</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.814>minimal</phrase> time. We develop <phrase_Q=0.755>optimization algorithms</phrase> using models that incorporate both sources and obstacles to speedup. We address <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.847>pipelined</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.814>partitioned</phrase> parallelism. We incorporate inherent constraints on available parallelism and the <phrase_Q=0.727>extra cost</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.831>parallel</phrase> execution. Our models are motivated by experiments with <phrase_Q=0.963>NonStop SQL</phrase>, a commercial <phrase_Q=0.831>parallel</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>DBMS</phrase>. We adopt a <phrase_Q=0.582>two-phase</phrase> approach to <phrase_Q=0.565>parallel query optimization</phrase>: JOQR (<phrase_Q=0.764>join ordering</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.863>query rewrite</phrase>), followed by <phrase_Q=0.802>parallelization</phrase>. JOQR minimizes total work. Then, <phrase_Q=0.802>parallelization</phrase> spreads work among processors to minimize <phrase_Q=0.643>response time</phrase>. For JOQR, we <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>communication</phrase> costs and <phrase_Q=0.834>abstract</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.755>physical characteristics</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> as colors. We devise <phrase_Q=1.000>tree</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.844>coloring</phrase> and reordering <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> that are <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase>. We <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.802>parallelization</phrase> as <phrase_Q=0.814>scheduling</phrase> a <phrase_Q=1.000>tree</phrase> whose <phrase_Q=0.630>nodes represent</phrase> operators and <phrase_Q=0.582>edges represent</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.831>parallel</phrase>/<phrase_Q=0.929>precedence constraints</phrase>. Computation/<phrase_Q=1.000>communication</phrase> costs are represented as node/<phrase_Q=0.803>edge</phrase> weights. We prove <phrase_Q=0.933>worst-case</phrase> bounds on the <phrase_Q=0.624>performance ratios</phrase> of our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> and measure <phrase_Q=1.000>average</phrase> cases using <phrase_Q=1.000>simulation</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> enable the <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>SQL</phrase> compilers that <phrase_Q=0.599>effectively exploit</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.831>parallel</phrase> machines.

A problem that all <phrase_Q=0.534>computer-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>natural language understanding</phrase> (NLU) systems encounter is that of <phrase_Q=1.000>linguistic</phrase> reference, and in particular <phrase_Q=0.864>anaphora</phrase> (abbreviated reference). For example, in a text as simple as: \begin{quote} Nadia showed <phrase_Q=0.817>Sue</phrase> her new <phrase_Q=1.000>car</phrase>. The seats were Day-Glo <phrase_Q=0.863>orange</phrase>. \end{quote} <phrase_Q=0.822>knowing</phrase> that <phrase_Q=0.835>``</phrase>her'''' probably means Nadia and not <phrase_Q=0.817>Sue</phrase> and that <phrase_Q=0.835>``</phrase>the seats'''' means the seats of Nadia''<phrase_Q=0.812>s</phrase> new <phrase_Q=1.000>car</phrase> is not a simple task. .<phrase_Q=0.870>br</phrase> This <phrase_Q=1.000>thesis</phrase> is an extensive review of the reference and anaphor problem, and the approaches to it that NLU systems have taken, from early systems such as <phrase_Q=1.000>STUDENT</phrase> through to current <phrase_Q=0.820>discourse</phrase>-oriented ones such as <phrase_Q=1.000>PAL</phrase>. .<phrase_Q=0.870>br</phrase> The problem is <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> examined in detail, and examples are given of many different types of anaphor, some of which have been ignored by <phrase_Q=0.546>previous authors</phrase>. The approaches taken in traditional systems are then described and abstracted and it is shown why they were inadequate, and why <phrase_Q=0.820>discourse</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.815>theme</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.802>anaphoric</phrase> focus need to be taken into account. The <phrase_Q=0.616>strengths and weaknesses</phrase> of current <phrase_Q=0.864>anaphora</phrase> theories and approaches are evaluated. The <phrase_Q=1.000>thesis</phrase> closes with a list of some remaining <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> problems. .<phrase_Q=0.870>br</phrase> The <phrase_Q=1.000>thesis</phrase> has been written so as to be as comprehensible as possible to both <phrase_Q=1.000>AI</phrase> workers who know no <phrase_Q=1.000>linguistics</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>linguists</phrase> who have not studied <phrase_Q=1.000>artificial intelligence</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=1.000>Randomness</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.823>Completeness</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>Computational Complexity</phrase>
<phrase_Q=1.000>Computational complexity</phrase> studies the inherent difficulty of <phrase_Q=0.737>computational problems</phrase> and the power of the tools we may use to solve them. We focus on <phrase_Q=1.000>randomness</phrase> and look at several properties of <phrase_Q=0.776>complete problems</phrase> to investigate its role as well as issues about nondeterminism, <phrase_Q=0.846>alternation</phrase>, and space versus time. We investigate the use of <phrase_Q=1.000>randomness</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.895>proof checking</phrase>. By <phrase_Q=0.915>derandomizing Arthur-Merlin games</phrase>, we show that every <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> with a <phrase_Q=0.802>bounded</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.586>round interactive proof</phrase> system has <phrase_Q=0.835>subexponential</phrase> size proofs unless <phrase_Q=0.618>the polynomial-time hierarchy collapses</phrase>. This provides the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.687>strong evidence</phrase> that <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase> nonisomorphism has <phrase_Q=0.835>subexponential</phrase> size proofs of membership. Under a stronger <phrase_Q=1.000>hypothesis</phrase> we can scale the proof size down to <phrase_Q=1.000>polynomial</phrase>. We also show how our approach applies to several <phrase_Q=1.000>randomized</phrase> processes other than <phrase_Q=0.910>Arthur-Merlin games</phrase>. We develop techniques for <phrase_Q=0.712>separating complexity classes</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.814>isolating</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.829>structural</phrase> difference between their <phrase_Q=0.573>complete languages</phrase>. We look at several properties from this <phrase_Q=0.829>perspective</phrase>: The <phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.573>complete languages</phrase>, the redundancy in <phrase_Q=0.573>complete languages</phrase>, and the <phrase_Q=1.000>frequency</phrase> of occurrence of <phrase_Q=0.823>completeness</phrase>. We show that there is no <phrase_Q=0.838>sparse</phrase> hard <phrase_Q=1.000>language</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>polynomial</phrase> time under <phrase_Q=0.946>logarithmic space</phrase> reductions with a <phrase_Q=0.802>bounded</phrase> number of queries unless <phrase_Q=1.000>polynomial</phrase> time collapses to <phrase_Q=1.000>logarithmic</phrase> space. <phrase_Q=0.918>View Synthesis</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.973>Stereo Vision</phrase>
This <phrase_Q=1.000>thesis</phrase> investigates the use of <phrase_Q=0.973>stereo vision</phrase> for the application of <phrase_Q=0.918>view synthesis</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.918>View synthesis</phrase> --the problem of creating images of a scene as it would appear from novel viewpoints --has <phrase_Q=0.808>traditionally</phrase> been approached using methods from <phrase_Q=0.682>computer graphics</phrase>. These methods, however, suffer from low <phrase_Q=0.737>rendering speed</phrase>, limited achievable realism, and, most severely, their dependence on a <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> scene <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, which typically needs to be constructed manually. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>thesis</phrase>, we present a new approach to <phrase_Q=0.918>view synthesis</phrase> that avoids the above problems by <phrase_Q=0.818>synthesizing</phrase> new views from existing images of a scene. Using an <phrase_Q=0.851>image-based</phrase> representation of <phrase_Q=0.869>scene geometry</phrase> computed by <phrase_Q=0.973>stereo vision</phrase> methods, a <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> can be avoided, and realistic new views can be synthesized quickly using <phrase_Q=0.945>image warping</phrase>. The new application of <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.918>view synthesis</phrase> makes it necessary to <phrase_Q=0.803>re</phrase>-evaluate the requirements on <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase>. We compare <phrase_Q=0.918>view synthesis</phrase> to several traditional applications of <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase>, and conclude that <phrase_Q=0.973>stereo vision</phrase> is better suited for <phrase_Q=0.918>view synthesis</phrase> than for <phrase_Q=0.601>applications requiring</phrase> explicit 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase>. We also discuss ways of dealing with <phrase_Q=0.976>partially occluded</phrase> regions of unknown depth and with completely <phrase_Q=0.804>occluded regions</phrase> of unknown texture, and present <phrase_Q=0.553>experiments demonstrating</phrase> that it is possible to efficiently <phrase_Q=0.527>synthesize realistic</phrase> new views even from inaccurate and incomplete <phrase_Q=0.839>depth information</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>thesis</phrase> also contributes several novel <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> that are motivated by the <phrase_Q=0.640>specific requirements</phrase> imposed by <phrase_Q=0.918>view synthesis</phrase>. We introduce a new evidence measure based on <phrase_Q=0.802>intensity gradients</phrase> for establishing <phrase_Q=0.506>correspondences between</phrase> images. This measure combines the notions of similarity and confidence, and allows <phrase_Q=0.883>stable matching</phrase> and easy assigning of <phrase_Q=0.833>canonical</phrase> depth interpretations in <phrase_Q=0.839>image regions</phrase> of insufficient <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>. We also present new <phrase_Q=1.000>diffusion</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> that are motivated by the need to correctly recover <phrase_Q=0.827>object boundaries</phrase>. In particular, we develop a novel <phrase_Q=0.922>Bayesian estimation</phrase> technique that <phrase_Q=0.781>significantly outperforms</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.544>based algorithms</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.861>fixed-sized</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>windows</phrase>. We provide <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> for all <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> on both synthetic and <phrase_Q=0.673>real images</phrase>.

"This <phrase_Q=1.000>book</phrase> presents a <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> framework for <phrase_Q=0.808>assessing</phrase> quality and <phrase_Q=0.811>handling</phrase> uncertainty, which is based on tested concepts and theories. <phrase_Q=0.845>Gaussian</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Scale-Space</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.791>Dense Disparity Estimation</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>Anisotropic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.702>Disparity-Field</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Diffusion</phrase>.
We present a new <phrase_Q=0.814>reliable</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.791>dense disparity estimation</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> which employs <phrase_Q=0.823>Gaussian scale-space</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>anisotropic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.702>disparity-field</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>diffusion</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> estimates <phrase_Q=0.803>edge</phrase>-preserving <phrase_Q=0.720>dense disparity</phrase> vectors using a <phrase_Q=1.000>diffusive</phrase> method on iteratively <phrase_Q=0.845>Gaussian</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.683>filtered images</phrase> with a scale, i.e. the <phrase_Q=0.845>Gaussian</phrase> scalespace. While a <phrase_Q=0.845>Gaussian</phrase> filter <phrase_Q=0.820>kernel</phrase> generates a <phrase_Q=0.750>coarser resolution</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.889>stereo image pairs</phrase>, only strong and meaningful boundaries are <phrase_Q=0.774>adaptively selected</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.683>filtered images</phrase>. Then, coarse <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.541>disparity vectors</phrase> are initialized using the <phrase_Q=0.509>boundary constraint</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.625>per-pixel</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.541>disparity vectors</phrase> are iteratively obtained by the local adjustment of the <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.541>disparity vectors</phrase> using an <phrase_Q=0.967>energy-minimization</phrase> framework. The <phrase_Q=0.504>proposed algorithm</phrase> preserves the boundaries while inner regions are <phrase_Q=0.823>smoothed</phrase> using <phrase_Q=1.000>anisotropic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.702>disparity-field</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>diffusion</phrase>. In this work, the <phrase_Q=0.823>Gaussian scale-space</phrase> efficiently avoids illegal matching on a large baseline by the restriction of the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase>. Moreover, it prevents the computation from iterating into <phrase_Q=0.925>local minima</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.691>ill-posed</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>diffusion</phrase> on large <phrase_Q=1.000>gradient</phrase> areas e.g. <phrase_Q=0.839>shadow</phrase> and texture <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase>, etc. The <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> prove the excellent <phrase_Q=0.823>localization</phrase> performance preserving the disparity discontinuity of each object.
<phrase_Q=0.875>Projection-Based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>Registration</phrase> Using a <phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>View Camera</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.878>Indoor Scene</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> method is proposed for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of an <phrase_Q=0.824>indoor</phrase> environment using a <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>view camera</phrase>. In <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.685>previous methods</phrase> have a <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>computational complexity</phrase> and are not <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>point cloud</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.831>low precision</phrase>. Thus, a <phrase_Q=0.875>projection-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> is presented. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase>, depth are refined based on <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>property</phrase> by excluding 3D points with a large variation, and <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>property</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.643>filling holes</phrase> referring neighboring 3D points. <phrase_Q=0.806>Second</phrase>, 3D <phrase_Q=0.979>point clouds</phrase> acquired at two views are <phrase_Q=0.594>projected onto</phrase> the same <phrase_Q=0.849>image plane</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.609>two-step</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>integer</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.828>mapping</phrase> enables the modified <phrase_Q=0.847>KLT</phrase> to find correspondences. Then, <phrase_Q=0.616>fine registration</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.501>carried out</phrase> by minimizing distance errors. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, a final <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> is evaluated using colors of corresponding points and an <phrase_Q=0.824>indoor</phrase> environment is reconstructed by <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> the above procedure to consecutive scenes. The <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> reduces <phrase_Q=1.000>computational complexity</phrase> by searching for correspondences within an <phrase_Q=0.849>image plane</phrase>. It not only enables an effective <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> even for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>point cloud</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.831>low precision</phrase>, but also need only a few views. The generated <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> can be adopted for interaction with as well as <phrase_Q=1.000>navigation</phrase> in a <phrase_Q=1.000>virtual environment</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.818>Registration</phrase> of Multiple <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Scans as a <phrase_Q=0.579>Location Recognition</phrase> Problem: <phrase_Q=1.000>Hypothesis</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.801>Generation</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.821>Refinement</phrase> and Verification.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> addresses the following version of the multiple <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.777>scan registration</phrase> problem. A <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase> with an associated intensity <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> is placed at a series of locations throughout a large environment; scans are acquired at each location. The problem is to decide automatically which scans overlap and to estimate the parameters of the transformations <phrase_Q=0.827>aligning</phrase> these scans. Our technique is based on (1) <phrase_Q=0.802>detecting</phrase> and matching <phrase_Q=0.806>keypoints</phrase> ¿ distinctive locations in <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.812>intensity images</phrase>, (2) generating andrefining a transformation estimate from each <phrase_Q=0.853>keypoint</phrase> match, and (3) <phrase_Q=0.809>deciding</phrase> if a given refined estimate is correct. While these steps are familiar, we present novel approaches to each. A new <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.853>keypoint</phrase> technique is presented that uses <phrase_Q=1.000>spin</phrase> images to describe holes in <phrase_Q=0.928>smooth surfaces</phrase>. Intensity <phrase_Q=0.806>keypoints</phrase> are detected using <phrase_Q=0.842>multiscale</phrase> filters, described using <phrase_Q=0.921>intensity gradient</phrase> histograms, and backprojected to form 3D <phrase_Q=0.806>keypoints</phrase>. A hypothesized transformation is generated by matching a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.853>keypoint</phrase> from one <phrase_Q=0.843>scan</phrase> to a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.853>keypoint</phrase> from another, and is refined using a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> form of the <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> in combination with controlled <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> growing. <phrase_Q=0.809>Deciding</phrase> whether a refined transformation is correct is based on three criteria: <phrase_Q=0.814>alignment</phrase> accuracy, <phrase_Q=0.807>visibility</phrase>, and a novel <phrase_Q=1.000>randomness</phrase> measure. Together these three steps produce good <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>test</phrase> scans of the Rensselaer <phrase_Q=1.000>campus</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.545>Class Selection</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.855>Prototyping</phrase> for 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.889>Object Classification</phrase>.
Most <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> on 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.889>object classification</phrase> and recognition focuses on recognition of objects in 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> scenes from a small <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> of known 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> models. Such an approach does not scale well to <phrase_Q=0.871>large databases</phrase> of objects and does not generalize well to unknown (but similar) <phrase_Q=0.889>object classification</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents two ideas to address these problems (<phrase_Q=0.820>i</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.545>class selection</phrase>, i.e., <phrase_Q=0.545>grouping similar</phrase> objects into classes (<phrase_Q=1.000>ii</phrase>) class <phrase_Q=0.855>prototyping</phrase>, i.e., <phrase_Q=0.803>exploiting</phrase> common structure within classes to represent the classes. At <phrase_Q=0.632>run time</phrase> matching a query against the <phrase_Q=1.000>prototypes</phrase> is sufficient for classification. This approach will not only reduce the <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> time but also will help increase the <phrase_Q=0.822>generalizing</phrase> power of theclassification <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. Objects are segmented into classes automatically using an <phrase_Q=0.623>agglomerative clustering algorithm</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Prototypes</phrase> from these classes are extracted using one of three class <phrase_Q=0.855>prototyping</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> demonstrate the effectiveness of the two steps in <phrase_Q=0.734>speeding up</phrase> the classification process <phrase_Q=0.555>without sacrificing</phrase> accuracy.

Accurate <phrase_Q=0.894>Principal Directions</phrase> Estimation in <phrase_Q=0.805>Discrete Surfaces</phrase>.
Accurate <phrase_Q=0.643>local surface</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> estimation in <phrase_Q=0.805>discrete surfaces</phrase> is an important problem with <phrase_Q=0.572>numerous applications</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.958>Principal curvatures</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.894>principal directions</phrase> can be used in applications such as <phrase_Q=0.914>shape analysis</phrase> and recognition, <phrase_Q=0.894>object segmentation</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.817>adaptive smoothing</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>anisotropic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.837>fairing</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.806>irregular</phrase> meshes, and <phrase_Q=1.000>anisotropic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>texture mapping</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, a novel approach for accurate <phrase_Q=0.868>principal direction</phrase> estimation in <phrase_Q=0.805>discrete surfaces</phrase> is described. The proposed approach is based on <phrase_Q=0.521>local directional</phrase> curve <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> of the surface where the <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>frequency</phrase> can be controlled. This local <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> has a <phrase_Q=0.522>large number</phrase> of degrees of freedoms compared with known techniques and so can better represent the <phrase_Q=0.795>local geometry</phrase>. The proposed approach is <phrase_Q=0.733>quantitatively evaluated</phrase> and compared with known techniques for <phrase_Q=0.868>principal direction</phrase> estimation. In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to perform an <phrase_Q=0.823>unbiased</phrase> evaluation in which <phrase_Q=0.805>smoothing</phrase> effects are <phrase_Q=0.846>factored</phrase> out, we use a set of <phrase_Q=0.868>randomly generated</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.740>Bezier surface</phrase> patches for which the <phrase_Q=0.894>principal directions</phrase> can be <phrase_Q=0.661>computed analytically</phrase>.
3D <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> System of <phrase_Q=1.000>Human</phrase> Face and Full 3D <phrase_Q=0.945>Facial Caricaturing</phrase>.

We propose the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> composed of 44 <phrase_Q=0.911>feature points</phrase> and 82 meshes to <phrase_Q=1.000>cover</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.809>head</phrase>. To generate the <phrase_Q=1.000>caricature</phrase> from this <phrase_Q=1.000>polygon</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, the individuality feature is defined in value by the difference of the <phrase_Q=0.911>feature points</phrase> between the input face and the mean face, which was defined from the <phrase_Q=1.000>average</phrase> of many input faces.

<phrase_Q=0.853>Uncalibrated</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.511>Multiple Image</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> System with Arbitrarily Movable <phrase_Q=1.000>Camera</phrase> and Projector for <phrase_Q=0.895>Wide Range</phrase> Scanning.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose an <phrase_Q=0.853>uncalibrated</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-image 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase>, using <phrase_Q=0.885>coded structured light</phrase>. Normally, a conventional <phrase_Q=0.885>coded structured light</phrase> system consists of a <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> and a projector and needs precalibration before scanning. Since the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> and the projector have to be fixed after <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.936>wide area</phrase> of the scene or reducing occlusions by multiple scanning are difficult and sometimes impossible. In the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase>, multiple scanning while moving the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> or the projector is possible by <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.908>uncalibrated stereo</phrase> method, thereby achieving a <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-image 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase>. As compared to the conventional <phrase_Q=0.885>coded structured light</phrase> method, our system does not require <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.729>extrinsic camera parameters</phrase>, occlusions are reduced, and a <phrase_Q=0.936>wide area</phrase> of the scene can be acquired. As compared to <phrase_Q=0.851>image-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.948>image reconstruction</phrase>, the proposed system can obtain <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> shape <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.792>higher precision</phrase>. As a result of these advantages, users can freely move either the cameras or projectors to <phrase_Q=0.843>scan</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.895>wide range</phrase> of objects, but not if both the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> and the projector are moved at the same time.

<phrase_Q=0.810>Efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>Discovery</phrase> Service for a <phrase_Q=1.000>Digital Library</phrase> of 3D Models.
Many <phrase_Q=0.920>geographically distributed</phrase> experts in different areas such as <phrase_Q=1.000>medical imaging</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>e-commerce</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>digital</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>museums</phrase>, are in need of 3D models. Although 3D models are becoming widely available due to the recent <phrase_Q=0.870>technological advancement</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> tools, we lack a <phrase_Q=1.000>digital library</phrase> system where they can be searched and retrieved efficiently. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we focus on <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>discovery</phrase> service consisting of <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-level <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> browsing service that <phrase_Q=0.554>enables users</phrase> to navigate large sets of 3D models. For this purpose, we use <phrase_Q=0.796>shape based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.832>clustering</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.834>abstract</phrase> a large set of 3D models to a small set of representative models (key models). Our service applies <phrase_Q=0.832>clustering</phrase> recursively to limit the number of key models that a <phrase_Q=0.799>user views</phrase> at a time. <phrase_Q=0.832>Clustering</phrase> is derived from metrics that are based on a concept of compression and <phrase_Q=0.892>similarity computation</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.586>surface signatures</phrase>. Signatures are the <phrase_Q=0.650>two-dimensional</phrase> representations of a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> and they can be used to define similarity between 3D models. We integrated the proposed browsing capability with 3DLIB,(a <phrase_Q=1.000>digital library</phrase> for 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> models that we are <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> at <phrase_Q=0.754>Old Dominion University</phrase>), and evaluated the proposed browsing service using the <phrase_Q=1.000>Princeton</phrase> Shape Benchmark (PSB). Our <phrase_Q=0.620>evaluation shows</phrase> significant better <phrase_Q=0.595>precision and recall</phrase> as compared to other approaches.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Industrial</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Painting</phrase> Inspection using <phrase_Q=1.000>Specular</phrase> Sharpness.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Digital</phrase> 3D plus <phrase_Q=0.849>color imaging</phrase> is a growing field as it has many <phrase_Q=1.000>industrial</phrase> applications. One of them is the precise <phrase_Q=0.816>understanding</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase> properties of objects, which is possible to obtain from 3D plus brightness or <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. Those properties are usually important inspection criteria; for example, the <phrase_Q=1.000>specular</phrase> sharpness of a coatted surface is usually related to the <phrase_Q=0.832>coating</phrase> quality. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> is related to a procedure for <phrase_Q=0.828>recovering</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>specular</phrase> sharpness and other surface-<phrase_Q=0.777>related properties</phrase> from objects. The current approach works on 3D plus brightness or <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, which are retrieved in two steps using a common <phrase_Q=0.944>structured-light</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>triangulation</phrase>-based technique and an ordinary non-<phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.853>spot</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase>. Some <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> obtained on <phrase_Q=1.000>industrial</phrase> parts are also shown.

The <phrase_Q=0.724>current research</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.802>challenge</phrase> is producing the <phrase_Q=0.678>final result</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase>. Using a <phrase_Q=0.815>recently</phrase> proposed framework, a <phrase_Q=0.623>surface model</phrase> is built in a <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> structure encoding a <phrase_Q=1.000>vector field</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>neighborhood</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.674>object surface</phrase>. Using <phrase_Q=1.000>ray tracing</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> approaches of the <phrase_Q=0.842>multiresolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>vector field</phrase> are described and compared. More precisely, it is shown that volume traversal can be optimized while preventing holes and <phrase_Q=0.577>reducing aliasing</phrase> in the rendered image.
A <phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.851>Image-Based</phrase> Method for 3D <phrase_Q=0.818>Registration</phrase>.
Today <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>reality</phrase> receives more and more attention. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we present a novel <phrase_Q=0.851>image-based</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> method. Compared with a previous one it does not require accurate <phrase_Q=0.648>starting position</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>albedo</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> invariants, but has to address the more apparent <phrase_Q=0.845>mismatch</phrase> problems. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase>, distinctive <phrase_Q=0.822>corner</phrase> points, which <phrase_Q=1.000>act</phrase> as <phrase_Q=0.883>salient features</phrase> for subsequent <phrase_Q=0.913>image matching</phrase>, are detected via the <phrase_Q=0.814>minimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>eigenvalue</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.895>auto-correlation</phrase> matrix. Then, a <phrase_Q=0.598>verification scheme</phrase> discards the potential mismatches by thresholds of the <phrase_Q=0.898>correlation coefficients</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.556>point-to-point</phrase> distances. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> demonstrate the superiority of our proposed <phrase_Q=0.598>verification scheme</phrase> to the previous one using only <phrase_Q=0.898>correlation coefficients</phrase> under the <phrase_Q=0.628>relaxed conditions</phrase>.
A 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Laser</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.860>Micro</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> Integrating Control and <phrase_Q=1.000>Data Processing</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.533>an FPGA-Based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Calculator</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.850>Hierarchical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.640>Coarse to Fine</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.934>Depth Estimation</phrase> for Realistic <phrase_Q=0.923>View Interpolation</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a novel approach for <phrase_Q=0.918>view synthesis</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.894>image interpolation</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is build up in a <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> way, and this on different <phrase_Q=0.829>structural</phrase> levels instead of using a classic <phrase_Q=0.720>image pyramid</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase> coarse matching is done on a ýshape basisý only. A <phrase_Q=0.752>background-foreground segmentation</phrase> yields a <phrase_Q=0.706>fairly accurate</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>contour</phrase> for every <phrase_Q=0.503>incoming video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stream</phrase>. Inter-<phrase_Q=0.805>relating</phrase> these contours is a 1D problem and as such very <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase>. This step is then used to compute small <phrase_Q=0.852>position dependent</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.829>bounding</phrase>-boxes in 3D space which enclose the underlying object. The <phrase_Q=0.822>next</phrase> step is a more expensive <phrase_Q=0.875>window based</phrase> matching, within the volume of these <phrase_Q=0.829>bounding</phrase>-boxes. This is limited to a number of regions around ýpromisingý <phrase_Q=0.911>feature points</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.816>Global</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.860>regularisation</phrase> is obtained by a <phrase_Q=0.921>graph cut</phrase>. Speed <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> here from limiting the number of <phrase_Q=0.911>feature points</phrase>. In a <phrase_Q=0.806>third</phrase> step the <phrase_Q=1.000>interpolation</phrase> is ýpre-renderedý and simultaneously evaluated on a <phrase_Q=0.625>per pixel</phrase> basis. This is done by <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> a Birchfield <phrase_Q=0.909>dissimilarity measure</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.625>Per pixel</phrase> parallelised operations keep <phrase_Q=0.737>computational cost</phrase> low. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase> the bad interpolated parts are ýpatchedý. This <phrase_Q=0.625>per pixel</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.811>correction</phrase> yields the final interpolated view at the finest level. Here we will also deal explicitly with <phrase_Q=0.816>opacity</phrase> at the <phrase_Q=1.000>borders</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.881>foreground object</phrase>.
3D <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.840>Outdoor</phrase> Environments by Integrating <phrase_Q=1.000>Omnidirectional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.822>Color</phrase> Images.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes a 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> method for <phrase_Q=0.936>wide area</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.840>outdoor</phrase> environments which is based on integrating <phrase_Q=1.000>omnidirectional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> images. In the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.840>outdoor</phrase> scenes can be efficiently digitized by an <phrase_Q=1.000>omnidirectional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>laser rangefinder</phrase> which can obtain a 3D shape with <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-accuracy and by an <phrase_Q=1.000>omnidirectional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.868>multi-camera</phrase> system (<phrase_Q=0.860>OMS</phrase>) which can capture a <phrase_Q=0.536>high-resolution color</phrase> image. <phrase_Q=0.647>Multiple range images</phrase> are registered by minimizing the distances between corresponding points in the different <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images. In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to register <phrase_Q=0.647>multiple range images</phrase> stably, points on plane portions detected from the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> are used in <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> process. The <phrase_Q=0.564>position and orientation</phrase> acquired by <phrase_Q=0.924>RTK-GPS</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>gyroscope</phrase> are used as <phrase_Q=0.794>initial values</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.804>simultaneous registration</phrase>. The 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> obtained by <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> is mapped by textures selected from <phrase_Q=1.000>omnidirectional</phrase> images in consideration of the <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> of texture and occlusions of the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. In experiments, we have <phrase_Q=0.501>carried out</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> of our <phrase_Q=1.000>campus</phrase> with the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.802>Detecting</phrase> Cylinders in 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Data</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=1.000>Model Selection</phrase> Criteria.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we use a <phrase_Q=1.000>model selection</phrase> criterion to <phrase_Q=0.552>decide whether</phrase> two cylinders should be merged as a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.813>cylinder</phrase> or they should be left separated. We compare and evaluate an extensive number of different <phrase_Q=1.000>model selection</phrase> criteria for this purpose and examine which factors can affect their performance. We conclude that <phrase_Q=0.849>SSC</phrase>, GIC, MCAIC and CAIC have a better performance (for this particular application) compared to the other criteria.
<phrase_Q=0.808>Constructing</phrase> Models of <phrase_Q=0.854>Articulating</phrase> Objects: <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.839>Data Partitioning</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we consider one <phrase_Q=1.000>aspect</phrase> of the problem of <phrase_Q=0.669>automatically building</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.804>shape models</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.854>articulating</phrase> objects from example <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images. Central to the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> problem is the <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, taken from different <phrase_Q=0.916>vantage points</phrase>, into a common <phrase_Q=0.812>coordinate frame</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=0.564>involves determining</phrase> a transformation for each set of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> which aligns overlapping <phrase_Q=0.660>surface points</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.527>common frame</phrase>. Current <phrase_Q=0.631>registration algorithms</phrase> have been developed <phrase_Q=0.808>specifically</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.899>rigid objects</phrase>, but it is not obvious how these can be <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> to articulated or more generally <phrase_Q=0.955>deformable objects</phrase>. Here, we propose that <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images of <phrase_Q=0.934>articulated objects</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> segmented into their rigid subcomponents. Each subcomponent can then be registered in isolation using the <phrase_Q=0.591>existing algorithms</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.560>designed specifically</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.693>rigid parts</phrase> and the final <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> formed by reassembling all of the submodels. This has motivated the development of a rigid part <phrase_Q=0.745>segmentation algorithm</phrase> which is described and demonstrated here. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is currently limited to non-umbilic surfaces, but in this more <phrase_Q=0.808>restricted</phrase> domain is shown to work well.
<phrase_Q=0.874>Human Identification</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.862>Body Shape</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.814>Extracting</phrase> Main Modes of <phrase_Q=0.685>Human Body Shape</phrase> Variation from 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Anthropometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Data</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.814>Characterizing</phrase> the variations of the <phrase_Q=0.960>human body</phrase> shape is <phrase_Q=0.612>fundamentally important</phrase> to many applications ranging from <phrase_Q=1.000>animation</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>product design</phrase>. 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> scanning <phrase_Q=1.000>technology</phrase> makes it possible to digitize the complete surfaces of a <phrase_Q=0.522>large number</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> bodies, providing much <phrase_Q=0.547>richer information</phrase> about the <phrase_Q=0.862>body shape</phrase> than the traditional <phrase_Q=1.000>anthropometric</phrase> measurements. This <phrase_Q=1.000>technology</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.556>opens up</phrase> opportunities to extract new measurements for <phrase_Q=0.826>quantifying</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.862>body shape</phrase>. Using the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.914>large scale</phrase> 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>anthropometric</phrase> survey, the <phrase_Q=1.000>CAESAR</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.810>project</phrase>, we demonstrate that the <phrase_Q=0.960>human body</phrase> shape can be represented by a small number of <phrase_Q=0.959>principal components</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Principal Component Analysis</phrase> extracts <phrase_Q=0.810>orthogonal basis</phrase> vectors, called eigenpersons, from the space of <phrase_Q=0.791>body shapes</phrase>. The shape of any individual person can then be expressed by the <phrase_Q=1.000>linear combination</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.805>basis vectors</phrase>. We demonstrate that some of these components correspond to the commonly used <phrase_Q=0.621>body measurements</phrase> like height and weight and others indicate new ways of charactering <phrase_Q=0.862>body shape</phrase> variations. We develop tools to visualize the changes of the <phrase_Q=0.862>body shape</phrase> along the <phrase_Q=0.562>main components</phrase>. These tools help understand the meaningful components of the <phrase_Q=0.960>human body</phrase> shape.

The <phrase_Q=0.532>on-chip</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>electronics</phrase> consists of an <phrase_Q=0.830>analog</phrase> part and a <phrase_Q=1.000>digital</phrase> part. The <phrase_Q=0.830>analog</phrase> preamplifiers deal with the <phrase_Q=1.000>low-pass</phrase> filtering of the <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase>-signals in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to reduce the noise bandwidth. The <phrase_Q=1.000>digital</phrase> part consists of an <phrase_Q=0.830>analog</phrase> current <phrase_Q=1.000>multiplexer</phrase>, implemented in <phrase_Q=1.000>ECL</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>technology</phrase>. Our goal is to achieve a 2 <phrase_Q=1.000>MHz</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase>/<phrase_Q=1.000>frequency</phrase> at 12 <phrase_Q=1.000>bits</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.717>Image-Gradient</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.829>Guided</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.662>Real-Time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.945>Graphics Hardware</phrase>.
We present a <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.839>correlation-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.804>improved</phrase> accuracy. Encouraged by the success of recent <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> that aggregate the matching <phrase_Q=0.712>cost based</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> segmentation, a novel <phrase_Q=0.717>image-gradient</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.829>guided</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.696>cost aggregation</phrase> scheme is presented in this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>. The new scheme is designed to fit the <phrase_Q=1.000>architecture</phrase> of recent <phrase_Q=0.967>graphics processing units</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>GPUs</phrase>). As a result, our <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> can run completely on the <phrase_Q=0.689>graphics board</phrase>: from <phrase_Q=0.833>rectification</phrase>, matching cost computation, <phrase_Q=0.696>cost aggregation</phrase>, to the final disparity selection. Compared with many <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> that use fixed <phrase_Q=1.000>windows</phrase>, noticeable <phrase_Q=0.869>accuracy improvement</phrase> has been obtained <phrase_Q=0.555>without sacrificing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.802>realtime</phrase> performance. In addition, existing <phrase_Q=1.000>global optimization</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> can also benefit from the new <phrase_Q=0.696>cost aggregation</phrase> scheme. The effectiveness of our approach is demonstrated with several widely used <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> datasets and <phrase_Q=1.000>live</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> captured from a <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo camera</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.508>Structure and Motion</phrase> from Two <phrase_Q=0.853>Uncalibrated</phrase> Views Using Points on Planes.
<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>CAD</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Industrial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.834>Pipes</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images.
We present in this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> a method to obtain automatically <phrase_Q=1.000>CAD</phrase> models of <phrase_Q=1.000>industrial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.834>pipes</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images. The models are based on two <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> primitives, cylinders and <phrase_Q=1.000>torii</phrase>, which are enough to represent most parts of the <phrase_Q=0.834>pipes</phrase>. The images are obtained with an accurate <phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase>-distance <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> developed for <phrase_Q=1.000>reverse engineering</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>industrial</phrase> structures. The <phrase_Q=0.545>key issue</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>CAD</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> is the <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> segmentation of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> into subsets of points corresponding to the desired primitives. To do so, we use <phrase_Q=1.000>differential geometry</phrase> to segment lines of centers of <phrase_Q=1.000>curvature</phrase> into <phrase_Q=0.528>straight and curved</phrase> parts, corresponding to the <phrase_Q=0.813>cylinder</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>torus</phrase> parts of the <phrase_Q=0.672>original image</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Differential geometry</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> being <phrase_Q=0.806>noisy</phrase> and biased, we use an <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase> approach for the computation of centers of <phrase_Q=1.000>curvature</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.732>Global Registration</phrase> of 3D <phrase_Q=0.601>Sampled Surfaces</phrase> using a <phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.848>Z</phrase>-Buffer Technique.
We present a new method for the <phrase_Q=0.732>global registration</phrase> of several overlapping 3D surfaces sampled on an object. The method is based on the <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.960>iterative closest point</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> and on a segmentation of the <phrase_Q=0.536>sampled points</phrase> in an optimized set of <phrase_Q=0.848>z</phrase>-buffers. This <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.848>z</phrase>-buffer technique provides a 3D <phrase_Q=0.891>space partitioning</phrase> which <phrase_Q=0.725>greatly accelerates</phrase> the search of the <phrase_Q=0.972>nearest neighbours</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.817>establishment</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.556>point-to-point</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> between overlapping surfaces. Then a <phrase_Q=1.000>randomized</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>iterative</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> is processed on the surface set. We have tested an implementation of this technique on real <phrase_Q=0.601>sampled surfaces</phrase>. It appears to be <phrase_Q=0.832>rapid</phrase> accurate and <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase>, especially in the case of <phrase_Q=0.659>highly curved</phrase> objects.
3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.813>Vision</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Technology</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.856>Occupant</phrase> Detection and Classification.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes a 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.813>vision</phrase> system based on a new 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>technology</phrase> for the detection and classification of occupants in a <phrase_Q=1.000>car</phrase>. New <phrase_Q=0.801>generation</phrase> of so-called "<phrase_Q=0.855>smart</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>airbags</phrase>" require the <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> about the occupancy type and position of the <phrase_Q=0.856>occupant</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> allows a distinct control of the <phrase_Q=1.000>airbag</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>inflation</phrase>. In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to reduce the <phrase_Q=1.000>risk</phrase> of injuries due to <phrase_Q=1.000>airbag</phrase> deployment, the <phrase_Q=1.000>airbag</phrase> can be suppressed completely in case of a child <phrase_Q=0.846>seat</phrase> oriented in reward direction. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we propose a 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.813>vision</phrase> system based on a 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase> time-of-<phrase_Q=0.815>flight</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.857>TOF</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase>, for the detection and classification of the occupancy on the <phrase_Q=0.828>passenger</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.846>seat</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.780>Geometrical shape</phrase> features are extracted from the 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.949>image sequences</phrase>. Polynomialclassifier is considered for the <phrase_Q=0.769>classification task</phrase>. A comparison of <phrase_Q=0.790>classifier performance</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.650>principle components</phrase> (eigenimages) is presented. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> also discuss the robustness of the features with variation of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. The full scale <phrase_Q=1.000>tests</phrase> have been conducted on a <phrase_Q=0.895>wide range</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.621>realistic situations</phrase> (adults/children/child seats etc.) which may occur in a <phrase_Q=0.815>vehicle</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.847>Object Model</phrase> Creation from <phrase_Q=0.647>Multiple Range Images</phrase>: <phrase_Q=0.807>Acquisition</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.829>Calibration</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.774>Model Building</phrase> and Verification.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> demonstrates the accuracy of a <phrase_Q=1.000>prototype</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Laser</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Camera</phrase> (LRC) developed at the <phrase_Q=1.000>National Research Council of Canada</phrase> for the creation of models of <phrase_Q=0.714>real objects</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> survey performed in collaboration with the <phrase_Q=1.000>Canadian Space Agency</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>NASA</phrase> is used as a <phrase_Q=1.000>test case</phrase>. The object selected for this particular <phrase_Q=1.000>test case</phrase> is the <phrase_Q=0.867>Orbiter</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.840>Docking</phrase> System (<phrase_Q=0.860>ODS</phrase>) located at the <phrase_Q=1.000>Kennedy Space Center</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>Florida</phrase>. During the <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> survey, 128 <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> (and registered intensity) images were acquired all around the <phrase_Q=0.860>ODS</phrase>. These images were then processed in our <phrase_Q=1.000>laboratory</phrase>. A full <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.820>top</phrase> portion of the <phrase_Q=0.860>ODS</phrase> was created along with an almost complete <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.860>ODS</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.860>ODS</phrase> has a <phrase_Q=1.000>diameter</phrase> of 1.6 <phrase_Q=0.826>m</phrase> and a height of 3.9 <phrase_Q=0.826>m</phrase>. Targets mounted on the <phrase_Q=0.820>top</phrase> portion of the <phrase_Q=0.860>ODS</phrase> were used to assess the accuracy of the <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> and of the <phrase_Q=1.000>image registration</phrase> process. These targets were measured with a network of theodolites a day prior to the <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> survey and used as a reference. With the current <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>image registration</phrase> techniques, an accuracy better than 0.25 <phrase_Q=0.850>mm</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.814>X</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.818>Y</phrase>, and, 0.80 <phrase_Q=0.850>mm</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.848>Z</phrase> was achieved. These <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> compare favorably with the <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> point accuracy obtained after <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase>, i.e., about 0.25 <phrase_Q=0.850>mm</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.814>X</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.818>Y</phrase>, and, 0.50 <phrase_Q=0.850>mm</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.848>Z</phrase>. These figures and others should testify on the usefulness of a LRC for accurate <phrase_Q=0.774>model building</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=0.906>Scene Analysis</phrase> System for the <phrase_Q=0.801>Generation</phrase> of 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> Models.

The system permits the insertion of highlevel constraints, like a specific angle between two <phrase_Q=1.000>house</phrase> walls, in an <phrase_Q=1.000>explicit knowledge</phrase> base implemented as a <phrase_Q=1.000>semantic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.855>net</phrase>. The applicability of those constraints is proved by asserting and <phrase_Q=0.821>testing</phrase> hypotheses in an interpretation phase. In the case of <phrase_Q=0.816>rejection</phrase> a more <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> constraint or <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is selected. The capabilities of the system were shown for the <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> of buildings using depth from <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.716>contour information</phrase>. The system reconstructs the surface of the <phrase_Q=0.571>scene objects</phrase> using the constraints selected in the prior interpretation.

Accuracy of 3D Scanning Technologies in a Face Scanning Scenario.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we will review several different 3D scanning devices. We will present a method for empirical accuracy analysis, and apply it to several scanners providing <phrase_Q=0.591>an overview</phrase> of their technologies. The scanners include both <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> purpose and face specific scanning devices. We will focus on face scanning technique, although the technique should be applicable to other domains as well. The <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> involves several different <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> faces of known shape and comparisons of their scans to investigate both <phrase_Q=0.660>absolute accuracy</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>repeatability</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.938>Hand Posture</phrase> Estimation from 2D <phrase_Q=1.000>Monocular</phrase> Image.
<phrase_Q=0.850>Hierarchical</phrase> Segmentation of <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images with <phrase_Q=0.806>Contour</phrase> Constraints.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes a new <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to segment in <phrase_Q=0.803>continuous</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.833>parametric</phrase> regions <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> starts with an <phrase_Q=0.505>initial partition</phrase> of small <phrase_Q=0.634>first order</phrase> regions using a <phrase_Q=0.690>robust fitting</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>constrained</phrase> by the detection of depth and <phrase_Q=0.572>orientation discontinuities</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> then optimally <phrase_Q=0.805>group</phrase> these regions into larger and larger regions using <phrase_Q=0.833>parametric</phrase> functions until an approximation limit is reached. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> uses <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>decision theory</phrase> to determine the local <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>grouping</phrase> and the complexity of the <phrase_Q=0.833>parametric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> used to represent the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> signal. After the segmentation process an <phrase_Q=0.836>exact</phrase> description of the boundary of each <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> is computed from the mutual intersections of the extracted surfaces. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show <phrase_Q=0.673>significant improvement</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.598>boundary localization</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=0.810>systematic</phrase> comparison of our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to the most well known <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase> is presented to highlight the contributions of this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.615>Non-Parametric</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.645>Surface Completion</phrase>.
We consider the <phrase_Q=0.820>completion</phrase> of the hidden or <phrase_Q=0.704>missing portions</phrase> of 3D objects after the visible portions have been acquired with 2½<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> (or 3D) <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> capture. Our approach uses a combination of <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.931>surface fitting</phrase>, to derive the underlying <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.645>surface completion</phrase>, together with an extension, from 2D to 3D, of <phrase_Q=0.615>non-parametric</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.961>texture synthesis</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to complete <phrase_Q=0.818>localised</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.862>surface texture</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>relief</phrase> and structure. Through this combination and adaptation of existing <phrase_Q=0.820>completion</phrase> techniques we are able to achieve realistic, plausible <phrase_Q=0.820>completion</phrase> of 2½<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> captures.

<phrase_Q=0.860>Micro</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>Stereoscopic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.813>Vision</phrase> System for the <phrase_Q=0.807>Determination</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.912>Air Bubbles</phrase> and Aqueous Droplets Content within <phrase_Q=1.000>Oil</phrase> Drops in Simulated Processes of <phrase_Q=0.830>Multiphase</phrase> Fermentations.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Industrial</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>fermentation</phrase> procedures involve the <phrase_Q=1.000>mixing</phrase> of multiple phases (solid, <phrase_Q=1.000>liquid</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.806>gaseous</phrase>), where the <phrase_Q=0.843>interfacial</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase> between the phases (<phrase_Q=0.912>air bubbles</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>oil</phrase> drops and aqueous medium) determines the <phrase_Q=1.000>nutrients</phrase> transfer and hence the performance of the <phrase_Q=1.000>culture</phrase>. Interactions between phases occur, <phrase_Q=0.508>giving rise to</phrase> the formation of <phrase_Q=0.792>complex structures</phrase> containing <phrase_Q=0.912>air bubbles</phrase> and small drops from the aqueous phase, trapped in <phrase_Q=1.000>oil</phrase> drops (<phrase_Q=1.000>water</phrase>-in-<phrase_Q=1.000>oil</phrase>-in-<phrase_Q=1.000>water</phrase>). A <phrase_Q=0.650>two-dimensional</phrase> observation of this phenomenon may <phrase_Q=1.000>lead</phrase> to an erroneous <phrase_Q=0.807>determination</phrase> of the phenomena occurring since <phrase_Q=0.804>bubbles</phrase> and droplets coming from different <phrase_Q=0.839>focal</phrase> planes may appear overlapped. In the present work, an original strategy to solve this problem is described. <phrase_Q=0.860>Micro</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>stereoscopic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.580>on-line</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.933>image acquisition</phrase> techniques have been used, so as to obtain accurate images from the cultures for further <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> analysis. Using this methodology, the <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> position of the trapped <phrase_Q=0.804>bubbles</phrase> and droplets moving at <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> speed can be calculated in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to determine their <phrase_Q=0.585>relative concentration</phrase>. To evaluate the accuracy of this technique, the <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> obtained with our system have been compared with those obtained by an <phrase_Q=0.812>expert</phrase>. An agreement of 95% was achieved. Also, this technique was able to evaluate 14% more <phrase_Q=0.804>bubbles</phrase> and droplets corresponding to overlaps that the <phrase_Q=0.812>expert</phrase> was not able to <phrase_Q=0.821>discern</phrase> in non-<phrase_Q=1.000>stereoscopic</phrase> images.
3D <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase> scanning <phrase_Q=0.816>diagnostics</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>Leonardo</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.844>Da</phrase> Vinci's "Adorazione dei <phrase_Q=1.000>Magi</phrase>" <phrase_Q=0.807>conservation</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.848>Unsupervised</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.956>Object Recognition</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> in Unordered Datasets.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a system for <phrase_Q=0.921>fully automatic</phrase> recognition and <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of 3D objects in <phrase_Q=0.918>image databases</phrase>. We pose the <phrase_Q=0.956>object recognition</phrase> problem as one of finding consistent matches between all images, subject to the constraint that the images were taken from a <phrase_Q=0.829>perspective</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>. We assume that the objects or scenes are rigid. For each image we associate a <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> matrix, which is <phrase_Q=0.848>parameterised</phrase> by rotation, <phrase_Q=1.000>translation</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>focal length</phrase>. We use <phrase_Q=0.521>invariant local features</phrase> to find matches between all images, and the <phrase_Q=0.537>RANSAC algorithm</phrase> to find those that are consistent with the <phrase_Q=0.882>fundamental matrix</phrase>. Objects are recognised as subsets of matching images. We then solve for the <phrase_Q=0.508>structure and motion</phrase> of each object, using a <phrase_Q=0.838>sparse</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.976>bundle adjustment</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> demonstrate that it is possible to recognise and reconstruct 3D objects from an unordered <phrase_Q=0.910>image database</phrase> with no <phrase_Q=0.823>user input</phrase> at all.
