<phrase_Q=0.819>Optimal</phrase> Postures and <phrase_Q=0.824>Positioning</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>Human</phrase> Body Scanning.
Advancements in <phrase_Q=1.000>technology</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>digitizing</phrase> the surface of the <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> body are providing new opportunities for <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>engineering</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>anthropometry</phrase>, the study of <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> body measurement for <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> and evaluation purposes. The <phrase_Q=0.820>availability</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>technology</phrase> is just the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> step in <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.698>surface scanning</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>engineering</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>anthropometry</phrase>; several issues remain to be resolved to make these tools useful for <phrase_Q=1.000>engineering</phrase> applications. One <phrase_Q=0.598>important issue</phrase> is the <phrase_Q=0.809>standardization</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.824>positioning</phrase> and the posture of the subject for scanning. In <phrase_Q=1.000>engineering</phrase> it is not enough to be able to measure one individual one time in one posture, but it is also necessary to measure the individual in different postures and compare the individual with many other people who have been comparably measured. Not <phrase_Q=0.839>surprisingly</phrase>, people can be more difficult to measure precisely than fixed <phrase_Q=0.598>stationary objects</phrase>. In the process of developing standardized procedures for <phrase_Q=1.000>surveying</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>civilian</phrase> populations of <phrase_Q=1.000>North America</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Europe</phrase>, an experiment was conducted to determine <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase> scanning positions. While this experiment used just one type of scanning <phrase_Q=1.000>technology</phrase>, many of the methods are <phrase_Q=0.840>transferable</phrase> to other methods as well. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> discusses the <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> from that investigation.
3D <phrase_Q=0.834>Digitization</phrase> of a Large <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Imperial Rome</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes 3D <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> of the "Plastico <phrase_Q=0.841>di</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Roma</phrase> antica", a large <phrase_Q=1.000>plaster</phrase>-of-<phrase_Q=1.000>Paris</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>imperial Rome</phrase> (16x17 meters) created in the <phrase_Q=0.828>last</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.811>century</phrase>. Its overall size demands an <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> approach typical of large structures, but it is also characterized by extremely <phrase_Q=0.837>tiny</phrase> details, typical of <phrase_Q=0.619>small objects</phrase>: houses are a few centimeters <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>; their <phrase_Q=0.827>doors</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>windows</phrase>, etc. are smaller than 1 <phrase_Q=0.855>cm</phrase>. The approach followed to resolve this "<phrase_Q=0.826>contradiction</phrase>" is described. The result is a huge but precise 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> created by using a special <phrase_Q=1.000>metrology</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Laser</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Radar</phrase>. We give an account of the procedures of reorienting the large <phrase_Q=0.979>point clouds</phrase> obtained after each <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> step (50-60 million points) into a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> reference system by means of <phrase_Q=0.802>measuring</phrase> fixed redundant <phrase_Q=0.883>reference points</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase> we show how the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> set can be properly <phrase_Q=0.515>divided into</phrase> 2x2 meters sub-areas for allowing <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> merging and <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>editing</phrase>..
3D <phrase_Q=0.818>Registration</phrase> by Textured <phrase_Q=1.000>Spin</phrase>-Images.
This work is motivated by the <phrase_Q=0.823>desire</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.803>exploiting</phrase> for 3D <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> purposes the <phrase_Q=1.000>photometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> current <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> cameras typically associate to <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> pairwise 3D <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> procedures are two steps procedures with the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> step performing an <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> crude estimate of the <phrase_Q=0.901>rigid motion</phrase> parameters and the <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> step <phrase_Q=0.812>refining</phrase> them by the <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> or some of its variations. Methods for <phrase_Q=0.624>efficiently implementing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> crude <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> estimate are still an <phrase_Q=0.822>open</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Spin</phrase>-images are a 3D matching tecnique very effective in this task. Since <phrase_Q=1.000>spin</phrase>-images solely exploit <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> it appears natural to extend their original definition to include <phrase_Q=0.645>texture information</phrase>. Such an operation can clearly be made in many ways. This work introduces one particular extension of <phrase_Q=1.000>spin</phrase>-images, called textured <phrase_Q=1.000>spin</phrase>-images, and demostrates its performance for 3D <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase>. It will be seen that textured <phrase_Q=1.000>spin</phrase>-images enjoy <phrase_Q=0.613>remarkable properties</phrase> since they can give <phrase_Q=0.901>rigid motion</phrase> estimates more <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase>, more precise, more <phrase_Q=0.836>resilient</phrase> to noise than standard <phrase_Q=1.000>spin</phrase>-images at a <phrase_Q=0.546>lower computational cost</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.829>Calibration</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.742>Zooming Camera</phrase> using the Normalized Image of the <phrase_Q=0.589>Absolute Conic</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=1.000>Euclidean</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.824>Translational</phrase> Motion Using <phrase_Q=0.882>Multiple Cameras</phrase>.
We investigate the possibility of <phrase_Q=1.000>Euclidean</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.824>translational</phrase> motion, using multiple <phrase_Q=0.945>uncalibrated cameras</phrase>. We show that in the case of <phrase_Q=0.882>multiple cameras</phrase> viewing a <phrase_Q=0.820>translating</phrase> scene, no <phrase_Q=0.668>additional constraints</phrase> are given by the <phrase_Q=0.824>translational</phrase> motion compared to the more <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> case with one <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> viewing a scene undergoing a <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> motion. However, the <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.824>translational</phrase> motion allows an intermediate <phrase_Q=0.840>affine</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> from each <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>aids</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> process by <phrase_Q=0.808>simplifying</phrase> several steps, resulting in a more <phrase_Q=0.814>reliable</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase>. We also identify the critical directions of <phrase_Q=1.000>translation</phrase>, for which no <phrase_Q=0.840>affine</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> is possible. Experiments on real and <phrase_Q=0.644>simulated data</phrase> are performed to illustrate that the <phrase_Q=0.520>method works</phrase> in practice.

<phrase_Q=0.558>Realistic Human</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.561>Head Modeling</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-View Hairstyle <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase>.

A <phrase_Q=0.942>weighted averaging</phrase> method is then used to extract a <phrase_Q=0.843>panoramic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.705>texture map</phrase> from the <phrase_Q=0.614>input images</phrase>. To recover the hairstyle of the specified person, a <phrase_Q=0.805>virtual</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>photo</phrase> plane is defined, according to a corresponding true <phrase_Q=0.806>photo</phrase> plane, on which one <phrase_Q=0.602>input image</phrase> is recorded. It provides hints to compute the 3D positions of the <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>contour</phrase> points of the <phrase_Q=1.000>hair</phrase> from the images taken at different viewpoints. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, more hairs are grown to <phrase_Q=1.000>cover</phrase> the whole <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>scalp</phrase> using an <phrase_Q=1.000>interpolation</phrase> method on the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>scalp</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> surfaces.

<phrase_Q=0.782>Automatic Registration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images Based on <phrase_Q=0.825>Correspondence</phrase> of Complete Plane Patches.
One of the difficulties in registering two <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images scanned by 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> scanners is how to get a correct <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> over the two images automatically. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose an <phrase_Q=0.782>automatic registration</phrase> method based on matching of extracted planes. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase>, we introduce a new class of features: complete plane patches (<phrase_Q=0.850>CPP</phrase>) on the basis of analysis of properties of <phrase_Q=0.899>real scenes</phrase>. Then we generate a <phrase_Q=0.829>compact</phrase> interpretation <phrase_Q=1.000>tree</phrase> for these features. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>image registration</phrase> is accomplished automatically by searching the interpretation <phrase_Q=1.000>tree</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Semi-Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>Registration</phrase>: A <phrase_Q=0.879>Feature-Based</phrase> Method.
A <phrase_Q=0.810>Self</phrase>-Referenced <phrase_Q=0.907>Hand-Held</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Sensor</phrase>.
Segmentation of <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images into <phrase_Q=0.826>Planar</phrase> Regions.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a <phrase_Q=1.000>hybrid</phrase> approach to the segmentation of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images into <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> regions. The term <phrase_Q=1.000>hybrid</phrase> refers to a combination of <phrase_Q=0.803>edge</phrase>- and <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase>-based considerations. A <phrase_Q=0.814>reliable</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.594>computational procedure</phrase> which takes the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> image discontinuities into account is presented for <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> the pixel's normal. The <phrase_Q=0.745>segmentation algorithm</phrase> consists of two parts. In the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> one, the <phrase_Q=1.000>pixels</phrase> are aggregated according to <phrase_Q=0.617>local properties</phrase> derived from the <phrase_Q=0.758>input data</phrase> and are represented by a <phrase_Q=0.814>region adjacency graph</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.838>RAG</phrase>). At this stage, the image is still over-segmented. In the <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> part, the segmentation is refined thanks to the <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> of an <phrase_Q=0.806>irregular</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>pyramid</phrase>. The base of the <phrase_Q=1.000>pyramid</phrase> is the <phrase_Q=0.838>RAG</phrase> previously extracted. The over-<phrase_Q=0.881>segmented regions</phrase> are merged using a <phrase_Q=0.679>surface-based</phrase> description. This <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> has been evaluated on 80 <phrase_Q=0.673>real images</phrase> acquired by two different <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> sensors using the methodology proposed in (<phrase_Q=1.000>Hoover</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.549>et al</phrase>., 1996). <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are presented and compared to others obtained by four <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> groups.
Locking onto 3D-Structure by a Combined <phrase_Q=0.856>Vergence</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Fusion</phrase> System.
A 3D Scanning System Based on Low-Occlusion Approach.
<phrase_Q=0.904>Multi-Resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>Geometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Fusion</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.836>Geometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>fusion</phrase> of multiple sets of overlapping surface measurements is an important problem for complete 3D object or environment <phrase_Q=0.812>modelling</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Fusion</phrase> based on a discrete <phrase_Q=0.912>implicit surface</phrase> representation enables <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.748>complex object</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>modelling</phrase>. However, surfaces are represented at a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> resulting in impractical <phrase_Q=0.776>storage costs</phrase> for accurate <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.628>large objects</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> addresses accurate <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.729>surface models</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.558>object size</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.510>An incremental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is presented for <phrase_Q=0.912>implicit surface</phrase> representation of an arbitrary <phrase_Q=0.707>triangulated mesh</phrase> in a <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>envelope</phrase> around the surface. A <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> structure is introduced for <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> representation by <phrase_Q=0.729>local approximation</phrase> of the surface within a fixed <phrase_Q=0.918>error bound</phrase> using the maximum <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase> size. <phrase_Q=0.904>Multi-resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>fusion</phrase> is achieved by incrementally <phrase_Q=0.808>constructing</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.808>surface representation</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.802>bounded</phrase> error. <phrase_Q=1.000>Results</phrase> are presented for validation of the <phrase_Q=0.904>multi-resolution</phrase> representation accuracy and <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.714>real objects</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.904>Multi-resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>fusion</phrase> achieves a significant reduction in representation cost for the same level of <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> accuracy.
A <phrase_Q=1.000>Light</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Modulation</phrase>/<phrase_Q=1.000>Demodulation</phrase> Method for <phrase_Q=0.662>Real-Time</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.817>Imaging</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes a novel method for <phrase_Q=1.000>digitizing</phrase> the 3D shape of an object in <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase>, which can be used for capturing <phrase_Q=1.000>live</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> of the 3D shape of moving or <phrase_Q=0.955>deformable objects</phrase> such as faces. Two DMD (= <phrase_Q=1.000>Digital</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.860>Micro</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Mirror</phrase>) devices are used as <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> speed switches for modulating and demodulating <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>rays</phrase>. One DMD is used to generate <phrase_Q=1.000>rays</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> pulses, which are <phrase_Q=0.594>projected onto</phrase> the object to be measured. Another DMD is used to demodulate the <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> reflected from the object <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminated</phrase> by the <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> pulses into <phrase_Q=0.693>intensity image</phrase> that describes the disparity. A <phrase_Q=1.000>prototype</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.936>range finder</phrase> implementing the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> has been built. The <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> showed that the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> works and <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> sequences of <phrase_Q=0.556>disparity images</phrase> can be captured in <phrase_Q=0.662>real time</phrase>.
Toward <phrase_Q=0.819>Optimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.944>Structured Light</phrase> Patterns.
A methodology for the <phrase_Q=1.000>optimal design</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.821>projection</phrase> patterns for stereometric <phrase_Q=0.944>structured light</phrase> systems is presented. The similarity as well as the difference between the <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.821>projection</phrase> patterns and the <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase> signals for <phrase_Q=1.000>digital</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>communication</phrase> are discussed. The <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.806>K</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>projection</phrase> patterns for a <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> system with <phrase_Q=0.845>L</phrase> distinct planes of <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> is shown to be equivalent to the placement of <phrase_Q=0.845>L</phrase> points in a <phrase_Q=0.806>K</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.706>dimensional space</phrase> subject to certain constraints. <phrase_Q=1.000>optimal design</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.851>MSE</phrase> sense is defined, but shown to <phrase_Q=1.000>lead</phrase> to an intractable <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-parameter <phrase_Q=1.000>global optimization</phrase> problem. <phrase_Q=0.808>Intuitively</phrase> appealing <phrase_Q=0.782>suboptimal solutions</phrase> derived from the <phrase_Q=1.000>family</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.806>K</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.706>dimensional space</phrase>-filling <phrase_Q=1.000>Hilbert</phrase> curves are obtained. <phrase_Q=0.700>Preliminary experimental results</phrase> are presented.
<phrase_Q=0.846>Edge-Based</phrase> Approach to <phrase_Q=0.967>Mesh Simplification</phrase>.
A Complete <phrase_Q=0.643>U-V-Disparity</phrase> Study for <phrase_Q=0.852>Stereovision</phrase> Based 3D <phrase_Q=0.731>Driving Environment</phrase> Analysis.
<phrase_Q=0.814>Reliable</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.816>understanding</phrase> of the 3D <phrase_Q=0.731>driving environment</phrase> is vital for <phrase_Q=0.956>obstacle detection</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.819>Adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Cruise Control</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>ACC</phrase>) applications. <phrase_Q=1.000>Laser</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.959>millimeter wave</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>radars</phrase> have shown good performance in <phrase_Q=0.802>measuring</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.575>relative speed</phrase> and distance in a <phrase_Q=1.000>highway</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.731>driving environment</phrase>. However the accuracy of these systems decreases in an <phrase_Q=1.000>urban</phrase> traffic environment as more confusion occurs due to factors such as <phrase_Q=0.939>parked vehicles</phrase>, guardrails, <phrase_Q=1.000>poles</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>motorcycles</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=0.852>stereovision</phrase> based sensing system provides an effective supplement to <phrase_Q=1.000>radar</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=0.889>road scene</phrase> analysis with its much wider <phrase_Q=0.534>field of view</phrase> and more accurate <phrase_Q=0.816>lateral</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> using a <phrase_Q=0.852>stereovision</phrase> based <phrase_Q=0.889>road scene</phrase> analysis <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> which employs the "<phrase_Q=0.643>U-V-disparity</phrase>" concept. This concept is used to classify a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>road</phrase> scene into relative surface planes and characterize the features of <phrase_Q=1.000>road</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.858>pavement</phrase> surfaces, <phrase_Q=0.820>roadside</phrase> structures and obstacles. <phrase_Q=0.662>Real-time</phrase> implementation of the <phrase_Q=0.914>disparity map</phrase> calculation and the "<phrase_Q=0.643>U-V-disparity</phrase>" classification is also presented.

<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Burr</phrase> Detection on <phrase_Q=0.533>Surfaces of Revolution</phrase> Based on <phrase_Q=0.819>Adaptive</phrase> 3D Scanning.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes how to <phrase_Q=0.710>automatically extract</phrase> the presence and location of <phrase_Q=0.826>geometrical</phrase> irregularities on a surface of <phrase_Q=1.000>revolution</phrase>. To this end a <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.843>scan</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.814>workpiece</phrase> under consideration is acquired by <phrase_Q=0.944>structured light</phrase> ranging. The application we focus on is the detection and <phrase_Q=0.805>removal</phrase> of burrs on <phrase_Q=1.000>industrial</phrase> workpieces. <phrase_Q=0.824>Cylindrical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>metallic</phrase> objects will cause a strong <phrase_Q=1.000>specular reflection</phrase> in every direction. These highlights are compensated for in the projected patterns, hence ýadaptive 3D scanningý. The <phrase_Q=0.950>triangular mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>produced</phrase> is then used to identify the <phrase_Q=1.000>axis</phrase> and generatrix of the corresponding surface of <phrase_Q=1.000>revolution</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.882>search space</phrase> for finding this <phrase_Q=1.000>axis</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.670>four dimensional</phrase>: a valid choice of parameters is two <phrase_Q=0.679>orientation angles</phrase> (as in <phrase_Q=1.000>spherical coordinates</phrase>) and the 2D <phrase_Q=0.783>intersection point</phrase> with the plane spanned by two out of three <phrase_Q=1.000>axis</phrase> of the local <phrase_Q=0.530>coordinate system</phrase>. For finding the <phrase_Q=1.000>axis</phrase> we <phrase_Q=1.000>test</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.831>circularity</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> intersections of the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> in different directions, using <phrase_Q=0.878>statistical estimation</phrase> methods to deal with noise. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase> the ýidealý generatrix derived from the <phrase_Q=0.622>scan data</phrase> is compared to the real <phrase_Q=0.522>surface topology</phrase>. The difference will identify the <phrase_Q=1.000>burr</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is demonstrated on a <phrase_Q=1.000>metal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.837>wheel</phrase> that has burrs on both sides. <phrase_Q=0.832>Visual</phrase> servoing of a <phrase_Q=1.000>robotic arm</phrase> based on this detection is work in progress.
<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images Obtained from Unknown Viewpoints.
<phrase_Q=0.823>Partial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.540>Surface Integration</phrase> Based on <phrase_Q=0.575>Variational Implicit</phrase> Functions and Surfaces for 3D <phrase_Q=0.774>Model Building</phrase>.
Most <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> systems generate several <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> reconstructions that have to be registered and integrated for <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> a complete 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose a <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> shape <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> method, consisting of <phrase_Q=0.835>weighted</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.723>signed distance functions</phrase> represented as <phrase_Q=0.575>variational implicit</phrase> functions (VIF) or surfaces (<phrase_Q=0.878>VIS</phrase>). Texture <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> is solved <phrase_Q=0.811>similarly</phrase> by using three <phrase_Q=0.835>weighted</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> functions also based on VIFs. Using these <phrase_Q=0.803>continuous</phrase> (not <phrase_Q=0.846>grid</phrase>-based) representations solves <phrase_Q=0.617>current limitations</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> methods: no <phrase_Q=1.000>memory</phrase> inefficient and <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> limiting <phrase_Q=0.846>grid</phrase> representation is required. The built-in <phrase_Q=0.805>smoothing</phrase> properties of the <phrase_Q=0.878>VIS</phrase> representations also improve the robustness of the final <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> against noise in the <phrase_Q=0.758>input data</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are performed on real-<phrase_Q=1.000>live</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.550>noiseless and noisy</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.775>synthetic data</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> faces in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to show the robustness and accuracy of the <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.836>Geometric</phrase> Matching of 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> Objects: <phrase_Q=0.808>Assessing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> of Successful <phrase_Q=0.827>Initial Configurations</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> and Accurate <phrase_Q=0.823>Partial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.882>Surface Registration</phrase> Based on <phrase_Q=0.575>Variational Implicit</phrase> Surfaces for <phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.774>Model Building</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.668>Three-dimensional</phrase> models are often assembled from several <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> reconstructions from unknown viewpoints. In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to provide a <phrase_Q=0.921>fully automatic</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> and accurate method for <phrase_Q=0.827>aligning</phrase> and integrating <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> reconstructions without any <phrase_Q=0.952>prior knowledge</phrase> of the relative viewpoints of the <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> or the <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase> process, we propose <phrase_Q=1.000>a 4</phrase>-step <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> based on a common <phrase_Q=0.575>Variational Implicit</phrase> Surface (<phrase_Q=0.878>VIS</phrase>) representation of the <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.748>surface reconstructions</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> crude <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> without a <phrase_Q=0.849>priori knowledge</phrase> is performed followed by a <phrase_Q=0.526>pose refinement</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> pairs. <phrase_Q=0.899>Pair-wise</phrase> registrations are <phrase_Q=0.533>converted into</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.882>multi-view</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase>, before a final <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> of the reconstructions into one entity or <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> occurs. Furthermore, making use of the <phrase_Q=0.805>smoothing</phrase> properties of the <phrase_Q=0.878>VIS</phrase> representations, the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> proves to be <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> against noise in the <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> on real-<phrase_Q=1.000>live</phrase>, as well as <phrase_Q=0.550>noiseless and noisy</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.644>simulated data</phrase> are presented to show the feasibility, the accuracy and robustness of our <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> scheme.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.854>Multiperspective</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>Imaging</phrase> under <phrase_Q=0.662>6 DOF</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Camera</phrase> Motion.
<phrase_Q=0.854>Multiperspective</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase> has been used to recover the structure of a scene. Although several <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.689>structure recovery</phrase> have been developed as typified by <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.819>panoramas</phrase>, there exists no <phrase_Q=0.530>common framework</phrase> which subsumes various <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> motions to capture <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> images. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a framework for <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.854>multiperspective</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase>, which is <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> in that it can handle 6 <phrase_Q=1.000>degree</phrase>-of-freedom (<phrase_Q=0.847>DOF</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> motion. We derive <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> constraints, equation for <phrase_Q=0.689>structure recovery</phrase> and that for an epipolar curve by <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> images using <phrase_Q=0.829>push</phrase>-broom cameras (line sensors). We consider a class of <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> motion called a <phrase_Q=0.817>vertical</phrase> view plane class and demonstrate that several <phrase_Q=0.650>previous results</phrase> are really <phrase_Q=0.779>special cases</phrase> of our <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.766>Numerical examples</phrase> are given to show the correctness of the derived equations.

<phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>Reality</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.930>Spatio-Temporal</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Fusion</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.860>Multiple View</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Video</phrase> Rate 3D Surfaces.
We consider the problem of <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> and representation of <phrase_Q=0.927>multiple views</phrase> of non-rigidly deforming 3D <phrase_Q=0.760>surface geometry</phrase> captured at <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> rate. Instead of treating each <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase> as a separate <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> we present a representation which <phrase_Q=0.578>takes into consideration</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.858>spatial coherence</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> where possible. We <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> segment <phrase_Q=0.841>gross</phrase> base transformations using <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> based on a <phrase_Q=0.925>closest point</phrase> metric and represent these motions as <phrase_Q=1.000>piecewise</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.782>rigid transformations</phrase>. The remaining <phrase_Q=0.833>residual</phrase> is encoded as <phrase_Q=0.856>displacement maps</phrase> at each <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase> giving a displacement <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase>. At both these stages occlusions and <phrase_Q=0.924>missing data</phrase> are interpolated to give a representation which is <phrase_Q=0.803>continuous</phrase> in space and time. We demonstrate the <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.927>multiple views</phrase> for four different non-rigidly deforming scenes: hand, face, cloth and a <phrase_Q=0.852>composite</phrase> scene. The <phrase_Q=0.551>approach achieves</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.860>multiple-view</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> at different times into one representation which can processed and edited.
<phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>Alignment</phrase> of 3D <phrase_Q=0.826>Geometrical</phrase> Models and 2D <phrase_Q=0.822>Color</phrase> Images Using 2D <phrase_Q=0.799>Distance Maps</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.965>pose estimation</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> of a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase> form object in 2D images using 2D <phrase_Q=0.799>distance maps</phrase>. One of the popular techniques of the <phrase_Q=0.965>pose estimation</phrase> of 3D object in 2D image is the <phrase_Q=0.826>point-based</phrase> method such as the <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. However, the calculation cost for <phrase_Q=0.801>determining</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.922>point correspondences</phrase> is expensive. To overcome this problem, the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> utilizes a <phrase_Q=0.771>distance map</phrase> on the 2D <phrase_Q=0.849>image plane</phrase>, which is constructed quite rapidly by the <phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Marching</phrase> Method. For <phrase_Q=0.965>pose estimation</phrase> of the object, <phrase_Q=0.806>contour</phrase> lines of the 2D image and the <phrase_Q=0.821>projection</phrase> of the 3D object are aligned using the <phrase_Q=0.771>distance map</phrase> iteratively by the <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>M</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>estimator</phrase>. Some <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> with simulated models and actual images of the <phrase_Q=1.000>endoscopic</phrase> operation are successfully <phrase_Q=0.501>carried out</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.807>Acquisition</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.788>View-Based</phrase> 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.830>Object Models</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.827>Supervised</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>Unstructured Data</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.647>Existing techniques</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.788>view-based</phrase> 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.956>object recognition</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.688>computer vision</phrase> rely on <phrase_Q=0.801>training</phrase> the system on a particular object before it is introduced into an environment. This <phrase_Q=0.801>training</phrase> often consists of taking over 100 images at predetermined points around the <phrase_Q=0.506>viewing sphere</phrase> in an attempt to account for most angles for viewing the object. However, in many circumstances, the environment is well known and we only expect to see a small <phrase_Q=1.000>subset</phrase> of all possible appearances. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we will <phrase_Q=1.000>test</phrase> the idea that under these conditions, it is possible to <phrase_Q=1.000>train</phrase> an <phrase_Q=0.956>object recognition</phrase> system on-the-<phrase_Q=1.000>fly</phrase> using images of an object as it appears in its environment, with <phrase_Q=0.827>supervision</phrase> from the user. Furthermore, because some views of an object are much more likely than others, the number of <phrase_Q=0.801>training</phrase> images required can be <phrase_Q=0.802>greatly reduced</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.828>Fusing</phrase> and Guiding <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Measurements with <phrase_Q=0.836>Colour</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Video</phrase> Images.
Combining <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from different sensors provides richer <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.815>visualisation</phrase> and helps in <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> detection and recognition of objects. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents two methods <phrase_Q=0.805>relating</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.650>two dimensional</phrase> images from <phrase_Q=0.836>colour</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>CCD</phrase> cameras with <phrase_Q=0.668>three dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> scanners. The <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> method is applicable in a static case and provides the <phrase_Q=0.827>geometrically correct</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> one offers an <phrase_Q=0.836>approximate</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> but can be used in a <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> environment for guiding <phrase_Q=0.806>selective</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> measurements and simplifies the <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> process. The error introduced by this approximation has been derived as a <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> of the distance to the object and <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> of the set-up. <phrase_Q=1.000>Results</phrase> of combining <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> from a <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.836>colour</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> are presented.
Using <phrase_Q=1.000>PCA</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> Shape for <phrase_Q=1.000>Process Control</phrase>.
Before <phrase_Q=1.000>surface mount</phrase> components can be placed on a <phrase_Q=1.000>circuit board</phrase>, it is necessary to print <phrase_Q=0.952>solder paste</phrase> onto <phrase_Q=0.862>pads</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.832>paste</phrase> is then melted to make an <phrase_Q=0.803>electrical</phrase> connection (reflow). A <phrase_Q=1.000>screen printing</phrase> process is used to print the <phrase_Q=0.952>solder paste</phrase> onto the <phrase_Q=0.802>board</phrase>. This is a complicated process with a <phrase_Q=0.522>large number</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.729>input parameters</phrase>. Some of these parameters can be controlled and it is the purpose of this work to investigate control of the <phrase_Q=0.617>process based</phrase> on measurement of the output shape of the printed <phrase_Q=0.832>paste</phrase>. The shape is measured using a <phrase_Q=0.914>laser range scanner</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Principal Component Analysis</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>PCA</phrase>) is proposed as a tool for describing <phrase_Q=0.952>solder paste</phrase> shape with a small number of parameters. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> discusses the use of <phrase_Q=1.000>PCA</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.914>shape analysis</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images as well as <phrase_Q=0.815>explaining</phrase> how such a description can be incorporated into a <phrase_Q=1.000>process control</phrase> loop.
Fitting of 3D <phrase_Q=0.577>Circles and Ellipses</phrase> Using a Parameter <phrase_Q=0.710>Decomposition Approach</phrase>.
Many optimization processes encounter a problem inefficiently reaching a <phrase_Q=0.782>global minimum</phrase> or a near <phrase_Q=0.782>global minimum</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.634>Traditional methods</phrase> such as <phrase_Q=0.757>Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.823>trust</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> method face the problems of dropping into <phrase_Q=0.925>local minima</phrase> as well. On the other hand, some <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> such as <phrase_Q=1.000>simulated annealing</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>genetic algorithm</phrase> try to find a <phrase_Q=0.782>global minimum</phrase> but they are mostly <phrase_Q=0.542>time-consuming</phrase>. Without a good initialization, many <phrase_Q=0.702>optimization methods</phrase> are unable to guarantee a <phrase_Q=0.782>global minimum</phrase> result. We address a novel method in 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>circle</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>ellipse</phrase> fitting, which alleviates the <phrase_Q=1.000>optimization problem</phrase>. It can not only increase the <phrase_Q=1.000>probability</phrase> of getting in <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> minima but also reduce the computation time. Based on our previous work, we decompose the parameters into two parts: one part of parameters can be solved by an <phrase_Q=0.808>analytic</phrase> or a <phrase_Q=0.811>direct</phrase> method and another part has to be solved by an <phrase_Q=0.836>iterative</phrase> procedure. Via this scheme, the <phrase_Q=1.000>topography</phrase> of optimization space is <phrase_Q=0.824>simplified</phrase> and therefore we reduce the number of <phrase_Q=0.925>local minima</phrase> and the computation time. We <phrase_Q=0.732>experimentally compare</phrase> our method with the traditional ones and show <phrase_Q=1.000>superior</phrase> performance.
Reducing <phrase_Q=0.538>Movement Artifacts</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.735>Whole Body</phrase> Scanning.
<phrase_Q=0.538>Movement artifacts</phrase> during <phrase_Q=0.735>whole body</phrase> scanning are a <phrase_Q=1.000>major</phrase> concern when <phrase_Q=0.582>reproducible results</phrase> are required. To determine the <phrase_Q=1.000>magnitude</phrase> of the artifacts, 11 subjects were scanned with and without a <phrase_Q=0.824>positioning</phrase> device on the <phrase_Q=0.809>head</phrase>. The sway of the body was determined by a force plate. It was shown that the pointer on the <phrase_Q=0.809>head</phrase> reduced the <phrase_Q=1.000>magnitude</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.962>forward/backward</phrase> sway by over 50%. The resulting <phrase_Q=1.000>standard deviation</phrase> is less than the <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.538>Movement artifacts</phrase> within the body, like <phrase_Q=0.809>head</phrase> rotation, are hard to control. Again, the pointer on the <phrase_Q=0.809>head</phrase> assists in reducing the artifacts. The <phrase_Q=0.815>ventilation</phrase> depth during the <phrase_Q=0.843>scan</phrase> determines the shape of the chest and should be standardized to get <phrase_Q=0.582>reproducible results</phrase>.
Extraction and <phrase_Q=0.814>Tracking</phrase> of Surfaces in <phrase_Q=0.856>Range Image</phrase> Sequences.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Image Registration</phrase>: A <phrase_Q=1.000>Software</phrase> Platform and <phrase_Q=0.887>Empirical Evaluation</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.882>Surface Registration</phrase> by Matching <phrase_Q=0.568>Oriented Points</phrase>.
For <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> of 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase>-form surfaces we have developed a representation which requires no <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> of the transformation between views. The representation comprises descriptive images associated with <phrase_Q=0.568>oriented points</phrase> on the surface of an object. Constructed using <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> point bases, these images are <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> level <phrase_Q=0.839>shape descriptions</phrase> that are used for <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> matching of <phrase_Q=0.568>oriented points</phrase>. Correlation of images is used to establish <phrase_Q=0.922>point correspondences</phrase> between two views; from these correspondences a <phrase_Q=0.727>rigid transformation</phrase> that aligns the views is calculated. The transformation is then refined and verified using a modified <phrase_Q=0.808>iterative closest point algorithm</phrase>. To demonstrate the generality of our approach, we present <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> from multiple sensing domains.
A <phrase_Q=0.914>Laser Range Scanner</phrase> Designed for <phrase_Q=0.815>Minimum</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.829>Calibration</phrase> Complexity.
A System for <phrase_Q=1.000>Semi-Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.749>Complex Environments</phrase>.
We present a <phrase_Q=1.000>perception</phrase> system, called <phrase_Q=1.000>Artisan</phrase>, that <phrase_Q=0.781>semi-automatically</phrase> builds 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> models of a robot's workspace. <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> images are acquired with a <phrase_Q=0.862>scanning laser</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>rangefinder</phrase> and then processed, based an a <phrase_Q=0.810>systematic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.808>characterization</phrase>, to <phrase_Q=0.563>remove noise</phrase> and artifacts. Complex 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> objects represented as <phrase_Q=0.922>surface meshes</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.823>subsequently</phrase> recognized in the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images and inserted into a <phrase_Q=0.805>virtual</phrase> workspace. This <phrase_Q=1.000>graphical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.805>virtual</phrase> workspace is then used to by <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> operators to plan and execute <phrase_Q=0.813>remote</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>robotic</phrase> operations.
<phrase_Q=0.851>Image-Based</phrase> Techniques for <phrase_Q=1.000>Digitizing</phrase> Environments and Artifacts.
<phrase_Q=0.818>Registration</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.821>Integration</phrase> of Textured 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Data</phrase>.
In <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.927>multiple views</phrase> are required to create a complete 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of an object or of a <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-roomed <phrase_Q=0.824>indoor</phrase> scene. In this work, we address the problem of <phrase_Q=0.519>merging multiple</phrase> textured 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> sets, each of which corresponds to a different view of a scene or object. There are two steps to the <phrase_Q=0.572>merging process</phrase>: <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase>. To register, or align, <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> sets we use a <phrase_Q=0.686>modified version</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.808>Iterative Closest Point algorithm</phrase>; our version, which we call <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase>, considers not only 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>, but <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> as well. We show that the use of <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> decreases <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> error by an <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>magnitude</phrase>. Once the 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> sets have been registered we integrate them to produce a <phrase_Q=0.846>seamless</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.852>composite</phrase> 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> textured <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. Our approach to <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> uses a 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.949>occupancy grid</phrase> to represent likelihood of <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> occupancy through <phrase_Q=0.845>voting</phrase>. In addition to occupancy <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>, we store <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase> in each <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.949>occupancy grid</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.872>Surface normal</phrase> is used to <phrase_Q=0.653>robustly extract</phrase> a surface from the <phrase_Q=0.949>occupancy grid</phrase>; on that surface we blend textures from <phrase_Q=0.927>multiple views</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.810>Building</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.839>Symbolic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Information</phrase> for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Human</phrase> Body <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Data</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> 3 -- <phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.834>Digitization</phrase> using a <phrase_Q=1.000>Laser Rangefinder</phrase> with a Small <phrase_Q=0.534>Field of View</phrase>.
We address the problem of the <phrase_Q=1.000>automation</phrase> of surface <phrase_Q=0.834>digitization</phrase> using a precision 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>laser rangefinder</phrase>. Because of their small <phrase_Q=0.534>field of view</phrase>, such sensors navigate closely to the digitized object and are subject to collisions. <phrase_Q=0.735>Unlike previous</phrase> techniques that addressed only the exhaustiveness of <phrase_Q=0.834>digitization</phrase>, this work focuses on <phrase_Q=0.968>collision avoidance</phrase>. To safely identify <phrase_Q=0.501>empty space</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.839>shadow</phrase> and occlusion phenomena are <phrase_Q=0.644>carefully analyzed</phrase>, and so is the effect of <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase>. Then, the <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase> problem is solved using a <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> approach. At <phrase_Q=0.861>low level</phrase>, we digitize a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> view and address <phrase_Q=0.968>collision avoidance</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.951>path planning</phrase> techniques. At <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> level, the problem becomes the choice of the <phrase_Q=0.822>next</phrase> best view. Some <phrase_Q=0.756>implementation details</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are presented.
<phrase_Q=0.668>Three-Dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>Modelling</phrase> and Rendering of the <phrase_Q=1.000>Human</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.823>Skeletal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.847>Trunk</phrase> from 2D <phrase_Q=0.933>Radiographic Images</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.829>Compact</phrase> 3D Profilometer with <phrase_Q=1.000>Grazing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.815>Incidence</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Diffraction</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Optics</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> Multiple-<phrase_Q=0.846>Baseline Stereo</phrase> with Occlusion.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a new and <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.700>multi-baseline stereo</phrase> designed to handle the occlusion problem. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is a <phrase_Q=1.000>hybrid</phrase> between <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>heuristic</phrase> occlusion <phrase_Q=0.818>overcoming</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> that precompute an <phrase_Q=0.574>approximate visibility</phrase> and slower methods that use correct <phrase_Q=0.807>visibility</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.811>handling</phrase>. Our approach is based on <phrase_Q=0.836>iterative</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>dynamic programming</phrase> and computes simultaneously disparity and <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>visibility</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.840>Interestingly</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>dynamic programming</phrase> makes it possible to compute exactly part of the <phrase_Q=0.667>visibility information</phrase>. The remainder is obtained through heuristics. The validity of our scheme is established using real imagery with <phrase_Q=0.942>ground truth</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.814>compares favorably</phrase> with otherstate-of-the-<phrase_Q=1.000>art</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.700>multi-baseline stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.810>Building</phrase> 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>City</phrase> Models from Multiple <phrase_Q=0.819>Unregistered</phrase> Profile Maps.
The <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents an approach for <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>city</phrase> models for <phrase_Q=0.960>virtual environments</phrase> from multiple 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> sets acquired from different viewpoints by <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>striping</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.845>raw data</phrase> sets are represented as <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> valued <phrase_Q=0.833>parametric</phrase> surfaces called the 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> profile maps. The profile maps are registered to the same <phrase_Q=0.530>coordinate system</phrase> by an <phrase_Q=0.836>iterative</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.798>surface matching</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> developed previously. The <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> proceeds hierarchically from low to <phrase_Q=0.931>high resolution</phrase> and all the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> sets are matched simultaneously but an initial <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> is assumed to be known. After having segmented each <phrase_Q=0.835>map</phrase> by a <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> growing <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>, the maps are integrated into a <phrase_Q=1.000>piecewise</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.839>planar surface</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> by merging compatible segments in the overlapping areas. The <phrase_Q=1.000>borders</phrase> of the segments are also traced an the <phrase_Q=0.833>parametric</phrase> domains of the maps as a step for <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.571>wireframe model</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Test</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are shown in the case of a <phrase_Q=1.000>scale model</phrase> of an <phrase_Q=1.000>urban area</phrase> digitized in <phrase_Q=1.000>laboratory</phrase> conditions.
<phrase_Q=0.552>An Improved</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.829>Calibration</phrase> Technique for <phrase_Q=0.827>Coupled</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Single</phrase>-Row Telemeter and <phrase_Q=1.000>CCD Camera</phrase>.
Toward a successful 3D and <phrase_Q=0.800>textural</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>urban</phrase> scenes, the use of both <phrase_Q=0.821>single-row</phrase> based <phrase_Q=0.868>telemetric</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.820>photographic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> in a same framework has proved to be a powerful technique. A necessary condition to obtain good <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> is to accurately calibrate the <phrase_Q=0.868>telemetric</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.820>photographic</phrase> sensors together. We present a study of this <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> process and propose <phrase_Q=0.552>an improved</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.794>extrinsic calibration</phrase> technique. It is based on an existing technique which consists in scanning a <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> pattern in several poses, giving a set of <phrase_Q=0.919>relative position</phrase> and orientation constraints. The <phrase_Q=1.000>innovation</phrase> is the use of a more appropriate <phrase_Q=1.000>laser beam</phrase> distance between <phrase_Q=0.868>telemetric</phrase> points and the <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>target</phrase>. Moreover, we use <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> methods to manage <phrase_Q=1.000>outliers</phrase> at several steps of the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.804>Improved</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> on both theoretical and <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> are given.

<phrase_Q=0.688>Transform-Based</phrase> Methods for <phrase_Q=0.818>Indexing</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.809>Retrieval</phrase> of 3D Objects.
We compare two <phrase_Q=0.688>transform-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>indexing</phrase> methods for <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> of 3D objects. We apply 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Discrete Fourier Transform</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>DFT</phrase>) and 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Radial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.855>Cosine</phrase> Transform (RCT) to the voxelized <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> of 3D objects. <phrase_Q=0.958>Rotation invariant</phrase> features are derived from the coefficients of these transforms. Furthermore we compare two different <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase> representations, namely, <phrase_Q=1.000>binary</phrase> denoting object and background space, and <phrase_Q=0.803>continuous</phrase> after <phrase_Q=0.825>distance transformation</phrase>. In the <phrase_Q=1.000>binary</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase> representation the <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase> values are simply set to 1 on the surface of the object and 0 elsewhere. In the <phrase_Q=0.803>continuous</phrase>-valued representation the space is filled with a <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.904>distance transform</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.952>rotation invariance</phrase> properties of the <phrase_Q=1.000>DFT</phrase> and RCT schemes are analyzed. We have conducted <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> experiments on the <phrase_Q=1.000>Princeton</phrase> Shape Benchmark and investigated the <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> performance of the methods using several <phrase_Q=0.858>quality measures</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.805>Identifying</phrase> the Interface between Two <phrase_Q=1.000>Sand</phrase> Materials.
To study the behavior of <phrase_Q=1.000>water</phrase> flow at interfaces between different <phrase_Q=1.000>soil</phrase> materials we made <phrase_Q=1.000>computed tomography</phrase> scans of <phrase_Q=1.000>sand</phrase> samples using <phrase_Q=1.000>synchrotron light</phrase>. The samples were prepared with an interface between two <phrase_Q=1.000>sand</phrase> materials. The <phrase_Q=0.836>contact</phrase> points between grains at the interface between the <phrase_Q=0.889>sands</phrase> were identified using a combination of <phrase_Q=1.000>watershed</phrase> segmentation and a classifier that used the <phrase_Q=1.000>grain-size</phrase> and -location. The process from a <phrase_Q=0.827>bilevel</phrase> image to a classified image is described. In the classified image five classes are represented; two for the grains and three for the <phrase_Q=0.836>contact</phrase> points to represent <phrase_Q=0.557>intra- and inter</phrase>-class <phrase_Q=0.836>contact</phrase> points.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Silhouette</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Fusion</phrase> for 3D <phrase_Q=0.770>Object Modeling</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we present a new approach to <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> quality 3D <phrase_Q=0.741>object reconstruction</phrase>. Starting from a calibrated <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> images, the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is able to reconstruct both the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> and the texture. The core of the method is based on a <phrase_Q=0.875>deformable model</phrase>, which defines the framework where texture and <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> can be fused. This is achieved by defining two <phrase_Q=0.848>external forces</phrase> based on the images: a texture driven force and a <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase> driven force. The texture force is computed in two steps: a <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> correlation <phrase_Q=0.845>voting</phrase> approach and a <phrase_Q=1.000>gradient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>vector</phrase> flow <phrase_Q=1.000>diffusion</phrase>. Due to the <phrase_Q=0.931>high resolution</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.845>voting</phrase> approach, a <phrase_Q=0.622>multi-grid</phrase> version of the <phrase_Q=1.000>gradient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>vector</phrase> flow has been developed. Concerning the <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase> force, a new formulation of the <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase> constraint is derived. It provides a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> way to integrate the silhouettes in the <phrase_Q=1.000>evolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. As a consequence, we are able to recover the <phrase_Q=0.806>contour</phrase> generators of the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> at the end of the iteration process. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=0.705>texture map</phrase> is computed from the <phrase_Q=0.629>original images</phrase> for the reconstructed 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.814>Extracting</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.927>Surface Patches</phrase> from Complete <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Descriptions.
<phrase_Q=0.808>Constructing</phrase> a full <phrase_Q=1.000>CAD</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of a part requires <phrase_Q=0.689>feature descriptions</phrase> from all sides; in this case we consider <phrase_Q=0.927>surface patches</phrase> as the <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> primitives. Most <phrase_Q=0.705>previous research</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.881>surface patch</phrase> extraction has concentrated on <phrase_Q=0.814>extracting</phrase> patches from a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> view. This leads to several problems with <phrase_Q=0.827>aligning</phrase> and combining <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> patch fragments in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to produce complete part models. We have avoided these problems by <phrase_Q=0.800>adapting</phrase> our <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> view, <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> segmentation program to extract patches, and thus models, directly from fully merged <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> datasets.

<phrase_Q=0.815>Coordination</phrase> of Appearance and <phrase_Q=0.586>Motion Data</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.750>Virtual View Generation</phrase> of Traditional Dances.
A novel method is proposed for <phrase_Q=0.750>virtual view generation</phrase> of traditional dances. In the proposed framework, a traditional <phrase_Q=1.000>dance</phrase> is captured separately for appearance <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> and motion <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase>. By <phrase_Q=0.822>coordinating</phrase> the appearance and <phrase_Q=0.586>motion data</phrase>, we can easily control <phrase_Q=0.805>virtual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> motion within a <phrase_Q=1.000>dancer</phrase>-centered <phrase_Q=0.530>coordinate system</phrase>. For this purpose, a <phrase_Q=0.815>coordination</phrase> problem should be solved between the appearance and <phrase_Q=0.586>motion data</phrase>, since they are captured separately and the <phrase_Q=1.000>dancer</phrase> moves freely in the <phrase_Q=0.826>room</phrase>. The present <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> shows a <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to solve it. A set of <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> are also provided for appearance and motion <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.750>virtual view generation</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.524>archived data</phrase>. In the appearance <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase>, a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> shape is recovered in each time from a set of <phrase_Q=0.614>input images</phrase> after <phrase_Q=0.820>suppressing</phrase> their backgrounds. By combining the recovered 3D shape and a set of images for each time, we can <phrase_Q=1.000>compose</phrase> archived <phrase_Q=1.000>dance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. In the motion <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>stereoscopic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> is accomplished for <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> markers placed on the <phrase_Q=1.000>dancer</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=0.750>virtual view generation</phrase> is formalized as a <phrase_Q=0.782>color blending</phrase> among <phrase_Q=0.927>multiple views</phrase>, and a novel and <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is proposed for the composition of a natural <phrase_Q=0.805>virtual</phrase> view from a set of images. In the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase>, weightings of the <phrase_Q=1.000>linear combination</phrase> are calculated from both an assumed viewpoint and a <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase>.

This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents techniques for the merging of 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Data</phrase> coming from different sensors, such as ground and <phrase_Q=0.830>aerial</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> scans. The reconstructed <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is based on a <phrase_Q=0.835>weighted</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> of all available <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> based on <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.525>specific parameters</phrase> such as <phrase_Q=0.755>noise level</phrase>, accuracy, <phrase_Q=1.000>inclination</phrase> and reflectivity of the <phrase_Q=1.000>target</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> distribution of points. The <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> is robustly reconstructed with a <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> approach. Once registered and weighed, all <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.803>re</phrase>-sampled in a <phrase_Q=0.904>multi-resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.783>distance field</phrase> usingout-of-core techniques. The final <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> is extracted by <phrase_Q=0.847>contouring</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>iso</phrase>-surface with a <phrase_Q=0.888>feature preserving</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.906>dual contouring</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> shows <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> of the above technique applied to <phrase_Q=1.000>Verona</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>Italy</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.849>city centre</phrase>.
Further <phrase_Q=0.802>Improving</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>Geometric</phrase> Fitting.
We give a <phrase_Q=0.869>formal definition</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> fitting in a way that suits <phrase_Q=0.688>computer vision</phrase> applications. We point out that the performance of <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> fitting should be evaluated in the limit of small noise rather than in the limit of a <phrase_Q=0.522>large number</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> as recommended in the <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase>. Taking the KCR <phrase_Q=1.000>lower</phrase> bound as an optimality requirement and <phrase_Q=0.801>focusing</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=0.844>linearized</phrase> constraint case, we compare the accuracy of Kanataniýs <phrase_Q=1.000>renormalization</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>maximum likelihood</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.858>ML</phrase>) approaches including the FNS of Chojnacki <phrase_Q=0.549>et al</phrase>. and the HEIV of Leedan and Meer. Our <phrase_Q=0.692>analysis reveals</phrase> the existence of a method <phrase_Q=1.000>superior</phrase> to all these.

<phrase_Q=0.806>Scale Selection</phrase> for Classification of <phrase_Q=0.802>Point-Sampled</phrase> 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> Surfaces.
<phrase_Q=0.668>Three-dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.765>ladar data</phrase> are commonly used to perform <phrase_Q=0.944>scene understanding</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.783>outdoor mobile robots</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.808>specifically</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.875>natural terrain</phrase>. One effective method is to classify points using features based on local <phrase_Q=1.000>point cloud</phrase> distribution into surfaces, <phrase_Q=0.707>linear structures</phrase> or clutter volumes. But the <phrase_Q=0.881>local features</phrase> are computed using 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> points within a support-volume. Local and <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> point <phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase> variations and the presence of <phrase_Q=0.605>multiple manifolds</phrase> make the problem of selecting the size of this support volume, or scale, challenging. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we adopt an approach inspired by <phrase_Q=0.938>recent developments</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>computational geometry</phrase> [5] and investigate the problem of <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>-driven <phrase_Q=0.806>scale selection</phrase> to improve <phrase_Q=1.000>point cloud</phrase> classification. The approach is validated with <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> using <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from different sensors in various environments classified into different <phrase_Q=0.843>terrain</phrase> types (<phrase_Q=1.000>vegetation</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.618>solid surface</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.574>linear structure</phrase>)¹.

Toward a <phrase_Q=0.684>Near Optimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.888>Quad/Triangle Subdivision</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.931>Surface Fitting</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we present a new framework for <phrase_Q=0.922>subdivision surface</phrase> fitting of <phrase_Q=0.696>arbitrary surfaces</phrase> (not closed objects) represented by <phrase_Q=0.969>polygonal meshes</phrase>. Our approach is particularly suited for output surfaces from a mechanical or <phrase_Q=1.000>CAD</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.894>object segmentation</phrase> for a <phrase_Q=1.000>piecewise</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.922>subdivision surface</phrase> approximation. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> produces a <phrase_Q=0.821>mixed</phrase> quadrangle-<phrase_Q=1.000>triangle</phrase> control <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.684>near optimal</phrase> in terms of face and vertex numbers while remaining <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> of the connectivity of the input <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> step approximates the boundaries with <phrase_Q=0.794>subdivision curves</phrase> and creates an initial <phrase_Q=0.922>subdivision surface</phrase> by optimally <phrase_Q=0.812>linking</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.738>boundary control</phrase> points with respect to the lines of <phrase_Q=1.000>curvature</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>target</phrase> surface. Then, a <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> step optimizes the initial control <phrase_Q=1.000>polyhedron</phrase> by iteratively moving <phrase_Q=0.793>control points</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.827>enriching</phrase> regions according to the <phrase_Q=0.716>error distribution</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.558>Experiments conducted</phrase> on several surfaces and on a whole segmented mechanical object, have <phrase_Q=1.000>proven</phrase> the coherency and theefficiency of our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>, compared with <phrase_Q=0.640>existing methods</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.552>An Efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.883>Scattered Data</phrase> Approximation Using <phrase_Q=0.844>Multilevel</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>B</phrase>-Splines Based on <phrase_Q=0.840>Quasi</phrase>-Interpolants.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>approximation algorithm</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.844>multilevel</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>B</phrase>-splines based on <phrase_Q=0.840>quasi</phrase>-interpolants. <phrase_Q=0.844>Multilevel</phrase> technique uses a <phrase_Q=0.640>coarse to fine</phrase> hierarchy to generate a <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.673>bicubic B-spline</phrase> functions whose <phrase_Q=0.840>sum</phrase> approaches the desired <phrase_Q=1.000>interpolation</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase>. To compute a set of <phrase_Q=0.793>control points</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.840>quasi</phrase>-interpolants gives a procedure for <phrase_Q=0.819>deriving</phrase> local <phrase_Q=0.895>spline approximation</phrase> methods where a <phrase_Q=1.000>B-spline</phrase> coefficient only depends on <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> points taken from the <phrase_Q=1.000>neighborhood</phrase> of the support corresponding the <phrase_Q=1.000>B-spline</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show that the <phrase_Q=0.684>smooth surface reconstruction</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> accuracy can be obtained from a selected set of scattered or <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>irregular</phrase> samples.

<phrase_Q=0.800>Evaluating</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.832>Collinearity</phrase> Constraint for <phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Image Registration</phrase>.
While most of the existing <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>image registration</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> either have to extract and match <phrase_Q=0.829>structural</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase>) features or have to estimate the <phrase_Q=0.724>motion parameters</phrase> of interest from <phrase_Q=1.000>outliers</phrase> corrupted <phrase_Q=0.944>point correspondence</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.824>elimination</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.832>false matches</phrase> in the process of <phrase_Q=1.000>image registration</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> error and the <phrase_Q=0.832>collinearity</phrase> error derived directly from the traditional <phrase_Q=0.925>closest point</phrase> criterion are also capable of doing the same job. The purpose of this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> is to investigate which definition of <phrase_Q=0.832>collinearity</phrase> is more accurate and stable in <phrase_Q=0.630>eliminating false</phrase> matches inevitably introduced by the <phrase_Q=0.925>closest point</phrase> criterion. The experiments based on <phrase_Q=0.673>real images</phrase> show the <phrase_Q=0.526>advantages and disadvantages</phrase> of different definitions of <phrase_Q=0.832>collinearity</phrase>.

At runtime the meshes are dynamically refined to <phrase_Q=0.810>higher resolution</phrase> in areas that are most likely to <phrase_Q=0.852>collide</phrase> with other objects. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.641>successfully demonstrated</phrase> in an <phrase_Q=0.822>interactive</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>haptic</phrase> environment. <phrase_Q=0.531>An Adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.693>Dandelion Model</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.816>Reconstructing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.832>Spherical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.843>Terrain</phrase>-Like <phrase_Q=0.832>Visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Hull</phrase> Surfaces.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we present <phrase_Q=0.531>an adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.693>Dandelion Model</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.816>reconstructing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.832>spherical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.843>terrain</phrase>-like <phrase_Q=0.832>Visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Hull</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.858>VH</phrase>) surfaces. The <phrase_Q=0.693>Dandelion Model</phrase> represents a solid by a <phrase_Q=0.826>pencil</phrase> of organized <phrase_Q=0.950>line segments</phrase> emitted from a common point. The directions and the <phrase_Q=1.000>topology</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.950>line segments</phrase> are derived from the <phrase_Q=1.000>triangle</phrase> facets of a <phrase_Q=1.000>geodesic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sphere</phrase>, which are recursively subdivided until the desired precision is achieved. The initial lines are <phrase_Q=0.834>cut</phrase> by silhouettes in 2D and then lifted back to 3D to determine the <phrase_Q=0.657>ending points</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.950>line segments</phrase> defining <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> points on the <phrase_Q=0.832>spherical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.843>terrain</phrase>-like <phrase_Q=0.858>VH</phrase> surface. A <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> can be easily constructed from the <phrase_Q=0.693>Dandelion Model</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> has the advantages of controllable precision, <phrase_Q=0.665>adaptive resolution</phrase>, simplicity and speediness. We validate our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> by theories and experiments.
A <phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> and Accurate 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Rangefinder</phrase> using the Biris <phrase_Q=1.000>Technology</phrase>: The TRID <phrase_Q=1.000>Sensor</phrase>.

The <phrase_Q=0.528>texture acquisition</phrase> is treated as a <phrase_Q=0.830>labeling problem</phrase> in an <phrase_Q=0.967>energy minimization</phrase> framework, which enables us to get realistic textures with a simple operation. A method for the <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of 3D objects from <phrase_Q=0.630>multiple camera views</phrase> for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>multimedia</phrase> applications is presented. Conventional 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> techniques use equipment that restrict the flexibility of the user. In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to increase this flexibility, the presented method is characterized by a simple measurement environment, that consists of a new <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> pattern placed below the object allowing object and <phrase_Q=0.509>pattern acquisition</phrase> simultaneously. This ensures, that each view can be calibrated individually. From these obtained <phrase_Q=0.902>calibrated camera</phrase> views, a textured 3D <phrase_Q=0.571>wireframe model</phrase> is estimated using a <phrase_Q=0.775>shape-from-silhouette</phrase> approach and <phrase_Q=1.000>texture mapping</phrase> of the original <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> views. Experiments with this system have confirmed a significant gain of flexibility for the user and a drastic reduction of costs for <phrase_Q=0.511>technical equipment</phrase> while ensuring comparable <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> quality as conventional <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> techniques at the same time.
