The <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> is part of <phrase_Q=0.510>an incremental</phrase> approach that <phrase_Q=0.786>progressively refines</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.818>identification</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> points. The <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> phase of <phrase_Q=0.818>identification</phrase> is to <phrase_Q=1.000>orient</phrase> and segment the <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> body <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> points. <phrase_Q=1.000>Algorithms</phrase> for these tasks are presented, with a description of their use. One of the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase>, a discrete point <phrase_Q=0.876>cusp</phrase> detector is believed to be unique. The <phrase_Q=1.000>software</phrase> has been tested on twenty different body <phrase_Q=0.622>scan data</phrase> sets and shown to be <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.752>Simultaneous Alignment</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.647>Multiple Range Images</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.801>Index</phrase> Images.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes a <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> and easy-to-use <phrase_Q=0.752>simultaneous alignment</phrase> method of <phrase_Q=0.647>multiple range images</phrase>. The most <phrase_Q=0.542>time consuming</phrase> part of <phrase_Q=0.814>alignment</phrase> process is searching corresponding points. Although "<phrase_Q=0.829>Inverse</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase>" method quickly searches corresponding points in complexity <phrase_Q=0.839>O</phrase>(n), where n is the number of vertices, the method requires some <phrase_Q=0.529>look-up</phrase> tables or precise sensorýs parameters. Then, we propose an easy-to-use method that uses "<phrase_Q=0.801>Index</phrase> Image": "<phrase_Q=0.801>Index</phrase> image" can be rapidly created using <phrase_Q=0.945>graphics hardware</phrase> without precise sensorýs parameters. For <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> computation of <phrase_Q=0.727>rigid transformation</phrase> matrices of a <phrase_Q=0.522>large number</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images, we utilized <phrase_Q=0.844>linearized</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>error function</phrase> and applied <phrase_Q=0.953>incomplete Cholesky</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.970>conjugate gradient</phrase> (ICCG) method for <phrase_Q=0.705>solving linear equations</phrase>. Some <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> that aligned a <phrase_Q=0.522>large number</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images measured with <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> sensors show the effectiveness of our method.
<phrase_Q=0.831>Parallel</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>Alignment</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.522>Large Number</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images.
<phrase_Q=0.806>Contour</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.617>Point Tracking</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.819>Enforcement</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.849>Rigidity</phrase> Constraints.
The <phrase_Q=1.000>aperture</phrase> problem is one of the omnipresent issues in <phrase_Q=0.688>computer vision</phrase>. Its local character constrains <phrase_Q=0.879>point matching</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.725>textured areas</phrase>, so that points ingradient- oriented regions (such as <phrase_Q=0.962>straight lines</phrase>) can not be reliably matched. We propose a new method to overcome this problem by devising a <phrase_Q=0.512>global matching</phrase> strategy under the <phrase_Q=0.825>factorization</phrase> framework. We solve the n-<phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> problem under this context by assuming the <phrase_Q=0.849>rigidity</phrase> of the scene. To this end, a <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> contraint is used that selects the matching <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> resulting in a <phrase_Q=0.801>rank</phrase>-4 <phrase_Q=0.541>observation matrix</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.801>rank</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.541>observation matrix</phrase> is a <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> of the matching solutions associated to each image and as such a simulteaneous <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> for all frames has to be found. An <phrase_Q=0.730>optimization procedure</phrase> is used in this text in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to find the <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.791>Dense Disparity Estimation</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.965>Gabor Filters</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.805>Image Derivatives</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.845>Incremental</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.917>Catmull-Clark Subdivision</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, a new <phrase_Q=0.819>adaptive</phrase> method for <phrase_Q=0.917>Catmull-Clark subdivision</phrase> is introduced. <phrase_Q=0.819>Adaptive</phrase> subdivision refines <phrase_Q=0.574>specific areas</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> according to user or application needs. Naive <phrase_Q=0.800>adaptive subdivision</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> change the connectivity of the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase>, causing <phrase_Q=0.826>geometrical</phrase> inconsistencies that alter the <phrase_Q=0.572>limit surface</phrase>. Our method expands the specified <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> such that when it is adaptively subdivided, it produces a <phrase_Q=0.856>smooth surface</phrase> whose selected <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase> is identical to when the entire <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> is refined. This technique also produces a surface with an increasing <phrase_Q=0.519>level of detail</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.640>coarse to fine</phrase> areas of the surface. We compare our <phrase_Q=0.819>adaptive</phrase> subdivision with other schemes and present some example applications.
A <phrase_Q=0.847>Contour-Based</phrase> Approach to 3D Text Labeling on <phrase_Q=0.965>Triangulated Surfaces</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a simple and <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> method of forming a 3D text <phrase_Q=1.000>label</phrase> on a 3D <phrase_Q=0.902>triangulated surface</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>label</phrase> is formed by projecting the 2D contours that define the text <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase> onto the <phrase_Q=0.902>triangulated surface</phrase>, forming 3D <phrase_Q=0.806>contour</phrase> paths. Surface <phrase_Q=1.000>polygons</phrase> upon which the 3D <phrase_Q=0.806>contour</phrase> paths <phrase_Q=0.850>lie</phrase> are retriangulated using a novel approach that forms a <phrase_Q=0.861>polyline</phrase> defining the <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> outside the <phrase_Q=0.806>contour</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> produces labeled 3D surfaces that conform to the specifications of the <phrase_Q=1.000>STL</phrase> format, making them suitable for fabrication by a <phrase_Q=1.000>rapid prototyping</phrase> machine. We demonstrate the effectiveness of the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> in forming flat and extruded <phrase_Q=1.000>labels</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.606>non-trivial</phrase> surfaces.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Nefertiti</phrase>: A Query by Content <phrase_Q=1.000>Software</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.668>Three-Dimensional</phrase> Models <phrase_Q=1.000>Databases</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Management</phrase>.

A set of <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> is introduced. These <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.876>content-based</phrase>, meaning that the input is not made out of keywords but of <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> models. <phrase_Q=1.000>Tensor</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>inertia</phrase>, distribution of normals, distribution of <phrase_Q=0.886>cords</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.842>multiresolution</phrase> analysis are used to describe each <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> can be searched by scale, shape or <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> or any combination of these parameters. A <phrase_Q=0.926>user friendly</phrase> interface makes the <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> operation simple and intuitive and allows to edit <phrase_Q=0.859>reference models</phrase> according to the specifications of the user. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> using a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> of more than 400 <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images and 1000 <phrase_Q=1.000>VRML</phrase> models are presented.

<phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>Modelling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.966>Camera Calibration</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.966>Camera calibration</phrase> methods, whether <phrase_Q=0.826>implicit</phrase> or explicit, are a critical part of most 3D <phrase_Q=0.813>vision</phrase> systems. These methods involve estimation of a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> that <phrase_Q=1.000>produced</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> input, and <phrase_Q=0.823>subsequently</phrase> to infer the 3D structure that gave <phrase_Q=0.832>rise</phrase> to the input. However, in these systems the error in <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> is typically unknown, or if known, the effect of <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> error on <phrase_Q=0.503>subsequent processing</phrase> (e.g. 3d <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase>) is not accounted for. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose a <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.966>camera calibration</phrase> method that explicitly computes <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> error, and we show how <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> of this error can be used to improve the accuracy of <phrase_Q=0.503>subsequent processing</phrase>. What distinguishes the work is the explicit computation of a <phrase_Q=0.837>posterior distribution</phrase> on unknown <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> parameters, rather than just a best estimate. <phrase_Q=0.840>Marginalizing</phrase> (averaging) subsequent estimates by this posterior is shown to reduce <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> error over <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> approaches that rely on a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> best estimate. The method is made <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> techniques, that require only the evaluation of the <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>error function</phrase> and the specification of <phrase_Q=0.806>priors</phrase>. Samples with their corresponding <phrase_Q=1.000>probability</phrase> weights can be used to produce better estimates of the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> parameters. Moreover, these samples can be directly used to improve estimates that rely on <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>, like 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase>. We evaluate our method using <phrase_Q=0.644>simulated data</phrase> for a <phrase_Q=0.625>structure from motion</phrase> problem, in which the same <phrase_Q=0.810>point matches</phrase> are used to calibrate the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>, estimate the motion, and reconstruct the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show <phrase_Q=0.804>improved</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> over <phrase_Q=0.542>non-linear</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.966>Camera calibration</phrase> methods like the <phrase_Q=1.000>Maximum Likelihood</phrase> estimate. Additionally, this approach scales much better in the face of increasingly <phrase_Q=0.806>noisy</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.810>point matches</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.840>Affine</phrase> Transformations of 3D Objects Represented with <phrase_Q=1.000>Neural Networks</phrase>.

A <phrase_Q=0.818>Registration</phrase> Aid.
Although the <phrase_Q=0.808>iterative closest point algorithm</phrase> is very effective in registering <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, the quality of <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> depends on the <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.601>sampled surfaces</phrase>. This work presents a <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> aid which can <phrase_Q=0.773>greatly reduce</phrase> the possibility of catastrophic <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> failure, increase the quality of <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> and register <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> which does not overlap. By placing the aid into the scene along with the object(<phrase_Q=0.812>s</phrase>) of interest, <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images taken from any <phrase_Q=0.913>vantage point</phrase> within the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> scanner's workspace can be registered onto a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of the aid and thus into a common <phrase_Q=1.000>reference frame</phrase>. By considering the causes of <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> failure, the surface of the aid is designed so that any <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> image taken of it from any point in the scanner's workspace will properly register with a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of the aid. The reliability of the aid is demonstrated with a <phrase_Q=1.000>Monte Carlo</phrase> experiment and its utility is demonstrated with examples from an <phrase_Q=0.824>automated</phrase> surface <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> system.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Free</phrase>-Form <phrase_Q=0.954>Surface Reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.671>Multiple Images</phrase> .

A <phrase_Q=0.834>MRF</phrase> Formulation for <phrase_Q=0.885>Coded Structured Light</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Multimedia</phrase> projectors and cameras make possible the use of <phrase_Q=0.944>structured light</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.560>solve problems</phrase> such as 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.914>disparity map</phrase> computation and <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.895>projector calibration</phrase>. Each <phrase_Q=0.713>projector displays</phrase> patterns over a scene viewed by a <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>, thereby allowing <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> computation of <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>-projector <phrase_Q=1.000>pixel</phrase> correspondences. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> introduces a new <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to establish this <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.608>difficult cases</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.933>image acquisition</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=0.699>probabilistic model</phrase> formulated as a <phrase_Q=1.000>Markov Random Field</phrase> uses the <phrase_Q=0.841>stripe</phrase> images to find the most likely correspondences in the presence of noise. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.797>specially tailored</phrase> to handle the unfavorable <phrase_Q=0.815>projector-camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>pixel</phrase> ratios that occur in multiple-projector <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> setups. For the case where more than one <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> is used, we propose a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> approach to establish <phrase_Q=0.506>correspondences between</phrase> the cameras and compute an accurate <phrase_Q=0.914>disparity map</phrase>. To <phrase_Q=0.704>conduct experiments</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=0.942>ground truth</phrase> was <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> reconstructed from a <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> quality <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase>. Various degradations were applied to the pattern images which were then solved using our method. The <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> were compared to the <phrase_Q=0.942>ground truth</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.837>error analysis</phrase> and showed very good performances, even near <phrase_Q=0.878>depth discontinuities</phrase>.

In the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>, at <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.749>shape model</phrase> is obtained by <phrase_Q=0.775>shape-from-silhouette</phrase> method almost automatically. <phrase_Q=0.822>Next</phrase>, concavities and complex parts on the <phrase_Q=0.674>object surface</phrase> are obtained by <phrase_Q=0.889>light-sectioning</phrase> method with manual scanning. For <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.889>light-sectioning</phrase> method to <phrase_Q=0.874>volume data</phrase>, we propose <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.889>light-sectioning</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> Meshes from Multiple <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Maps.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a method for <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> the surface of an object from a <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> maps. Our method is based on a <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> approach that produces a <phrase_Q=0.829>compact</phrase> surface without boundary. It provides robustness through the use of <phrase_Q=0.870>interval analysis</phrase> techniques and <phrase_Q=0.736>computational efficiency</phrase> through <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> processing using octrees.
<phrase_Q=0.801>Determining</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.795>Characteristic Views</phrase> of a 3D Object by <phrase_Q=0.937>Visual Hulls</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Hausdorff</phrase> Distance.
<phrase_Q=0.813>Nowadays</phrase>, with the exponential growing of 3D <phrase_Q=0.837>object representations</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>private</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase> or on the <phrase_Q=0.835>web</phrase>, it is all the more required to match these objects from some views. To improve the <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> of their matching, we work on the <phrase_Q=0.795>characteristic views</phrase> of an object. The aim of this study is to find how many <phrase_Q=0.795>characteristic views</phrase> are required and what <phrase_Q=0.870>relative positions</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase>. This is the reason why the <phrase_Q=0.937>visual hulls</phrase> are used. From some 2D masks, the nearest possible 3D <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> from the original object is computed. <phrase_Q=1.000>OpenGL</phrase> views are used to build the <phrase_Q=0.937>visual hulls</phrase> of 3D models from a given collection and then the distance between the <phrase_Q=0.937>visual hulls</phrase> and the models are measured thanks to the <phrase_Q=1.000>Hausdorff</phrase> distance. Then the best view parameters are deduced to reduce the distance. These shots show that three <phrase_Q=0.834>orthogonal</phrase> views give <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> very close to the ones given by twelve views on a isocahedron. Some other <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> on the view <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=0.534>field of view</phrase> are discussed.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Projective</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.798>Surface Matching</phrase> of Colored 3D Scans.
We present a new method for registering multiple 3D scans of a colored object. Each <phrase_Q=0.843>scan</phrase> is regarded as a <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> image of the object recorded by a <phrase_Q=1.000>pinhole camera</phrase>. Consider a pair of cameras that see <phrase_Q=0.686>overlapping parts</phrase> of the objects. For correct <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> poses, the actual image of the <phrase_Q=0.675>overlap area</phrase> in one <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> matches the rendition of the <phrase_Q=0.675>overlap area</phrase> as seen by the other <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>. We define a <phrase_Q=0.845>mismatch</phrase> score <phrase_Q=0.823>summarizing</phrase> discrepancies in <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase> between pairs of images, and we present an <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to efficiently minimize this <phrase_Q=0.845>mismatch</phrase> score over <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> poses.

<phrase_Q=0.803>Relighting</phrase> Acquired Models of <phrase_Q=0.840>Outdoor</phrase> Scenes.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we introduce a <phrase_Q=0.803>relighting</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for diffuse <phrase_Q=0.840>outdoor</phrase> scenes that enables us to create <phrase_Q=0.827>geometrically correct</phrase> and illumination consistent models from a series of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> scans and a set of overlapping photographs that have been taken under different <phrase_Q=0.862>illumination conditions</phrase>. To perform the <phrase_Q=0.803>relighting</phrase> we compute a set of mappings from the <phrase_Q=0.561>overlap region</phrase> of two images. We call these mappings <phrase_Q=1.000>Irradiance</phrase> Ratio Maps (IRMs). Our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> handles <phrase_Q=0.856>cast</phrase> shadows, being able to relight <phrase_Q=0.824>shadowed</phrase> regions into non-<phrase_Q=0.824>shadowed</phrase> regions <phrase_Q=0.526>and vice-versa</phrase>. We solve these cases by <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> four different IRMs, to handle all four combinations of <phrase_Q=0.824>shadowed</phrase> vs. non-<phrase_Q=0.824>shadowed</phrase> surfaces. To relight the <phrase_Q=0.594>non-overlapping</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> of an image, we look into the appropriate <phrase_Q=0.854>IRM</phrase> which we <phrase_Q=0.801>index</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase>, and apply its value to the corresponding <phrase_Q=1.000>pixels</phrase>. The result is an illumination consistent set of images.

3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Imagery: <phrase_Q=0.510>An Incremental</phrase> Method with a <phrase_Q=0.812>Planning</phrase> Component.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we present a method for <phrase_Q=0.775>automatically constructing</phrase> a <phrase_Q=1.000>CAD</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of an unknown object from <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images. The method is <phrase_Q=0.510>an incremental</phrase> one that interleaves a sensing operation that acquires and merges <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> into the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> with a <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase> phase to determine the <phrase_Q=0.822>next</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> position or "view". This is accomplished by integrating a system for 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> with a <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>planner</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> system provides facilities for <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.933>image acquisition</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.706>solid model</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> merging: both <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> surface and solid representations are used to build a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from each view, which is then merged with the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> built from previous sensing operations. The <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase> system utilizes the resulting incomplete <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> to plan the <phrase_Q=0.822>next</phrase> sensing operation by finding a <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> viewpoint that will improve the fidelity of the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are presented for a complex part that includes <phrase_Q=0.823>polygonal</phrase> faces, <phrase_Q=0.818>curved</phrase> surfaces, and large <phrase_Q=0.810>self</phrase>-occlusions.
<phrase_Q=0.805>Virtual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Clay</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> System Using <phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-Viewpoint Images.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> proposes a "non-<phrase_Q=0.836>contact</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.805>virtual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>clay</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> system." We developed a <phrase_Q=1.000>prototype</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> system that allows users to shape "<phrase_Q=0.805>virtual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>clay</phrase>" with their <phrase_Q=0.938>hand movements</phrase>. In our <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase>, the usersý <phrase_Q=0.938>hand movements</phrase> are observed with <phrase_Q=0.882>multiple cameras</phrase> to estimate their positions. The <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> hand surface and <phrase_Q=0.805>virtual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>clay</phrase> are modeled by using <phrase_Q=0.922>subdivision surface</phrase>. Using these estimated <phrase_Q=0.555>hand positions</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.805>virtual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>clay</phrase> is shaped based on a <phrase_Q=0.811>direct</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.947>free-form deformation</phrase> technique. To improve <phrase_Q=0.701>processing speed</phrase>, we implemented the proposed system on a <phrase_Q=1.000>PC</phrase> cluster. This system proves the feasibility of an intuitive <phrase_Q=0.805>virtual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>clay</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> system.

3D Models from <phrase_Q=0.816>Extended</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.852>Uncalibrated Video Sequences</phrase>: Addressing <phrase_Q=1.000>Key-Frame</phrase> Selection and <phrase_Q=1.000>Projective</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>Drift</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>; we present an approach that is able to reconstruct 3D models from <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> sequences captured with an <phrase_Q=0.853>uncalibrated</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>hand-held camera</phrase>. We focus on two <phrase_Q=0.520>specific issues</phrase>: (1) <phrase_Q=1.000>key-frame</phrase> selection, and ( 2 ) <phrase_Q=1.000>projective</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>drift</phrase>. Given a <phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> it is often not <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> to work with all videoframes. In addition, to allow for effective <phrase_Q=0.960>outlier rejection</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.957>motion estimation</phrase> it is necessary to have a sufficient baseline between frames. For this purpose, we propose a <phrase_Q=0.873>key-frame selection</phrase> procedure based on a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model selection</phrase> criterion. Our approach guarantees that the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> motion can be estimated reliably by <phrase_Q=0.803>analyzing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.883>feature correspondences</phrase> between three consecutive views. Another problem for <phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.852>uncalibrated video sequences</phrase> is <phrase_Q=1.000>projective</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>drift</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.879>Error accumulation</phrase> leads to a non-<phrase_Q=1.000>projective</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>distortion</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. This causes the <phrase_Q=1.000>projective</phrase> basis at the beginning and the end of the <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> to become inconsistent and leads to the failure of <phrase_Q=0.681>self-calibration</phrase>. We propose a <phrase_Q=0.681>self-calibration</phrase> approach that is insensitive to this <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>projective</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>drift</phrase>. Afterself-<phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> triplets of <phrase_Q=0.875>key-frames</phrase> are aligned using <phrase_Q=0.813>absolute orientation</phrase> and hierarchically merged into a complete <phrase_Q=0.782>metric reconstruction</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.822>Next</phrase>, we compute a detailed 3D <phrase_Q=0.623>surface model</phrase> using <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> matching. The 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is textured using some of the frames.
<phrase_Q=0.811>Correction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.769>Color Information</phrase> of a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> Using a <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.693>Intensity Image</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.693>intensity image</phrase>, which is also called a <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase> image, refers to the <phrase_Q=0.693>intensity image</phrase> that is acquired simultaneously with the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> image captured using an <phrase_Q=0.823>active</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> proposes a method that uses this image to correct the <phrase_Q=0.769>color information</phrase> of a textured 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.769>color information</phrase> is usually obtained by <phrase_Q=1.000>texture mapping</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.945>color images</phrase> acquired by a <phrase_Q=1.000>digital camera</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.876>lighting condition</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> images are usually not controlled, thus the <phrase_Q=0.769>color information</phrase> is not precise. On the other hand, the <phrase_Q=0.876>lighting condition</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.693>intensity image</phrase> is controlled since it is obtained from a controlled and known lighting as required for the purpose of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> measurement. The <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes the method for combining the two sources of <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>; experiments show the effectiveness of the <phrase_Q=0.811>correction</phrase> method.

<phrase_Q=0.898>Shape Reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Human</phrase> Foot from <phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>Camera</phrase> Images Based on <phrase_Q=1.000>PCA</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Human</phrase> Shape <phrase_Q=1.000>Database</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.815>Recently</phrase>, researches and developments for <phrase_Q=0.802>measuring</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> body are taking much attention. Our aim is to capture accurate shape of <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> foot, using 2D <phrase_Q=0.736>images acquired</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.882>multiple cameras</phrase>, which can capture <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> behavior of the object. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, 3D <phrase_Q=0.932>active shape models</phrase> is used for accurate <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.867>surface shape</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> foot. We apply <phrase_Q=1.000>Principal Component Analysis</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>PCA</phrase>) of <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> shape <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>, so that we can represent humanýs <phrase_Q=0.828>foot shape</phrase> by approximately 12 <phrase_Q=0.932>principal component</phrase> shapes. Because of the reduction of dimensions for representing the <phrase_Q=0.832>object shape</phrase>, we can efficiently recover the <phrase_Q=0.832>object shape</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.868>multi-camera</phrase> images, even though the <phrase_Q=0.832>object shape</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.976>partially occluded</phrase> in some of input views. To demonstrate the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase>, two kinds of experiments are presented: <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> accuracy <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> foot in a <phrase_Q=1.000>virtual reality</phrase> environment with <phrase_Q=0.861>CG</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> images and in <phrase_Q=0.885>real world</phrase> with eight <phrase_Q=1.000>CCD</phrase> cameras. In those experiments, the recovered shape error with our method is around 2mm, while the error is around 4mm with <phrase_Q=0.848>volume intersection</phrase> method.
Registering Two <phrase_Q=0.778>Overlapping Range Images</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.818>Registration</phrase> of 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.823>Partial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.729>Surface Models</phrase> using <phrase_Q=1.000>Luminance</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.839>Depth Information</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.725>Textured surface</phrase> models of <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> objects are <phrase_Q=0.734>gaining importance</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.682>computer graphics</phrase> applications. These models often have to be merged from several overlapping <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> models which have to be registered (i.e. the relative transformation between the <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> models has to be determined) prior to the <phrase_Q=0.572>merging process</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> a method is presented that makes use of both <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=0.839>depth information</phrase> (e.g. from <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase>) and the <phrase_Q=1.000>luminance</phrase> image. The <phrase_Q=1.000>luminance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> is exploited to determine corresponding <phrase_Q=0.963>point sets</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> surfaces using an <phrase_Q=1.000>optical flow</phrase> approach. <phrase_Q=1.000>Quaternions</phrase> are then employed to determine the transformation between the <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> models which minimizes the <phrase_Q=0.840>sum</phrase> of the 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>Euclidian</phrase> distances between the corresponding <phrase_Q=0.963>point sets</phrase>. In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to find corresponding points on the <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> surfaces <phrase_Q=1.000>luminance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.844>linearized</phrase>. The procedure is <phrase_Q=0.846>iterated</phrase> until convergence is reached. In contrast to only using <phrase_Q=0.839>depth information</phrase>, employing <phrase_Q=1.000>luminance</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.579>speeds up</phrase> convergence and reduces remaining <phrase_Q=0.647>degrees of freedom</phrase> (e.g. when registering <phrase_Q=1.000>sphere</phrase>-like shapes).

<phrase_Q=0.662>Real-Time</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.851>Image Based</phrase> Rendering from <phrase_Q=0.894>Uncalibrated Images</phrase>.
We present a novel <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.851>image-based</phrase> rendering system for <phrase_Q=0.793>generating realistic</phrase> novel views of <phrase_Q=0.908>complex scenes</phrase> from a set of <phrase_Q=0.894>uncalibrated images</phrase>. A combination ofstructure-and-motion and <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> techniques is used to obtain <phrase_Q=0.847>calibrated cameras</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.834>dense depth maps</phrase> for all recorded images. These <phrase_Q=0.926>depth maps</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.533>converted into</phrase> restrictive <phrase_Q=0.866>quadtrees</phrase>, which allow for <phrase_Q=0.819>adaptive</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.921>view-dependent</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.860>tessellations</phrase> while storing per-vertex quality. When rendering a novel view, a <phrase_Q=1.000>subset</phrase> of suitable cameras is selected based upon a <phrase_Q=0.843>ranking</phrase> criterion. In the <phrase_Q=1.000>spirit</phrase> of the unstructured lumigraph rendering approach a <phrase_Q=0.805>blending</phrase> field is evaluated, although the implementation is adapted on several points. We alleviate the need for the creation of a <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.830>proxy</phrase> for each novel view while the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.805>blending</phrase> field is sampled in a more <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.631>non-uniform</phrase> way and combined with the per-vertex quality to reduce texture artifacts. In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to make <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> possible, all critical steps of the <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> pipeline are programmed in a <phrase_Q=0.800>highly optimized</phrase> way on <phrase_Q=0.802>commodity graphics hardware</phrase> using the <phrase_Q=0.942>OpenGL Shading Language</phrase>. The proposed system can handle <phrase_Q=0.908>complex scenes</phrase> such as <phrase_Q=0.562>large outdoor</phrase> scenes as well as <phrase_Q=0.619>small objects</phrase> with a <phrase_Q=0.522>large number</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.508>acquired images</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=1.000>Digitizing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Archaeological</phrase> Excavations from <phrase_Q=0.927>Multiple Views</phrase>.
We present a novel approach on <phrase_Q=1.000>digitizing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.539>large scale unstructured</phrase> environments like <phrase_Q=1.000>archaeological</phrase> excavations using off-the-<phrase_Q=0.826>shelf</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>digital</phrase> still cameras. The cameras are calibrated with respect to few markers captured by a <phrase_Q=1.000>theodolite</phrase> system. Having all cameras registered in the same <phrase_Q=0.530>coordinate system</phrase> enables a <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> approach. Our new <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> has as input multiple <phrase_Q=0.668>calibrated images</phrase> and outputs an occupancy <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase> space where occupied <phrase_Q=1.000>pixels</phrase> have a <phrase_Q=0.757>local orientation</phrase> and a confidence value. Both, orientation and confidence facilitate <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> rendering and <phrase_Q=1.000>texture mapping</phrase> of the resulting <phrase_Q=1.000>point cloud</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> combines the following new features: Images are <phrase_Q=0.504>back-projected</phrase> to hypothesized <phrase_Q=0.603>local patches</phrase> in the world and correlated on these patches yielding the best orientation. Adjacent cameras build tuples which yield a product of <phrase_Q=0.874>pairwise correlations</phrase>, called strength. <phrase_Q=0.802>Multiple camera</phrase> tuples compete each other for the best strength for each <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase> is regarded as occupied if strength is maximum along the normal. <phrase_Q=0.821>Unlike</phrase> other <phrase_Q=0.868>multi-camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> using silhouettes, photoconsistency, or <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase>, our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> makes no assumption on <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> locations being outside the <phrase_Q=1.000>convex hull</phrase> of the scene. We present compelling <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> of outdoors <phrase_Q=0.861>excavation</phrase> areas.
<phrase_Q=0.900>Appearance-Based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.750>Virtual View Generation</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.871>Temporally-Varying</phrase> Events from <phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>Camera</phrase> Images in the 3D <phrase_Q=0.826>Room</phrase>.
A Mechanism for <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Image <phrase_Q=0.821>Integration</phrase> without <phrase_Q=1.000>Image Registration</phrase>.
A mechanism is introduced that automatically integrates <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-view <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images without registering the images. The mechanism is based on a reference <phrase_Q=0.842>double</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase> that acts as the <phrase_Q=0.530>coordinate system</phrase> of the scene. A <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase>-view <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> image of a scene is obtained by <phrase_Q=0.836>sweeping</phrase> a <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> line over the scene by hand and <phrase_Q=0.803>analyzing</phrase> the acquired <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> stripes. <phrase_Q=0.923>Range images</phrase> captured from different views of the scene will be in the <phrase_Q=0.530>coordinate system</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.842>double</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase>, and thus, will automatically integrate without further processing.
<phrase_Q=0.535>Three-Dimensional Shape</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.816>Extended</phrase> Hyperquadrics.

The pose is planned after each new image is merged into <phrase_Q=0.524>a unified</phrase> representation. A rating <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.812>planning</phrase> is defined to take into consideration the factors such as possibility of merging new <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> accuracy and <phrase_Q=0.795>control point</phrase> selection.
<phrase_Q=0.732>Shape Measurement</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.821>Discontinuous</phrase> Objects using Projected <phrase_Q=0.851>Fringes</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.817>Temporal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.970>Phase Unwrapping</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.817>Temporal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.970>phase unwrapping</phrase> is a method of <phrase_Q=0.803>analyzing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.864>fringe</phrase> patterns in which the <phrase_Q=0.864>fringe</phrase> phase, /<phrase_Q=0.805>spl Phi</phrase>/, at each <phrase_Q=1.000>pixel</phrase> is measured and <phrase_Q=1.000>unwrapped</phrase> as a <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> of time, <phrase_Q=0.834>t</phrase>. We propose a method for <phrase_Q=0.802>improving</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>signal-to-noise ratio</phrase> of the total <phrase_Q=1.000>phase change</phrase> by incorporating <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from the intermediate phase values. The performance of the method is compared theoretical and experimentally, using <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from a <phrase_Q=0.864>fringe</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.770>projector based</phrase> on a <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> tight modulator. The best way to use the method is with /<phrase_Q=0.805>spl Phi</phrase>/ decreasing exponentially with time from its maximum value to zero; this provides <phrase_Q=0.730>significant improvements</phrase> in reliability, accuracy and computation time compared with the original <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>unwrapping</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.868>Bootstrapped</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.662>Real-Time</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.895>Ego Motion Estimation</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.743>Scene Modeling</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.808>Estimating</phrase> the motion of a <phrase_Q=0.907>moving camera</phrase> in an <phrase_Q=0.762>unknown environment</phrase> is essential for a number of applications ranging from as-built <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> to <phrase_Q=1.000>augmented reality</phrase>. It is a <phrase_Q=0.543>challenging problem</phrase> especially when <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> performance is required. Our approach is to estimate the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> motion while <phrase_Q=0.816>reconstructing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.502>shape and appearance</phrase> of the most salient <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> features in the scene. In our 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> process, correspondences are obtained by <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> features from <phrase_Q=0.500>frame to frame</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>optical flow</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Optical-flow</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> methods have limitations in <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.883>salient features</phrase>. Often larger <phrase_Q=0.824>translational</phrase> motions and even moderate <phrase_Q=0.832>rotational</phrase> motions can result in drifts. We propose to augment <phrase_Q=0.779>flow-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.828>landmark</phrase> representation around reliably reconstructed features. A <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> patch around the reconstructed <phrase_Q=0.804>feature point</phrase> provides matching <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> that prevents drifts in <phrase_Q=0.779>flow-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.894>feature tracking</phrase> and allows <phrase_Q=0.817>establishment</phrase> of correspondences across the frames with large baselines. <phrase_Q=0.806>Selective</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.832>periodic</phrase> such <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> mappings <phrase_Q=0.681>drastically improve</phrase> scene and <phrase_Q=0.667>motion reconstruction</phrase> while adhering to the <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> requirements. The method is <phrase_Q=0.700>experimentally tested</phrase> to be both accurate and computational <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.972>Globally Convergent</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Image Registration</phrase> by <phrase_Q=1.000>Graph</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>Kernel</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Algorithm</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>image registration</phrase> without any <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> of the viewpoint requires <phrase_Q=0.818>identification</phrase> of common regions across different <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images and then establishing <phrase_Q=0.922>point correspondences</phrase> in these regions. We formulate this as a <phrase_Q=0.866>graph-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>optimization problem</phrase>. More <phrase_Q=0.808>specifically</phrase>, we define a <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase> in which each vertex represents a putative match of two points, each <phrase_Q=0.803>edge</phrase> represents <phrase_Q=1.000>binary</phrase> consistency decision between two matches, and each <phrase_Q=0.803>edge</phrase> orientation represents match quality from worse to better putative match. Then strict sub-<phrase_Q=0.820>kernel</phrase> defined in the <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase> is maximized. The maximum strict sub-<phrase_Q=0.820>kernel</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> enables us to <phrase_Q=0.737>uniquely determine</phrase> the largest consistent matching of points. To evaluate the quality of a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> match, we employ the <phrase_Q=1.000>histogram</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.851>triple</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>products</phrase> that are generated by all <phrase_Q=0.912>surface normals</phrase> in a point <phrase_Q=1.000>neighborhood</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show the effectiveness of our method for <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>image registration</phrase>.

We present the <phrase_Q=1.000>prototype</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.826>Planar</phrase>, a novel <phrase_Q=1.000>input/output</phrase> device designed for applications in task areas <phrase_Q=0.801>focusing</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=0.801>generation</phrase> and manipulation of 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, e.g. <phrase_Q=1.000>CAD</phrase> or styling. Technically, the <phrase_Q=0.826>Planar</phrase> offers a <phrase_Q=0.933>spatially aware</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.840>pen</phrase>-sensitive display, mounted on an <phrase_Q=0.827>adjustable</phrase>, scooter-like <phrase_Q=0.834>autonomous</phrase> platform. The movable screen, with 6 <phrase_Q=0.647>degrees of freedom</phrase>, can <phrase_Q=1.000>act</phrase> like a window into 3D <phrase_Q=0.960>virtual environments</phrase> and allows for <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> 2D and 3D interaction at the same time. We <phrase_Q=1.000>report</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=0.965>pose estimation</phrase> system of the Planar's display where we focus on two <phrase_Q=0.819>enhanced</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>mice</phrase> combined to <phrase_Q=1.000>track</phrase> horizontal 2D <phrase_Q=0.694>position/orientation</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Results</phrase> of this <phrase_Q=0.835>pragmatic</phrase> approach are presented and discussed. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a new method for <phrase_Q=0.816>reconstructing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>animated</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>anatomy</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=0.590>facial models</phrase> of individuals from <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.814>minimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.827>manual intervention</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=1.000>prototype</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> with a <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-layer <phrase_Q=1.000>skin</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>muscle</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>skull</phrase> structure serves as the <phrase_Q=0.832>starting point</phrase> for our method. Discrete <phrase_Q=0.727>Pose Space</phrase> Estimation to Improve <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase>-Based <phrase_Q=0.814>Tracking</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.960>Iterative Closest Point</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase>) -based <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> works well when the <phrase_Q=0.863>interframe</phrase> motion is within the <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.815>minimum</phrase> well space. For large <phrase_Q=0.863>interframe</phrase> motions resulting from a limited <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> rate relative to the speed of the <phrase_Q=0.778>object motion</phrase>, it suffers from <phrase_Q=0.807>slow convergence</phrase> and a tendency to be stalled by <phrase_Q=0.925>local minima</phrase>. A novel method is proposed to improve the performance of <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase>. The method is based upon the <phrase_Q=0.802>Bounded</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.969>Hough Transform</phrase> (BHT) which estimates the <phrase_Q=0.750>object pose</phrase> in a coarse discrete <phrase_Q=0.727>pose space</phrase>. Given an initial <phrase_Q=0.588>pose estimate</phrase>, and assuming that the <phrase_Q=0.863>interframe</phrase> motion is <phrase_Q=0.802>bounded</phrase> in all 6 pose dimensions, the BHT estimates the current frameýs pose. On its own, the BHT is able to <phrase_Q=1.000>track</phrase> an objectýs pose in <phrase_Q=0.520>sparse range data</phrase> both efficiently and reliably, albeit with a <phrase_Q=0.815>limited precision</phrase>. Experiments on both simulated and <phrase_Q=0.676>real data</phrase> show the BHT to be more <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> than a number of variants of the <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase> for a similar <phrase_Q=1.000>degree</phrase> of reliability. A <phrase_Q=1.000>hybrid</phrase> method has also been implemented wherein at each <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase> the BHT is followed by a few <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase> iterations. This <phrase_Q=1.000>hybrid</phrase> method is more <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> than the <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase>, and is more <phrase_Q=0.814>reliable</phrase> than either the BHT or <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase> separately.
3D <phrase_Q=0.941>Head Pose Estimation</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>Optical Flow</phrase> and Depth Constraints.
<phrase_Q=0.810>Efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Photometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> Technique for <phrase_Q=0.668>Three-Dimensional</phrase> Surfaces with Unknown <phrase_Q=0.852>BRDF</phrase>.
The present <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> focuses on <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.829>inverse</phrase> rendering using a <phrase_Q=1.000>Photometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> technique for realistic surfaces. The technique primarily assumes the <phrase_Q=0.866>Lambertian</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.831>reflection</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> only. For <phrase_Q=0.541>non-Lambertian</phrase> surfaces, application of the technique to real surfaces in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to estimate 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> shape and <phrase_Q=0.863>spatially varying reflectance</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.838>sparse</phrase> images <phrase_Q=0.595>remains difficult</phrase>. In the present <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose a new <phrase_Q=1.000>Photometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> technique by which to efficiently recover a full <phrase_Q=0.623>surface model</phrase>, starting from a small set of photographs. The proposed technique allows diffuse <phrase_Q=1.000>albedo</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.720>vary arbitrarily</phrase> over surfaces while non-diffuse characteristics <phrase_Q=0.651>remain constant</phrase> for a material. <phrase_Q=0.808>Specifically</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>basic</phrase> approach is to <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> recover the <phrase_Q=1.000>specular</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase> parameters of the surfaces by a novel <phrase_Q=0.730>optimization procedure</phrase>. These parameters are then used to estimate the <phrase_Q=0.924>diffuse reflectance</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase> for each point. As a result, a lighting-<phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase> properties of the surface is established using the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase>, which can be used to <phrase_Q=0.803>re</phrase>-render the images under novel lighting via traditional rendering methods.

<phrase_Q=0.810>Efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>Interactive</phrase> Rendering of Detailed Models with <phrase_Q=0.629>Hierarchical Levels</phrase> of Detail.
Recent <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> systems, such as the one developed at the <phrase_Q=1.000>University</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>California</phrase> at <phrase_Q=1.000>Berkeley</phrase>, are capable of collecting large, detailed, <phrase_Q=0.744>highly textured</phrase> models that standard <phrase_Q=0.508>levels of detail</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>LOD</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.833>rendering techniques</phrase> [<phrase_Q=0.819>Adaptive</phrase> display <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.725>interactive frame rates</phrase> during <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.639>complex virtual environments</phrase>] cannot handle efficiently. We propose an out-of-core <phrase_Q=0.874>rendering engine</phrase> which applies the cost and benefit approach of the <phrase_Q=0.819>Adaptive</phrase> Display <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> by Funkhouser and Séquin [<phrase_Q=0.819>Adaptive</phrase> display <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.725>interactive frame rates</phrase> during <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.639>complex virtual environments</phrase>] to <phrase_Q=0.629>Hierarchical Levels</phrase> of Detail (HLODs) [HLODs for faster display of large static and <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> environments]. <phrase_Q=0.821>Unlike</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.819>Adaptive</phrase> Display <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>, we do not <phrase_Q=0.866>skip</phrase> objects to maintain <phrase_Q=1.000>interactivity</phrase> when many objects are visible. Funkhouser and Séquin apply <phrase_Q=1.000>hysteresis</phrase> by adding a penalty in the benefit heuristics to discourage disturbing <phrase_Q=1.000>visual effects</phrase> due to <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> switching of detail in the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. However, this penalty may not be sufficient if the user is moving around rapidly in the scene. Instead, we have developed a more <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>hysteresis</phrase> by retaining how much detail is rendered over a time <phrase_Q=1.000>period</phrase>. We have implemented our <phrase_Q=0.874>rendering engine</phrase> to run on a common <phrase_Q=0.708>personal computer</phrase> with a standard <phrase_Q=1.000>graphics card</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>engine</phrase> is capable of <phrase_Q=0.814>visualizing</phrase>, in both <phrase_Q=0.820>walk</phrase>-through and <phrase_Q=1.000>fly</phrase>-through mode, a detailed <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of 25 <phrase_Q=1.000>city</phrase> blocks comprised of 7 <phrase_Q=0.794>million triangles</phrase> and 720 million <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>pixels</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>engine</phrase> maintains a <phrase_Q=0.592>constant frame rate</phrase> and limits excessive flickering simultaneously.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Network Protocol</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.820>I</phrase> teraction and <phrase_Q=0.722>Scalable Distributed</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.811>Visualization</phrase>.
Disordered Patterns <phrase_Q=0.821>Projection</phrase> For 3D Motion <phrase_Q=0.828>Recovering</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we present a new <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> technique based on a disordered codeword strategy. The aim of this method is to recover 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> in moving scenes in such a way that the <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> problem is easily and robustly solved. With this goal in <phrase_Q=0.859>mind</phrase> a six-connectivity <phrase_Q=1.000>topology</phrase> has been introduced in our pattern and <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> features have been inserted on it. <phrase_Q=0.823>Repetition</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.816>disorder</phrase> are allowed in the codeword which implies that the <phrase_Q=1.000>Hamming distance</phrase> between contiguous codewords increases. As a consequence of that, code loss circumstances can be <phrase_Q=0.531>efficiently handled</phrase>. Additionally, <phrase_Q=0.737>computational cost</phrase> in the code <phrase_Q=0.828>recovering</phrase> phase is highly reduced since codewords are defined as sets. A <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>projection</phrase> system has been built in our <phrase_Q=0.861>lab</phrase> and a wide <phrase_Q=1.000>test</phrase> under real moving conditions has been <phrase_Q=0.501>carried out</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=0.808>experimentation</phrase> has been performed on <phrase_Q=0.742>medium resolution</phrase> and for slow movements specifications giving <phrase_Q=0.691>promising results</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.889>Object Classification</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.811>Functional</phrase> Parts.

This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes an approach to <phrase_Q=1.000>texture mapping</phrase> a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>city</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> obtained from aerialand <phrase_Q=0.850>ground-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> scans with <phrase_Q=0.841>oblique</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.830>aerial</phrase> imagery. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase>, the images are automatically registered by matching 2D image lines with projections of 3D lines from the <phrase_Q=1.000>city</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. Then, for each <phrase_Q=1.000>triangle</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase> image is selected by <phrase_Q=0.548>taking into account</phrase> occlusion, <phrase_Q=1.000>image resolution</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase> orientation, and <phrase_Q=0.828>coherence</phrase> with neighboring <phrase_Q=1.000>triangles</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, the utilized <phrase_Q=0.686>texture patches</phrase> from all images are combined into one <phrase_Q=0.852>texture atlas</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.829>compact</phrase> representation and <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> rendering. We evaluate our approach on a <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> set of <phrase_Q=1.000>downtown</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Berkeley</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Human</phrase> Motion: <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> and Recognition of Actions and Interactions.
Processing of <phrase_Q=0.949>image sequences</phrase> has progressed from simple <phrase_Q=0.625>structure from motion</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>paradigm</phrase> to the recognition of actions / interactions as events. <phrase_Q=0.816>Understanding</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> activities in <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> has many <phrase_Q=0.572>potential applications</phrase> including <phrase_Q=0.824>automated</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>surveillance</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>archival</phrase>/<phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>medical diagnosis</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>sports</phrase> analysis, and <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase>-computer interaction. <phrase_Q=0.816>Understanding</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> activities involves various steps of <phrase_Q=0.857>low-level vision</phrase> processing such as segmentation, <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.861>pose recovery</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.907>trajectory estimation</phrase> as well as <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-level <phrase_Q=0.549>processing tasks</phrase> such as body <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> and representation of <phrase_Q=1.000>action</phrase>. While <phrase_Q=0.861>low-level</phrase> processing has been <phrase_Q=0.546>actively studied</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-level processing is just beginning to receive attention. This is partly because <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-level processing depends on the <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.861>low-level</phrase> processing. However, <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-level processing also requires some <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> and additional approaches and methodologies. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we focus on the following aspects of <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-level processing: (1) <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> body <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase>, (2) <phrase_Q=0.519>level of detail</phrase> needed to understand <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> actions, (3) approaches to <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>action</phrase> recognition, and (4) <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-level recognition schemes with <phrase_Q=0.916>domain knowledge</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.656>Linear Shift-Invariant</phrase> Operators for Processing <phrase_Q=0.922>Surface Meshes</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.809>Shift</phrase>-invariant operators for <phrase_Q=0.922>surface meshes</phrase> are defined using <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> realizations of the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase>. Then, <phrase_Q=0.890>shift-invariance</phrase> essentially means <phrase_Q=1.000>isotropy</phrase> w.r.t. a <phrase_Q=0.823>distance metric</phrase>. The particular case of the so-defined <phrase_Q=1.000>LSI</phrase> operators with small support is analyzed in detail, showing a connection to <phrase_Q=0.644>mean value coordinates</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>topological</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Laplacian</phrase> operator turns out to be the <phrase_Q=1.000>LSI</phrase> operator of the <phrase_Q=1.000>topological</phrase> realization of the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase>. More generally, assuming different <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> realizations or metrics allows <phrase_Q=0.814>interpreting</phrase> various <phrase_Q=0.754>mesh processing</phrase> techniques as <phrase_Q=1.000>LSI</phrase> operators.

<phrase_Q=1.000>Archaeology</phrase> is a destructive process in which accurate and detailed <phrase_Q=1.000>recording</phrase> of a site is imperative. <phrase_Q=0.819>Enhanced</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.662>Real-time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.831>Bilateral</phrase> Filtering.
In <phrase_Q=0.774>recent years</phrase>, there have been significant strides in increasing quality of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> techniques such as <phrase_Q=0.967>energy minimization</phrase>. These methods cannot yet achieve <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> performance. However, the need to improve <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> quality for <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> applications persists. All <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> implementations rely on a simple correlation step which employs some <phrase_Q=0.800>local similarity</phrase> metric between the <phrase_Q=0.516>left and right</phrase> image. Typically, the correlation <phrase_Q=0.822>takes place</phrase> on an <phrase_Q=0.719>image pair</phrase> modified in some way to compensate for <phrase_Q=1.000>photometric</phrase> variations between the <phrase_Q=0.516>left and right</phrase> cameras. Improvements and modifications to such <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> tend to <phrase_Q=0.802>fall</phrase> into one of two <phrase_Q=0.707>broad categories</phrase>: those which address the correlation step itself (e.g., shiftable <phrase_Q=1.000>windows</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.819>adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>windows</phrase>) and those which address the <phrase_Q=0.865>pre-processing</phrase> of input imagery (e.g. <phrase_Q=1.000>band</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>pass</phrase> filtering, <phrase_Q=0.801>Rank</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>Census</phrase>). Our efforts <phrase_Q=0.850>lie</phrase> in the latter <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase>. We present in this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> a modification of the standard <phrase_Q=0.640>band-pass filtering</phrase> technique used by many <phrase_Q=1.000>SSD</phrase>- and <phrase_Q=0.841>SAD</phrase>-based correlation <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase>. By using the <phrase_Q=0.831>bilateral</phrase> filter of <phrase_Q=0.836>Tomasi</phrase> and Manduchi [<phrase_Q=0.831>Bilateral</phrase> filtering for <phrase_Q=0.861>gray</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.945>color images</phrase>], we minimize blurring at the filtering stage. We show that in conjunction with <phrase_Q=0.841>SAD</phrase> correlation, our new method improves <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> quality at <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> discontinuities while maintaining <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> performance.
<phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> Interpolated Cameras by Combining a <phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase> based <phrase_Q=0.919>Plane Sweep</phrase> with a <phrase_Q=0.856>Max</phrase>-Flow <phrase_Q=0.860>Regularisation</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Algorithm</phrase>.
The <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a method for the <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> speed calculation of crude <phrase_Q=0.926>depth maps</phrase>. Performance and applicability are illustrated for <phrase_Q=0.923>view interpolation</phrase> based on two input <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> streams, but the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is perfectly amenable to <phrase_Q=0.868>multi-camera</phrase> environments. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.737>plane sweep algorithm</phrase> generates the crude <phrase_Q=0.946>depth map</phrase>. Speed <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.941>hardware accelerated</phrase> transformations and <phrase_Q=1.000>parallel processing</phrase> available on the <phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase>. All computations on the <phrase_Q=1.000>graphical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.802>board</phrase> are performed <phrase_Q=0.914>pixel-wise</phrase> and a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>pass</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.836>sweep</phrase> only processes one input <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> step uses a <phrase_Q=0.866>min-cut/max-flow</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to ameliorate the previous result. The <phrase_Q=0.946>depth map</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=0.806>noisy</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.534>interpolated image</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.733>correlation measures</phrase> are available on the <phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase>. They are reused and combined with <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.600>connectivity information</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase> continuity considerations in a <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase> formulation. <phrase_Q=0.852>Position dependent</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> densities allow the system to use <phrase_Q=0.511>multiple image</phrase> resolutions. The <phrase_Q=0.927>min-cut</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>separation</phrase> of this <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase> yields the <phrase_Q=0.782>global minimum</phrase> of the associated <phrase_Q=1.000>energy</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase>. Limiting the <phrase_Q=0.774>search range</phrase> according to the initialisation provided by the <phrase_Q=0.919>plane sweep</phrase> further <phrase_Q=0.579>speeds up</phrase> the process. The required hardware are only two cameras and a regular <phrase_Q=1.000>PC</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> Framework for 3D Models <phrase_Q=0.809>Retrieval</phrase> Based on <phrase_Q=0.795>Characteristic Views</phrase>.
The <phrase_Q=1.000>management</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.810>big</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> models (used in <phrase_Q=1.000>CAD</phrase> applications, <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>games</phrase>, etc.) is a very important domain. The ability to characterize and <phrase_Q=0.554>easily retrieve</phrase> models is a <phrase_Q=0.545>key issue</phrase> for the designers and the final users. In this <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase>, two main approaches exist: search by example of a <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, and search by a 2D view. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we present a novel framework for the <phrase_Q=0.808>characterization</phrase> of a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> by a set of views (called <phrase_Q=0.795>characteristic views</phrase>), and an <phrase_Q=0.818>indexing</phrase> process of these models with a <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.853>probabilistic</phrase> approach using the <phrase_Q=0.795>characteristic views</phrase>. The framework is <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> from the descriptor used for the <phrase_Q=0.818>indexing</phrase>. We illustrate our <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> using different descriptors on a collection of threedimensional models supplied by <phrase_Q=1.000>Renault</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.805>Group</phrase>.
3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>Watermarking</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.818>Indexing</phrase> using the <phrase_Q=0.840>Generalized</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Radon Transform</phrase>.
The present <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> proposes a novel method for 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>watermarking</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.818>indexing</phrase>. The proposed approach is based on the use of a <phrase_Q=0.840>Generalized</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Radon</phrase> Transformation. More <phrase_Q=0.808>specifically</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.824>Cylindrical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>Integration</phrase> Transform (<phrase_Q=0.801>CIT</phrase>) is initially applied to the 3D models in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to produce <phrase_Q=0.576>descriptor vectors</phrase>. At the same time a <phrase_Q=0.825>watermarking</phrase> technique, based on <phrase_Q=0.801>CIT</phrase> is used in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to embed a specific <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> identifier in the nodes of the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. This identifier links the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> to its descriptor <phrase_Q=1.000>vector</phrase>, which is extracted only once and stored in a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>. Every time this <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is employed as a <phrase_Q=0.597>query model</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>watermark</phrase> detection is used so as to retrieve the corresponding identifier and further the descriptor <phrase_Q=1.000>vector</phrase>, which can be further used in a <phrase_Q=0.733>matching algorithm</phrase>. The proposed techniques are <phrase_Q=0.721>evaluated experimentally</phrase> in terms of both <phrase_Q=0.825>watermarking</phrase> efficiency and <phrase_Q=0.894>content-based retrieval</phrase> performance.
A <phrase_Q=0.625>Structure-from-Motion</phrase> Method: Use of Motion in <phrase_Q=0.668>Three-Dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.929>Moving Objects</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.860>Multiple-View</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.949>Image Sequences</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.811>Solving</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> problem is the most essential task for <phrase_Q=0.882>multiview reconstruction</phrase> techniques, yet finding unique <phrase_Q=0.506>correspondences between</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.927>multiple views</phrase> is impossible at some points, due to such problems as occlusions and ambiguities. We have developed a <phrase_Q=1.000>closed-form</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> through <phrase_Q=0.854>constructive</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> for a <phrase_Q=0.737>special case</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.625>structure-from-motion</phrase> (SfM) problem with four <phrase_Q=0.909>rigidly moving</phrase> points. This <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> allows the 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> position of a point on a <phrase_Q=0.948>moving object</phrase> to be computed without having to find the <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> between its projections on the <phrase_Q=0.567>image planes</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.927>multiple views</phrase>, given its projected 2-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.919>motion vector</phrase> on an <phrase_Q=0.849>image plane</phrase> and 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> of three other points. With this method we do not have to depend entirely on <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase>/<phrase_Q=0.859>multiview</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.883>feature correspondences</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.816>reconstructing</phrase> 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> objects, hence <phrase_Q=0.823>easing</phrase> those problems caused by occlusions and ambiguities.
3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Data Acquisition</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.825>Elaboration</phrase> for Classification and Recognition of Objects and People.

<phrase_Q=0.821>Projection</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase>, 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.901>Rigid Motion</phrase> Estimation from Non-<phrase_Q=0.960>Central Catadioptric</phrase> Images.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> addresses the problem of <phrase_Q=0.901>rigid motion</phrase> estimation and 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.813>vision</phrase> systems where it is possible to recover the <phrase_Q=0.823>incident light</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>ray</phrase> direction from the <phrase_Q=0.656>image points</phrase>. Such systems include <phrase_Q=1.000>pinhole</phrase> cameras and <phrase_Q=0.959>catadioptric cameras</phrase>. The estimation process aims at having corresponding incident <phrase_Q=1.000>rays</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>intersecting</phrase> at the same 3D point. <phrase_Q=0.826>Geometrical</phrase> relationships are derived to support the <phrase_Q=0.758>estimation method</phrase>. Furthermore, this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> also addresses the problem of the <phrase_Q=0.828>mapping</phrase> from 3D points to <phrase_Q=0.656>image points</phrase>, for non-<phrase_Q=0.920>central catadioptric cameras</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>mirror</phrase> surfaces given by <phrase_Q=0.860>quadrics</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.821>projection</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> presented can be expressed in a <phrase_Q=0.542>non-linear</phrase> equation of only one <phrase_Q=1.000>variable</phrase>, being more stable and easier to solve than the <phrase_Q=1.000>classical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Snell's law</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.822>Scalable</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.810>Efficient</phrase> Coding of 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> Extracted from a <phrase_Q=1.000>Video</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.849>scalable coding</phrase> scheme for transmitting a <phrase_Q=1.000>stream</phrase> of 3D models extracted from a video.As in <phrase_Q=1.000>classical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.841>model-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> coding, the <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase>, connectivity, and texture of the 3D models have to be transmitted, as well as the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> position for each <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase> in the original <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> is based on <phrase_Q=0.803>exploiting</phrase> the interrelations existing between each type of <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>, instead of coding them independently, allowing a better prediction of the <phrase_Q=0.822>next</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>stream</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Scalability</phrase> is achieved through the use of <phrase_Q=0.910>wavelet-based</phrase> representations for both texture and <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> of the models. A consistent connectivity is built for all 3D models extracted from the <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase>, which allows a more <phrase_Q=0.829>compact</phrase> representation and straightforward <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>morphing</phrase> between successive models. Furthermore this leads to a consistent <phrase_Q=1.000>wavelet</phrase> decomposition for 3D models in the <phrase_Q=1.000>stream</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.511>Quantitative and qualitative</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.572>proposed scheme</phrase> are compared with the <phrase_Q=1.000>state</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>art</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> coder H264, 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>-based Galpin coder and <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>MPEG4</phrase>-based coding of the <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>. Targeted applications include distant <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> of the original <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> at <phrase_Q=0.614>very low bitrate</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.822>interactive</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>navigation</phrase> in the extracted 3D scene on heterogeneous terminals.

A <phrase_Q=0.789>commonly encountered</phrase> problem when creating 3D models of large <phrase_Q=0.899>real scenes</phrase> is unnatural <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> texture <phrase_Q=1.000>fusion</phrase>. When <phrase_Q=0.603>fusing multiple</phrase> views to create larger models, this <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> variation leads to a poor appearance with odd <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.832>tilings</phrase> on homogeneous surfaces. The <phrase_Q=0.584>central idea</phrase> is to estimate a set of <phrase_Q=0.805>blending</phrase> transformations that minimize the overall <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>discrepancy</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.669>overlapping regions</phrase>, thus spreading <phrase_Q=0.833>residual</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> errors, rather than letting them accumulate.

<phrase_Q=1.000>Mixed reality</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.875>MR</phrase>), sometimes called <phrase_Q=0.819>enhanced</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reality</phrase>, is a <phrase_Q=1.000>variety</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>virtual environment</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.850>VE</phrase>) which explores various approaches to combine <phrase_Q=1.000>natural environment</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.877>immersive display</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>technology</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.850>VE</phrase> technologies completely immerse a user inside a <phrase_Q=0.787>synthetic environment</phrase>. The objective of our <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> is to investigate the potential of <phrase_Q=0.875>MR</phrase> technique on <phrase_Q=0.802>improving</phrase> interaction between <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> and computer through developing a <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase>-see through <phrase_Q=1.000>mixed reality</phrase> system.
