<phrase_Q=0.837>Stereo Image</phrase> Coder Based on <phrase_Q=0.834>MRF</phrase> Analysis for <phrase_Q=0.971>Disparity Estimation</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.850>Morphological</phrase> Encoding.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a <phrase_Q=0.889>stereoscopic image</phrase> coder based on the <phrase_Q=0.838>MRF model</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.835>MAP</phrase> estimation of the <phrase_Q=0.702>disparity field</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.838>MRF model</phrase> minimizes the noise of the <phrase_Q=0.884>disparity compensation</phrase> because it <phrase_Q=0.552>takes into account</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.928>residual energy</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>smoothness</phrase> constraints and the occlusion field. The <phrase_Q=0.884>disparity compensation</phrase> is formulated as a <phrase_Q=0.866>MAP-MRF</phrase> problem in the <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> domain and the <phrase_Q=0.834>MRF</phrase> field consists of the <phrase_Q=0.650>disparity vector</phrase> and occlusion field, which is <phrase_Q=0.814>partitioned</phrase> into three regions by an initial <phrase_Q=0.778>double-threshold</phrase> setting. The <phrase_Q=0.835>MAP</phrase> search is conducted in a <phrase_Q=0.857>block-based</phrase> sense on one or two of the three regions, providing <phrase_Q=0.519>faster execution</phrase>. The reference and the <phrase_Q=0.833>residual</phrase> images are decomposed by a <phrase_Q=1.000>discrete wavelet transform</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=0.891>transform coefficients</phrase> are encoded by employing the <phrase_Q=0.850>morphological</phrase> representation of <phrase_Q=1.000>wavelet</phrase> coefficients <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. As a result of the <phrase_Q=0.850>morphological</phrase> encoding, the reference and <phrase_Q=0.833>residual</phrase> images together with the <phrase_Q=0.650>disparity vector</phrase> field are transmitted in <phrase_Q=1.000>partitions</phrase> lowering the total <phrase_Q=1.000>entropy</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> evaluation on synthetic and <phrase_Q=0.673>real images</phrase> shows beneficial performance of the <phrase_Q=0.504>proposed algorithm</phrase>.

An Analysis of Errors in <phrase_Q=0.791>Feature-Preserving Mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>Simplification</phrase> Based on <phrase_Q=0.916>Edge Contraction</phrase>.
The <phrase_Q=0.938>Quadric Error Metric</phrase> (QEM) [1] criterion has been <phrase_Q=0.697>widely applied</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.967>mesh simplification</phrase> procedures. Related criteria--such as the <phrase_Q=0.840>Quasi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>Covariance</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.813>Error Metric</phrase> (QCEM) [2], which may produce <phrase_Q=1.000>superior</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> to the QEM--have also been reported in <phrase_Q=0.774>recent years</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, the underlying reasons that criteria such as QEM and QCEM are so successful in <phrase_Q=0.967>mesh simplification</phrase> processes are considered through analysis of error in the <phrase_Q=0.826>simplification</phrase> process. <phrase_Q=0.662>Real-Time</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.548>Accurate Depth</phrase> of Field using <phrase_Q=1.000>Anisotropic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Diffusion</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.830>Programmable</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Graphics Cards</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.682>Computer graphics</phrase> cameras lack the <phrase_Q=0.620>finite Depth</phrase> of Field (<phrase_Q=0.847>DOF</phrase>) present in <phrase_Q=0.885>real world</phrase> ones. This <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> in all objects being rendered <phrase_Q=0.815>sharp</phrase> regardless of their depth, reducing the realism of the scene. On <phrase_Q=0.820>top</phrase> of that, <phrase_Q=0.885>real-world</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.847>DOF</phrase> provides a <phrase_Q=0.891>depth cue</phrase>, that helps the <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> system decode the elements of a scene. Several methods have been proposed to render images with finite <phrase_Q=0.847>DOF</phrase>, but these have always implied an important <phrase_Q=1.000>trade</phrase>-off between speed and accuracy. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we introduce a novel <phrase_Q=1.000>anisotropic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>diffusion</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Partial Differential Equation</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>PDE</phrase>) that is applied to the 2D image of the scene rendered with a <phrase_Q=0.836>pin-hole</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>PDE</phrase>, the amount of blurring on the 2D image depends on the <phrase_Q=0.839>depth information</phrase> of the 3D scene, present in the <phrase_Q=0.848>Z</phrase>-buffer. This equation is <phrase_Q=0.622>well posed</phrase>, has <phrase_Q=0.580>existence and uniqueness</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase>, and it is a good approximation of the <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase> phenomenon, without the <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> artifacts and depth inconsistencies present in other approaches. Because both inputs to our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> are present at the <phrase_Q=1.000>graphics card</phrase> at every moment, we can run the processing entirely in the <phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=0.814>fact</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.827>coupled</phrase> with the particular <phrase_Q=0.585>numerical scheme</phrase> chosen for our <phrase_Q=1.000>PDE</phrase>, allows for <phrase_Q=1.000>real-time rendering</phrase> using a <phrase_Q=0.830>programmable</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>graphics card</phrase>.
Dynamically <phrase_Q=0.809>Optimised</phrase> 3D (<phrase_Q=1.000>Virtual Reality</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>Data Transmission</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>Mobile</phrase> Devices.
<phrase_Q=0.813>Nowadays</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.681>processing power</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>mobile phones</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>Smartphones</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.868>PDA's</phrase> is increasing as well as the transmission bandwidth.Nevertheless there is still the need to reduce the content and the need of processing the data.Discussed will be proposals and solutions for <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> reduction of the transmitted content.For that, <phrase_Q=0.604>device specific</phrase> properties will be taken into account, as much as for the aim to reduce the need of <phrase_Q=0.681>processing power</phrase> at the <phrase_Q=1.000>client side</phrase> to be able to display the 3D (<phrase_Q=1.000>Virtual Reality</phrase>) data.Therefore, well known technologies e.g. <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> compression are combined with new developed ideas to reach the goal of <phrase_Q=0.819>adaptive</phrase> content transmission.To achieve a device dependent reduction of <phrase_Q=0.681>processing power</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> have to be <phrase_Q=0.817>pre processed</phrase> at the <phrase_Q=0.698>server side</phrase> or the server even has to take over functionality of weak <phrase_Q=1.000>mobile</phrase> devices.
<phrase_Q=0.807>Learning</phrase> Illumination Models While <phrase_Q=0.814>Tracking</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we present a method for estimation of 3D motion of a <phrase_Q=0.751>rigid object</phrase> from a <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase>, while simultaneously <phrase_Q=0.807>learning</phrase> the parameters of an <phrase_Q=0.622>illumination model</phrase> that describe the <phrase_Q=0.898>lighting conditions</phrase> under which the <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> was captured. This is achieved by alternately <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> motion and illumination parameters in a <phrase_Q=0.815>recently</phrase> proposed <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematical</phrase> framework for integrating the effects of motion, illumination and structure. The motion is represented in terms of <phrase_Q=1.000>translation</phrase> and rotation of the object <phrase_Q=1.000>centroid</phrase>, and the illumination is represented using a <phrase_Q=1.000>spherical harmonics</phrase> linear basis. The method does not assume any <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> for the variation of the <phrase_Q=0.862>illumination conditions</phrase>-lighting can change slowly or drastically, <phrase_Q=0.597>locally or globally</phrase>. Also, it can be composed of combinations of point and <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> sources. For <phrase_Q=0.882>multiple cameras</phrase> viewing an object, we derive a new <phrase_Q=1.000>photometric</phrase> constraint that relates the illumination parameters in two or more <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> sequences. This constraint allows verification of the illumination parameters obtained from <phrase_Q=0.927>multiple views</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.803>synthesis</phrase> of new views under the same <phrase_Q=0.898>lighting conditions</phrase>. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> under severe changes of <phrase_Q=0.898>lighting conditions</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>VENUS</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.849>Subsurface</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Ionosphere</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Radar</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Sounder</phrase>: VENSIS.

As a <phrase_Q=0.849>subsurface</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sounder</phrase>, VENSIS would obtain fundamentally different kinds of <phrase_Q=0.825>geologic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> than <phrase_Q=1.000>Magellan</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.828>Mapping</phrase> of interfaces of <phrase_Q=0.825>geologic</phrase> units (e.g. <phrase_Q=1.000>tessera</phrase>, plains, <phrase_Q=1.000>lava flows</phrase>, impact <phrase_Q=0.827>debris</phrase>) could be <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> into the <phrase_Q=0.806>third</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>dimension</phrase>. Reflectivity variations recorded at the surface by <phrase_Q=1.000>Magellan</phrase> are likely to extend into <phrase_Q=0.849>subsurface</phrase>, providing <phrase_Q=1.000>dielectric</phrase> contrast at interfaces.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Human</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Action</phrase> Recognition By <phrase_Q=1.000>Sequence</phrase> of Movelet Codewords.
<phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> Bore Detection in <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.770>Image Data</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>Industrial Automation</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> method to precisely segment and locate bore holes of 4 to 50mm <phrase_Q=1.000>diameter</phrase>. The task is solved by a <phrase_Q=1.000>robot</phrase> moving a <phrase_Q=0.829>compact</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>triangulation</phrase> scanning <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> to all sides of the object and scanning the bore holes. <phrase_Q=0.803>Exploiting</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> about the expected bore <phrase_Q=1.000>diameter</phrase> and bore pose makes it possible to develop <phrase_Q=0.702>highly robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> for an <phrase_Q=1.000>industrial</phrase> application. <phrase_Q=0.785>Sparse data</phrase> of the bore <phrase_Q=0.827>hole</phrase> is sufficient to segment the bore <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> of bore <phrase_Q=0.827>hole</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>chamfer</phrase> type using a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.840>normal vector</phrase> fit and a <phrase_Q=0.616>classification based</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=0.845>Gaussian</phrase> image. A <phrase_Q=0.830>sequential</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to fit the bore <phrase_Q=0.813>cylinder</phrase> makes it possible to calculate the bore pose in less than 1 <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.640>Experiments demonstrate</phrase> that 120 degrees of the bore <phrase_Q=0.827>hole</phrase> surface are sufficient for <phrase_Q=0.732>robust localization</phrase> within 0.3mm and 0.5 degrees even in the presence of <phrase_Q=1.000>ghost</phrase> points and notches in the bore holes.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Helmholtz</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereopsis</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.827>Rough</phrase> and Strongly <phrase_Q=0.951>Textured Surfaces</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Helmholtz</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereopsis</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.882>HS</phrase>) has <phrase_Q=0.815>recently</phrase> been explored as a promising technique for capturing shape of objects with unknown <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase>. So far, it has been <phrase_Q=0.697>widely applied</phrase> to objects of smooth <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>piecewise</phrase> uniform <phrase_Q=0.950>Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.852>BRDF</phrase>). Moreover, for <phrase_Q=0.562>non-convex</phrase> surfaces the <phrase_Q=0.685>inter-reflection</phrase> effects have been completely neglected. We extend the method to surfaces which <phrase_Q=0.520>exhibit strong</phrase> texture, nontrivial <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> and are possibly <phrase_Q=0.562>non-convex</phrase>. The problem associated with these <phrase_Q=0.766>surface features</phrase> is that <phrase_Q=1.000>Helmholtz</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.824>reciprocity</phrase> is apparently violated when <phrase_Q=0.826>point-based</phrase> measurements are used independently to establish the matching constraint as in the standard <phrase_Q=0.882>HS</phrase> implementation. We argue that the problem is avoided by <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>radiance</phrase> measurements on <phrase_Q=0.839>image regions</phrase> corresponding exactly to projections of the same <phrase_Q=0.531>surface point</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>neighbourhood</phrase> with appropriate scale. The <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> demonstrate the success of the novel method proposed on <phrase_Q=0.714>real objects</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Ellipsoid</phrase> decomposition of 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Construction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.914>Large-Scale</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Virtual Environment</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.828>Fusing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Data</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.877>Texture Images</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.831>Airborne</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.600>Altimetry Data</phrase>.
Accurate 3D <phrase_Q=0.807>Acquisition</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.867>Freely Moving</phrase> Objects.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a new <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> method for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> scanners that combines <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>geometrical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.933>object tracking</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.965>pose estimation</phrase> to register <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> profiles of <phrase_Q=0.867>freely moving</phrase> objects. The method was developed to solve the constraint of <phrase_Q=0.849>rigidity</phrase> between <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.929>moving objects</phrase> and a 3D <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase> while preserving the accuracy of the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> measurements. <phrase_Q=0.849>Rigidity</phrase> constraint imposes that a 3D <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase> or any external <phrase_Q=0.824>positioning</phrase> devices must be perfectly stable relative to the object during scanning. This is often impossible for moving structures such as when using <phrase_Q=1.000>scaffolding</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>industrial</phrase> conveyers, or <phrase_Q=0.945>robotic arms</phrase>. The method starts by creating a <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase>, and distorted estimate of the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of the object from an initial <phrase_Q=1.000>subset</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.520>sparse range data</phrase>. Then, it recursively improves and refines the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> by adding new <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>. In <phrase_Q=0.831>parallel</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.524>real-time tracking</phrase> of the object is performed to <phrase_Q=1.000>center</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.843>scan</phrase> on the object. A <phrase_Q=0.931>high-resolution</phrase> and accurate 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase>-floating object, and <phrase_Q=0.524>real-time tracking</phrase> of its position is obtained.
Using <phrase_Q=1.000>Omnidirectional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.625>Structure from Motion</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.818>Registration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images of <phrase_Q=0.814>Minimal</phrase> Overlap.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose a novel method of merging a series of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images with a <phrase_Q=0.814>minimal</phrase> overlap between any two consecutive <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images. We rigidly <phrase_Q=1.000>mount</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.815>parabolic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.947>catadioptric camera</phrase> to the <phrase_Q=0.813>range scanner</phrase>. Using two omniviews we are able to <phrase_Q=0.758>accurately estimate</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.739>relative displacement</phrase> between two <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> views. The resultant motion is used for the <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> of all <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> to the same <phrase_Q=0.530>coordinate system</phrase>. An additional <phrase_Q=0.829>perspective</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> calibrated with respect to the <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase> is used for <phrase_Q=1.000>texture mapping</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=0.809>Statistical</phrase> Method for <phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.954>Surface Reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.785>Sparse Data</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>General</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> about a class of objects, such as <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> faces or teeth, can help to solve the otherwise <phrase_Q=0.691>ill-posed</phrase> problem of <phrase_Q=0.816>reconstructing</phrase> a complete surface from <phrase_Q=0.838>sparse</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.911>feature points</phrase> or 2D projections of points. We present a technique that uses a <phrase_Q=1.000>vector space</phrase> representation of shape (3D <phrase_Q=0.838>Morphable Model</phrase>) to infer missing <phrase_Q=0.702>vertex coordinates</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.831>Regularization</phrase> derived from a <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> approach makes the system stable and <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> with respect to noise by <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.509>tradeoff between</phrase> fitting quality and <phrase_Q=0.817>plausibility</phrase>. We present a <phrase_Q=0.811>direct</phrase>, non-<phrase_Q=0.740>iterative algorithm</phrase> to calculate this <phrase_Q=0.834>optimum</phrase> efficiently, and a method for simultaneously <phrase_Q=0.829>compensating</phrase> unknown <phrase_Q=0.782>rigid transformations</phrase>. The system is applied and evaluated in two different fields: (1) <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of 3D faces at unknown orientations from 2D <phrase_Q=0.911>feature points</phrase> at <phrase_Q=0.822>interactive</phrase> rates, and (2) <phrase_Q=1.000>restoration</phrase> of missing <phrase_Q=0.515>surface regions</phrase> of teeth for <phrase_Q=0.973>CAD-CAM</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>production</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.833>dental</phrase> inlays and other <phrase_Q=1.000>medical</phrase> applications.
<phrase_Q=0.819>Enhanced</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Vector Quantization</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>Data</phrase> Reduction and Filtering.
Modern <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> digitizers can sample <phrase_Q=0.536>huge amounts</phrase> of 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> points on the <phrase_Q=0.674>object surface</phrase> in a <phrase_Q=1.000>short</phrase> time. <phrase_Q=0.826>Point based</phrase> graphics is becoming a popular framework to reduce the <phrase_Q=1.000>cardinality</phrase> of these <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> sets and to filter <phrase_Q=0.814>measurement noise</phrase>, without having to store in <phrase_Q=1.000>memory</phrase> and process <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> connectivity. <phrase_Q=0.781>Main contribution</phrase> of this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> is the <phrase_Q=0.822>introduction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.816>soft clustering</phrase> techniques in the field of <phrase_Q=0.979>point clouds</phrase> processing. In this approach <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> points are not assigned to a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> cluster, but they contribute in the <phrase_Q=0.807>determination</phrase> of the position of several <phrase_Q=0.719>cluster centres</phrase>. As a result a better representation of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> is achieved. In <phrase_Q=0.816>Soft clustering</phrase> techniques, a <phrase_Q=1.000>data set</phrase> is represented with a reduced number of points called <phrase_Q=0.779>Reference Vectors</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.888>RV</phrase>), which minimize an adequate <phrase_Q=0.750>error measure</phrase>. As the position of the <phrase_Q=1.000>RVs</phrase> is determined by "<phrase_Q=0.807>learning</phrase>", which can be viewed as an <phrase_Q=0.865>iterative optimization</phrase> procedure, they are inherently slow. We show here how <phrase_Q=0.814>partitioning</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> domain into disjointed regions called hyperboxes (<phrase_Q=0.878>HB</phrase>), the computation can be localized and the computational time reduced to linear in the number of <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> points (<phrase_Q=0.839>O</phrase>(N)), saving more than 75% on <phrase_Q=0.578>real applications</phrase> with respect to <phrase_Q=1.000>classical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.845>soft</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.857>VQ</phrase> solutions, making therefore <phrase_Q=0.857>VQ</phrase> suitable to the task. The procedure is suitable for a <phrase_Q=0.831>parallel</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.887>HW</phrase> implementation, which would <phrase_Q=1.000>lead</phrase> to a complexity sub-linear in N. An <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> procedure for setting the <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase> side and the other parameters can be derived from the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>-set analysis. <phrase_Q=1.000>Results</phrase> obtained in the <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of faces of both humans and puppets as well as on models from <phrase_Q=0.849>clouds</phrase> of points made available on the <phrase_Q=0.835>WEB</phrase> are reported and discussed in comparison with other available methods.
ShapeLab: <phrase_Q=0.524>A Unified</phrase> Framework for 2D & 3D <phrase_Q=0.861>Shape Retrieval</phrase>.
2D or 3D shapes are the most important <phrase_Q=0.881>visual information</phrase> that we use to recognize an object. We propose <phrase_Q=0.524>a unified</phrase> framework "ShapeLab" to search similar 2D or 3D shapes from an existing <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>. Users can search 3D shapes with a 2D input, <phrase_Q=0.526>and vice versa</phrase>. ShapeLab is composed of four <phrase_Q=0.591>key components</phrase>: (1) <phrase_Q=0.938>pose determination</phrase> for 3D models; (2) 2D <phrase_Q=0.834>orthogonal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.604>view generation</phrase> based on <phrase_Q=0.512>multiple levels</phrase> of detail; (3) <phrase_Q=0.909>similarity measurement</phrase> between 2D shapes; and (4) <phrase_Q=0.818>freehand</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.875>sketch-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>user interface</phrase>. Key <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> supporting the above components are <phrase_Q=0.537>briefly described</phrase>. Experiments show ShapeLab can provide a better performance such as <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> accuracy, flexibility and <phrase_Q=1.000>scalability</phrase> compared to the available methods.
<phrase_Q=0.837>Online</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.954>Surface Reconstruction</phrase> from Unorganized 3D-Points for the <phrase_Q=1.000>DLR</phrase> Hand-<phrase_Q=0.829>Guided</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>Scanner</phrase> System.
Hand-<phrase_Q=0.829>guided</phrase> scanners allow for <phrase_Q=0.834>digitization</phrase> by manually <phrase_Q=0.836>sweeping</phrase> a <phrase_Q=1.000>laser beam</phrase> over an <phrase_Q=0.737>object's surface</phrase>. The result highly depends on the way the user handles the system and his ability to keep <phrase_Q=1.000>track</phrase> of the parts of the surface that are already scanned. Processing and <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> during <phrase_Q=1.000>data acquisition</phrase> are helpful in this context. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose an <phrase_Q=0.837>online</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.502>surface reconstruction algorithm</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>DLR</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase> system <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> successively generates a <phrase_Q=0.948>triangle mesh</phrase> by incrementally inserting 3D points. Point neighborhoods are used to limit the point <phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase>, to estimate the <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase> at the inserted point, and to locally <phrase_Q=0.803>re</phrase>-triangulate the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data structure</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>neighborhood</phrase> search without restrictions to the amount of vertices or the <phrase_Q=0.558>object size</phrase> and with <phrase_Q=0.920>low complexity</phrase> is introduced. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> with the hand-<phrase_Q=0.829>guided</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase> system are presented.
<phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.625>Structure from Motion</phrase> under <phrase_Q=0.839>Weak Perspective</phrase>.
It is widely known that, for the <phrase_Q=0.589>affine camera model</phrase>, both shape and <phrase_Q=0.586>motion data</phrase> can be <phrase_Q=0.858>factorized</phrase> directly from the <phrase_Q=0.754>measurement matrix</phrase> constructed from 2D <phrase_Q=0.656>image points</phrase> coordinates. However, <phrase_Q=1.000>classical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.625>Structure from Motion</phrase> (SfM) are not <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase>: measurement <phrase_Q=1.000>outliers</phrase>, that is, incorrectly detected or <phrase_Q=0.559>matched feature points</phrase> can destroy the result. A few methods to robustify SfM have already been proposed. Different <phrase_Q=0.970>outlier detection</phrase> schemes have been used. We examine <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> by Trajkovic <phrase_Q=0.549>et al</phrase>. [<phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.855>recursive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.518>structure and motion recovery</phrase> under <phrase_Q=0.896>affine projection</phrase>] who use <phrase_Q=0.589>affine camera model</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=0.518>Least Median of Squares</phrase> (LMedS) method to separate inliers from <phrase_Q=1.000>outliers</phrase>. LMedS is only applicable when the ratio of inliers exceeds 50%. We show that the <phrase_Q=0.761>Least Trimmed Squares</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.839>LTS</phrase>) method is more <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> SfM than LMedS. In particular, we demonstrate that <phrase_Q=0.839>LTS</phrase> can handle inlier ratios below 50%. We also show that using the real (<phrase_Q=1.000>Euclidean</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.586>motion data</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> in a more precise SfM <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> that using the <phrase_Q=0.589>affine camera model</phrase>. Based on these observations, we propose a novel <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> SfM <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> and discuss its advantages and limits. The <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> and the Trajkovicprocedure are quantitatively compared on <phrase_Q=0.775>synthetic data</phrase> in different simulated situations. The methods are also tested on synthesized and real <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> sequences.
<phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.815>Assisted</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.848>Z</phrase>-Field <phrase_Q=0.826>Simplification</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.942>Height fields</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.926>depth maps</phrase> which we collectively refer to as <phrase_Q=0.848>z</phrase>-fields, usually carry a <phrase_Q=0.823>lot</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.688>redundant information</phrase> and are often used in <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> applications. This is the reason why <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> methods for their <phrase_Q=0.826>simplification</phrase> are necessary. On the other hand, the <phrase_Q=0.532>computation power</phrase> and programmability of <phrase_Q=0.802>commodity graphics hardware</phrase> has significantly grown. We present an adaptation of an existing <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.848>z</phrase>-field <phrase_Q=0.826>simplification</phrase> method for execution in <phrase_Q=0.945>graphics hardware</phrase>. The main parts of the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> are implemented as fragment programs which run on the <phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase>. The resulting <phrase_Q=0.902>polygonal models</phrase> are identical to the ones obtained by the original method. The main benefit is that the <phrase_Q=0.547>computation load</phrase> is imposed on the <phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase>, freeing-up the <phrase_Q=1.000>CPU</phrase> for other tasks. Additionally, the new method exhibits a <phrase_Q=1.000>performance improvement</phrase> when compared to a pure <phrase_Q=1.000>CPU</phrase> implementation.

<phrase_Q=0.860>Multiple View</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> of People.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents <phrase_Q=0.524>a unified</phrase> framework for <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>-based and <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of people from <phrase_Q=0.630>multiple camera views</phrase> in a <phrase_Q=0.872>studio</phrase> environment. <phrase_Q=0.502>Shape and appearance</phrase> of the reconstructed <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.809>optimised</phrase> simultaneously based on <phrase_Q=0.860>multiple view</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.886>feature correspondence</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=0.849>priori knowledge</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.690>surface structure</phrase> is introduced as <phrase_Q=0.860>regularisation</phrase> constraints. <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> assumes a known <phrase_Q=0.809>generic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>humanoid</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> a priori, which is fitted to the <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-view observations to produce a <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> representation for <phrase_Q=1.000>animation</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> makes no <phrase_Q=0.523>priori assumptions</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.869>scene geometry</phrase> allowing the <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of complex <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> scenes. <phrase_Q=1.000>Results</phrase> are presented for <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of sequences of people from <phrase_Q=0.927>multiple views</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.841>model-based</phrase> approach produces a consistent <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> representation, which is <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> in the presence of <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> ambiguities. This overcomes limitations of existing <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>hull</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> techniques. <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> allows <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-quality <phrase_Q=0.556>novel view-synthesis</phrase> with accurate reproduction of the detailed dynamics for <phrase_Q=1.000>hair</phrase> and loose <phrase_Q=1.000>clothing</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.860>Multiple view</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.827>optimisation</phrase> achieves a <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> quality comparable to the <phrase_Q=0.506>captured video</phrase> without <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> artefacts due to <phrase_Q=0.813>misalignment</phrase> of images.
<phrase_Q=0.905>Blind Watermarking</phrase> of 3D Shapes using Localized Constraints.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> develops a <phrase_Q=0.951>digital watermarking</phrase> methodology for 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>graphical</phrase> objects defined by <phrase_Q=0.969>polygonal meshes</phrase>. In <phrase_Q=0.825>watermarking</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.854>fingerprinting</phrase> the aim is to embed a code in a given <phrase_Q=1.000>media</phrase> without producing identifiable changes to it. One should be able to retrieve the embedded <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> even after the shape had suffered various modifications. Two <phrase_Q=0.905>blind watermarking</phrase> techniques <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> perturbations onto the <phrase_Q=0.795>local geometry</phrase> for selected vertices are described in this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>. The proposed methods produce localized changes of <phrase_Q=0.646>vertex locations</phrase> that do not alter the <phrase_Q=0.849>mesh topology</phrase>. A study of the effects caused by vertex location modification is provided for a <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> class of surfaces. The robustness of the proposed <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> is tested at <phrase_Q=0.526>noise perturbation</phrase> and object cropping.
<phrase_Q=0.866>Tele</phrase>-3D - Developing a Handheld <phrase_Q=0.820>Scanner</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.944>Structured Light</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>Projection</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.874>User-Controlled</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>Simplification</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.902>Polygonal Models</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.902>Polygonal Models</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.817>ubiquitous</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.682>Computer Graphics</phrase> but their <phrase_Q=0.662>real time</phrase> manipulation and rendering especially in <phrase_Q=0.822>interactive</phrase> application environments have become a <phrase_Q=0.814>threat</phrase> because of their huge sizes and complexity. A whole <phrase_Q=1.000>family</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> emerged during the <phrase_Q=0.828>last</phrase> decade to help out this problem, but they reduce the complexity of the models uniformly without <phrase_Q=0.840>caring</phrase> about <phrase_Q=1.000>semantic</phrase> importance of localized parts of a <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase>. Only a few <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> deal with <phrase_Q=0.819>adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>simplification</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.902>polygonal models</phrase>. We propose a new <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.897>user-driven</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>simplification</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>exploiting</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.826>simplification</phrase> hierarchy and hypertriangulation <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> [A <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> system] that lends a user the most of the functionalities of existing <phrase_Q=0.819>adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>simplification</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> in one place and is quite simple to implement. The proposed new underlying <phrase_Q=1.000>data structures</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.829>compact</phrase> and support <phrase_Q=0.662>real time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>navigation</phrase> across <phrase_Q=0.803>continuous</phrase> LODs of a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>; any desirable <phrase_Q=1.000>LOD</phrase> can be extracted efficiently and can further be <phrase_Q=0.818>fine</phrase>-tuned. The proposed <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.819>adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>simplification</phrase> supports two key operations for <phrase_Q=0.828>selective refinement</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.806>selective</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>simplification</phrase>; their effect has been shown on various <phrase_Q=0.902>polygonal models</phrase>. Comparison with related work shows that the proposed <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> provides combined environment at <phrase_Q=0.727>reduced overhead</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.735>memory space</phrase> usage and faster <phrase_Q=0.778>running times</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.674>Non-Rigid</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.650>Scan Alignment</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.801>Thin-Plate Splines</phrase>.
We present a <phrase_Q=0.674>non-rigid</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.588>alignment algorithm</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.827>aligning</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.931>high-resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> in the presence of <phrase_Q=0.941>low-frequency</phrase> deformations, such as those caused by <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> error. Traditional <phrase_Q=0.860>iterative closest points</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase>, which rely on <phrase_Q=1.000>rigid-body</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>alignment</phrase>, fail in these cases because the error appears as a <phrase_Q=0.674>non-rigid</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.862>warp</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> combines the robustness and efficiency of <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase> with the expressiveness of <phrase_Q=0.801>thin-plate splines</phrase> to align <phrase_Q=0.931>high-resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.640>scanned data</phrase> accurately, such as scans from the <phrase_Q=1.000>Digital</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Michelangelo</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.810>Project</phrase> [The <phrase_Q=1.000>Digital</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Michelangelo</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.810>Project</phrase>: 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> scanning of large statues]. This application is distinguished from previous uses of the <phrase_Q=0.803>thin-plate spline</phrase> by the <phrase_Q=0.814>fact</phrase> that the <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> and size of <phrase_Q=1.000>warping</phrase> are several <phrase_Q=0.616>orders of magnitude</phrase> smaller than the extent of the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase>, thus requiring especially precise <phrase_Q=0.886>feature correspondence</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.869>Metrological</phrase> Analysis of a Procedure for the <phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.833>Dental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Plaster</phrase> Casts.
As well known, in the <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of the 3D models through <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase> systems, the errors are due to the <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase>-view <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> error and to the 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> procedure. The latter can be ascribed to the various phases of the 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> pipeline: <phrase_Q=0.680>pairwise registration</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.732>global registration</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.540>surface integration</phrase>. This contribution derives a simple <phrase_Q=0.950>error propagation</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, rather useful for <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>simulation</phrase> purposes. From a <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> viewpoint, this contribution proposes a useful <phrase_Q=1.000>simulation</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.950>error propagation</phrase> in 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase>, it shows the quality of an <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> procedure <phrase_Q=0.815>recently</phrase> proposed and it shows the accuracy of 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.833>dental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>plaster</phrase> casts by current commercial <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> cameras and the considered <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> method.

<phrase_Q=0.832>Spherical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Diffusion</phrase> for 3D <phrase_Q=0.802>Surface Smoothing</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=1.000>diffusion</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.784>based approach</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.802>surface smoothing</phrase> is presented. Surfaces are represented as <phrase_Q=0.822>scalar functions</phrase> defined on the <phrase_Q=1.000>sphere</phrase>. The approach is equivalent to <phrase_Q=0.822>Gaussian smoothing</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=1.000>sphere</phrase> and is <phrase_Q=0.912>computationally efficient</phrase> since it does not require <phrase_Q=0.836>iterative</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.805>smoothing</phrase>. Furthermore, it does not suffer from the well-known <phrase_Q=0.816>shrinkage</phrase> problem. <phrase_Q=1.000>Evolution</phrase> of important <phrase_Q=0.856>shape features</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.815>parabolic</phrase> curves) under <phrase_Q=1.000>diffusion</phrase> is demonstrated. A <phrase_Q=0.824>nonlinear</phrase> modification of the <phrase_Q=1.000>diffusion</phrase> process is introduced in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to improve <phrase_Q=0.805>smoothing</phrase> behavior of elongated and poorly centered objects.

In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to analyze the sensitivity of children to <phrase_Q=0.872>RF</phrase> fields and <phrase_Q=1.000>mobile phones</phrase> in particular, the <phrase_Q=0.874>SAR</phrase> (Specific <phrase_Q=0.820>Absorption</phrase> Ratio) defined as the power absorbed by a unit of <phrase_Q=1.000>mass</phrase> of tissues (<phrase_Q=0.851>W</phrase>/<phrase_Q=0.855>kg</phrase>) should be computed based on a <phrase_Q=0.562>numerical model</phrase> of the head.We propose to build realistic models from 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>MRI</phrase> of children heads.The method is composed of two steps. The <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> one consists in <phrase_Q=0.811>segmenting</phrase> the main tissues in these images (<phrase_Q=1.000>skin</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>fat</phrase>, muscles, <phrase_Q=1.000>cortical</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>marrow</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>bones</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>cerebrospinal fluid</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.835>grey</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>white matter</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>blood</phrase>, etc).The segmentation is based on <phrase_Q=1.000>mathematical morphology</phrase> methods which are well adapted to this aim and provide a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> method requiring <phrase_Q=0.815>minimum</phrase> user intervention.Using <phrase_Q=0.824>simplified</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.870>segmented images</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> step concerns the <phrase_Q=0.957>tetrahedral mesh</phrase> generation.Our method uses almost <phrase_Q=0.768>regular meshes</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>topological</phrase> tools to preserve the <phrase_Q=1.000>topological</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>arrangement</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.809>head</phrase> tissues.A method to guarantee a good <phrase_Q=0.826>geometrical</phrase> quality is also provided.

Local <phrase_Q=0.836>Approximate</phrase> 3D Matching of <phrase_Q=1.000>Proteins</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>Viral</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.936>Cryo-EM</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Density</phrase> Maps.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.650>structure analysis</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.869>biological molecules</phrase> (e.g, <phrase_Q=1.000>proteins</phrase>) or <phrase_Q=1.000>macromolecular</phrase> complexes (e.g, <phrase_Q=1.000>viruses</phrase>) can be used to generate <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase> maps of these entities. Such a <phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>map</phrase> can be viewed as a <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.946>gray-scale</phrase> image where space is subdivided in voxels of a given size. The focus of this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> is the analysis of <phrase_Q=1.000>virus</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase> maps. The <phrase_Q=1.000>hull</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>virus</phrase> consists of many copies of one or several different <phrase_Q=1.000>proteins</phrase>. An important tool for the study of <phrase_Q=1.000>viruses</phrase> is <phrase_Q=1.000>cryo-electron microscopy</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.936>cryo-EM</phrase>), a technique with insufficient <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> to directly determine the <phrase_Q=1.000>arrangement</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>proteins</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>virus</phrase>. We therefore created a tool that locates <phrase_Q=1.000>proteins</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>map</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>virus</phrase>. The goal is to fully determine the locations and orientations of the <phrase_Q=1.000>protein</phrase>(<phrase_Q=0.812>s</phrase>) in the <phrase_Q=1.000>virus</phrase> given the <phrase_Q=1.000>virus</phrase>' <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>map</phrase> and a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase> maps of one or more <phrase_Q=1.000>protein</phrase> candidates.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Stochastic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>Mesh</phrase>-Based <phrase_Q=0.882>Multiview Reconstruction</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.539>An Experimental Comparison</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.879>Feature-Based</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>Retrieval</phrase> Methods.
3D objects are an important type of <phrase_Q=1.000>multimedia</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> with many promising application possibilities. Defining the aspects that constitute the similarity among 3D objects, and <phrase_Q=0.801>designing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> that implement such similarity definitions is a <phrase_Q=0.505>difficult problem</phrase>. Over the <phrase_Q=0.828>last</phrase> few years, a strong interest in methods for <phrase_Q=0.879>feature-based</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.947>similarity search</phrase> has arisen, and a growing number of <phrase_Q=0.506>competing algorithms</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.894>content-based retrieval</phrase> of 3D objects have been proposed. We present an <phrase_Q=0.611>extensive experimental evaluation</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> effectiveness and efficiency of a large part of the <phrase_Q=0.771>current state</phrase>-of-the-<phrase_Q=1.000>art</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.879>feature-based</phrase> methods for 3D <phrase_Q=0.947>similarity search</phrase>, giving a <phrase_Q=0.819>contrasting</phrase> assessment of the different approaches.
<phrase_Q=0.819>Neural</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>Mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>Ensembles</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> proposes the use of <phrase_Q=0.923>neural network ensembles</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.818>boost</phrase> the performance of <phrase_Q=0.526>a neural network based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.502>surface reconstruction algorithm</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.852>Ensemble</phrase> is a very popular and powerful <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> technique based on the idea of averaging several outputs of a <phrase_Q=0.853>probabilistic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. In the context of <phrase_Q=0.954>surface reconstruction</phrase>, two main <phrase_Q=0.645>problems arise</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> is finding <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> way to <phrase_Q=1.000>average</phrase> meshes with different connectivity, and the <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.805>tuning</phrase> the parameters for <phrase_Q=0.954>surface reconstruction</phrase> to maximize the performance of the <phrase_Q=0.852>ensemble</phrase>. We solve the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> problem by voxelizing all the meshes on the same <phrase_Q=0.727>regular grid</phrase> and taking <phrase_Q=1.000>majority vote</phrase> on each <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase>. We tune the parameters experimentally, <phrase_Q=0.844>borrowing</phrase> ideas from <phrase_Q=0.539>weak learning</phrase> methods.

From the <phrase_Q=0.861>Lab</phrase> to the <phrase_Q=1.000>Silver</phrase> Screen: <phrase_Q=0.688>Computer Vision</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=1.000>Art</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Special Effects</phrase>.
RoboScan: An <phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> System for Accurate and <phrase_Q=0.802>Unattended</phrase> 3D Scanning.
We describe an <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> system for <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.802>unattended</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> of accurate and complete 3D models, called RoboScan. The <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> goal is to reduce the three main bottlenecks in <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.815>assisted</phrase> 3D scanning: the selection of the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> maps to be taken (<phrase_Q=0.761>view planning</phrase>), the <phrase_Q=0.824>positioning</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase> in the environment, and the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> maps' <phrase_Q=0.814>alignment</phrase>. The system is designed around a commercial <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase>-based 3D <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase> moved by a <phrase_Q=1.000>robotic arm</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> session is organised in two stages. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase>, an initial <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> of the surface is performed by the <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> selection of a set of views. Then, some added views are <phrase_Q=0.659>automatically selected</phrase>, acquired and merged to the initial set in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to fill the <phrase_Q=0.515>surface regions</phrase> left unsampled. Both the initial set of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> maps and the <phrase_Q=0.823>subsequently</phrase> added ones are <phrase_Q=0.844>post</phrase>-processed automatically, by using the known <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase> positions to initialise the <phrase_Q=0.814>alignment</phrase> phase. <phrase_Q=1.000>Results</phrase> of the assessment of the system on real acquisitions are presented and discussed.
<phrase_Q=0.682>Computational Experiments</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>Area</phrase>-Based <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.851>Image-Based</phrase> Rendering.
<phrase_Q=0.819>Optimal</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.684>Near - Optimal</phrase> Solutions for 3D Structure Comparisons.
<phrase_Q=0.876>Photo-Consistency</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.601>Based Registration</phrase> of an <phrase_Q=0.853>Uncalibrated</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.719>Image Pair</phrase> to a 3D <phrase_Q=0.623>Surface Model</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=1.000>Genetic Algorithm</phrase>.
We consider the following <phrase_Q=1.000>data fusion</phrase> problem. A 3D object with textured <phrase_Q=0.866>Lambertian</phrase> surface is measured and independently photographed. A triangulated <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of the object and two <phrase_Q=0.894>uncalibrated images</phrase> are obtained. The goal is to precisely register the images to the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.811>Solving</phrase> this problem is necessary for <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.738>geometrically accurate</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>photorealistic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase>-scanned 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> quality images. <phrase_Q=0.815>Recently</phrase>, we have proposed a novel method that generalises the <phrase_Q=0.806>photo</phrase>-consistency approach by <phrase_Q=0.853>Clarkson</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.549>et al</phrase>. [Using <phrase_Q=0.806>photo</phrase>-consistency to register 2D <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase> images of the <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> face to a 3D <phrase_Q=0.623>surface model</phrase>] to the case of <phrase_Q=0.945>uncalibrated cameras</phrase>, when both <phrase_Q=0.612>intrinsic and extrinsic</phrase> parameters are unknown. This gives a user the freedom of taking the pictures by a conventional <phrase_Q=1.000>digital camera</phrase>, from arbitrary positions and with varying <phrase_Q=0.854>zoom</phrase>. The method is based on manual <phrase_Q=0.571>pre-registration</phrase> followed by a <phrase_Q=1.000>genetic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.675>optimisation algorithm</phrase>. A brief description of the <phrase_Q=1.000>pilot</phrase> version of the method [<phrase_Q=0.683>Precise registration</phrase> of an <phrase_Q=0.853>uncalibrated</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.719>image pair</phrase> to a 3D <phrase_Q=0.623>surface model</phrase>] has been given together with the <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> of a few initial <phrase_Q=1.000>tests</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we <phrase_Q=1.000>report</phrase> on some new significant developments in this <phrase_Q=0.810>project</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.605>critical issue</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.521>robustness against</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.606>illumination changes</phrase> is addressed and various <phrase_Q=0.836>colour</phrase> representations and <phrase_Q=0.915>cost functions</phrase> are tested and compared. Natural constraints are introduced and <phrase_Q=0.840>experimentally validated</phrase> to simplify the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> and accelerate the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, we present synthetic and <phrase_Q=0.676>real data</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.942>ground truth</phrase>, apply the <phrase_Q=0.804>improved</phrase> method to the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> and measure the quality of the <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.803>Acquiring</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.712>Height Maps</phrase> of Faces from a <phrase_Q=1.000>Single</phrase> Image.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we explore how to improve the quality of the <phrase_Q=0.865>height map</phrase> recovered from faces using <phrase_Q=0.680>shape-from-shading</phrase>. View Dependence of 3D Recovery from <phrase_Q=0.840>Folded</phrase> Pictures and <phrase_Q=0.857>Warped</phrase> 3D Faces.

When this <phrase_Q=0.840>folded</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.823>picture</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.825>tilted</phrase> back and <phrase_Q=0.857>forth</phrase> horizontally the face undergoes striking changes in expression. This <phrase_Q=1.000>distortion</phrase> reveals two insights concerning 3D representation in the <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> system and we have explored these with experiments on simple <phrase_Q=0.841>schematic</phrase> faces and observations on distortions of <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images of faces. 3D <phrase_Q=0.871>Shape Registration</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.844>Regularized</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.800>Medial</phrase> Scaffolds.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> proposes a novel method for <phrase_Q=0.732>global registration</phrase> based on matching 3D <phrase_Q=0.800>medial</phrase> structures of <phrase_Q=0.950>unorganized point clouds</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.872>triangulated meshes</phrase>. Most <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> known methods are based on the <phrase_Q=0.960>Iterative Closest Point</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>, which requires an <phrase_Q=0.737>initial alignment</phrase> close to the <phrase_Q=0.937>globally optimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> to ensure convergence to a valid <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase>. Furthermore, it can also fail when there are points in one dataset with no corresponding matches in the other dataset. The <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.557>automatically finds</phrase> an <phrase_Q=0.737>initial alignment</phrase> close to the <phrase_Q=0.602>global optimal</phrase> by using the <phrase_Q=0.800>medial</phrase> structure of the datasets. For this purpose, we <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> compute the <phrase_Q=0.866>medial scaffold</phrase> of a 3D dataset: a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase> made of special <phrase_Q=0.832>shock</phrase> curves <phrase_Q=0.812>linking</phrase> special <phrase_Q=0.832>shock</phrase> nodes. This <phrase_Q=0.866>medial scaffold</phrase> is then <phrase_Q=0.844>regularized</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>exploiting</phrase> the known transitions of the 3D <phrase_Q=0.948>medial axis</phrase> under deformation or <phrase_Q=1.000>perturbation</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.758>input data</phrase>. The resulting <phrase_Q=0.824>simplified</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.800>medial</phrase> scaffolds are then registered using a modified <phrase_Q=0.850>graduated</phrase> assignment <phrase_Q=0.906>graph matching</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> shows robustness to noise, <phrase_Q=0.884>shape deformations</phrase>, and varying surface <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> densities.
A <phrase_Q=0.904>Multi-Resolution</phrase> Scheme <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Algorithm</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.871>Shape Registration</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.801>Applying</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>Mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.810>Conformation</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.914>Shape Analysis</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.924>Missing Data</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.810>conformation</phrase> approach that makes use of <phrase_Q=0.821>deformable</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>generic</phrase> meshes has been applied to establishing <phrase_Q=0.506>correspondences between</phrase> 3D shapes with missing data.Given a <phrase_Q=0.805>group</phrase> of shapes with correspondences, we can build up a <phrase_Q=0.790>statistical shape model</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>principal component analysis</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>PCA</phrase>). The <phrase_Q=0.810>conformation</phrase> at <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> globally maps the <phrase_Q=0.809>generic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> to the 3D <phrase_Q=0.796>shape based</phrase> on manually located corresponding landmarks, and then locally deforms the <phrase_Q=0.809>generic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> to clone the 3D shape.The <phrase_Q=0.648>local deformation</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.818>constrained</phrase> by minimizing the <phrase_Q=1.000>energy</phrase> of an <phrase_Q=0.850>elastic</phrase> model.An <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> was also embedded in the <phrase_Q=0.810>conformation</phrase> process to fill missing surface <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> of the shapes.Using <phrase_Q=0.775>synthetic data</phrase>, we demonstrate that the <phrase_Q=0.810>conformation</phrase> preserves the configuration of the <phrase_Q=0.809>generic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> and hence it helps to establish good correspondences for shape analysis.Case studies of the <phrase_Q=1.000>principal component analysis</phrase> of shapes were presented to illustrate the successes and advantages of our approach.

<phrase_Q=0.792>Markerless Human Motion</phrase> Transfer.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we develop a <phrase_Q=0.688>computer vision</phrase>-based system to transfer <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> motion from one subject to another. Our system uses a network of eight calibrated and <phrase_Q=0.769>synchronized cameras</phrase>. We <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> build detailed <phrase_Q=1.000>kinematic</phrase> models of the subjects based on our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.814>extracting</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.775>shape from silhouette</phrase> across time [A 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> combining shape-<phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase>-shilhouette]. Our <phrase_Q=0.616>rendering algorithm</phrase> uses an <phrase_Q=0.852>ensemble</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.645>spatially and temporally</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>distributed</phrase> images to generate <phrase_Q=0.806>photo</phrase>-realistic <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> of the transferred motion. We demonstrate the performance of the system by rendering throwing and kungfu motions on subjects who did not perform them.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Topology</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Geometry</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.950>Unorganized Point Clouds</phrase>.
We present a new method for defining neighborhoods, and assigning <phrase_Q=0.910>principal curvature</phrase> frames, and mean and <phrase_Q=1.000>Gauss</phrase> curvatures to the points of an unorganized oriented <phrase_Q=1.000>point-cloud</phrase>. The neighborhoods are estimated by <phrase_Q=0.802>measuring</phrase> implicitly the surface distance between points. The 3D <phrase_Q=0.901>shape recovery</phrase> is based on <phrase_Q=1.000>conformal geometry</phrase>, works directly on the <phrase_Q=1.000>cloud</phrase>, does not rely on the <phrase_Q=0.801>generation</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.823>polygonal</phrase>, or smooth models. <phrase_Q=1.000>Test</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.616>publicly available</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.775>synthetic data</phrase>, as <phrase_Q=0.942>ground truth</phrase>, demonstrate that the method <phrase_Q=0.814>compares favorably</phrase> to the established approaches for <phrase_Q=0.838>quantitative</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.901>shape recovery</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.942>Face Recognition</phrase> from 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Data</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.808>Iterative Closest Point Algorithm</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.963>Gaussian Mixture Models</phrase>.
A new approach to <phrase_Q=0.905>face verification</phrase> from 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> is presented. The method uses 3D <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> techniques designed to work with <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> levels typical of the <phrase_Q=0.806>irregular</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>point cloud</phrase> representations provided by <phrase_Q=0.944>Structured Light</phrase> scanning. <phrase_Q=0.825>Preprocessing</phrase> using a-priori <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> face and the <phrase_Q=0.808>Iterative Closest Point algorithm</phrase> are employed to establish <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> between <phrase_Q=1.000>test</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>target</phrase> and to compensate for the <phrase_Q=0.674>non-rigid</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>nature</phrase> of the surfaces. <phrase_Q=0.749>Statistical modelling</phrase> in the form of <phrase_Q=0.963>Gaussian Mixture Models</phrase> is used to parameterise the distribution of errors in <phrase_Q=0.783>facial surfaces</phrase> after <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> and is employed to differentiate between <phrase_Q=0.817>intra</phrase>- and extra-personal comparison of <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images. An <phrase_Q=0.942>Equal Error Rate</phrase> of 2.67% was achieved on the 30 subject manual <phrase_Q=1.000>subset</phrase> of the the 3d_rma <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase>.
Entire <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>Acquisition</phrase> System using Handheld 3D Digitizer.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase>, handheld 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> system consisting of a <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> projector, a <phrase_Q=1.000>video camera</phrase> and a <phrase_Q=0.857>turntable</phrase> is described. The user projects a <phrase_Q=0.841>stripe</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> at the 3D object by hand while rotating the object on a <phrase_Q=0.857>turntable</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.806>projected light</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>LED</phrase> markers attached to the <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> projector and <phrase_Q=0.857>turntable</phrase> are captured by the <phrase_Q=1.000>video camera</phrase>. By <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> the 3D orientation of the <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> projector and the <phrase_Q=0.857>turntable</phrase> angle from the 2D locations of the markers, the 3D location of the surface <phrase_Q=0.875>lit</phrase> by the <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> can be calculated. In addition, <phrase_Q=0.912>post-processing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.812>refining</phrase> the estimated 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> have been proposed. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> not only improves the accuracy of the 3D measurement, but also achieves to decrease the number of <phrase_Q=1.000>LEDs</phrase> for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> estimation; therefore, it <phrase_Q=0.768>significantly improves</phrase> the userýs convenience in scanning the object. With this system, users can measure an entire 3D object in <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase>.
3D Effect <phrase_Q=0.801>Generation</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>Monocular</phrase> View.
<phrase_Q=0.684>Synthetic Image</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.842>Multiresolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Sketch</phrase> Leads to New Features.
A new approach to <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> features is proposed and applied to an instance of the <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> problem. The <phrase_Q=0.721>main idea</phrase> is to construct a <phrase_Q=0.684>synthetic image</phrase> by a <phrase_Q=0.842>multiresolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sketch</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.875>MS</phrase>) of an image and involve it into extraction of the invariants. The <phrase_Q=0.875>MS</phrase> is constructed by processing the image with a <phrase_Q=0.822>scalable</phrase> detector of the <phrase_Q=0.819>semi</phrase>-local 1D-elements. Then, a <phrase_Q=0.684>synthetic image</phrase> is constructed with all elements of the <phrase_Q=0.875>MS</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.912>Local maxima</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> derivatives of the <phrase_Q=0.684>synthetic image</phrase> along <phrase_Q=0.687>discrete curves</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.875>MS</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>lead</phrase> to some <phrase_Q=0.812>singular</phrase> elements represented by the points of a 4D <phrase_Q=1.000>manifold</phrase>. It turns out that a representative <phrase_Q=1.000>subset</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.812>singular</phrase> elements is stable. To prove that, the <phrase_Q=0.899>pair-wise</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> between subsets of <phrase_Q=0.812>singular</phrase> elements of two shots of a <phrase_Q=1.000>film</phrase> was established experimentally by a consistency technique, which, <phrase_Q=0.821>unlike</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.504>past approaches</phrase>, does not involve <phrase_Q=0.863>epipolar constraints</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.850>Hierarchical</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.954>Surface Reconstruction</phrase> based on <phrase_Q=0.974>Radial Basis Functions</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.835>Volumetric</phrase> methods based on <phrase_Q=0.826>implicit</phrase> surfaces are commonly used in <phrase_Q=0.954>surface reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.871>uniformly distributed</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.838>sparse</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. The case of <phrase_Q=0.631>non-uniform</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>distributed</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> has <phrase_Q=0.815>recently</phrase> deserved more attention, because it <phrase_Q=0.643>occurs frequently</phrase> in practice. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes a <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> approach to <phrase_Q=0.954>surface reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.631>non-uniform</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> which is suitable for the <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of surfaces from images, in particular from <phrase_Q=0.927>multiple views</phrase>. Differently from <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> methods which use both 3D <phrase_Q=0.660>surface points</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.912>surface normals</phrase>, the approach does not use the <phrase_Q=0.912>surface normals</phrase> because they are often unreliable when estimated from <phrase_Q=0.770>image data</phrase>. The method is based on a <phrase_Q=0.737>hierarchical partitioning</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.874>volume data</phrase> set. The working volume is <phrase_Q=1.000>split</phrase> and classified at different scales of <phrase_Q=0.935>spatial resolution</phrase> into surface, <phrase_Q=0.536>internal and external</phrase> voxels and this hierarchy is described by an <phrase_Q=1.000>octree</phrase> structure in a <phrase_Q=0.842>multiscale</phrase> framework. The <phrase_Q=1.000>octree</phrase> structure is used to build a <phrase_Q=0.842>multiresolution</phrase> description of the surface by means of <phrase_Q=0.829>compact</phrase> support <phrase_Q=0.974>radial basis functions</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.839>RBF</phrase>). A hierarchy of surface approximations at different levels of details is built by representing the voxels at the same <phrase_Q=1.000>octree</phrase> level as <phrase_Q=0.839>RBF</phrase> of similar <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> support. At each scale, <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> related to the <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> error drives the <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> process at the following <phrase_Q=0.682>finer scale</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.924>Preliminary results</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.775>synthetic data</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.739>future perspectives</phrase> are presented.
<phrase_Q=0.926>Shape Matching</phrase> using the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Radon Transform</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> a novel method for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.876>content-based</phrase> search and <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> based on the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Radon Transform</phrase> and a querying-by-3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> approach, is presented. This <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> to a very <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> and accurate <phrase_Q=0.681>matching method</phrase>. Experiments were performed using two different <phrase_Q=1.000>databases</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.812>comparing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> with others. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show that the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> can be used for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> search and <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> in a <phrase_Q=0.890>highly efficient</phrase> manner.

<phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>Concealment</phrase> for Erroneous Block Bursts in <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereoscopic</phrase> Images.
With the increasing number of image <phrase_Q=1.000>communication</phrase> applications especially in the <phrase_Q=0.920>low complexity</phrase> domain, <phrase_Q=0.971>error concealment</phrase> has become a very important field of <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase>. Since many <phrase_Q=0.714>compression standards</phrase> for images and videos are <phrase_Q=0.857>block-based</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.823>lot</phrase> of methods were applied to conceal block losses in <phrase_Q=1.000>monocular</phrase> images. The <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> progress of capture, representation and <phrase_Q=0.722>display technologies</phrase> for 3D <phrase_Q=0.770>image data</phrase> advances the efforts on 3D <phrase_Q=0.806>concealment</phrase> strategies. Because of their <phrase_Q=0.866>psycho</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> characteristics, <phrase_Q=1.000>stereoscopic</phrase> images have to fulfill a very <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> quality demand. We propose an <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> that makes use of the redundancies between two views of a <phrase_Q=0.747>stereo image pair</phrase>. In many cases erroneous block bursts occur and can be highly disturbing, thus we will mainly concentrate on these errors. In addition, we focused on the <phrase_Q=0.959>quality assessment</phrase> of several <phrase_Q=0.971>error concealment</phrase> strategies. Beside the <phrase_Q=0.545>objective evaluation</phrase> measures, we <phrase_Q=0.501>carried out</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.895>subjective quality</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>test</phrase> following the DSCQS methodology as proposed by <phrase_Q=1.000>MPEG</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> of this <phrase_Q=1.000>test</phrase> demonstrate the efficiency of our approach.
