Using 3D-<phrase_Q=0.806>Bresenham</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.825>Resampling</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>Structured Grids</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.836>Structured grids</phrase> and some of their applications in <phrase_Q=1.000>natural sciences</phrase> are discussed. The problem of their <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.838>quantitative</phrase> evaluation is considered and possible ways for itssolution sketched. <phrase_Q=0.825>Resampling</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.649>structured grid</phrase> onto a regular one is such a possible <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> offering the additional benefit of enabling <phrase_Q=0.838>quantitative</phrase> evaluations, too. This <phrase_Q=0.825>resampling</phrase> is achieved by a <phrase_Q=0.809>preliminary</phrase> tetrahedronization of the <phrase_Q=0.649>structured grid</phrase>(<phrase_Q=0.812>s</phrase>)and a subsequent <phrase_Q=0.828>digitalization</phrase> of the constituent tetrahedrons using an adaptation of the 3D-<phrase_Q=0.806>Bresenham</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.526>Advantages and disadvantages</phrase> of this approach as compared to other possible schemes are discussed. An implementation based on our <phrase_Q=1.000>open source</phrase> f3d-<phrase_Q=1.000>file format</phrase> for storage and transmission of <phrase_Q=0.895>volumetric data</phrase> is presented, and <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> it to <phrase_Q=0.639>real-world data</phrase> shown.
<phrase_Q=0.794>Interactive Walkthroughs</phrase> using "Morphable 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>Mosaics</phrase>".
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a <phrase_Q=1.000>hybrid</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase>- & <phrase_Q=0.851>image-based</phrase>) technique suitable for providing <phrase_Q=0.794>interactive walkthroughs</phrase> of large, complex <phrase_Q=0.840>outdoor</phrase> scenes. Motion is <phrase_Q=0.808>restricted</phrase> along a smooth predefined path and the input to the system is a <phrase_Q=0.838>sparse</phrase> set of <phrase_Q=1.000>stereoscopic</phrase> views at certain points (key-positions) along that path (one view per position). An <phrase_Q=0.836>approximate</phrase> local 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is constructed from each view, capable of capturing <phrase_Q=1.000>photometric</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> properties of the scene only locally. Then during the rendering process, a <phrase_Q=0.803>continuous</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>morphing</phrase> (both <phrase_Q=1.000>photometric</phrase> & <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.822>takes place</phrase> between successive local 3D models, using what we call a "morphable 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>". The <phrase_Q=1.000>morphing</phrase> proceeds in a <phrase_Q=0.751>physically-valid</phrase> way. For this reason, a <phrase_Q=0.563>wide-baseline image matching</phrase> technique is proposed, <phrase_Q=0.811>handling</phrase> cases where the <phrase_Q=0.928>wide baseline</phrase> between the two images is mainly due to a <phrase_Q=0.805>looming</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>. Our system can be <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> in the event of multiple <phrase_Q=1.000>stereoscopic</phrase> views (and therefore multiple <phrase_Q=0.680>local models</phrase>) per key-position of the path (related by a <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> rotation). In that case one local 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>mosaic</phrase> (per key-position) is constructed comprising all local 3D models therein and a "morphable 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>mosaic</phrase>" is used during the rendering process. A <phrase_Q=1.000>partial-differential equation</phrase> is adopted to handle the problem of <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> consistency of each 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>mosaic</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.822>Color</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>Fusion</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereopsis</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=0.795>Graph Cut based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.819>Adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.944>Structured Light</phrase> Approach for <phrase_Q=0.662>Real-Time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>Acquisition</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes a new <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> that yields <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> maps in real-time.Reconstruction are based on a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> illumination.On-the-<phrase_Q=1.000>fly</phrase> adaptation of the <phrase_Q=0.821>projection</phrase> pattern renders the system more <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> against scene variability. A <phrase_Q=0.803>continuous</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>trade</phrase> off between speed and quality is made. The <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> problem is solved by using <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> pattern coding in combination with <phrase_Q=0.838>sparse</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> coding. Only <phrase_Q=0.544>local spatial</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase> continuity are assumed. This allows to construct a <phrase_Q=0.608>neighbor relationship</phrase> within every <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase> and to <phrase_Q=1.000>track</phrase> correspondences over time.All cues are integrated in one consistent labeling.This is achieved by <phrase_Q=0.880>reformulating</phrase> the problem as a <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase> cut.Every <phrase_Q=0.804>cue</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.835>weighted</phrase> based on its <phrase_Q=1.000>average</phrase> consistency with the result within a small time window.Integration and <phrase_Q=0.814>weighting</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.547>additional cues</phrase> is straightforward. The correctness of the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> maps is not guaranteed, but an estimation of the uncertainty is provided for each part of the reconstruction.Our <phrase_Q=1.000>prototype</phrase> is implemented using unmodified <phrase_Q=1.000>consumer</phrase> hardware only.Frame rates vary between 10 and 25fps dependent on <phrase_Q=0.646>scene complexity</phrase>.
3D Volume Extraction and <phrase_Q=0.935>Mesh Generation</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.967>Energy Minimization</phrase> Techniques.
<phrase_Q=0.870>Multi-Spectral</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.837>Stereo Image</phrase> Matching using <phrase_Q=1.000>Mutual Information</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Mutual information</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.845>MI</phrase>) has <phrase_Q=0.507>shown promise</phrase> as an effective <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> matching measure for images affected by <phrase_Q=1.000>radiometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>distortion</phrase>. This is due to the robustness of <phrase_Q=0.845>MI</phrase> against changes in illumination. However, <phrase_Q=0.613>MI-based</phrase> approaches are particularly prone to the <phrase_Q=0.801>generation</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.832>false matches</phrase> due to the small <phrase_Q=1.000>statistical power</phrase> of the matching <phrase_Q=1.000>windows</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.811>Consequently</phrase>, most previous <phrase_Q=0.845>MI</phrase> approaches utilise large matching <phrase_Q=1.000>windows</phrase> which smooth the estimated <phrase_Q=0.702>disparity field</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> proposes extensions to <phrase_Q=0.613>MI-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> matching in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to increase the robustness of the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.813>Firstly</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.933>prior probabilities</phrase> are incorporated into the <phrase_Q=0.845>MI</phrase> measure in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.522>considerably increase</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>statistical power</phrase> of the matching <phrase_Q=1.000>windows</phrase>. These <phrase_Q=0.933>prior probabilities</phrase>, which are calculated from the <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.828>joint</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>histogram</phrase> between the <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> pair, are tuned to a <phrase_Q=0.584>two level</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> approach. A 2D match surface, in which the <phrase_Q=0.879>match score</phrase> is computed for every possible combination of template and matching window, is also utilised. This enforces <phrase_Q=0.741>left-right</phrase> consistency and <phrase_Q=0.827>uniqueness</phrase> constraints. These additions to <phrase_Q=0.613>MI-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> matching <phrase_Q=0.719>significantly enhance</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.677>algorithm's ability</phrase> to detect <phrase_Q=0.626>correct matches</phrase> while decreasing computation time and <phrase_Q=0.802>improving</phrase> the accuracy. <phrase_Q=1.000>Results</phrase> show that the <phrase_Q=0.845>MI</phrase> measure does not perform quite as well for standard <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> pairs when compared to traditional <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase>-based metrics. However, the <phrase_Q=0.845>MI</phrase> approach is far <phrase_Q=1.000>superior</phrase> when matching across <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-spectra <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> pairs.

Challenges related to viewpoint <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>forest</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.843>terrain</phrase> can be quite different compared to those faced in <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> environments. Manoeuvring the <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> between measurement positions introduces large error into the a priori estimates of the <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> coordinates. As a consequence, <phrase_Q=0.910>locally optimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> methods may not work properly. Moreover, due to the clutter, the <phrase_Q=0.532>scene contents</phrase> can change substantially even due to a relative small displacement of the <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase>. Often, the <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> has to be moved to the other side of the <phrase_Q=1.000>target</phrase> object, such as a <phrase_Q=0.805>group</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>trees</phrase>, to get a good coverage of its <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase>. In both cases, overlap between the two 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> sets will be <phrase_Q=0.814>minimal</phrase> ruling out conventional <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> methods. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=0.879>feature-based</phrase> method for registering 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> scans for <phrase_Q=0.828>mapping</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.581>natural outdoor</phrase> environments is proposed. The method utilizes <phrase_Q=0.824>cylindrical</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.821>rotation symmetric</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.583>features extracted</phrase> from the 3D <phrase_Q=0.737>measurement data</phrase> for viewpoint <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase>. The method is tested on real <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images.
<phrase_Q=0.842>Multiresolution</phrase> Distance Volumes for <phrase_Q=0.851>Progressive</phrase> Surface Compression.
<phrase_Q=0.851>Progressive</phrase> Compression of <phrase_Q=0.835>Volumetric</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.737>Subdivision Meshes</phrase>.
We present a <phrase_Q=0.824>progressive compression</phrase> technique for <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.737>subdivision meshes</phrase> based on the <phrase_Q=0.769>slow growing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>refinement</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. The system is comprised of a <phrase_Q=1.000>wavelet transform</phrase> followed by a <phrase_Q=0.851>progressive</phrase> encoding of the resulting <phrase_Q=1.000>wavelet</phrase> coefficients. We compare the efficiency of two <phrase_Q=1.000>wavelet</phrase> transforms. The <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> transform is based on the <phrase_Q=0.805>smoothing</phrase> rules used in the <phrase_Q=0.769>slow growing</phrase> subdivision technique. The <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> transform is a <phrase_Q=0.820>generalization</phrase> of lifted linear <phrase_Q=0.561>B-spline wavelets</phrase> to the same <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-tier <phrase_Q=0.821>refinement</phrase> structure. <phrase_Q=0.811>Direct</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>coupling</phrase> with a <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> coder produces <phrase_Q=0.851>progressive</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>bit</phrase> streams. <phrase_Q=0.928>Rate distortion</phrase> metrics are evaluated for both <phrase_Q=1.000>wavelet</phrase> transforms. We tested the <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> performance of the scheme on <phrase_Q=0.775>synthetic data</phrase> as well as <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.833>indirect</phrase>-drive <phrase_Q=1.000>fusion</phrase> simulations with <phrase_Q=0.537>multiple fields</phrase> per vertex. Both <phrase_Q=1.000>wavelet</phrase> transforms result in <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> quality <phrase_Q=1.000>trade</phrase> off curves and produce qualitatively good coarse representations.

<phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Euclidean</phrase> Planes from Voxels.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we aim to formulate the recognition of a planes from a discrete <phrase_Q=0.879>point set</phrase> as a <phrase_Q=0.824>nonlinear</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>optimization problem</phrase>, and we prove a <phrase_Q=0.713>uniqueness theorem</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> of this problem. We deal with the <phrase_Q=0.835>supercover</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> in a space for the expression of <phrase_Q=0.809>discrete planes</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> achieves <phrase_Q=0.835>invertible</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> compression of <phrase_Q=1.000>digital</phrase> objects, since the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> transforms a collection voxels to a collection of <phrase_Q=0.515>plane parameters</phrase>, which classify the voxels.
Thickness <phrase_Q=1.000>Histogram</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.809>Statistical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Harmonic</phrase> Representation for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>Retrieval</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.616>Similarity measuring</phrase> is a key problem for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose a novel <phrase_Q=0.943>shape descriptor</phrase> "Thickness <phrase_Q=1.000>Histogram</phrase>" (<phrase_Q=0.859>TH</phrase>) by uniformly <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> thickness of a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> using <phrase_Q=1.000>statistical methods</phrase>. It is <phrase_Q=1.000>translation</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.958>rotation-invariant</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.835>discriminative</phrase> to different shapes, and very <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> to compute with the <phrase_Q=0.620>Shape Distribution</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.866>SD</phrase>) proposed by Osada etc. For <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> performance of the <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase>, we propose a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> method for <phrase_Q=0.820>translating</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.843>directional</phrase> form of the <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> distribution to the <phrase_Q=1.000>harmonic</phrase> representation. By summing up energies at different <phrase_Q=1.000>frequencies</phrase>, a matrix <phrase_Q=0.772>shape signature</phrase> is formed to provide an exhaustive <phrase_Q=0.808>characterization</phrase> of 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase>. Experiments show that the performance of the <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>harmonic</phrase> representation is among the <phrase_Q=0.820>top</phrase> ones of existing <phrase_Q=0.943>shape descriptors</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.661>Motion-induced</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.970>error correction</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.958>ultrasound imaging</phrase>.
3D <phrase_Q=0.541>Image Sensing</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>Bit</phrase> Plane Method of <phrase_Q=0.851>Progressive</phrase> Transmission.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Image Compression</phrase> has received a <phrase_Q=0.823>lot</phrase> of interest over the years. Almost all the <phrase_Q=0.768>compression algorithms</phrase> and standards, discussed in <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.513>gather statistics</phrase> and compress on the complete image and compresses to suit various requirements such as <phrase_Q=1.000>lossy</phrase> / <phrase_Q=0.847>lossless</phrase>, baseline/<phrase_Q=0.851>progressive</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> on interest. <phrase_Q=0.899>Natural images</phrase> such as <phrase_Q=0.877>gray scale images</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> images are best <phrase_Q=0.819>compressed</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.618>existing literature</phrase> based on the local and <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> properties such as attributes of constituent <phrase_Q=1.000>pixels</phrase> of the given image. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, it is proposed to quantize the amplitudes of <phrase_Q=1.000>pixel</phrase> values to form a number of <phrase_Q=1.000>bit</phrase> planes and these <phrase_Q=1.000>bit</phrase> planes are transmitted in either <phrase_Q=1.000>lossy</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.847>lossless</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.851>progressive</phrase> manner. <phrase_Q=1.000>Bit</phrase> plane formation is attempted from the image <phrase_Q=0.803>acquiring</phrase> stage to compress and then to transmission stage. <phrase_Q=1.000>Results</phrase> obtained are promising and give <phrase_Q=0.832>rise</phrase> to new method or <phrase_Q=1.000>ideology</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.541>image sensing</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.803>acquiring</phrase>, storage and transmission.
Small <phrase_Q=1.000>CPU</phrase> Times and <phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Interactivity</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>Sonar</phrase> Seabottom Surveys.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Sonar</phrase> profiling of the seabottom provide 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> sets that can <phrase_Q=1.000>cover</phrase> huge survey areas with many gaps. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes a <phrase_Q=0.842>multiresolution</phrase> framework or <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> pipeline that is being optimized for dealing with such <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.548>taking into account</phrase> both the <phrase_Q=1.000>CPU</phrase> time and the <phrase_Q=0.726>user interactivity</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes the techniques employed: (a) the <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>quadtree</phrase> that allows to eliminate gaps by <phrase_Q=1.000>interpolating</phrase> available 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, (<phrase_Q=0.820>b</phrase>) a <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> but coarse <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> at a <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>tree</phrase> level in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to rapidly change or adjust the <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> of interest, and (<phrase_Q=0.839>c</phrase>) a very <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>triangulation</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> reduction) that allows for a <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>interactivity</phrase> even at the highest detail level. By using one <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>octree</phrase>, all processing can be combined because (1) gaps can be filled by <phrase_Q=1.000>interpolation</phrase> since they are smaller at higher <phrase_Q=1.000>tree</phrase> levels, and (2) <phrase_Q=0.935>connected components</phrase> can be projected down the <phrase_Q=1.000>tree</phrase> and refined using the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> available there. As a result, <phrase_Q=0.749>huge data sets</phrase> can be visualized in near <phrase_Q=0.802>realtime</phrase> on normally-sized discrete <phrase_Q=0.846>grids</phrase> using shading instead of <phrase_Q=1.000>wire</phrase>-frames, and this enables a <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> searching for objects in the seabottom. Real <phrase_Q=1.000>CPU</phrase> times are presented for a real <phrase_Q=1.000>sonar</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> set which is visualized at a <phrase_Q=0.935>low resolution</phrase>, showing the overall shape of the seabottom, and at a <phrase_Q=0.931>high resolution</phrase>, showing a (<phrase_Q=0.819>semi</phrase>-)<phrase_Q=0.826>buried</phrase> pipeline. In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to detect an object at such a <phrase_Q=0.931>high resolution</phrase> additional techniques are applied to the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>: (a) an interslice <phrase_Q=1.000>interpolation</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.858>cope</phrase> with the increased <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> sparseness and (<phrase_Q=0.820>b</phrase>) a maximum-homogeneity filtering in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.858>cope</phrase> with the decreased <phrase_Q=1.000>signal-to-noise-ratio</phrase>. After the extraction of the pipeline a <phrase_Q=0.805>thinning</phrase> technique is applied in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to be able to quantify its length.
<phrase_Q=0.814>Visualizing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.617>I/O</phrase> Predictability.

This approach gives a new <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> of models which have the structure of the drawn <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> but the movement of the captured <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase>.

Filling the <phrase_Q=0.905>Signed Distance</phrase> Field by Fitting Local <phrase_Q=0.860>Quadrics</phrase>.

We solve this problem by iteratively fitting <phrase_Q=1.000>quadratic function</phrase> to generate smoothly connected <phrase_Q=1.000>SDF</phrase>. We analyzed the relationship between the <phrase_Q=0.816>quadratic</phrase> coefficients and the <phrase_Q=0.939>surface curvature</phrase>, and by using the coefficients, we evenly propagated the <phrase_Q=1.000>SDF</phrase> so that it satisfies the constraints of the field. The <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> was tested on <phrase_Q=0.500>synthetic data and real</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> that was generated by <phrase_Q=0.733>integrating multiple</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images.

At <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> surface is <phrase_Q=0.814>partitioned</phrase> into <phrase_Q=0.555>small blocks</phrase> and points in each block are reorganized into error-controlled LODs by <phrase_Q=1.000>hierarchical clustering</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>LOD</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>organization</phrase>. In the <phrase_Q=0.822>interactive</phrase> rendering process, a <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>block scheduling</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is used to realize the <phrase_Q=0.921>view-dependent</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>paging</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show that the <phrase_Q=0.843>viewer</phrase> can perform <phrase_Q=0.907>interactive visualization</phrase> of huge point models on <phrase_Q=1.000>commodity</phrase> graphics platforms with ease.

<phrase_Q=0.819>Adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.926>Space Carving</phrase>.
In this work, we present <phrase_Q=0.531>an adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.926>space carving</phrase> method for <phrase_Q=0.926>scene reconstruction</phrase> from a set of images obtained from <phrase_Q=0.921>low cost</phrase> calibrated webcams. Our method uses a combination of <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>photometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> to efficiently carve the shape of the observed scene out of a <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> space represented by an <phrase_Q=1.000>octree</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data structure</phrase>. In this method different resolutions are considered both in <phrase_Q=0.809>object space</phrase> and in <phrase_Q=0.837>image space</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>led</phrase> us to adopt a strategy in which the <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> used by the <phrase_Q=0.806>photo</phrase>-consistency <phrase_Q=1.000>test</phrase> is registered in scene space by <phrase_Q=1.000>projective</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>texture mapping</phrase>. Another <phrase_Q=0.541>important question</phrase> addressed in this work is the <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> level of noise present in <phrase_Q=0.921>low cost</phrase> webcams. To deal with this problem we devised a <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>photo</phrase>-consistency <phrase_Q=1.000>test</phrase> that uses <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> estimators for the noise introduced by the sensors of the cameras.
<phrase_Q=0.827>Dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.667>Multiple View Stereo</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>General</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Camera</phrase> Placement using <phrase_Q=0.970>Tensor Voting</phrase>.
We present a <phrase_Q=0.647>computational framework</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.818>inference</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> descriptions from <phrase_Q=0.667>multiple view stereo</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> placement. Thus far <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.667>multiple view stereo</phrase> has evolved along three axes: computation of scene approximations in the form of <phrase_Q=0.937>visual hulls</phrase>; merging of <phrase_Q=0.926>depth maps</phrase> derived from simple configurations, such as <phrase_Q=1.000>binocular</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.850>trinocular</phrase>; and <phrase_Q=0.667>multiple view stereo</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.808>restricted</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> placement. These approaches are either <phrase_Q=0.517>sub-optimal</phrase>, since they do not maximize the use of available <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>, or cannot be applied to <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> configurations. Our approach does not involve <phrase_Q=1.000>binocular</phrase> processing other than the detection of <phrase_Q=0.802>tentative</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>pixel</phrase> correspondences. We require <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> for all cameras and that there exist <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> pairs which enable <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>pixel</phrase> matching. The <phrase_Q=0.818>inference</phrase> of scene surfaces is based on the premise that correct <phrase_Q=1.000>pixel</phrase> correspondences, reconstructed in 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase>, form salient, coherent surfaces, while wrong correspondences form less <phrase_Q=0.797>coherent structures</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.970>tensor voting</phrase> framework is suitable for this task since it can process the <phrase_Q=0.548>very large</phrase> datasets we generate with reasonable <phrase_Q=1.000>computational complexity</phrase>. We show <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.673>real images</phrase> that present <phrase_Q=0.641>numerous challenges</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>Acquisition</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> Images.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.954>Surface Reconstruction</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we illustrate an <phrase_Q=0.806>innovative</phrase> method which estimates the surfaces -modelled as <phrase_Q=0.969>polygonal meshes</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.829>bounding</phrase> objects present in a scene, viewed by arbitrarily placed cameras. We present a Montecarlo <phrase_Q=0.501>based iterative</phrase> approach which, at every step, increases its <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> about the scene <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> the unknown volume around the <phrase_Q=0.509>current estimation</phrase>. Then, the samples which mostly appear to be consistent with the measurements are used to extend the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> representing the surface. The <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.844>regularized</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.726>filter -based</phrase> on a <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> system- to the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase>. This operation will preserve the <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>curvature</phrase> areas of the surface, while <phrase_Q=0.805>smoothing</phrase> away the noise in the estimation.
A Non <phrase_Q=0.852>Causal</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> Framework for <phrase_Q=0.933>Object Tracking</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.928>Occlusion Handling</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.803>Synthesis</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereoscopic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Video</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a framework for the <phrase_Q=0.803>synthesis</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>stereoscopic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> using as input only a monoscopic <phrase_Q=0.919>image sequence</phrase>. Initially, <phrase_Q=0.922>bi-directional</phrase> 2D <phrase_Q=0.957>motion estimation</phrase> is performed, which is followed by <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> method for the <phrase_Q=0.814>reliable</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.865>object contours</phrase>. Rigid 3D motion and structure is recovered utilizing <phrase_Q=0.860>extended Kalman filtering</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, occlusions are dealt with a novel <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> framework, which exploits future <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> to correctly reconstruct <phrase_Q=0.670>occluded areas</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.864>Experimental evaluation</phrase> shows that the <phrase_Q=0.858>layered</phrase> object <phrase_Q=0.879>scene representation</phrase>, combined with the proposed methods for <phrase_Q=0.933>object tracking</phrase> throughout the <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.928>occlusion handling</phrase>, yields very <phrase_Q=0.556>accurate results</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.818>Exploring</phrase> Boundary Concavities in <phrase_Q=0.823>Active</phrase> Contours and Surfaces.
<phrase_Q=0.823>Active</phrase> contours and surfaces are <phrase_Q=0.947>deformable models</phrase> used for 2D and 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>image segmentation</phrase>. These models <phrase_Q=0.521>generally lack</phrase> of convergence into boundary concavities, when <phrase_Q=0.811>segmenting</phrase> highly concave objects. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose a method for <phrase_Q=0.818>exploring</phrase> concavities, applicable on discrete <phrase_Q=0.823>active</phrase> contours and surfaces deformed thanks to the <phrase_Q=1.000>greedy algorithm</phrase>, which minimizes the <phrase_Q=1.000>energy</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.811>functional</phrase>. As a basis of this method, we introduce the <phrase_Q=1.000>gradient</phrase> line <phrase_Q=1.000>energy</phrase> (GLE), which goal is to make discrete parts of the surface coincide with boundaries, and the <phrase_Q=0.802>exploration</phrase> force, computed from this <phrase_Q=1.000>energy</phrase>, driving the surface into the object concavities. Our method lies on a <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> framework, enabling application on discrete 2D contours and 3D meshes with easy adaptation between both models.
<phrase_Q=0.811>Segmenting</phrase> Correlation <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images using <phrase_Q=0.618>Surface Elements</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes methods for <phrase_Q=0.811>segmenting</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> surfaces from <phrase_Q=0.806>noisy</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> obtained from correlation <phrase_Q=0.973>stereo vision</phrase>. We make use of local <phrase_Q=0.839>planar surface</phrase> elements called patchlets. Patchlets have 3D position, orientation and size parameters. As well, they have <phrase_Q=0.827>positional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.905>confidence measures</phrase> based on the <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. Patchlet orientations (i.e., <phrase_Q=0.912>surface normals</phrase>) provide important additional dimensionality that reduces the ambiguity of segmentation-by-<phrase_Q=0.832>clustering</phrase>. Patchlet size allows the use of continuity or coverage constraints when <phrase_Q=0.811>segmenting</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.802>bounded</phrase> surfaces from <phrase_Q=0.804>depth images</phrase>. We use a <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase>-growing approach to identify the number of surfaces that exist in a <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> image and obtain an <phrase_Q=0.507>initial estimate</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.574>surface parameters</phrase>. We refine segmentation using a <phrase_Q=1.000>maximum likelihood</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.832>clustering</phrase> approach that is <phrase_Q=0.809>optimised</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.947>Expectation-Maximisation</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.905>Confidence measures</phrase> on the patchlet parameters allow proper <phrase_Q=0.814>weighting</phrase> of patchlet contributions to the <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase>. We provide <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> of the segmentation on complex <phrase_Q=0.840>outdoor</phrase> scenes.
Viewpoint Consistent <phrase_Q=0.961>Texture Synthesis</phrase>.
The purpose of this work is to synthesize textures of <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.885>real world</phrase> surfaces under <phrase_Q=0.693>freely chosen</phrase> viewing and <phrase_Q=0.668>illumination directions</phrase>. Moreover, such textures are <phrase_Q=1.000>produced</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.837>continuously changing</phrase> directions in such a way that the different textures are <phrase_Q=0.833>mutually consistent</phrase>, i.e. emulate the same piece of surface. This is necessary for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>animation</phrase>. It is assumed that the mesostructure (<phrase_Q=0.904>small-scale</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> of a surface is not known, and that the only input consists of a set of images, taken under different viewing and <phrase_Q=0.668>illumination directions</phrase>. These are automatically aligned to build an appropriate <phrase_Q=0.837>Bidirectional</phrase> Texture <phrase_Q=1.000>Function</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.841>BTF</phrase>). Directly <phrase_Q=0.813>extending</phrase> 2D <phrase_Q=0.803>synthesis</phrase> methods for <phrase_Q=1.000>pixels</phrase> to complete <phrase_Q=0.841>BTF</phrase> columns has drawbacks which are exposed, and a <phrase_Q=1.000>superior</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.830>sequential</phrase> but <phrase_Q=0.883>highly parallelizable</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is proposed. Examples demonstrate the quality of the <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase>.
A Hierarchy of Cameras for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Photography</phrase>.
The <phrase_Q=0.784>view-independent</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> of 3D scenes is most often based on rendering accurate 3D models or utilizes <phrase_Q=0.893>image-based rendering</phrase> techniques. To compute the 3D structure of a scene from a moving <phrase_Q=0.900>vision sensor</phrase> or to use <phrase_Q=0.851>image-based</phrase> rendering approaches, we need to be able to estimate the motion of the <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> from the recorded <phrase_Q=0.525>image information</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> accuracy, a problem that has been well-studied. In this work, we investigate the relationship between <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> and our ability to perform accurate 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>photography</phrase>, by <phrase_Q=0.810>examining</phrase> the influence of <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> on the estimation of the motion and structure of a scene from <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. By <phrase_Q=0.805>relating</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.806>differential</phrase> structure of the <phrase_Q=0.630>time varying</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.646>plenoptic function</phrase> to different known and new <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> designs, we can establish a hierarchy of cameras based upon the <phrase_Q=0.809>stability</phrase> and complexity of the computations necessary to estimate <phrase_Q=0.508>structure and motion</phrase>. At the <phrase_Q=0.848>low end</phrase> of this hierarchy is the standard <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>pinhole camera</phrase> for which the <phrase_Q=0.625>structure from motion</phrase> problem is <phrase_Q=0.542>non-linear</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.691>ill-posed</phrase>. At the <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> end is a <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>, which we call the full <phrase_Q=0.534>field of view</phrase> polydioptric <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>, for which the <phrase_Q=0.957>motion estimation</phrase> problem can be <phrase_Q=0.627>solved independently</phrase> of the depth of the scene which leads to <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Photography</phrase>. In between are <phrase_Q=0.860>multiple view</phrase> cameras with a large <phrase_Q=0.534>field of view</phrase> which we have built, as well as <phrase_Q=0.945>omni-directional</phrase> sensors.
<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.824>Passive</phrase> Recovery of 3D from Images and <phrase_Q=1.000>Video</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> gives a <phrase_Q=0.856>summary</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.824>passive</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of 3D scenes from images and <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase>. Features are tracked between the images. Relative <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> poses are then estimated based on the feature tracks. Both the <phrase_Q=0.894>feature tracking</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> method used to estimate the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> poses has <phrase_Q=0.815>recently</phrase> been shown to provide <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> performance. Given the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> poses, a more elaborate method is used to derive <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.951>textured surfaces</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> method was originally part of the authors <phrase_Q=1.000>thesis</phrase> [<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.827>Dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.852>Uncalibrated Video Sequences</phrase>]. It <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> computesdepth maps using <phrase_Q=0.966>graph cuts</phrase>, optimizing a <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> formulation. The <phrase_Q=0.921>graph cut</phrase> operation is used to <phrase_Q=0.828>let</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.946>depth map</phrase> hypotheses from various sources compete in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to optimize the <phrase_Q=0.840>cost function</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>hypothesis</phrase> generators used are <phrase_Q=0.879>feature based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.840>surface triangulation</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.816>plane fitting</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>hypothesis</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-scale <phrase_Q=0.881>patch-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase>. The requirements for a <phrase_Q=0.840>cost function</phrase> to fit into the <phrase_Q=0.921>graph cut</phrase> framework were already given in [<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.827>Dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.852>Uncalibrated Video Sequences</phrase>], along with a procedure for <phrase_Q=0.808>constructing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase> weights corresponding to any <phrase_Q=0.840>cost function</phrase> that satisfies the requirements. <phrase_Q=0.926>Depth maps</phrase> from many different viewpoints are then robustly fused to give a consistent <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> result using a process called <phrase_Q=0.837>median</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>fusion</phrase>. The robustness of the <phrase_Q=0.837>median</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>fusion</phrase> is important. It departs from the too <phrase_Q=0.726>common practice</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.828>fusing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> by either using the <phrase_Q=1.000>union</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase>-space constraints as the resulting <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase>-space, or the <phrase_Q=1.000>union</phrase> of all predicted surfaces as the resulting surfaces, which is tremendously <phrase_Q=0.884>error-prone</phrase>, since it essentially corresponds to taking either the <phrase_Q=0.815>minimum</phrase> or maximum of the individual <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase>.
Heterogeneous <phrase_Q=0.762>Deformation Model</phrase> for 3D Shape and <phrase_Q=0.804>Motion Recovery</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-Viewpoint Images.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a framework for <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> 3D shape and <phrase_Q=0.667>motion reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-viewpoint images using a <phrase_Q=0.870>deformable mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. By deforming a <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> at a <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase> to that at the <phrase_Q=0.822>next</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase>, we can obtain both 3D shape and motion of the object simultaneously. The deformation process of our <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is heterogeneous. Each vertex changes its deformation process according to its 1) <phrase_Q=1.000>photometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>property</phrase> (i.e., if it has prominent texture or not), and 2) <phrase_Q=1.000>physical property</phrase> (i.e., if it is an element of rigid part of the object or not). This heterogeneous <phrase_Q=0.762>deformation model</phrase> enables us to reconstruct the object which consists of different kinds of materials or parts with different <phrase_Q=0.721>motion models</phrase>, e.g., rigidly acting <phrase_Q=0.924>body parts</phrase> and deforming <phrase_Q=0.845>soft</phrase> clothes or its skins, by a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.826>unified</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.647>computational framework</phrase>.
The Influence of Shape on <phrase_Q=0.825>Image Correspondence</phrase>.
We examine the implications of shape on the process of finding <phrase_Q=0.876>dense correspondence</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.764>half-occlusions</phrase> for a <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> pair of images. The desired <phrase_Q=1.000>property</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.946>depth map</phrase> is that it should be a <phrase_Q=1.000>piecewise</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>continuous function</phrase> which is consistent with the images and which has the <phrase_Q=0.815>minimum</phrase> number of discontinuities. To zeroeth <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>piecewise</phrase> continuity becomes <phrase_Q=1.000>piecewise</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.800>constancy</phrase>. Using this approximation, we <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> discuss an approach for dealing with such a <phrase_Q=0.775>fronto-parallel</phrase> shapeless world, and the problems involved therein. We then introduce <phrase_Q=0.620>horizontal and vertical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>slant</phrase> to create a <phrase_Q=0.634>first order</phrase> approximation to <phrase_Q=1.000>piecewise</phrase> continuity. We highlight the <phrase_Q=0.814>fact</phrase> that a horizontally slanted surface (<phrase_Q=0.832>ie</phrase>. having depth variation in the direction of the <phrase_Q=0.820>separation</phrase> of the two cameras) will appear horizontally <phrase_Q=0.812>stretched</phrase> in one image as compared to the other image. Thus, while corresponding two images, N <phrase_Q=1.000>pixels</phrase> on a scanline in one image may correspond to a different number of <phrase_Q=1.000>pixels</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>M</phrase> in the other image, which has consequences with regard to <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.858>occlusion detection</phrase>. We also discuss the asymmetry between <phrase_Q=0.817>vertical</phrase> and horizontal <phrase_Q=1.000>slant</phrase>, and the central role of non-<phrase_Q=0.736>horizontal edges</phrase> in the context of <phrase_Q=0.817>vertical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>slant</phrase>. Using experiments, we discuss cases where <phrase_Q=0.591>existing algorithms</phrase> fail, and how the incorporation of new constraints provides correct <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.818>Registration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images that Preserves <phrase_Q=0.643>Local Surface</phrase> Structures and <phrase_Q=0.822>Color</phrase>.
We propose an <phrase_Q=1.000>ICP</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.601>based registration</phrase> method for <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images that preserves fundamental features, i.e., <phrase_Q=0.619>local structures</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase>, of <phrase_Q=0.710>object surfaces</phrase>. The method employs local surfaces as an attribute for establishing <phrase_Q=0.506>correspondences between</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images where local surfaces are evaluated geometrically and photometrically. In <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.506>correspondences between</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images, our method evaluates consistency of shape patterns and <phrase_Q=1.000>chromaticity</phrase> of local surfaces together. In <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.585>transformation parameters</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.805>relating</phrase> the coordinates between different <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images, on the other hand, our method evaluates <phrase_Q=1.000>skewness</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>chromaticity</phrase> of correspondences. These two kinds of evaluation enhances accuracy of the estimation and <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> in preserving <phrase_Q=0.619>local structures</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.710>object surfaces</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Construction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Animal</phrase> Models and <phrase_Q=0.893>Motion Synthesis</phrase> in 3D <phrase_Q=0.805>Virtual</phrase> Environments using <phrase_Q=0.949>Image Sequences</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we describe a system that can build 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>animal</phrase> models and synthesize animations in 3D <phrase_Q=0.960>virtual environments</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is constructed by 2D <phrase_Q=0.734>images captured</phrase> by specific views. The <phrase_Q=1.000>animation</phrase> is synthesised by using <phrase_Q=0.590>physical motion</phrase> models of the <phrase_Q=1.000>animal</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.949>image sequences</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, the user selects some points of the 3D world and a smooth and <phrase_Q=0.841>safe</phrase> motion path, which <phrase_Q=1.000>passes</phrase> by these points, is created. The main assumption of the 3D <phrase_Q=0.812>modelling</phrase> is that the <phrase_Q=1.000>animal</phrase> could be <phrase_Q=0.515>divided into</phrase> parts whose normal sections are ellipses. Joints and angles between <phrase_Q=1.000>skeleton</phrase> points are used in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to decrease models complexity. Using the above methodology, a <phrase_Q=1.000>snake</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=1.000>lizard</phrase> and a <phrase_Q=1.000>goat</phrase> are reconstructed.
The <phrase_Q=0.805>Virtual</phrase> Boutique: a Synergic Approach to <phrase_Q=1.000>Virtualization</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.876>Content-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Management</phrase> of 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Information</phrase>, 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Data Mining</phrase> an <phrase_Q=1.000>Virtual Reality</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>E-commerce</phrase>.
Specularity <phrase_Q=0.824>Elimination</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Sensing for Accurate 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Specular</phrase> Objects.
We present a novel <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> sensing method that is capable of <phrase_Q=0.808>constructing</phrase> accurate 3Dmodels of <phrase_Q=1.000>specular</phrase> objects. Our method utilizes a new <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase> concept called <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>peak</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase>, which accounts for the effects of mutual <phrase_Q=0.819>reflections</phrase>. False measurements generated by mutual <phrase_Q=0.819>reflections</phrase> are then eliminated by <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> a series of constraint <phrase_Q=1.000>tests</phrase> based on <phrase_Q=0.772>local smoothness</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> coordinate consistency and <phrase_Q=0.807>visibility</phrase> consistency. We show the usefulness of our method by <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> the method to three <phrase_Q=0.714>real objects</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>specular</phrase> surfaces. The <phrase_Q=0.706>ground truth data</phrase> for those three objects were also acquired in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to evaluate the <phrase_Q=0.824>elimination</phrase> of false measurements and to justify the selection of the parameters in the constraint <phrase_Q=1.000>tests</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> indicate that our method <phrase_Q=0.768>significantly improves</phrase> upon the <phrase_Q=0.634>traditional methods</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.521>constructing reliable</phrase> 3D models of <phrase_Q=1.000>specular</phrase> objects with <phrase_Q=0.712>complex shapes</phrase>.

3D <phrase_Q=0.542>Non-Linear</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>Invisible</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.936>Boundary Detection</phrase> Filters.

Detection and Compensation of <phrase_Q=0.919>Image Sequence</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Jitter</phrase> Due to an Unstable <phrase_Q=1.000>CCD Camera</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>Video</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>Tracking</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.925>Moving Target</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.813>Nowadays</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.767>image motion</phrase> analysis is considered as a significant subject in <phrase_Q=1.000>image processing</phrase> and according to its characteristics is <phrase_Q=0.515>divided into</phrase> different categories. Surface <phrase_Q=1.000>Illuminance</phrase> Flow.
We introduce the concept of "surface <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminance</phrase> flow" in two steps.First we reiterate the notion of the "<phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>vector</phrase>", then we proceed to decompose the <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>vector</phrase> into a scalar "normal <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminance</phrase>" and a <phrase_Q=1.000>vector</phrase> "surface <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminance</phrase> flow".The scalar normal <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminance</phrase> generates the familiar <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminance</phrase> pattern that is often known as the "shading".The <phrase_Q=1.000>vector</phrase> surface <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminance</phrase> flow is irrelevant for <phrase_Q=0.928>smooth surfaces</phrase> (which probably explains why it is <phrase_Q=0.837>conventionally</phrase> ignored) but it generates the texture due to surface mesorelief.We show how observation of the <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminance</phrase> induced texture leads to <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> inferences of the surface <phrase_Q=0.804>illuminance flow</phrase> direction <phrase_Q=1.000>modulo</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.620>180°</phrase>. This makes surface <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminance</phrase> flow a <phrase_Q=1.000>property</phrase> that is <phrase_Q=1.000>observable</phrase> in natural scenes.Muchl <phrase_Q=0.878>ike</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>optical flow</phrase>, the surface <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminance</phrase> flow is largely due to a <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>property</phrase> that exists <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.780>local structure</phrase>, namely the direction of the <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>illuminating</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>beam</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>sunlight</phrase> or <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> from the overcast <phrase_Q=0.821>sky</phrase> in a typical outdoors scene).However, due to the <phrase_Q=0.814>fact</phrase> that there exists "true <phrase_Q=0.828>screening</phrase>" in <phrase_Q=1.000>radiometry</phrase> (thus removing any hope for a "<phrase_Q=1.000>field theory</phrase>" of <phrase_Q=1.000>radiometry</phrase>) the local <phrase_Q=0.775>scene structure</phrase> has an influence on the local <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> field.Such "<phrase_Q=1.000>vignetting</phrase>" is a main cause of the complexity of <phrase_Q=1.000>radiometry</phrase>, the other cause being the ever present multiple scatterings.This complicates <phrase_Q=0.800>matters</phrase> but also introduces additional sources of information.We illustrate instances of the observation of <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminance</phrase> flow in scenes.We also present a <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> base of roughly <phrase_Q=0.832>spherical</phrase> objects, <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminated</phrase> in a number of standard ways that we have used to study <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminance</phrase> flow over actual <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase> objects.
<phrase_Q=0.614>Interactive Modeling</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.827>Dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>Color</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.838>Sparse</phrase> Depth.

<phrase_Q=0.912>Surface Normals</phrase> and Height from <phrase_Q=0.541>Non-Lambertian</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.770>Image Data</phrase>.
It is well known that many surfaces exhibit <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase> that is not well modelled by <phrase_Q=0.917>Lambert's law</phrase>. This is the case not only for surfaces that are <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.843>shiny</phrase>, but also those that are matte and composed of materials that are <phrase_Q=1.000>particle</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.815>suspensions</phrase>. As a result, standard <phrase_Q=0.866>Lambertian</phrase> shape-from-shadingmethods can not be <phrase_Q=0.542>applied directly</phrase> to the analysis of <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.756>shiny surfaces</phrase>. In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to overcome this difficulty, in this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, weconsider how to reconstruct the <phrase_Q=0.866>Lambertian</phrase> component for <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.843>shiny</phrase> surfaceswhen the object is <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminated</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.820>viewing direction</phrase>. To do this we make use of the <phrase_Q=0.924>diffuse reflectance</phrase> models described by Oren and Nayar, and by Wolff. Our experiments with <phrase_Q=0.533>synthetic and real-world</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> reveal the effectiveness of the <phrase_Q=0.811>correction</phrase> method, leading to <phrase_Q=0.804>improved</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.541>height recovery</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.821>Testing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Reflectance</phrase> Models Against <phrase_Q=1.000>Radiance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Data</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes <phrase_Q=0.651>an empirical investigation</phrase> of departures from <phrase_Q=0.917>Lambert's law</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.756>shiny surfaces</phrase>. We commence by using a <phrase_Q=0.815>recently</phrase> reported method to recover estimates ofthe <phrase_Q=0.573>surface radiance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> for objects <phrase_Q=1.000>illuminated</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.843>viewer</phrase> direction. This method is <phrase_Q=0.615>non-parametric</phrase>, and offers the advantage that it is simple to use since it does not require detailed <phrase_Q=0.966>camera calibration</phrase>. We compare the <phrase_Q=1.000>radiance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> with a number of phenomenological and <phrase_Q=1.000>physics</phrase>-basedreflectance models. The models studied include those of Oren-Nayar, Wolff and different variants of the <phrase_Q=0.611>Beckmann model</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.731>main conclusion</phrase> of the study is that among these models the <phrase_Q=0.646>best fit</phrase> to the <phrase_Q=0.722>empirical data</phrase> is found to be the Wolff <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> for smooth objects and the modified <phrase_Q=0.611>Beckmann model</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase> objects.
<phrase_Q=0.524>A Unified</phrase> Approach for <phrase_Q=0.867>Motion Analysis</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.918>View Synthesis</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.851>Image based</phrase> rendering (<phrase_Q=0.846>IBR</phrase>) consists of several steps: (<phrase_Q=0.820>i</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.829>Calibration</phrase> (or <phrase_Q=0.930>ego-motion</phrase> computation) of all <phrase_Q=0.614>input images</phrase>. (<phrase_Q=1.000>ii</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.807>Determination</phrase> of regions in the <phrase_Q=0.614>input images</phrase> used to synthesize the new view. (iii) <phrase_Q=1.000>Interpolating</phrase> the new view from the selected areas of the <phrase_Q=0.614>input images</phrase>. We propose <phrase_Q=0.524>a unified</phrase> representation for all these aspects of <phrase_Q=0.846>IBR</phrase> using the <phrase_Q=0.611>Space-Time</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.570>x-y</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.834>t</phrase>) volume. The presented approach is very <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase>, and allows to use <phrase_Q=0.846>IBR</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> conditions even with a <phrase_Q=1.000>hand-held camera</phrase>. To take <phrase_Q=0.841>care</phrase> of (<phrase_Q=0.820>i</phrase>), the <phrase_Q=0.611>Space-Time</phrase> volume is constructed by placing frames at locations along the time <phrase_Q=1.000>axis</phrase> so that <phrase_Q=0.846>image features</phrase> create <phrase_Q=0.962>straight lines</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.851>EPI</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.889>epipolar plane</phrase> images). Different slices of the <phrase_Q=0.611>Space-Time</phrase> volume are used to produce new views, taking <phrase_Q=0.841>care</phrase> of (<phrase_Q=1.000>ii</phrase>). Step (iii) is done by <phrase_Q=1.000>interpolating</phrase> between image samples using the <phrase_Q=0.821>feature lines</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.851>EPI</phrase> images. <phrase_Q=0.846>IBR</phrase> Examples are shown for various cases: sequences taken from a driving <phrase_Q=1.000>car</phrase>, from a <phrase_Q=1.000>hand held camera</phrase>, or when using a <phrase_Q=1.000>tripod</phrase>.
A Surface <phrase_Q=0.814>Partitioning</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Spectrum</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>SPS</phrase>) for <phrase_Q=0.809>Retrieval</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.818>Indexing</phrase> of 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>CAD</phrase> Models.
<phrase_Q=0.708>Manual indexing</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.871>large databases</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.642>geometric information</phrase> is costly and often impracticable. Because of this <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> into <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.818>indexing</phrase> schemes has focused on the development of various 3D to 2D mappings that characterise a shape as a <phrase_Q=1.000>histogram</phrase> with a small number of parameters. Many methods of generating such 2D signatures (i.e. histograms) have been proposed, generally based on <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> measures of say <phrase_Q=1.000>curvature</phrase> or distance. However these <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> signatures lack <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> about <phrase_Q=1.000>topology</phrase> and tend to become indistinct as the complexity of the shape increases. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes a new method for <phrase_Q=0.839>characterising</phrase> both the <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>topology</phrase> of shapes in a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> 2D <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase>, the Surface <phrase_Q=0.814>Partitioning</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Spectrum</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>SPS</phrase>). We evaluate the effectiveness of using the <phrase_Q=1.000>SPS</phrase> with a <phrase_Q=1.000>Neural Network</phrase> to assess the similarity of shapes within a <phrase_Q=1.000>test</phrase> set.
<phrase_Q=0.811>Visualization</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.911>Arbitrary-Shaped</phrase> 3D Scenes on <phrase_Q=0.556>Depth-Limited</phrase> 3D Displays.
We propose a depth <phrase_Q=0.809>scaling</phrase> method that enables <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.911>arbitrary-shaped</phrase> 3D scenes on 3D displays.Most current 3D displays have a depth limitation, while the scene to be displayed has not.The trivial solutions as clipping or <phrase_Q=0.758>linear scaling</phrase> of the scene's 3D <phrase_Q=0.943>bounding box</phrase> suffer from non-<phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase> utilization of the display's capabilities. Our approach uses <phrase_Q=0.919>spatially adaptive</phrase> depth <phrase_Q=0.809>scaling</phrase> that maximizes the <phrase_Q=1.000>perceptual</phrase> 3D effect.From the original <phrase_Q=0.869>scene geometry</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>topology</phrase> and local <phrase_Q=0.861>depth ordering</phrase> among objects are preserved, while depth <phrase_Q=0.834>linearity</phrase> is disregarded. The <phrase_Q=0.809>scaling</phrase> method applies to nearly all 3D displays, such as glasses-based, <phrase_Q=0.809>head</phrase>-tracked, <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-view, <phrase_Q=0.860>holographic</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> 3D displays.Subjective <phrase_Q=1.000>tests</phrase> with the <phrase_Q=0.833>Dynamic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Dimension</phrase> display system show that our method <phrase_Q=0.715>significantly increases</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>perceptual</phrase> 3D effect.

<phrase_Q=0.808>Estimating</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.573>Surface Radiance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Function</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>Single</phrase> Images.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes a simple method for <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.573>surface radiance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> images of <phrase_Q=0.928>smooth surfaces</phrase> made of materials whose <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> is <phrase_Q=1.000>isotropic</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.822>monotonic</phrase>. The method makes <phrase_Q=0.826>implicit</phrase> use of the <phrase_Q=1.000>Gauss</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>map</phrase> between the surface and a <phrase_Q=1.000>unit sphere</phrase>. We assume that the material brightness is <phrase_Q=0.822>monotonic</phrase> with respect to the angle between the <phrase_Q=0.827>illuminant</phrase> direction and the <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase>. Under conditions in which the <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> source and the <phrase_Q=0.843>viewer</phrase> directions are identical, we show how a <phrase_Q=0.836>tabular</phrase> representation of the <phrase_Q=0.573>surface radiance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> can be estimated using the <phrase_Q=0.817>cumulative</phrase> distribution of <phrase_Q=0.780>image gradients</phrase>. Using this <phrase_Q=0.836>tabular</phrase> representation of the <phrase_Q=1.000>radiance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase>, surfaces may be rendered under varying <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> source direction by rotating the corresponding <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>map</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=1.000>Gauss</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sphere</phrase> about the <phrase_Q=1.000>specular</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.852>spike</phrase> direction. We present a sensitivity study on <phrase_Q=0.533>synthetic and real-world</phrase> imagery. We also present two applications which make use of the estimated <phrase_Q=1.000>radiance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> of these illustrates how the <phrase_Q=1.000>radiance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> estimates can be used to render objects when the <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.843>viewer</phrase> directions are <phrase_Q=0.504>no longer</phrase> coincident. The <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> application involves <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> corrected <phrase_Q=0.866>Lambertian</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>radiance</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.756>shiny surfaces</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.823>Surface Height</phrase> Recovery Using <phrase_Q=1.000>Heat Flow</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Manifold</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>Embedding</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> makes two contributions to the problem of <phrase_Q=0.680>shape-from-shading</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase>, we develop a new method for <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase> recovery. We pose the problem as that of <phrase_Q=0.811>solving</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>steady state</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>heat equation</phrase> subject to the <phrase_Q=0.609>hard constraint</phrase> that <phrase_Q=0.917>Lambert's law</phrase> is satisfied. According to this <phrase_Q=0.823>picture</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.912>surface normals</phrase> are found by taking the <phrase_Q=1.000>gradient</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>scalar field</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>heat equation</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=1.000>scalar field</phrase> can be solved using simple <phrase_Q=1.000>finite difference</phrase> methods and leads to an <phrase_Q=0.836>iterative</phrase> procedure for <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase> estimation. The <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> contribution is to show how <phrase_Q=0.823>surface height</phrase> recovery from the <phrase_Q=0.524>field of surface normals</phrase> can be posed as one of <phrase_Q=0.639>low dimensional embedding</phrase>. We experiment with the resulting method on a <phrase_Q=1.000>variety</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.885>real-world</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.770>image data</phrase>, where it produces qualitatively good <phrase_Q=0.590>reconstructed surfaces</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.809>Audio</phrase> effects to enhance <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> informition displays.
<phrase_Q=0.808>Estimating</phrase> Curvatures and Their Derivatives on <phrase_Q=1.000>Triangle</phrase> Meshes.
The computation of <phrase_Q=1.000>curvature</phrase> and other <phrase_Q=0.806>differential</phrase> properties of surfaces is essential formany techniques in analysis and rendering. We present a <phrase_Q=0.930>finite-differences</phrase> approach for <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> curvatures on <phrase_Q=0.806>irregular</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>triangle</phrase> meshes that may be thought of as an extension of a common method for <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> per-<phrase_Q=0.848>vertex normals</phrase>. The technique is <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> in space and time, and <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.760>significantly fewer</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>outlier</phrase> estimates while more broadly offering accuracy comparable to <phrase_Q=0.640>existing methods</phrase>. It generalizes naturally to <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> derivatives of <phrase_Q=1.000>curvature</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.946>higher-order</phrase> surface <phrase_Q=0.859>differentials</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.834>Colon</phrase> Centreline Calculation for <phrase_Q=0.875>CT</phrase> Colonography using <phrase_Q=0.809>Optimised</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.778>Topological Thinning</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Octree</phrase> approximation and <phrase_Q=0.671>compression methods</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>Free</phrase>-Form Surfaces and <phrase_Q=0.680>Shape From Shading</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> a <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase>-form 3D-surface from a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> view has been a widely pursued problem. The <phrase_Q=0.623>existing schemes</phrase> are either <phrase_Q=0.921>fully-automatic</phrase> shape-from-<phrase_Q=0.814>X</phrase> techniques or involve <phrase_Q=0.877>adept</phrase> interaction from the user but little or no <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>photometric</phrase>) basis. We propose a novel scheme of <phrase_Q=0.614>interactive modeling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase>-form <phrase_Q=0.866>lambertian</phrase> surfaces where the <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> obtained is consistent with the <phrase_Q=0.680>Shape from Shading</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. To this end, a <phrase_Q=1.000>reinforcement learning</phrase> based scheme has been adopted which allows <phrase_Q=0.749>user intervention</phrase> at any stage of the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to guide the <phrase_Q=1.000>SFS</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> to a <phrase_Q=0.782>global minimum</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> Extraction of <phrase_Q=0.826>Planar</phrase> Projections from <phrase_Q=0.843>Panoramic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a <phrase_Q=0.729>segmentation technique</phrase> to decompose automatically a <phrase_Q=0.843>panoramic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> image into a set of <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> projections. It consists of three stages. <phrase_Q=0.813>Firstly</phrase>, two <phrase_Q=0.834>orthogonal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.882>surface orientation</phrase> histograms are generated. <phrase_Q=0.807>Secondly</phrase>, from these histograms the <phrase_Q=1.000>major</phrase> surfaces' orientations are extracted. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=1.000>histogram</phrase> of distances is computed for each one of these orientations; it will be used to define the position of the <phrase_Q=0.821>projection</phrase> planes as well as the corresponding clipping planes. The original <phrase_Q=0.843>panoramic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> image is <phrase_Q=0.515>divided into</phrase> as many <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> projections as main directions in the <phrase_Q=0.888>orientation histograms</phrase> are extracted. This technique can be used with both <phrase_Q=0.678>indoor and outdoor scenes</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> result with a <phrase_Q=0.843>panoramic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> image is presented.
<phrase_Q=0.623>Surface Model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.801>Generation</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images of <phrase_Q=1.000>Industrial</phrase> Environments.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents an <phrase_Q=1.000>hybrid</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.729>segmentation technique</phrase> that combines both the speed of an <phrase_Q=0.846>edge based</phrase> approach with the robustness of a <phrase_Q=0.679>surface based</phrase> approach. It consists of three stages. In the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> stage a <phrase_Q=1.000>scan line</phrase> approximation process extracts the edges contained into the given <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> image. These edges are later on used to define the positions of <phrase_Q=1.000>seed</phrase> points. Through the <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> stage a two steps <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> growing technique is applied. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase> a 2D growing process enlarges the original <phrase_Q=1.000>seed</phrase> points generating bigger regions. <phrase_Q=0.822>Next</phrase>, each <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> is fitted to a plane and a <phrase_Q=0.813>cylinder</phrase>. The one that <phrase_Q=0.646>best fit</phrase> the given points is selected to represent that <phrase_Q=1.000>region</phrase> and used during the 3D growing stage. The 3D growing stage is <phrase_Q=0.501>carried out</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.548>taking into account</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.782>approximation error</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.615>candidate points</phrase> to be added to the fitted surface. In this way, each surface is grown until no points can be added according to a <phrase_Q=0.868>user defined</phrase> threshold. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, in the <phrase_Q=0.806>third</phrase> stage, a <phrase_Q=0.912>post-processing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> merges neighbour regions that belong to the same surface. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> by using <phrase_Q=1.000>industrial</phrase> environments are presented.
<phrase_Q=0.848>Unsupervised</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.522>Motion Classification</phrase> by Means of <phrase_Q=0.810>Efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Feature Selection</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.814>Tracking</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> technique for <phrase_Q=0.928>human motion</phrase> recognition; in particular, it is focused on labeling a movement as a <phrase_Q=0.810>walking</phrase> or running displacement, which are the most frequent type of <phrase_Q=0.805>locomotion</phrase>. The proposed technique consists of two stages and is based on the study of <phrase_Q=0.911>feature points</phrase>' trajectories. The <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> stage detects <phrase_Q=1.000>peaks</phrase> and valleys of points' trajectories, which are used on the <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> stage to <phrase_Q=0.821>discern</phrase> whether the movement corresponds to a <phrase_Q=0.810>walking</phrase> or a running displacement. <phrase_Q=0.952>Prior knowledge</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.960>human body</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>kinematics</phrase> structure together with the corresponding <phrase_Q=0.678>motion model</phrase> are the basis for the <phrase_Q=0.717>motion recognition</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> with different <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> sequences are presented.

A Formulation of Boundary <phrase_Q=0.820>Mesh</phrase> Segmentation.
We present a formulation of boundary <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> segmentation as an <phrase_Q=1.000>optimization problem</phrase>. Previous segmentation solutions are classified according to the different segmentation goals, the <phrase_Q=0.801>optimization criteria</phrase> and the various <phrase_Q=0.838>algorithmic</phrase> techniques used. We identify two primarily distinct types of <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> segmentation, namely partssegmentation and patch segmentation. We also define <phrase_Q=0.809>generic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=1.000>major</phrase> techniques used for segmentation.
Extraction and Description of 3D (Articulated) <phrase_Q=0.929>Moving Objects</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Pyramid</phrase> Coordinates for <phrase_Q=1.000>Morphing</phrase> and Deformation.
Many <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>editing</phrase> operations, such as <phrase_Q=1.000>morphing</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.805>blending</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.927>shape deformation</phrase>, require the ability to interactively transform the surface of a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> in response to some <phrase_Q=0.730>control mechanism</phrase>. For most <phrase_Q=0.682>computer graphics</phrase> applications, it is important to preserve the <phrase_Q=0.818>local shape</phrase> properties of input models during <phrase_Q=1.000>editing</phrase> operations. Our work introduces the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase>, to our <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>editing</phrase> technique that explicitly preserves <phrase_Q=0.818>local shape</phrase> properties. The method is based on a <phrase_Q=0.818>local shape</phrase> representation, which we refer to as <phrase_Q=1.000>pyramid</phrase> coordinates. The <phrase_Q=1.000>pyramid</phrase> coordinates capture the <phrase_Q=0.818>local shape</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> around each vertex and help maintain this shape under various <phrase_Q=1.000>editing</phrase> operations. They are based on a set of angles and lengths <phrase_Q=0.805>relating</phrase> a vertex to its <phrase_Q=0.553>immediate neighbors</phrase>. This representation is invariant under <phrase_Q=0.782>rigid transformations</phrase>. Using <phrase_Q=1.000>pyramid</phrase> coordinates, we introduce a new technique for <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> deformation and <phrase_Q=1.000>morphing</phrase> based on a small number of <phrase_Q=0.554>user-specified</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.508>control vertices</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> generate <phrase_Q=0.547>natural looking</phrase> deformations and <phrase_Q=1.000>morphing</phrase> sequences in seconds with <phrase_Q=0.814>minimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.932>user interaction</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.832>Unifying</phrase> Measured Point Sequences of <phrase_Q=0.834>Deforming Objects</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.886>Recent progress</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>digitizing</phrase> technologies is making it possible to capture the 3D shapes of <phrase_Q=0.929>moving objects</phrase>. To <phrase_Q=0.631>efficiently utilize</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.635>time series</phrase> records of <phrase_Q=0.852>spatial data</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> must be <phrase_Q=0.826>unified</phrase> to yield coherent deforming models. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> method that unifies <phrase_Q=0.819>unregistered</phrase> 3D point sequences to generate <phrase_Q=0.772>deforming mesh</phrase> models. The method does not assume any specific <phrase_Q=1.000>kinematic</phrase> structure, and is applicable to any digitizer. The method <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> polygonizes the <phrase_Q=0.660>initial points</phrase> and then deforms meshes to <phrase_Q=0.646>best fit</phrase> the subsequent <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> points while minimizing the <phrase_Q=0.712>deformation energy</phrase>. Experiments are conducted on real <phrase_Q=0.592>measured data</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.861>CG</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, and successful <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are obtained. As an application of the method, we examine <phrase_Q=1.000>data compression</phrase> and achieve a 380 fold reduction rate for a <phrase_Q=0.592>measured data</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.954>Surface Reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.927>Multiple Views</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.557>Rational B-Splines</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.842>Knot</phrase> Insertion.
