<phrase_Q=0.817>Visual-Hull Reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.853>Uncalibrated</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.825>Unsynchronized</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Video</phrase> Streams.
We present an approach for <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> event using multiple <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> cameras <phrase_Q=1.000>recording</phrase> from different viewpoints. Those cameras do not need to be calibrated or even synchronized. Our approach recovers all the necessary <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.803>analyzing</phrase> the motion of the silhouettes in the <phrase_Q=0.667>multiple video streams</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> step consists of <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.808>synchronization</phrase> for pairs of cameras. We compute the <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase> offset and <phrase_Q=0.973>epipolar geometry</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.688>RANSAC-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to search for the epipoles as well as for robustness. In the <phrase_Q=0.822>next</phrase> stage the <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.808>synchronization</phrase> for the complete <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> network is recovered and then refined through <phrase_Q=1.000>maximum likelihood estimation</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>hull</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is used to the recover the <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> shape of the observed object. For <phrase_Q=0.825>unsynchronized</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> streams silhouettes are interpolated to deal with <phrase_Q=1.000>subframe</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase> offsets. We demonstrate the validity of our approach by obtaining the <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.808>synchronization</phrase> and 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of a moving person from a set of 4 minute videos recorded from 4 <phrase_Q=0.889>widely separated</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> cameras.
<phrase_Q=0.851>Image-Based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>Photo</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>Hulls</phrase>.
Facial <phrase_Q=0.918>View Synthesis</phrase> from a <phrase_Q=1.000>Single</phrase> Image using <phrase_Q=0.680>Shape from Shading</phrase>.
We present a facial <phrase_Q=0.918>view synthesis</phrase> technique based on explicit shape and <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> extracted from a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> image. The technique combines an <phrase_Q=0.851>image based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase> estimation process with a novel method of <phrase_Q=1.000>interpolating</phrase> between <phrase_Q=0.832>needle</phrase>-maps recovered using <phrase_Q=0.680>shape from shading</phrase>. This allows images of a face to be synthesised under novel lighting, pose and <phrase_Q=1.000>skin</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase> given only one example image. We exploit <phrase_Q=0.717>facial symmetry</phrase> by reflecting the <phrase_Q=0.813>needle-map</phrase> of a rotated face to yield the <phrase_Q=0.813>needle-map</phrase> of the face rotated in the <phrase_Q=0.753>opposite direction</phrase>. This provides two <phrase_Q=0.832>needle</phrase>-maps between which <phrase_Q=1.000>interpolation</phrase> can be performed.
A <phrase_Q=0.815>Variational</phrase> Analysis of Shape from Specularities using <phrase_Q=0.785>Sparse Data</phrase>.
Looking around in our every day environment, many of the encountered objects are <phrase_Q=1.000>specular</phrase> to some <phrase_Q=1.000>degree</phrase>. Actively using this <phrase_Q=0.814>fact</phrase> when <phrase_Q=0.816>reconstructing</phrase> objects from <phrase_Q=0.949>image sequences</phrase> is the scope of the shape from specularities problem. One reason why this problem is important is that standard <phrase_Q=0.625>structure from motion</phrase> techniques fail when the <phrase_Q=0.710>object surfaces</phrase> are <phrase_Q=1.000>specular</phrase>. Here this problem is addressed by <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.867>surface shape</phrase> using <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> from the <phrase_Q=0.957>specular reflections</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=1.000>specular reflection</phrase> gives constraints on the <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase>. The approach taken in this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.652>differs significantly</phrase> from many earlier shape from specularities methods since the normal <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> used is <phrase_Q=0.838>sparse</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.781>main contribution</phrase> of this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> is to give a <phrase_Q=0.604>solid foundation</phrase> for shape from specularities problems. Estimation of <phrase_Q=0.867>surface shape</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.819>reflections</phrase> is formulated as a <phrase_Q=0.815>variational</phrase> problem and the surface is <phrase_Q=0.586>represented implicitly</phrase> using <phrase_Q=1.000>a level</phrase> set formulation. A <phrase_Q=0.811>functional</phrase> incorporating all surface constraints is proposed and the corresponding <phrase_Q=1.000>level set</phrase> motion <phrase_Q=1.000>PDE</phrase> is explicitly derived. This motion is then <phrase_Q=1.000>proven</phrase> to minimize the <phrase_Q=0.811>functional</phrase>. As a part of this <phrase_Q=0.811>functional</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.815>variational</phrase> approach to normal <phrase_Q=0.814>alignment</phrase> is proposed and analyzed. Also novel methods for <phrase_Q=0.912>implicit surface</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>interpolation</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.507>sparse point</phrase> sets are presented together with a <phrase_Q=0.815>variational</phrase> analysis. Experiments on both real and <phrase_Q=0.775>synthetic data</phrase> support the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.954>Surface Reconstruction</phrase> from the <phrase_Q=0.821>Projection</phrase> of Points, Curves and Contours.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> the problem of <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.816>reconstructing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>geometrical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.729>surface models</phrase> from multiple <phrase_Q=0.668>calibrated images</phrase> is considered. We build an appropriate <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> from the images alone and show how this a priori <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> can be used to automatically reconstruct new instances of the <phrase_Q=0.811>object category</phrase> from one or several images. The <phrase_Q=0.954>surface reconstruction</phrase> method is based on <phrase_Q=1.000>a level</phrase> set representation and one of the main novel contributions <phrase_Q=0.850>lie</phrase> within the <phrase_Q=1.000>level set</phrase> framework. <phrase_Q=0.505>Standard methods</phrase> use either <phrase_Q=0.716>image-correlation</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.922>point correspondences</phrase> to achieve this goal. We show how this framework can be <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> to incorporate image curves and <phrase_Q=0.947>apparent contours</phrase> (i.e. the projections of silhouettes). In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to automatically obtain <phrase_Q=0.883>feature correspondences</phrase>, we use a <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> shape modelfor the <phrase_Q=0.811>object category</phrase> of interest. The <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is based on the <phrase_Q=0.924>Active Shape Model</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.853>Probabilistic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>PCA</phrase>. The scheme is applied to build and automatically reconstruct 3D <phrase_Q=0.729>surface models</phrase> of faces. The resulting system is demonstrated on a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> of real <phrase_Q=0.878>face images</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.810>Efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> Creation of Large Structures based on <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Segmentation.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> method from 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>-sets that is utilizing <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> segmentation. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> starts with a set of <phrase_Q=0.819>unregistered</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> scans of a <phrase_Q=0.914>large scale</phrase> scene. The scans are being <phrase_Q=0.817>pre-processed</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.960>noise removal</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.827>hole</phrase> filling. The <phrase_Q=0.822>next</phrase> step is <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> segmentation and the extraction of <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.621>linear features</phrase>. These features are utilized for the <phrase_Q=0.782>automatic registration</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> scans into a <phrase_Q=0.527>common frame</phrase> of reference [<phrase_Q=0.824>Automated</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.879>feature-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>urban</phrase> scenes of <phrase_Q=0.914>large scale</phrase>]. A <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.523>based algorithm</phrase> is used for the <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> of a coherent 3D <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> that encloses all <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> scans. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, the original segmented scans are used in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to simplify the constructed <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> can now be represented as a set of <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> regions at areas of <phrase_Q=0.920>low complexity</phrase> and as a set of <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.804>triangular</phrase> elements at areas of <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> complexity. This is achieved by <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> the overlaps of the original segmented <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> areas on the generated 3D <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase>. The example of the <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> of the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>NYC</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase> is presented.
<phrase_Q=1.000>PDE</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.530>based Multi</phrase>-view <phrase_Q=0.934>Depth Estimation</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.948>Triangle Mesh</phrase>-Based <phrase_Q=0.792>Surface Modeling</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.817>Adaptive Smoothing</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.912>Implicit Surface</phrase> Texture <phrase_Q=0.821>Integration</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.913>Image Matching</phrase> based on <phrase_Q=0.832>Co</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.669>Motion Statistics</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a method for matching <phrase_Q=0.901>partially overlapping</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.875>image-pairs</phrase> where the object of interest is in motion, even if the motion is <phrase_Q=0.821>discontinuous</phrase> and in an <phrase_Q=0.694>unstructured environment</phrase>. In a typical <phrase_Q=0.840>outdoor</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.804>multi-camera surveillance</phrase> system, an observed object as seen by separate cameras may appear very different, due to the <phrase_Q=1.000>variable</phrase> influence of factors such as <phrase_Q=0.898>lighting conditions</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> angles. Thus <phrase_Q=0.510>static features</phrase> such as <phrase_Q=0.525>object color</phrase>, shape, and contours cannot be used for <phrase_Q=0.913>image matching</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> a different method is proposed for matching <phrase_Q=0.901>partially overlapping</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.734>images captured</phrase> by such cameras. The matching is achieved by calculation of <phrase_Q=0.832>co</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.669>motion statistics</phrase>, followed by detection and <phrase_Q=0.816>rejection</phrase> of points outside the <phrase_Q=0.675>overlap area</phrase> and a <phrase_Q=0.886>nonlinear optimization</phrase> process. The <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> we describe finds <phrase_Q=0.922>point correspondences</phrase> in two images without searching for any structures and without the need for <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>continuous</phrase> motion. Trials using <phrase_Q=0.809>statistical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.724>motion-based</phrase> image <phrase_Q=0.802>cross</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.509>rejection algorithm</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.800>image-transformation</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.966>camera calibration</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.860>real-life</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.840>outdoor</phrase> images have demonstrated the feasibility of this approach.
<phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> 3D Segmentation for <phrase_Q=0.946>Underwater Acoustic</phrase> Images.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, a new technique for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>acoustic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>image segmentation</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.812>modelling</phrase> is proposed. Especially, in the <phrase_Q=0.837>underwater</phrase> environment, in which <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase> sensors suffer from <phrase_Q=0.807>visibility</phrase> problems, the <phrase_Q=0.852>acoustical</phrase> devices may provide <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> solutions, but, on the other hand, <phrase_Q=1.000>acoustic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.897>image interpretation</phrase> is surely more difficult for a <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> operator. The proposed application involves the use of an <phrase_Q=1.000>acoustic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> which directly acquires images <phrase_Q=0.804>structured</phrase> as a set of 3D points. Due to the <phrase_Q=0.806>noisy</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>nature</phrase> of this type of <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, the segmentation problem becomes more challenging and the standard <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>image segmentation</phrase> are likely to fail. The <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> is based on a <phrase_Q=0.824>simplified</phrase> version of the so called recover and select <phrase_Q=1.000>paradigm</phrase> in which the <phrase_Q=1.000>seed</phrase> areas, from which the segmentation starts, are generated by adopting a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> approach based on the <phrase_Q=0.891>RANSAC</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.817>RANdom</phrase> Sample And <phrase_Q=0.859>Consensus</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.871>Superquadric</phrase> primitives are directly recovered from <phrase_Q=0.845>raw data</phrase> without any <phrase_Q=0.565>pre-segmentation</phrase> processing. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> trials using both synthetic and real <phrase_Q=0.852>acoustical</phrase> images confirm the goodness of the method, and a large robustness of the resulting <phrase_Q=0.870>segmented images</phrase>, associated to a relatively low <phrase_Q=0.694>computational load</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.917>Panoramic Image</phrase> Transform of <phrase_Q=1.000>Omnidirectional</phrase> Images Using <phrase_Q=1.000>Discrete Geometry</phrase> Techniques.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> proposes an <phrase_Q=1.000>omnidirectional</phrase>-to-<phrase_Q=0.917>panoramic image</phrase> transform with <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> accuracy using <phrase_Q=1.000>PDE</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=0.825>resampling</phrase> models. For the application of <phrase_Q=0.688>computer-vision</phrase> techniques to <phrase_Q=1.000>omnidirectional</phrase> images, the transformation of <phrase_Q=1.000>omnidirectional</phrase> images to <phrase_Q=0.558>uniform-resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>quadric</phrase>-surface images is needed in the two reasons. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase>, an <phrase_Q=0.945>omni-directional</phrase> image does not have a <phrase_Q=0.558>uniform resolution</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.806>Second</phrase>, the development of the <phrase_Q=0.688>computer-vision</phrase>-based techniques on the <phrase_Q=1.000>quadric</phrase> surface is mathematically accurate compared with the development of the techniques on the <phrase_Q=1.000>omnidirectional</phrase> image directly. Therefore, our aim is to generate <phrase_Q=0.558>uniform-resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.949>panoramic images</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.824>cylindrical</phrase> surface from <phrase_Q=0.835>nonuniform</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>omnidirectional</phrase> images. The <phrase_Q=0.558>uniform-resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.949>panoramic images</phrase> allow us to reconstruct 3D objects and scenes from <phrase_Q=1.000>omnidirectional</phrase> images robustly. Our <phrase_Q=0.843>panoramic</phrase> transformation selects the <phrase_Q=0.558>uniform resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>pixels</phrase> on <phrase_Q=1.000>omnidirectional</phrase> images employing the <phrase_Q=0.826>geometrical</phrase> configuration of cameras in the estimation and <phrase_Q=0.825>resampling</phrase> process. Therefore, our method is mathematically accurate <phrase_Q=0.812>comparing</phrase> to the traditional <phrase_Q=0.843>panoramic</phrase> transformation using <phrase_Q=0.556>point-to-point</phrase> correspondences with the geometries of cameras and the <phrase_Q=0.825>cubic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>convolution</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.840>Generalized</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.891>RANSAC</phrase> Framework for Relaxed <phrase_Q=0.825>Correspondence</phrase> Problems.
Finding <phrase_Q=0.506>correspondences between</phrase> two (widely) <phrase_Q=0.541>separated views</phrase> is essential for several <phrase_Q=0.688>computer vision</phrase> tasks, such as <phrase_Q=0.508>structure and motion</phrase> estimation and <phrase_Q=0.956>object recognition</phrase>. In the <phrase_Q=0.928>wide-baseline</phrase> matching using scale and/or <phrase_Q=0.961>affine invariant</phrase> features the search for correspondences typically proceeds in two stages. In the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> stage a putative set of correspondences is obtained based on distances between <phrase_Q=0.916>feature descriptors</phrase>. In the <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> stage the matches are refined by imposing <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> constraints by means of <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> estimation of the <phrase_Q=0.973>epipolar geometry</phrase> and the incorrect matches are rejected as <phrase_Q=1.000>outliers</phrase>. For a feature in one view, usually only one "best" feature (the <phrase_Q=0.964>nearest neighbor</phrase>) in the other view is chosen as corresponding feature, despite the <phrase_Q=0.814>fact</phrase> that several match candidates exist. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we will consider <phrase_Q=0.611>multiple candidate</phrase> matches for each feature, and integrate this choice with the <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> estimation stage, thus avoiding the early commitment to the "best" one. This yields a <phrase_Q=0.840>generalized</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.891>RANSAC</phrase> framework for <phrase_Q=0.805>identifying</phrase> the true correspondences among sets of matches. We examine the effectiveness of different <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> strategies for sets of correspondences and <phrase_Q=1.000>test</phrase> the approach extensively using real examples of hard <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> problems caused by a large motion between views and/or ambiguities due to repetitive scene structures.
<phrase_Q=0.827>Exploitation</phrase> of 3D Images for <phrase_Q=0.870>Face Authentication</phrase> Under <phrase_Q=0.535>Pose and Illumination</phrase> Variations.
An <phrase_Q=0.900>appearance-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.870>face authentication</phrase> system integrating 2D <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.812>intensity images</phrase> and 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> is presented in this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>. The proposed system is based on a <phrase_Q=0.921>low-cost</phrase> 3D and <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase>, capable of <phrase_Q=0.837>synchronous</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> of 3D images and associated <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> images. Novel <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> are proposed that exploit <phrase_Q=0.839>depth information</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.952>prior knowledge</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.583>face geometry</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>symmetry</phrase> to achieve <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>face detection</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.823>localization</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>authentication</phrase> under conditions of <phrase_Q=0.853>background clutter</phrase>, occlusion, <phrase_Q=0.856>face pose</phrase> alteration and harsh illumination. A method for the <phrase_Q=0.822>enrichment</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.683>face databases</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.866>synthetically generated</phrase> views depicting variations in <phrase_Q=0.535>pose and illumination</phrase> is proposed to <phrase_Q=0.858>cope</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.809>head</phrase> rotations and <phrase_Q=0.917>illumination variations</phrase>, avoiding a cumbersome enrolment process. The performance of the proposed <phrase_Q=1.000>authentication</phrase> scheme is tested thoroughly on a <phrase_Q=0.854>face database</phrase> of 1500 images, recorded with the 3D <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> system. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> demonstrate <phrase_Q=0.681>significant gains</phrase> resulting from the combined use of depth and <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.684>intensity information</phrase>, in comparison to the use of 2D images alone.
<phrase_Q=0.827>Archiving</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Cultural</phrase> Objects with <phrase_Q=0.531>Surface Point</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.854>Wise</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Database</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Information</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.524>A Unified</phrase> Representation for <phrase_Q=0.822>Interactive</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.822>Interactive</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> is the process of <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of an object or a scene in <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> while the 3D (<phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> is acquired. This is possible only if the <phrase_Q=1.000>computational complexity</phrase> of all involved <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> is linear with respect to the amount of <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. We propose a new framework for 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> where a complete <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> chain meets with this requirement. The framework is based on the use of <phrase_Q=1.000>vector fields</phrase> as an <phrase_Q=0.912>implicit surface</phrase> representation. Each <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> step, <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.954>surface reconstruction</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>fusion</phrase>, compression and <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> is solved and explained using the <phrase_Q=1.000>vector fields</phrase> without anyintermediate representations. The proposed framework allows <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> from any type of 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.927>surface patches</phrase>, curves, unorganized sets of points or a combination of these.
A <phrase_Q=0.835>Volumetric</phrase> Approach for <phrase_Q=0.822>Interactive</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>image registration</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.954>surface reconstruction</phrase> have been <phrase_Q=0.808>traditionally</phrase> considered as two <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> processes where the latter relies on the <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> of the former. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a new approach to <phrase_Q=0.694>surface recovery</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images where the two processes are <phrase_Q=0.826>unified</phrase> and performed in a common <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> representation. While the reconstructed surface is described in its <phrase_Q=0.826>implicit</phrase> form as a <phrase_Q=0.905>signed distance</phrase> field within a volume, <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> for matching <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> surfaces is encoded in the same volume as the <phrase_Q=1.000>gradient</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.783>distance field</phrase>. This allows <phrase_Q=0.820>coupling</phrase> of both <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> and leads to an <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> whose complexity is linear with respect to the number of images and the number of measured 3D points. The close <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.648>performance gain</phrase> improve <phrase_Q=1.000>interactivity</phrase> in the process of <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.933>image acquisition</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.954>surface reconstruction</phrase>. The distances computed in the direction of filtered normals improve robustness while preserving the <phrase_Q=0.815>sharp</phrase> details of the initial <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images. It is shown that the integrated <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is tolerant to initial <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> errors as well as to <phrase_Q=0.820>measurement errors</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes the representation and formalizes the approach. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> demonstrate performance advantages and tolerance to aforementioned types of errors.
A <phrase_Q=1.000>Closed-Form</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Solution</phrase> for a Two-View <phrase_Q=0.681>Self-Calibration</phrase> Problem under Fixation.
It is well known that the <phrase_Q=0.973>epipolar geometry</phrase> between two <phrase_Q=0.853>uncalibrated</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.829>perspective</phrase> views is completely encapsulated in the <phrase_Q=0.882>fundamental matrix</phrase>. Since the <phrase_Q=0.882>fundamental matrix</phrase> has seven <phrase_Q=0.647>degrees of freedom</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.847>DOF</phrase>), <phrase_Q=0.681>self-calibration</phrase> is possible if at most seven of the <phrase_Q=0.817>intrinsic</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.729>extrinsic camera parameters</phrase> are unknown by <phrase_Q=0.814>extracting</phrase> them from the <phrase_Q=0.882>fundamental matrix</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a linear <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.722>self-calibrating</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.829>perspective</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> which undergoes fixation, that is, a special motion in which the camera's <phrase_Q=1.000>optical axis</phrase> is confined in a plane. Since this fixation has four <phrase_Q=0.647>degrees of freedom</phrase>, which is one smaller than that of <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> motion, we can extract at most three <phrase_Q=0.817>intrinsic</phrase> parameters from the <phrase_Q=0.882>fundamental matrix</phrase>. We here assume that the <phrase_Q=1.000>focal length</phrase> (1 <phrase_Q=0.847>DOF</phrase>) and the <phrase_Q=0.721>principal point</phrase> (2 <phrase_Q=0.847>DOF</phrase>) are unknown but fixed for two views. It will be shown that these three parameters are obtained from the <phrase_Q=0.882>fundamental matrix</phrase> in an analytical <phrase_Q=1.000>fashion</phrase> and a <phrase_Q=1.000>closed-form</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> is derived. We also characterize all the <phrase_Q=0.813>degenerate</phrase> motions under which there exists an <phrase_Q=1.000>infinite set</phrase> of solutions.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Long</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-performance time-of-<phrase_Q=0.815>flight</phrase>-based 3D <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase> sensors.
3-Dimensional <phrase_Q=0.770>Object Modeling</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.967>Mesh Simplification</phrase> Based <phrase_Q=0.813>Resolution</phrase> Adjustment.
A 3-Dimensional (3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase>) <phrase_Q=0.770>object modeling</phrase> technique with <phrase_Q=0.967>mesh simplification</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.821>refinement</phrase> based <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> adjustment is proposed in this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.902>Polygonal models</phrase> which are <phrase_Q=0.601>widely utilized</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> of 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> objects are taken as basis, making use of the <phrase_Q=0.823>polygonal</phrase> structure and <phrase_Q=0.702>vertex coordinates</phrase> for the display of 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> models. The amount of <phrase_Q=1.000>polygons</phrase> and vertices of a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is <phrase_Q=1.000>proportional</phrase> to the <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> as well as <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> quantity. In other words the <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> increases with the number of <phrase_Q=1.000>polygons</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, it is proposed to utilize <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase>, and hence <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> amount, <phrase_Q=0.827>adjustable</phrase> 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> so that <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> and transmitted <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> amount can be regulated according to access constraints.

The <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> on analysis of <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> motion by using a <phrase_Q=1.000>monocular</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> instead of a <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo camera</phrase> has important applications for making the <phrase_Q=1.000>microscopes</phrase> used in <phrase_Q=1.000>microbiology</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.808>constructing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.960>autonomous robots</phrase> used in various fields of <phrase_Q=1.000>industry</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.867>Fan</phrase>-Meshes: A <phrase_Q=0.836>Geometric</phrase> Primitive for <phrase_Q=0.826>Point-Based</phrase> Description of 3D Models and Scenes.
We propose a new <phrase_Q=1.000>data structure</phrase>, called <phrase_Q=0.867>Fan</phrase>-Meshes (<phrase_Q=1.000>FM</phrase>), for <phrase_Q=0.816>reconstructing</phrase> 3D models and scenes represented by <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> scanning <phrase_Q=0.979>point clouds</phrase>. It is a local <phrase_Q=1.000>piecewise</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>linear approximation</phrase> to the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase>, and can serve as primitives in <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> with a good balance between <phrase_Q=0.587>computational loads</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> quality. In our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>, local remeshing is performed in <phrase_Q=0.825>preprocessing</phrase> to obtain regular <phrase_Q=0.850>FMs</phrase>, and a three-level-<phrase_Q=0.616>point data</phrase> structure called <phrase_Q=1.000>Triangle</phrase> Selection Record (<phrase_Q=1.000>TSR</phrase>) is then used to reduce redundancies in the <phrase_Q=0.845>raw data</phrase> and overlapping in the original <phrase_Q=0.850>FMs</phrase>. Furthermore, to apply the method to <phrase_Q=0.804>raw</phrase> 3D scanning <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, we use a <phrase_Q=0.805>smoothing</phrase> operator to the <phrase_Q=1.000>point cloud</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to eliminate some <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> noises. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> demonstrate that our scheme is effective even for <phrase_Q=0.914>large-scale</phrase> scenes with <phrase_Q=0.676>real data</phrase>.

<phrase_Q=0.765>Speech-Driven</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.709>Face Synthesis</phrase> from 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Video</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a framework for <phrase_Q=0.765>speech-driven</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>synthesis</phrase> of real faces from a corpus of 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> of a person speaking.Video-rate capture of <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.731>face shape</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.836>colour</phrase> appearance provides the basis for a <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>speech synthesis</phrase> model.A <phrase_Q=0.770>displacement map</phrase> representation combines <phrase_Q=0.731>face shape</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.836>colour</phrase> into a 3D video.This representation is used to efficiently register and integrate shape and <phrase_Q=0.576>colour information</phrase> captured from multiple views.To allow <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>speech synthesis</phrase> viseme primitives are identified from the corpus using <phrase_Q=1.000>automatic speech recognition</phrase>. A novel <phrase_Q=0.674>non-rigid</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.588>alignment algorithm</phrase> is introduced to estimate <phrase_Q=0.876>dense correspondence</phrase> between 3D <phrase_Q=0.731>face shape</phrase> and appearance for different visemes.The registered <phrase_Q=0.770>displacement map</phrase> representation together with a novel <phrase_Q=1.000>optical flow</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.827>optimisation</phrase> using both shape and <phrase_Q=0.836>colour</phrase>, enables accurate and <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.674>non-rigid</phrase> alignment.Face <phrase_Q=0.803>synthesis</phrase> from speech is performed by <phrase_Q=1.000>concatenation</phrase> of the corresponding viseme <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> using the <phrase_Q=0.674>non-rigid</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> to reproduce both 3D <phrase_Q=0.731>face shape</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.836>colour</phrase> appearance. <phrase_Q=0.932>Concatenative synthesis</phrase> reproduces both viseme timing and <phrase_Q=0.832>co</phrase>-articulation.Face capture and <phrase_Q=0.803>synthesis</phrase> has been performed for a <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> of 51 people.Results demonstrate <phrase_Q=0.803>synthesis</phrase> of 3D <phrase_Q=0.846>visual speech</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>animation</phrase> with a quality comparable to the <phrase_Q=0.506>captured video</phrase> of a person.
<phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>Camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> based on <phrase_Q=0.872>Surface Normal</phrase> Estimation and Best <phrase_Q=0.851>Viewpoint Selection</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we present a new <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.816>reconstructing</phrase> an environment from images recorded by multiple <phrase_Q=0.847>calibrated cameras</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.802>Multiple camera</phrase> systems <phrase_Q=0.802>challenge</phrase> traditional <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> in many issues including <phrase_Q=0.535>view registration</phrase>, selection of commonly visible image parts for matching, and the <phrase_Q=0.814>fact</phrase> that surfaces are imaged differently from different viewpoints and poses. On the other hand, <phrase_Q=0.882>multiple cameras</phrase> have the advantage of revealing surfaces at <phrase_Q=0.970>occluding contours</phrase> and covering <phrase_Q=0.791>wide areas</phrase>. The presented <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> makes no assumption on <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.816>loci</phrase> and outputs an occupancy <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.846>grid</phrase>, with occupied voxels being <phrase_Q=0.509>accompanied by</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase>. It is <phrase_Q=0.839>correlation-based</phrase>, however, outperforms the conventional <phrase_Q=0.839>correlation-based</phrase> approach in <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> quality. It is <phrase_Q=0.883>highly parallelizable</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=0.512>most importantly</phrase>, is <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> against artifacts due to <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> errors that are typically encountered when using <phrase_Q=0.882>multiple cameras</phrase>.

A method for <phrase_Q=0.812>modelling</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.814>visualizing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>lungs</phrase> using <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>lung</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>anatomy</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.722>High Resolution CT</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.818>HRCT</phrase>) images is presented. <phrase_Q=0.850>Hierarchical</phrase> Representation of <phrase_Q=0.805>Virtual</phrase> Cities for <phrase_Q=0.851>Progressive</phrase> Transmission over Networks.
<phrase_Q=0.822>Interactive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.776>network-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>navigation</phrase> over large <phrase_Q=1.000>urban</phrase> environments raises <phrase_Q=0.638>difficult problems</phrase> due to the size and complexity of these scenes. Furthermore, <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> coding methods are used to compress the representation <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> allowing <phrase_Q=0.880>quick start</phrase>-up of the <phrase_Q=0.886>interactive visualisation</phrase> with a <phrase_Q=0.758>highly-detailed</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. The method efficiently exploits the <phrase_Q=0.814>fact</phrase> that most <phrase_Q=0.824>automated</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>modelling</phrase> techniques of <phrase_Q=1.000>urban</phrase> scenes provides 2D<phrase_Q=0.586>\frac</phrase>{1} {2} models (<phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> footprint, height, <phrase_Q=1.000>altitude</phrase>, ...). So as to efficiently and faithfully <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.584>complex buildings</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=0.822>procedural</phrase> representation for roofs and <phrase_Q=1.000>facades</phrase> is proposed. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, we present an <phrase_Q=1.000>MPEG4</phrase> compatible implementation based on the <phrase_Q=0.822>introduction</phrase> of new <phrase_Q=0.568>node types</phrase> with the associated <phrase_Q=1.000>bitstream</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.885>Image Guided</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Geometry</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>Inference</phrase>.
We introduce a new method for <phrase_Q=0.643>filling holes</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> obtained from 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> scanners. Our method makes use of 2D images of the areas where <phrase_Q=0.597>geometric data</phrase> is missing. The 2D images guide the filling using the relationship between the images and <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> learned from the existing 3D <phrase_Q=0.640>scanned data</phrase>. Our method builds on <phrase_Q=0.647>existing techniques</phrase> for using scanned <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> and for <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> shape from <phrase_Q=0.757>shaded images</phrase>. Rather than creating plausibly filled holes, we attempt to <phrase_Q=0.836>approximate</phrase> the missing <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase>. We present <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.640>scanned data</phrase> from both <phrase_Q=1.000>triangulation</phrase> and time-of-<phrase_Q=0.815>flight</phrase> scanners for various types of materials. To quantitatively validate our <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase>, we also compare the filled areas with <phrase_Q=0.706>ground-truth data</phrase>.
Scanline Optimization for <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> on <phrase_Q=0.945>Graphics Hardware</phrase>.
In this work we propose a scanline <phrase_Q=0.730>optimization procedure</phrase> for computational <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> using a linear <phrase_Q=1.000>smoothness</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.712>cost model</phrase> performed by <phrase_Q=0.801>programmable graphics hardware</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.721>main idea</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.552>an efficient</phrase> implementation of this <phrase_Q=1.000>dynamic programming</phrase> approach is a <phrase_Q=0.855>recursive</phrase> scheme to calculate the <phrase_Q=0.846>min</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>convolution</phrase> in a manner suitable for the <phrase_Q=0.831>parallel</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stream</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.641>computation model</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.967>graphics processing units</phrase>. Since many <phrase_Q=0.881>image similarity</phrase> functions can be efficiently calculated by <phrase_Q=0.681>modern graphics hardware</phrase>, it is reasonable to address the final disparity extraction by <phrase_Q=0.906>graphics processors</phrase> as well. Our timing <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> indicate that the proposed approach is beneficial for larger <phrase_Q=0.641>image resolutions</phrase> and disparity <phrase_Q=1.000>ranges</phrase> in particular.
A <phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.790>Correlation Measure</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.825>Correspondence</phrase> Estimation.
A <phrase_Q=0.837>median</phrase> correlation for the estimation of corresponding points in <phrase_Q=0.852>stereovision</phrase> is proposed. It is based on the <phrase_Q=0.817>normalised</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>correlation coefficient</phrase> using the <phrase_Q=0.837>median</phrase> instead of the mean. Its performance appears to be <phrase_Q=1.000>superior</phrase> than conventional correlation specially in <phrase_Q=0.878>depth discontinuities</phrase> image areas. This conclusion is derived from <phrase_Q=0.518>an empirical evaluation</phrase> in which the proposed correlation is compared with the <phrase_Q=0.817>normalised</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>correlation coefficient</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=0.724>sum of absolute difference</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show that the <phrase_Q=0.837>median</phrase> correlation produces <phrase_Q=0.566>higher scores</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>lower</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.790>estimation errors</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.806>Scale Selection</phrase> for the Analysis of <phrase_Q=0.802>Point-Sampled</phrase> Curves.
An important task in the analysis and <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.833>curvilinear</phrase> structures from unorganized 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.582>point samples</phrase> is the estimation of <phrase_Q=1.000>tangent</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> at each <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> point. Its main challenges are in (1) the selection of an appropriate scale of analysis to accommodate noise, <phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase> variation and <phrase_Q=0.839>sparsity</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>, and in (2) the formulation of a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> and associated <phrase_Q=0.849>objective function</phrase> that correctly expresses their effects. We pose this problem as one of <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>neighborhood</phrase> size for which the <phrase_Q=0.831>principal eigenvector</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.838>scatter</phrase> matrix is best aligned with the true <phrase_Q=1.000>tangent</phrase> of the curve, in a <phrase_Q=0.853>probabilistic</phrase> sense. We analyze the <phrase_Q=1.000>perturbation</phrase> on the direction of the <phrase_Q=1.000>eigenvector</phrase> due to <phrase_Q=0.726>finite samples</phrase> and noise using the expected <phrase_Q=1.000>statistics</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.838>scatter</phrase> matrix estimators, and employ a simple <phrase_Q=0.836>iterative</phrase> procedure to choose the <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>neighborhood</phrase> size. Experiments on synthetic and <phrase_Q=0.676>real data</phrase> validate the behavior predicted by the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, and show <phrase_Q=0.606>competitive performance</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.804>improved</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>stability</phrase> over leading <phrase_Q=1.000>polynomial</phrase>-fitting alternatives that require a preset scale.
3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.955>Natural Scenes</phrase> with View-<phrase_Q=0.819>Adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.667>Multi-Texturing</phrase>.
We present a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> system that operates on a number of <phrase_Q=0.514>input photographs</phrase> that show a <phrase_Q=0.921>natural scene</phrase>. Approaches from <phrase_Q=0.682>computer graphics</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>image processing</phrase> are combined and performance is shown via experiments. Furthermore, <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> quality is analyzed w.r.t. the number and distribution of textures, used for <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> pipeline starts with <phrase_Q=0.933>image acquisition</phrase>, which consists of a number of photographs of the scene that are sequentially taken at different positions. Since the photographs are not acquired concurrently, they are influenced by different <phrase_Q=0.862>illumination conditions</phrase> that we mandate to be preserved in the final 3D representation. In the <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> step, <phrase_Q=0.894>object segmentation</phrase> is applied and <phrase_Q=0.966>camera calibration</phrase> provided. This allows the application of <phrase_Q=0.775>shape-from-silhouette</phrase> approaches, namely a <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase> approach, where different <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> layers are organized within an <phrase_Q=1.000>octree</phrase> structure. For <phrase_Q=0.801>applying</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>texture mapping</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>voxel</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is transformed into a <phrase_Q=0.810>wireframe</phrase>, which provides <phrase_Q=0.805>smoothing</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.737>object's surface</phrase> and also reduces the number of surface primitives. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=1.000>subset</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.629>original images</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.583>mapped onto</phrase> the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> to provide <phrase_Q=0.645>texture information</phrase>. Here, view-<phrase_Q=0.819>adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.667>multi-texturing</phrase> is used to preserve <phrase_Q=0.778>natural illumination</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.795>Intermediate views</phrase> are interpolated automatically using <phrase_Q=0.819>adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> weight calculations for original textures.
<phrase_Q=0.810>Efficient</phrase> Constraint Evaluation <phrase_Q=1.000>Algorithms</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.850>Hierarchical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.622>Next-Best-View</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>Planning</phrase>.
We <phrase_Q=0.815>recently</phrase> proposed a new and <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>next</phrase>-best-view <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.824>indoor</phrase> scenes using <phrase_Q=0.823>active</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> sensing. We overcome the computation difficulty of <phrase_Q=0.800>evaluating</phrase> the view metric <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> by using <phrase_Q=0.531>an adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> approach to exploit the various <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> coherences inherent in the <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> constraints and <phrase_Q=0.890>quality requirements</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.827>impressive speedups</phrase> have allowed our NBV <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to become the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> to be able to exhaustively evaluate a large set of 3D views with respect to a large set of surfaces, and to include many <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> constraints and <phrase_Q=0.890>quality requirements</phrase>. The success of the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is greatly dependent on the implementation efficiency of the constraint and <phrase_Q=0.648>quality evaluations</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we describe the <phrase_Q=0.838>algorithmic</phrase> details of the <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> view evaluation, and present <phrase_Q=0.686>efficient algorithms</phrase> that evaluate sensing constraints and surface <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> densities between a view volume and a <phrase_Q=0.881>surface patch</phrase> instead of simply between a <phrase_Q=0.863>single view</phrase> point and a <phrase_Q=0.531>surface point</phrase>. The presentation here provides examples for the <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.686>efficient algorithms</phrase> for new sensing constraints.
3D <phrase_Q=0.942>Face Recognition</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>Region</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.865>Committee</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.845>Voting</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we introduce a new system for <phrase_Q=0.942>face recognition</phrase> by matching 3D <phrase_Q=0.731>face shape</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> selects <phrase_Q=0.601>multiple regions</phrase> of the face for matching in an attempt to reduce the effects caused by variations in expression between <phrase_Q=0.565>gallery and probe</phrase> images. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are reported using the <phrase_Q=0.810>Face Recognition Grand Challenge</phrase> v2.0 <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> set. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> demonstrate <phrase_Q=0.804>improved</phrase> performance relative to those of four <phrase_Q=0.774>previous papers</phrase> using this same <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> set.
<phrase_Q=0.803>Towards</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.580>On-Line</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Digital</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Doubles</phrase>.
We present a <phrase_Q=0.831>modular</phrase> system for <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> 3D-scanning of <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> bodies under motion. The <phrase_Q=0.931>high-resolution</phrase> shape and <phrase_Q=0.836>colour</phrase> appearance is captured by several scanning units positioned around the object of interest. Each of these units performs a <phrase_Q=0.887>foreground-background segmentation</phrase> and computes a valid <phrase_Q=0.622>depth-range</phrase> for the spatially neighbouring units. Multiple depth-<phrase_Q=1.000>ranges</phrase> are combined in a <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>hull</phrase> representation, which limits the <phrase_Q=0.774>search-range</phrase> for the 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.934>Depth-estimation</phrase> is based on a <phrase_Q=0.850>hierarchical</phrase> mult-<phrase_Q=0.704>view-stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.919>plane sweep</phrase> approach. Robustness and accuracy is increased by incorporating imperceptible <phrase_Q=1.000>infrared</phrase> illumination as well as adding <phrase_Q=0.555>local pixel</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>gradient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase>. All parts of the <phrase_Q=0.698>processing pipeline</phrase>, involving <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> conversions, segmentation, <phrase_Q=0.622>depth-range</phrase> computation, <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>hull</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.801>generation</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.952>lossless image compression</phrase>, network transfer of the <phrase_Q=1.000>infrared</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.836>colour</phrase> images, and the <phrase_Q=0.737>plane sweep algorithm</phrase>, are implemented on the <phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.800>highly optimized</phrase> for speed, allowing scanning times of less than 40ms per <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> demonstrate the applicability of our system to the creation of <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.580>on-line</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>digital</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>doubles</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>High</phrase>-Quality <phrase_Q=0.662>Real-Time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.819>Adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.696>Cost Aggregation</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Dynamic Programming</phrase>.
We present a <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> that <phrase_Q=0.551>achieves high</phrase> quality <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> while maintaining <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> performance. The <phrase_Q=0.665>key idea</phrase> is simple: we introduce <phrase_Q=0.531>an adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>aggregation</phrase> step in a <phrase_Q=1.000>dynamic-programming</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.867>DP</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> framework. The <phrase_Q=0.625>per-pixel</phrase> matching cost is aggregated in the <phrase_Q=0.817>vertical</phrase> direction only. Compared to traditional <phrase_Q=0.867>DP</phrase>, our approach reduces the typical "<phrase_Q=1.000>streaking</phrase>" artifacts without the penalty of blurry <phrase_Q=0.827>object boundaries</phrase>. Evaluation using the benchmark <phrase_Q=1.000>Middlebury</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> shows that our approach is among the best (ranked <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> in the new evaluation system) for <phrase_Q=0.867>DP</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.639>based approaches</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.648>performance gain</phrase> mainly comes from a <phrase_Q=0.849>computationally expensive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>weighting</phrase> scheme based on <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> and distance proximity. We utilize the <phrase_Q=0.863>vector processing</phrase> capability and parallelism in <phrase_Q=0.802>commodity graphics hardware</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.555>speed up</phrase> this process over two <phrase_Q=0.616>orders of magnitude</phrase>. Over <phrase_Q=0.529>50 million</phrase> disparity evaluations per <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.849>MDE</phrase>/<phrase_Q=0.812>s</phrase>)1 are achieved in our current implementation.
A <phrase_Q=0.571>Spatio-Temporal Modeling</phrase> Method for <phrase_Q=0.919>Shape Representation</phrase>.
The <phrase_Q=1.000>spherical harmonic</phrase> (SPHARM) description is a powerful <phrase_Q=0.792>surface modeling</phrase> technique that can <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.966>arbitrarily shaped</phrase> but <phrase_Q=1.000>simply connected</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.668>three dimensional</phrase> (3D) objects. Because SPHARM based 3D models can derive <phrase_Q=0.811>functional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> analysis and classify different pathological symptoms, it has been used in many applications in <phrase_Q=0.816>biomedical</phrase> image <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase>. There is an urgent requirement for <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.930>spatio-temporal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.877>shape modeling</phrase> to represent the <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.931>anatomical structures</phrase> in many applications (e.g., <phrase_Q=1.000>medical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>image analysis</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.898>geospatial information</phrase> systems). In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we propose a novel real <phrase_Q=1.000>spherical harmonics</phrase> based <phrase_Q=0.930>spatio-temporal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.877>shape modeling</phrase> method to efficiently and flexibly represent the shapes <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.931>anatomical structures</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>medical</phrase> images. Our <phrase_Q=0.520>method works</phrase> well on the <phrase_Q=1.000>simply connected</phrase> 3D objects and the effectiveness of our approach is demonstrated through theoretic and <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.802>exploration</phrase> of a set of <phrase_Q=1.000>medical</phrase> image applications. Furthermore, an <phrase_Q=0.640>evaluation criterion</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.930>spatio-temporal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.877>shape modeling</phrase> efficiency is proposed and the <phrase_Q=0.513>comparison results</phrase> showed the good performance of our method.
<phrase_Q=0.810>Efficient</phrase>, Precise, and Accurate Utilization of the <phrase_Q=0.827>Uniqueness</phrase> Constraint in <phrase_Q=0.877>Multi-View Stereo</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.891>depth cue</phrase> due to the assumption of texture <phrase_Q=0.827>uniqueness</phrase> is reviewed. The <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> direction over which a <phrase_Q=0.942>similarity measure</phrase> is optimized, in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to establish a <phrase_Q=0.956>stereo correspondence</phrase>, is considered and methods to increase the precision and accuracy of <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> reconstructions are presented. <phrase_Q=0.552>An efficient</phrase> implementation of the above methods is offered, based on optimizations that evaluate potential correspondences hierarchically, in the <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.812>angular</phrase> dimensions. Furthermore, the <phrase_Q=0.803>expansion</phrase> of the above techniques in a <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-view framework where <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> errors cause the misregistration of individually obtained reconstructions are considered, and a treatment of the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> is proposed for the <phrase_Q=0.824>elimination</phrase> of duplicate reconstructions of a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.531>surface point</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, a processing step is proposed for the increase of <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> precision and <phrase_Q=0.912>post-processing</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.678>final result</phrase>. The above contributions are integrated in a <phrase_Q=0.809>generic</phrase> and parallelizable implementation of the <phrase_Q=0.827>uniqueness</phrase> constraint to observe speedup and increase in the fidelity of <phrase_Q=0.954>surface reconstruction</phrase>.
Orientation of Fragments of Rotationally <phrase_Q=0.814>Symmetrical</phrase> 3D-Shapes for <phrase_Q=1.000>Archaeological</phrase> Documentation.
Motivated by the requirements of modern <phrase_Q=1.000>archaeologists</phrase>, we are developing a documentation system based on <phrase_Q=0.944>structured light</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> of ceramics. Fragments of ceramics are <phrase_Q=1.000>daily</phrase> finds at excavations and important for <phrase_Q=1.000>archaeological</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase>, because their shape leads to <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> about <phrase_Q=0.849>ancient</phrase> cultures. The shapes used for documentation are called profile lines and estimated by a <phrase_Q=0.817>vertical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.802>cross</phrase>-section of <phrase_Q=0.833>orientated</phrase> fragments. As ceramics have been <phrase_Q=1.000>produced</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.832>rotational</phrase> plates for several thousands of years, the <phrase_Q=0.832>rotational</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>axis</phrase> can be used for orientation. Therefore we <phrase_Q=0.590>conducted experiments</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.640>existing methods</phrase> for estimation of the <phrase_Q=0.832>rotational</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>axis</phrase>. The drawbacks of these methods are the requirement of either complete objects or <phrase_Q=0.822>industrialized</phrase> quality of <phrase_Q=1.000>symmetry</phrase>. Therefore we show a new method using <phrase_Q=1.000>circle</phrase> templates, which has been inspired by the manual method of <phrase_Q=1.000>archaeologists</phrase>. In this work we present <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> using previous and related work in comparison with the estimation of the <phrase_Q=0.832>rotational</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>axis</phrase> using <phrase_Q=1.000>circle</phrase> templates. The <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> of the presented methods are shown for <phrase_Q=0.775>synthetic data</phrase>, well-known fragments and <phrase_Q=0.676>real data</phrase> acquired at an <phrase_Q=1.000>archaeological</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.861>excavation</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase> a conclusion and an <phrase_Q=0.877>outlook</phrase> is given.
<phrase_Q=0.768>Point Containment</phrase> in Discrete <phrase_Q=0.912>Arbitrary Dimension</phrase>.
The <phrase_Q=0.768>point containment</phrase> predicate which specifies if a point is part of a <phrase_Q=0.612>mathematically defined</phrase> shape is one of the most <phrase_Q=1.000>elementary</phrase> operations in <phrase_Q=0.682>computer graphics</phrase> and is a natural way to perform the many <phrase_Q=1.000>raster</phrase> calculations. It plays an essential role in several important processes such as filling, stroking, <phrase_Q=1.000>anti-aliasing</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.908>geometric modeling</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>volume rendering</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents a <phrase_Q=0.840>generalized</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.768>point containment</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.912>arbitrary dimension</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.580>discrete objects</phrase> whose <phrase_Q=0.633>main characteristics</phrase> are <phrase_Q=0.920>low complexity</phrase>, simple <phrase_Q=1.000>data structures</phrase> and suitability for <phrase_Q=0.910>hardware implementation</phrase>.

New <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> sources and sensors bring new possibilities for <phrase_Q=0.843>terrain</phrase> representations, and new types of characteristic errors. We develop a system to visualize and compare <phrase_Q=0.843>terrain</phrase> representations and the errors they produce.
<phrase_Q=0.803>Exploiting</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.822>Spatial</phrase> Continuity for <phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.838>Horizon</phrase> Matching across Faults.
<phrase_Q=0.573>Oil and gas exploration</phrase> decisions are made based on inferences obtained from <phrase_Q=0.891>seismic data</phrase> interpretation. The interpretation task is getting very <phrase_Q=0.542>time-consuming</phrase> as <phrase_Q=0.891>seismic data</phrase> sets become larger. <phrase_Q=1.000>Image processing</phrase> tools such as <phrase_Q=0.847>auto</phrase>-trackers assist manual interpretation of <phrase_Q=0.838>horizons</phrase>-visible boundaries between certain <phrase_Q=1.000>sediment</phrase> layers in <phrase_Q=0.891>seismic data</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.847>Auto</phrase>-trackers assume <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> continuities; therefore, their <phrase_Q=0.832>assistance</phrase> is very limited in areas of discontinuities such as faults. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we present a method for <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.838>horizon</phrase> matching across faults based on a <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> approach. A <phrase_Q=1.000>stochastic</phrase> matching <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> which integrates 3d <phrase_Q=0.887>spatial information</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.891>seismic data</phrase> and prior <phrase_Q=0.824>geological</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>knowledge</phrase> is introduced. The <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase> matching <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> is found by <phrase_Q=0.835>MAP</phrase> estimate of this <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=1.000>simulated annealing</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.940>reversible jump Markov Chain Monte Carlo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is employed to sample from <phrase_Q=0.585>a-posteriori</phrase> distribution. The <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> was applied to real 3d <phrase_Q=0.891>seismic data</phrase>, and has shown to produce geologically acceptable <phrase_Q=0.838>horizons</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>matchings</phrase>.
