The proposed system is an effective tool for producing 3D content amenable to a great number of applications.
<phrase_Q=0.838>Qualitative</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.808>Characterization</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.818>Deforming Surfaces</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> extends the idea of <phrase_Q=0.718>classification schemes</phrase> for static <phrase_Q=0.939>surface curvature</phrase> into the <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase> domain. We seek to identify regions in sequences of <phrase_Q=0.540>depth data</phrase> that exhibit variations in <phrase_Q=0.657>shape change</phrase>, and to characterise the <phrase_Q=1.000>nature</phrase> of the deformation. From observing the change in principle curvatures we show how it is possible to decouple the type of change into one of fifteen classes, and also reveal the extent of alteration. <phrase_Q=1.000>Results</phrase> are presented for synthetic and <phrase_Q=0.676>real data</phrase> sequences, with additional <phrase_Q=0.814>alignment</phrase> performed to accommodate <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> motion. This technique <phrase_Q=0.629>shows promise</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.818>analysing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase>-rate <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> sensors, with <phrase_Q=0.572>potential applications</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.826>biometric</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>psychological</phrase> analysis of the face and other <phrase_Q=0.955>deformable objects</phrase>.
Constraint <phrase_Q=0.821>Integration</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.859>Multiview</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.965>Pose Estimation</phrase> of Humans with <phrase_Q=0.810>Self</phrase>-Occlusions.
Detection of <phrase_Q=0.934>articulated objects</phrase> such as humans is an important task in <phrase_Q=0.688>computer vision</phrase>. We present a system that incorporates a <phrase_Q=1.000>variety</phrase> of constraints in <phrase_Q=0.524>a unified</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-view framework to <phrase_Q=0.682>automatically detect</phrase> humans in possibly <phrase_Q=0.951>crowded scenes</phrase>. These constraints include the <phrase_Q=1.000>kinematic</phrase> constraints, the occlusion of one part by another and the <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> correlation between the appearance of parts such as the two <phrase_Q=1.000>arms</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>graphical</phrase> structure (non-<phrase_Q=1.000>tree</phrase>) obtained is optimized in a <phrase_Q=0.905>nonparametric belief propagation</phrase> framework using prior <phrase_Q=0.591>based search</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.944>Structured Light</phrase> Based <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> under <phrase_Q=0.544>Local Spatial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.828>Coherence</phrase> Assumption.
3D scanning techniques based on <phrase_Q=0.944>structured light</phrase> usually achieve <phrase_Q=0.521>robustness against</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>outliers</phrase> by performing <phrase_Q=0.625>multiple projections</phrase> to simplify <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase>. However, for cases such as <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> scenes, the number of frames captured from a certain view must be kept as low as possible, which makes it difficult to reconstruct <phrase_Q=0.908>complex scenes</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>frequency</phrase> shapes and inappropriate <phrase_Q=0.831>reflection</phrase> properties. To tackle this problem, we present a novel set of <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.841>stripe</phrase> patterns and a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> that assume <phrase_Q=0.544>local spatial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.828>coherence</phrase> in the captured <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. This assumption allows us to <phrase_Q=1.000>design</phrase> our <phrase_Q=0.841>stripe</phrase> sequences with <phrase_Q=0.657>globally unique</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>neighborhood</phrase> properties to effectively avoid wrong correspondences. The concept of <phrase_Q=0.544>local spatial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.828>coherence</phrase> is further exploited to make the ensuing <phrase_Q=0.954>surface reconstruction</phrase> practically insensitive to noise, <phrase_Q=1.000>outliers</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>anisotropic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>density</phrase>. Thus, the recovery of a <phrase_Q=1.000>topologically</phrase> consistent <phrase_Q=1.000>manifold</phrase> surface can be drastically <phrase_Q=0.824>simplified</phrase>. We have successfully generated <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> quality meshes of various <phrase_Q=0.716>colored objects</phrase> using a <phrase_Q=0.850>minimalistic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.557>projector-camera system</phrase>. In particular, the full <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> capabilities of our devices can be exhausted by taking only three shots.
Recognition of <phrase_Q=1.000>Free</phrase>-Form Objects in <phrase_Q=0.908>Complex Scenes</phrase> Using DGI-<phrase_Q=1.000>BS</phrase> Models.
<phrase_Q=0.956>Object recognition</phrase> in 3D scenes with occlusion means <phrase_Q=0.805>identifying</phrase> an incomplete and unknown object, which is arbitrarily posed, in an <phrase_Q=1.000>object database</phrase>. This hard <phrase_Q=0.688>computer vision</phrase> problem is solved in this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> through a new 3D <phrase_Q=0.919>shape representation</phrase> called Depth <phrase_Q=1.000>Gradient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.851>Image Based</phrase> on <phrase_Q=1.000>Silhouette</phrase> (DGI-<phrase_Q=1.000>BS</phrase>). DGI-<phrase_Q=1.000>BS</phrase> can be used to obtain a complete <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> as well as a <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of an object. This <phrase_Q=1.000>property</phrase> allows us to use it in <phrase_Q=0.908>complex scenes</phrase> where incomplete surfaces of objects are available. The complete DGI-<phrase_Q=1.000>BS</phrase> version synthesizes surface <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> (through <phrase_Q=0.813>depth image</phrase>) and <phrase_Q=0.784>shape information</phrase> (through <phrase_Q=0.806>contour</phrase>) of the whole object in a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> image smaller than 1 <phrase_Q=0.889>mega pixel</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.956>Object recognition</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.501>carried out</phrase> by means of a simple <phrase_Q=0.733>matching algorithm</phrase> in the DGI-<phrase_Q=1.000>BS</phrase> space which yields a <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.556>point-to-point</phrase> between scene and <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. This method has been <phrase_Q=0.655>successfully tested</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.899>real scenes</phrase> with no special restrictions using <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> sensors.
<phrase_Q=0.832>Visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Hull</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Construction</phrase> in the Presence of <phrase_Q=0.823>Partial</phrase> Occlusion.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose a <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>hull</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>, which guarantees a correct <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> even in the presence of <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> occlusion, while "correct" here means that the real shape is <phrase_Q=0.714>located inside</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>hull</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is based on a new idea of the "<phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase>", which requires the <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.974>background subtraction</phrase> and the "occlusion mask" of the same view. In <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to prepare the occlusion mask, we also propose a novel concept of "effective boundary" of <phrase_Q=0.703>moving foreground objects</phrase> in a <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> obtained from a <phrase_Q=0.612>static camera</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.823>accumulation</phrase> of the effective boundary through time automatically gives <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> occluder boundaries. We <phrase_Q=0.565>theoretically prove</phrase> that our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> deterministically computes the tightest, correct <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>hull</phrase> in the presence of occlusion. Both synthetic and real examples are given as a <phrase_Q=0.815>demonstration</phrase> of the correctness of the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase> we analyze that this new <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is still within the time complexity of the traditional method.
<phrase_Q=0.774>Aerial LiDAR Data</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.736>Classification Using Support Vector Machines</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>SVM</phrase>).
We classify 3D <phrase_Q=0.830>aerial</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>LiDAR</phrase> scattered height <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> into buildings, <phrase_Q=1.000>trees</phrase>, roads, and <phrase_Q=1.000>grass</phrase> using the <phrase_Q=1.000>Support Vector Machine</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>SVM</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. To do so we use five features: height, height variation, <phrase_Q=0.634>normal variation</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>LiDAR</phrase> return intensity, and <phrase_Q=0.838>image intensity</phrase>. We also use only <phrase_Q=1.000>LiDAR</phrase>-derived features to organize the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> into three classes (the <phrase_Q=1.000>road</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>grass</phrase> classes are merged). We have implemented and experimented with several variations of the <phrase_Q=1.000>SVM</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.845>soft</phrase>-margin classification to allow for the noise in the <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. We have applied our <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> to classify <phrase_Q=0.774>aerial LiDAR data</phrase> collected over approximately 8 <phrase_Q=0.821>square</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.853>miles</phrase>. We visualize the <phrase_Q=0.565>classification results</phrase> along with the associated confidence using a variation of the <phrase_Q=1.000>SVM</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> producing <phrase_Q=0.853>probabilistic</phrase> classifications. We observe that the <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are stable and <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase>. We compare the <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> against the <phrase_Q=0.942>ground truth</phrase> and obtain higher than 90% accuracy and convincing <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.813>Resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>Scalable</phrase> Coding and <phrase_Q=1.000>Region</phrase> of Interest Access with <phrase_Q=0.668>Three-Dimensional</phrase> SBHP <phrase_Q=1.000>Algorithm</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=0.920>low-complexity</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>image compression</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> based on <phrase_Q=1.000>wavelet</phrase> transforms and <phrase_Q=0.850>set-partitioning</phrase> strategy is presented. The <phrase_Q=0.823>Subband</phrase> Block <phrase_Q=0.888>Hierarchial</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>Partitioning</phrase> (SBHP) <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is modified and <phrase_Q=0.816>extended</phrase> to three dimensions, and applied to every code block independently. The resultant <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>, 3D-SBHP, efficiently encodes 3D <phrase_Q=0.770>image data</phrase> by the <phrase_Q=0.827>exploitation</phrase> of the dependencies in all dimensions, while enabling <phrase_Q=0.851>progressive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.844>SNR</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>decompression</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>Region</phrase>-of-Interest (<phrase_Q=0.854>ROI</phrase>) access from the same <phrase_Q=1.000>bit</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stream</phrase>. The code-<phrase_Q=0.542>block selection</phrase> method by which <phrase_Q=1.000>random access</phrase> decoding can be achieved is outlined.The <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>scalable</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>random access</phrase> performances are <phrase_Q=0.574>empirically investigated</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show 3D-SBHP is a good candidate to compress 3D <phrase_Q=0.770>image data</phrase> sets for <phrase_Q=1.000>multimedia</phrase> applications.
<phrase_Q=0.808>Estimating</phrase> a-priori Unknown 3D <phrase_Q=0.955>Axially Symmetric</phrase> Surfaces from <phrase_Q=0.806>Noisy</phrase> Measurements of Their Fragments.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we present a <phrase_Q=0.912>computationally efficient</phrase> technique for <phrase_Q=0.811>solving</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.505>difficult problem</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> shape of a <phrase_Q=1.000>ceramic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.870>pot</phrase> from measurements of its fragments. Each unknown <phrase_Q=0.870>pot</phrase> is modeled as a surface of <phrase_Q=1.000>revolution</phrase>, i.e., a 3D line-- the <phrase_Q=0.790>central axis</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.870>pot</phrase> -- and a 2D <phrase_Q=0.540>profile curve</phrase> with respect to that <phrase_Q=1.000>axis</phrase>. For each fragment, a <phrase_Q=0.853>probabilistic</phrase> distribution is estimated which models both the <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> shape of the fragment and the variability of the estimated fragment shape. Estimation of the <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.870>pot</phrase> shape is then a <phrase_Q=1.000>Maximum Likelihood Estimation</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.840>MLE</phrase>) problem where we seek the values of the <phrase_Q=1.000>Euclidean</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.585>transformation parameters</phrase> that maximize the <phrase_Q=0.828>joint</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>probability</phrase> of the matched fragments' <phrase_Q=1.000>axis</phrase>/profile-curvemodels (which includes the additional constraint that the matched fragments must share a common <phrase_Q=0.790>central axis</phrase>). This is a new type of curve-analysis problem and our <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> is a new and effective approach applicable for <phrase_Q=0.809>generic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.818>constrained</phrase> 2D <phrase_Q=0.638>curve alignment</phrase> and for <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> of 3D <phrase_Q=0.955>axially-symmetric</phrase> surfaces and for <phrase_Q=0.812>comparing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> models which may correspond over a <phrase_Q=1.000>subset</phrase> of the complete <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>.
On 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>Retrieval</phrase> from Photos.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose a method for 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> from one or more photos. This method provides an "<phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase>" selection of 2D views to represent a 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, and a <phrase_Q=0.853>probabilistic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> method for 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> from realistic photos and sketches using these views. The characteristic <phrase_Q=0.874>view selection</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is based on <phrase_Q=0.531>an adaptive</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.826>clustering algorithm</phrase> and uses <phrase_Q=1.000>statistical model</phrase> distribution scores to select the <phrase_Q=0.819>optimal</phrase> number of views. We also introduce a <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> approach to score the <phrase_Q=1.000>probability</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> between the queries and the 3D-models. We present our <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=1.000>Princeton</phrase> 3D Shape <phrase_Q=0.633>Benchmark database</phrase> (1814 3D-models) and 50 photos (real photographs, sketches, synthesised images). A <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.580>on-line</phrase> 3D-<phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> system based on our approach is available on the <phrase_Q=0.835>web</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.830>asset</phrase> our <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> [1].
The <phrase_Q=0.818>Reverse</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>Projection</phrase> Correlation Principle for <phrase_Q=0.716>Depth from Defocus</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we address the problem of finding <phrase_Q=0.716>depth from defocus</phrase> in a fundamentally new way. Most <phrase_Q=0.685>previous methods</phrase> have used an <phrase_Q=0.836>approximate</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> in which blurring is <phrase_Q=0.809>shift</phrase> invariant and <phrase_Q=1.000>pixel</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase> is negligible. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> avoids these assumptions. We consider the <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase> in the scene whose <phrase_Q=1.000>radiance</phrase> is recorded by a <phrase_Q=1.000>pixel</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase>, and relate the size and shape of that <phrase_Q=1.000>area</phrase> to the scene's position with respect to the plane of focus. This is the notion of <phrase_Q=0.818>reverse</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>projection</phrase>, which allows us to illustrate that, when out of focus, <phrase_Q=0.853>neighboring pixels</phrase> will record <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.669>overlapping regions</phrase> in the scene. This overlap <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> in a measurable change in the correlation between the <phrase_Q=1.000>pixels</phrase>' <phrase_Q=0.776>intensity values</phrase>. We demonstrate that this relationship can be characterized in such a way as to recover depth from <phrase_Q=0.808>defocused images</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show the ability of this relationship to <phrase_Q=0.783>accurately predict</phrase> depth from <phrase_Q=0.502>correlation measurements</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.510>Direct and Indirect</phrase> 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.807>Opti</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>Acoustic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>Imaging</phrase>.
Utilization of an <phrase_Q=1.000>acoustic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> measurements is a significant advantage for 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.901>shape recovery</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.837>underwater</phrase> targets by <phrase_Q=0.807>opti</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>acoustic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase>, where the associated <phrase_Q=0.973>epipolar geometry</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.832>visual</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>acoustic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.720>image correspondences</phrase> is described in terms of <phrase_Q=1.000>conic sections</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>trigonometric functions</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose and analyze a number of methods based on <phrase_Q=0.510>direct and indirect</phrase> approaches that <phrase_Q=0.559>provide insight</phrase> on the merits of the new <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase> and 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.741>object reconstruction</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>paradigm</phrase>. We have devised certain <phrase_Q=0.833>indirect</phrase> methods, built on a <phrase_Q=0.831>regularization</phrase> formulation, to <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> compute from <phrase_Q=0.806>noisy</phrase> correspondences <phrase_Q=1.000>maximum likelihood</phrase> estimates that satisfy the <phrase_Q=0.973>epipolar geometry</phrase>. The 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>target</phrase> points can then be determined from a number of <phrase_Q=1.000>closed-form</phrase> solutions applied to these <phrase_Q=0.858>ML</phrase> estimates. An <phrase_Q=1.000>alternative</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.811>direct</phrase> approach is also presented for 3-<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> reocnstruction directly from <phrase_Q=0.806>noisy</phrase> correspondences. Computer simulations verify consistency between the analytical and <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.854>SNRs</phrase> -- the criterion applied in <phrase_Q=0.894>performance assessment</phrase> of these various solutions.
<phrase_Q=0.782>Automatic Registration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.647>Multiple Range Images</phrase> by the Local <phrase_Q=0.914>Log-Polar</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase> Images.
We propose a method for <phrase_Q=0.782>automatic registration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.647>multiple range images</phrase> by matching <phrase_Q=0.872>invariant feature</phrase> vectors generated from the local <phrase_Q=0.914>log-polar</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> images. <phrase_Q=0.702>Point pairs</phrase> are corresponded by finding the <phrase_Q=0.964>nearest neighbor</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.872>invariant feature</phrase> vectors. The <phrase_Q=0.825>correspondence</phrase> is validated, and the pairwise transformations between the <phrase_Q=0.630>input range</phrase> images are determined by using the <phrase_Q=0.537>RANSAC algorithm</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> of all <phrase_Q=0.630>input range</phrase> images are determined by <phrase_Q=0.808>constructing</phrase> the view <phrase_Q=1.000>tree</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.630>input range</phrase> images. The <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> result of the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> is used as the <phrase_Q=0.513>initial value</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.616>fine registration</phrase> methods for <phrase_Q=0.832>object shape</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=0.831>Modular</phrase> Scheme for 2D/3D <phrase_Q=0.806>Conversion</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>TV</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Broadcast</phrase>.
The 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> from 2D <phrase_Q=1.000>broadcast</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> is a <phrase_Q=0.543>challenging problem</phrase> with many <phrase_Q=0.572>potential applications</phrase>, such as 3DTV, <phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase>-viewpoint <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> or <phrase_Q=1.000>augmented reality</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, a <phrase_Q=0.831>modular</phrase> system capable of efficiently <phrase_Q=0.816>reconstructing</phrase> 3D scenes from <phrase_Q=1.000>broadcast</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> is proposed. The system consists of four constitutive modules: <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> and segmentation, <phrase_Q=0.681>self-calibration</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.838>sparse</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> and, <phrase_Q=0.807>finally</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> also introduces some novel approaches for <phrase_Q=0.948>moving object</phrase> segmentation and <phrase_Q=0.838>sparse</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> problems. According to the simulations for both synthetic and <phrase_Q=0.676>real data</phrase>, the system achieves a <phrase_Q=0.516>promising performance</phrase> for typical <phrase_Q=1.000>TV</phrase> content, indicating that it is a significant step <phrase_Q=0.803>towards</phrase> the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> of scenes from <phrase_Q=1.000>broadcast</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.846>Fast</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.810>Efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.827>Dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.815>Variational</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> on <phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase>.
Thanks to their <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> performance and programmability, the latest <phrase_Q=1.000>graphics cards</phrase> can now be used for scientific purpose. They are indeed very <phrase_Q=0.758>efficient parallel</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.925>Single Instruction Multiple Data</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>SIMD</phrase>) machines. This new trend is called <phrase_Q=1.000>General</phrase> Purpose computation on <phrase_Q=1.000>Graphics Processing Unit</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.849>GPGPU</phrase> [4]). Regarding the <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> problem, <phrase_Q=0.815>variational</phrase> methods based on <phrase_Q=0.947>deformable models</phrase> provide <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase>, smooth and <phrase_Q=0.556>accurate results</phrase>. Nevertheless, they prove to be <phrase_Q=0.564>slower than</phrase> usual disparity-<phrase_Q=0.639>based approaches</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we present a <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.811>handling</phrase> occlusions, using three cameras as inputs and entirely implemented on a <phrase_Q=1.000>Graphics Processing Unit</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase>). <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> speedups prove that our approach is <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> and perfectly adapted to the <phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase>, leading to nearly <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>frame rate</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Face Detection</phrase>, Normalization and Recognition.
A <phrase_Q=0.921>fully automatic</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.942>face recognition</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is presented. Several novelties are introduced to make the recognition <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.937>facial expressions</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase>. These novelties include: (1) <phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>face detection</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.802>detecting</phrase> the nose; (2) <phrase_Q=0.816>Automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.748>pose correction</phrase> and normalization of the 3D face as well as its corresponding 2D face using the <phrase_Q=0.844>Hotelling</phrase> Transform; (3) A <phrase_Q=0.832>Spherical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.734>Face Representation</phrase> and its use as a <phrase_Q=0.816>rejection</phrase> classifier to quickly reject a <phrase_Q=0.522>large number</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.544>candidate faces</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> recognition; and (4) Robustness to <phrase_Q=0.937>facial expressions</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.791>automatically segmenting</phrase> the face into expression sensitive and insensitive regions. <phrase_Q=0.507>Experiments performed</phrase> on the <phrase_Q=0.832>FRGC</phrase> Ver 2.0 dataset (9,500 2D/3D faces) show that our <phrase_Q=0.630>algorithm outperforms</phrase> existing 3D <phrase_Q=0.648>recognition algorithms</phrase>. We achieved verification rates of 99.47% and 94.09% at 0.001 FAR and <phrase_Q=0.818>identification</phrase> rates of 98.03% and 89.25% for probes with neutral and non-<phrase_Q=0.740>neutral expression</phrase> respectively.
<phrase_Q=0.814>Extracting</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.856>Shape Features</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.638>Discrete Scale-Space</phrase>.
3D <phrase_Q=0.856>shape features</phrase> are inherently <phrase_Q=0.765>scale-dependent</phrase>. For instance, on a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> body, the <phrase_Q=0.820>top</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.809>head</phrase> and a <phrase_Q=0.839>fingertip</phrase> can both be detected as <phrase_Q=0.822>corner</phrase> points, however, at entirely different scales. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we present a method for <phrase_Q=0.814>extracting</phrase> and integrating 3D <phrase_Q=0.856>shape features</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=0.638>discrete scale-space</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.950>triangular mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. We <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> parameterize the surface of the <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> on a 2D plane and then construct a <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.872>surface normal</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>map</phrase>. In <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=1.000>parametrization</phrase> is not <phrase_Q=0.828>isometric</phrase>. To account for this, we compute the relative stretch of the original <phrase_Q=0.803>edge</phrase> lengths. <phrase_Q=0.822>Next</phrase>, we compute a <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>distortion</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>map</phrase> which is used to <phrase_Q=0.836>approximate</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>geodesic</phrase> distances on the <phrase_Q=0.764>normal map</phrase>. Then, we construct a <phrase_Q=0.638>discrete scale-space</phrase> of the original 3D shape by successively convolving the <phrase_Q=0.764>normal map</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>distortion</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.571>adapted Gaussian</phrase> kernels of increasing <phrase_Q=1.000>standard deviation</phrase>. We derive <phrase_Q=0.822>corner</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.803>edge</phrase> detectors to extract 3D features at each scale in the <phrase_Q=0.638>discrete scale-space</phrase>. Furthermore, we show how to combine the detector responses from different scales to form <phrase_Q=0.524>a unified</phrase> representation of the 3D features.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Philips</phrase> 3D Solutions: From <phrase_Q=0.933>Content Creation</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.811>Visualization</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Philips</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.800>realizing</phrase> an <phrase_Q=0.572>end-to-end</phrase> 3D display <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> from 3D <phrase_Q=0.933>content creation</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase>. This development fits in our <phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase>-standing tradition of combining expertise in <phrase_Q=1.000>video processing</phrase> with our strength in display development to create the most exciting and best <phrase_Q=0.696>viewing experience</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>Philips</phrase> developed several <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-quality 3D displays, ranging in <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.911>viewing angle</phrase>, depth experience, and sizes from 4" to 40" and up. <phrase_Q=0.874>Backwards compatibility</phrase> with 2D content is enabled via <phrase_Q=1.000>signal-processing</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.931>opto-electronic</phrase> 3D & 2D <phrase_Q=0.840>dual</phrase> mode displays. <phrase_Q=0.933>Content creation</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.806>conversion</phrase> methods are provided, which are a key factor for the success of 3D displays. <phrase_Q=0.921>Fully automatic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>conversion</phrase> from monoscopic 2D content into 3D enables the <phrase_Q=0.803>re</phrase>-use of all existing 2D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> material. Our efforts in <phrase_Q=1.000>MPEG</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>standardization</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>towards</phrase> the "2D-plus-depth" format for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> enables a <phrase_Q=0.821>flexible</phrase> interface between the <phrase_Q=1.000>variety</phrase> in 3D <phrase_Q=0.933>content creation</phrase> methods and the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> in 3D displays. Furthermore, the 3D format is compatible with existing 2D content, standards and <phrase_Q=1.000>infrastructure</phrase>. Currently, <phrase_Q=1.000>Philips</phrase> offers several commercial 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>products</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>professional</phrase> use such as <phrase_Q=1.000>digital signage</phrase>, and progress is being made <phrase_Q=0.803>towards</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>consumer</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>products</phrase> such as 3DTV.
<phrase_Q=0.920>Gaze Tracking</phrase> by Using <phrase_Q=0.858>Factorized</phrase> Likelihoods <phrase_Q=1.000>Particle</phrase> Filtering and <phrase_Q=0.973>Stereo Vision</phrase>.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> describes a <phrase_Q=0.668>non-intrusive</phrase> method to estimate the <phrase_Q=0.804>gaze</phrase> direction of a person by using <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> cameras. <phrase_Q=0.817>First</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.922>facial features</phrase> are tracked with an adapted <phrase_Q=0.971>particle filtering</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.858>factorized</phrase> likelihoods to estimate the 3D <phrase_Q=0.809>head</phrase> pose. <phrase_Q=0.822>Next</phrase> the 3D <phrase_Q=0.804>gaze</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>vector</phrase> is calculated by <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.809>eyeball</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>center</phrase> and the <phrase_Q=1.000>cornea</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>center</phrase> of both <phrase_Q=0.803>eyes</phrase>. For the intended application of <phrase_Q=1.000>visual perception</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase>, we also propose a new screen <phrase_Q=0.818>registration</phrase> scheme to <phrase_Q=0.749>accurately locate</phrase> a <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> screen in <phrase_Q=0.653>world coordinates</phrase> within 2 <phrase_Q=0.850>mm</phrase> error. We combine the 3D screen location with the 3D <phrase_Q=0.804>gaze</phrase> vectors from both <phrase_Q=0.803>eyes</phrase> to establish a point of focus on the screen. The <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> indicate that an <phrase_Q=1.000>average</phrase> error of the <phrase_Q=0.804>gaze</phrase> direction of about 4.6± can be achieved and an <phrase_Q=1.000>average</phrase> error of about 4 <phrase_Q=0.850>mm</phrase> for the focus <phrase_Q=0.891>point location</phrase> at a <phrase_Q=0.737>viewing distance</phrase> of 50 <phrase_Q=0.855>cm</phrase>.
Invariant <phrase_Q=1.000>High</phrase> Level <phrase_Q=0.945>Reeb Graphs</phrase> of 3D <phrase_Q=0.969>Polygonal Meshes</phrase>.
Many applications in <phrase_Q=0.682>computer graphics</phrase> need <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> level <phrase_Q=0.839>shape descriptions</phrase>, in <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> to benefit from a <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.816>understanding</phrase> of shapes. <phrase_Q=1.000>Topological</phrase> approaches enable pertinent surface decompositions, providing <phrase_Q=0.829>structural</phrase> descriptions of 3D <phrase_Q=0.969>polygonal meshes</phrase>; but in practice, their use raises several difficulties. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we present a novel method for the <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> of invariant <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> level <phrase_Q=0.945>Reeb graphs</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>topological</phrase> entities that give a good <phrase_Q=0.839>overview</phrase> of the shape structure. With this aim, we propose an accurate and straightforward <phrase_Q=0.703>feature point extraction</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for the computation of an invariant and meaningful <phrase_Q=0.832>quotient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase>. Moreover, we propose a new <phrase_Q=1.000>graph</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>, based on an analysis of the connectivity evolutions of discrete <phrase_Q=0.799>level lines</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> brings a <phrase_Q=0.804>practical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>solution</phrase> for the suppression of non-significant <phrase_Q=0.915>critical points</phrase> over <phrase_Q=1.000>piecewise</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>continuous</phrase> functions, providing meaningful <phrase_Q=0.945>Reeb graphs</phrase>. Presented method gives <phrase_Q=0.556>accurate results</phrase>, with satisfactory <phrase_Q=0.842>execution times</phrase> and without <phrase_Q=0.632>input parameter</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.826>geometrical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.804>invariance</phrase> of resulting <phrase_Q=1.000>graphs</phrase> and their robustness to variation in <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> pose and <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.815>sampling</phrase> make them good candidates for several applications, like <phrase_Q=0.927>shape deformation</phrase> (experimented in this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>), recognition, compression, <phrase_Q=0.818>indexing</phrase>, etc.
<phrase_Q=0.828>Recovering</phrase> Illumination and Texture Using Ratio Images.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we consider the problem of <phrase_Q=0.842>factoring</phrase> illumination and texture from a pair of images of a diffuse object of known <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase>. This <phrase_Q=0.635>problem arises</phrase> frequently in 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>photography</phrase> applications that use images to acquire <phrase_Q=1.000>photometric</phrase> properties of a scanned object. Our approach uses the ratio of the images and the <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> to compute the relative incident <phrase_Q=1.000>irradiance</phrase> of one image with respect to the other. After the <phrase_Q=1.000>irradiance</phrase> maps are recovered, we build a <phrase_Q=0.962>spatially varying</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>albedo</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.835>map</phrase>, which can then be used to render the object under different <phrase_Q=0.862>illumination conditions</phrase>. We present two <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase>, one for <phrase_Q=0.747>point-light source</phrase> illumination, and another one based on <phrase_Q=1.000>spherical harmonics</phrase> for more <phrase_Q=1.000>general</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.862>illumination conditions</phrase>.
A 3D <phrase_Q=0.840>Outdoor</phrase> Scene <phrase_Q=0.820>Scanner</phrase> Based on a <phrase_Q=1.000>Night-Vision</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Range</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.842>Gated</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.823>Active</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>Imaging</phrase> System.
We present a 3D <phrase_Q=0.840>outdoor</phrase> scene <phrase_Q=0.820>scanner</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.807>acquisition</phrase> of kilometers-<phrase_Q=0.838>deep</phrase> scenes in <phrase_Q=0.845>night</phrase> conditions. Its <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase> system is based on a <phrase_Q=0.829>compact</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.921>low-cost</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.840>pulsed</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> illuminator and a <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>intensifier</phrase> equipped <phrase_Q=1.000>CCD camera</phrase>. By precisely <phrase_Q=0.829>synchronizing</phrase> both the illuminator and the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> shutter, it is possible to acquire "slices" of the scene at specific known distances. We show that even with large <phrase_Q=1.000>laser</phrase> pulses and without <phrase_Q=1.000>megahertz</phrase>-capable <phrase_Q=1.000>electronics</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.806>third</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>dimension</phrase> can be recovered for the whole <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> of the scene by processing only two <phrase_Q=0.736>images acquired</phrase> in specific conditions. As the <phrase_Q=1.000>pixel</phrase> intensities of the images <phrase_Q=1.000>produced</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.823>active</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase> systems vary with the <phrase_Q=0.821>square</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase>, and due to the limited dynamics of <phrase_Q=0.787>image sensors</phrase>, scanning <phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> scenes with shorter "slices" allows the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> gain to be adjusted with respect to the <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> and the accuracy to be <phrase_Q=0.819>enhanced</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase> system as well as the different <phrase_Q=1.000>image processing</phrase> steps are detailed in this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> and an example of typical <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> is given.
<phrase_Q=0.870>Deformable Mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> for Complex <phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-Object 3D <phrase_Q=0.957>Motion Estimation</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-Viewpoint <phrase_Q=1.000>Video</phrase>.
We propose a new <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.870>deformable mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> for complex 3D <phrase_Q=0.957>motion estimation</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.760>multiple objects</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-viewpoint <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we define "<phrase_Q=0.575>complex motion</phrase>" as motion which includes <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> change of the <phrase_Q=0.832>object shape</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>topology</phrase>. In <phrase_Q=0.575>complex motion</phrase>, a part of the object may touch the other parts. To manage this effect, we introduce (1) "<phrase_Q=0.811>repulsive</phrase> force" into <phrase_Q=0.870>deformable mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> for simple <phrase_Q=0.957>motion estimation</phrase> which integrates texture and <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>information</phrase> into <phrase_Q=0.826>unified</phrase> computation scheme, and (2) <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>collision detection</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.870>deformable mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=0.870>deformable mesh</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.811>repulsive</phrase> force keeps hidden, collided surfaces to be touched each other, and gives <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.674>non-rigid</phrase> complex 3D motion of the object. Some <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> show that our <phrase_Q=0.762>deformation model</phrase> can estimate motions of <phrase_Q=0.760>multiple objects</phrase> and the object's motion with <phrase_Q=0.630>time-varying</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.816>global</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>topology</phrase>, and gives <phrase_Q=1.000>topologically</phrase>-consistent <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> models which can be <phrase_Q=0.819>compressed</phrase> efficiently by conventional <phrase_Q=0.889>inter-frame</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>data compression</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> and be used for 3D <phrase_Q=0.867>motion analysis</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Computing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.937>Camera Motion</phrase> Direction from Many Images.
We analyze the problem of <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> a camera's <phrase_Q=0.727>motion direction</phrase> from a calibrated <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=0.919>image sequence</phrase>. We assume that the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> moves roughly along a line and that its <phrase_Q=1.000>velocity</phrase> and orientation are unknown and can vary over time. For <phrase_Q=1.000>infinitesimal</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> motion (<phrase_Q=0.620>multiple flows</phrase> rather than <phrase_Q=0.671>multiple images</phrase>), we give a <phrase_Q=1.000>closed-form expression</phrase> for the result of minimizing the true <phrase_Q=0.752>least-squares</phrase> error over all variables but the camera's <phrase_Q=0.727>motion direction</phrase>. Our result includes the <phrase_Q=0.849>rigidity</phrase> constraint that the scene stays fixed over time. For finite motion, we present a <phrase_Q=0.868>noniterative</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> that approximates the <phrase_Q=0.836>exact</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-image coplanarity error to better than a percent. Also, we define a new error contribution that incorporates the <phrase_Q=0.849>rigidity</phrase> constraint and is analogous to the <phrase_Q=0.849>rigidity</phrase> component of the error for <phrase_Q=1.000>infinitesimal</phrase> motion. By adding this to the coplanarity error, we obtain a <phrase_Q=0.868>noniterative</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> that approximates the complete finite motion <phrase_Q=0.752>least-squares</phrase> error--including <phrase_Q=0.849>rigidity</phrase>--as a <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> just of the <phrase_Q=1.000>translation</phrase> direction.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Minimum Spanning Tree</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.965>Pose Estimation</phrase>.
The <phrase_Q=0.729>extrinsic camera parameters</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stream</phrase> images can be <phrase_Q=0.652>accurately estimated</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> features through the <phrase_Q=0.919>image sequence</phrase> and using these features to compute <phrase_Q=0.842>parameter estimates</phrase>. The poses for <phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> sequences have been estimated in this manner. However, the poses of large sets of still images cannot be estimated using the same strategy because <phrase_Q=0.928>wide-baseline</phrase> correspondences are not as <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> as <phrase_Q=0.728>narrow-baseline</phrase> feature tracks. Moreover, <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.965>pose estimation</phrase> requires a linear or hierarchically-<phrase_Q=0.779>linear ordering</phrase> on the images to be calibrated, reducing the image matches to the neighboring <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> frames. We propose a novel <phrase_Q=0.820>generalization</phrase> to the <phrase_Q=0.779>linear ordering</phrase> requirement of <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.965>pose estimation</phrase> by <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>Minimum Spanning Tree</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.896>adjacency graph</phrase> and using the <phrase_Q=1.000>tree</phrase> hierarchy to determine the <phrase_Q=0.829>calibration</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>order</phrase> for a set of <phrase_Q=0.614>input images</phrase>. We validate the pose accuracy using an <phrase_Q=0.813>error metric</phrase> that is <phrase_Q=0.612>functionally independent</phrase> of the estimation process. Because we do not rely on <phrase_Q=0.894>feature tracking</phrase> for generating <phrase_Q=0.883>feature correspondences</phrase>, our method can use internally calibrated wide- or <phrase_Q=0.728>narrow-baseline</phrase> images as input, and can estimate the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> poses from <phrase_Q=0.667>multiple video streams</phrase> without special <phrase_Q=0.865>pre-processing</phrase> to concatenate the streams.
<phrase_Q=0.859>Multiview</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.814>Tracking</phrase> with an Incrementally Constructed 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase>.
We propose a <phrase_Q=0.859>multiview</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> method for <phrase_Q=0.899>rigid objects</phrase>. Assuming that a part of the object is visible in at least two cameras, a <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is reconstructed in terms of a collection of small 3D <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> patches of <phrase_Q=0.849>arbitrary topology</phrase>. The 3D representation, recovered <phrase_Q=0.653>fully automatically</phrase>, allows to formulate <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> as <phrase_Q=1.000>gradient</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>minimization</phrase> in pose (<phrase_Q=1.000>translation</phrase>, rotation) space. As the object moves, the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.731>incrementally updated</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=0.841>virtuous</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>circle</phrase> emerges: <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> enables composition of the <phrase_Q=0.823>partial</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>; the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> facilitates and robustifies the <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-view <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase>. We <phrase_Q=0.639>demonstrate experimentally</phrase> that the <phrase_Q=0.829>interleaved</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>track</phrase>-and-reconstruct approach successfully tracks a <phrase_Q=0.636>360 degrees</phrase> turn-around and a <phrase_Q=0.895>wide range</phrase> of motions. <phrase_Q=1.000>Monocular</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> is also possible after the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> is constructed. Using more cameras, however, <phrase_Q=0.715>significantly increases</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>stability</phrase> in critical poses and moves. We demonstrate how to exploit the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> to increases <phrase_Q=0.809>stability</phrase> in the presence of uneven and/or changing illumination.
<phrase_Q=0.855>Hemispherical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Harmonic</phrase> Surface Description and Applications to <phrase_Q=1.000>Medical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Image Analysis</phrase>.
The use of surface <phrase_Q=1.000>harmonics</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.550>rigid and nonrigid</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.924>shape description</phrase> is well known. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we define a set of complete <phrase_Q=0.855>hemispherical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>harmonic</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.947>basis functions</phrase> on a hemisphere domain and propose a novel <phrase_Q=0.644>parametric shape</phrase> description method to efficiently and flexibly represent the surfaces of <phrase_Q=0.931>anatomical structures</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>medical</phrase> images. As the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> application of <phrase_Q=0.855>hemispherical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>harmonic</phrase> theory in <phrase_Q=0.924>shape description</phrase>, our technique differs from the previous surface <phrase_Q=1.000>harmonics</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.943>shape descriptors</phrase>, all of which don't work efficiently on the hemisphere-like objects that often exist in <phrase_Q=1.000>medical</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.931>anatomical structures</phrase> (e.g., <phrase_Q=0.826>ventricles</phrase>, atriums, etc.). We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through theoretic and <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.802>exploration</phrase> of a set of <phrase_Q=1.000>medical</phrase> image applications. Furthermore, an <phrase_Q=0.640>evaluation criterion</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.792>surface modeling</phrase> efficiency is described and the <phrase_Q=0.513>comparison results</phrase> demonstrated that our method outperformed the <phrase_Q=0.745>previous approaches</phrase> using <phrase_Q=1.000>spherical harmonic</phrase> models.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Belief Propagation</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>Panorama</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.801>Generation</phrase>.
We present an <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for generating <phrase_Q=0.949>panoramic images</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.908>complex scenes</phrase> from a <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>. We further present a <phrase_Q=0.801>programmable graphics hardware</phrase> implementation to process the <phrase_Q=0.848>large data sets</phrase> more quickly. Because the sensors do not share the same <phrase_Q=1.000>center</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.821>projection</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.546>nearby objects</phrase> may not be <phrase_Q=0.617>properly aligned</phrase>, creating a <phrase_Q=0.831>ghosting</phrase> or echoing effect in the generated <phrase_Q=1.000>panorama</phrase>, unless correct <phrase_Q=0.839>depth information</phrase> is taken into account. Taking a <phrase_Q=0.804>cue</phrase> from the similar problem of <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase>, we <phrase_Q=0.836>approximate</phrase> our scene with a <phrase_Q=1.000>Markov random field</phrase> and use <phrase_Q=1.000>belief propagation</phrase> to estimate the <phrase_Q=0.773>maximum a posteriori</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.843>panoramic</phrase> image for that scene.
<phrase_Q=1.000>Reflectance</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.858>Layered</phrase> Dielectrics with <phrase_Q=0.931>Rough Surface</phrase> Boundaries.
A new <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=1.000>scattering</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.858>layered</phrase> dielectrics with <phrase_Q=0.931>rough surface</phrase> boundaries is introduced. The <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> contains a <phrase_Q=0.895>surface scattering</phrase> component together with a <phrase_Q=1.000>subsurface scattering</phrase> component. The former component corresponds to the roughness on the <phrase_Q=1.000>upper</phrase> surface boundary and is modeled using the modified <phrase_Q=0.611>Beckmann model</phrase>. The latter component accounts for both <phrase_Q=1.000>refraction</phrase> due to <phrase_Q=1.000>Fresnel</phrase> transmission through the layer and <phrase_Q=0.827>rough</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>scattering</phrase> at the <phrase_Q=1.000>lower</phrase> layer boundary. By allowing <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.658>roughness parameters</phrase> for each surface boundary we can <phrase_Q=0.523>achieve excellent</phrase> fits of the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> to the measured <phrase_Q=0.852>BRDF</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. Using a well known method of <phrase_Q=0.821>testing</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase> models, we experiment with <phrase_Q=0.852>BRDF</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> from <phrase_Q=1.000>skin</phrase> surface samples (<phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> volunteers) and show that the new <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> outperforms <phrase_Q=1.000>alternative</phrase> variants of the <phrase_Q=0.611>Beckmann model</phrase> and the Lafortune <phrase_Q=0.549>et al</phrase>. <phrase_Q=1.000>reflectance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. As an application in <phrase_Q=0.682>computer graphics</phrase>, we also show that <phrase_Q=0.546>realistic images</phrase> of 3D surfaces can be generated using the new <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, by setting the values of its <phrase_Q=0.674>physical parameters</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-View <phrase_Q=0.823>Multi</phrase>-Exposure <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.882>Multi-view</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> typically rely on same-exposure images as inputs due to the <phrase_Q=0.934>brightness constancy</phrase> assumption. While <phrase_Q=1.000>state</phrase>-of-the-<phrase_Q=1.000>art</phrase> depth <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are excellent, they do not produce <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>dynamic range</phrase> textures required for <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-quality <phrase_Q=0.588>view reconstruction</phrase>. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we propose a technique that adapts <phrase_Q=0.877>multi-view stereo</phrase> for different exposure inputs to simultaneously recover <phrase_Q=0.814>reliable</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> depth and <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>dynamic range</phrase> textures. In our technique, we use an exposure-invariant similarity statistic to establish correspondences, through which we <phrase_Q=0.653>robustly extract</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>radiometric</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.832>response function</phrase> and the image exposures. This enables us to then convert all images to <phrase_Q=1.000>radiance</phrase> space and selectively use the <phrase_Q=1.000>radiance</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> depth and <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>dynamic range</phrase> texture recovery. We show <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> for synthetic and <phrase_Q=0.899>real scenes</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.803>Synthesis</phrase> of 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>Magnetic Field</phrase>-Influenced Body from a <phrase_Q=1.000>Single</phrase> Image.
A method for recovery of a 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=1.000>planet</phrase>-sized <phrase_Q=1.000>cloud</phrase>-like structure that is in motion and deforming but approximately <phrase_Q=0.510>governed by</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>magnetic field</phrase> properties is described. The method allows recovery of the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> from a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.693>intensity image</phrase> in which the structure's <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase> can be observed. The method exploits <phrase_Q=0.836>envelope</phrase> theory and a <phrase_Q=1.000>magnetic field</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. Given one <phrase_Q=0.693>intensity image</phrase> and the segmented <phrase_Q=1.000>silhouette</phrase> in the image, the method proceeds without <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> intervention to produce the 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>. In addition to allowing 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>synthesis</phrase>, the method's capability to yield a very <phrase_Q=0.829>compact</phrase> description offers further utility. Application of the method to <phrase_Q=0.639>real-world data</phrase> is also demonstrated.
A <phrase_Q=0.825>Factorization</phrase> Based <phrase_Q=0.681>Self-Calibration</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.964>Radially Symmetric</phrase> Cameras.
The <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> proposes a novel approach for <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.681>self-calibration</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.964>radially symmetric</phrase> cameras. We <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> these <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> images using notions of <phrase_Q=1.000>distortion</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>center</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.829>concentric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>distortion</phrase> circles around it. The <phrase_Q=1.000>rays</phrase> corresponding to <phrase_Q=1.000>pixels</phrase> lying on a <phrase_Q=1.000>single</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>distortion</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>circle</phrase> form a right <phrase_Q=0.759>circular cone</phrase>. Each of these cones is associated with two unknowns; <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>center</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>focal length</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.806>opening</phrase> angle). In the central case, we consider all <phrase_Q=1.000>distortion</phrase> circles to have the same <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>center</phrase>, whereas in the non-central case they have different <phrase_Q=0.812>optical</phrase> centers lying on the same <phrase_Q=1.000>optical axis</phrase>. Based on this <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> we provide a <phrase_Q=0.825>factorization</phrase> based <phrase_Q=0.681>self-calibration</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> scenes from <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> image matches. Our formulation provides a rich set of constraints to validate the correctness of the <phrase_Q=1.000>distortion</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>center</phrase>. We also propose possible extensions of this <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> in terms of non-<phrase_Q=0.826>planar</phrase> scenes, non-unit <phrase_Q=1.000>aspect ratio</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.823>multi</phrase>-view constraints. <phrase_Q=1.000>Experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are shown.

In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> a novel method for 3D <phrase_Q=0.876>content-based</phrase> search and <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> is proposed. <phrase_Q=0.829>Guided</phrase> by the imperative need for a <phrase_Q=0.814>reliable</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.689>content based search</phrase> tool and the very <phrase_Q=0.558>interesting results</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>research</phrase> work done in the past on the performance of <phrase_Q=0.944>Krawtchouk moments</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.821>Krawtchouk</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.959>moment invariants</phrase> in <phrase_Q=1.000>image processing</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.835>Weighted</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=0.944>Krawtchouk moments</phrase> are introduced for <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> 3D analysis which are suitable for <phrase_Q=0.876>content-based</phrase> search and <phrase_Q=0.809>retrieval</phrase> applications. The <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> was tested on <phrase_Q=1.000>Princeton</phrase> Shape Benchmark. Experiments have shown that the <phrase_Q=0.549>proposed method</phrase> is <phrase_Q=1.000>superior</phrase> in terms of <phrase_Q=0.938>precision-recall</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.812>comparing</phrase> with other well-known methods reported in the <phrase_Q=1.000>literature</phrase>.
A <phrase_Q=0.855>CSC</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.577>Based Classification</phrase> Method for <phrase_Q=0.875>CT</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Bone</phrase> Images.
The <phrase_Q=0.855>CSC</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> structure code) is a <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.846>fast</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.650>two dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.744>segmentation method</phrase> which has been already <phrase_Q=0.840>generalized</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.668>three dimensional</phrase> images. As the <phrase_Q=0.855>CSC</phrase> does not need any <phrase_Q=0.952>prior knowledge</phrase> it can be used for different applications. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we focus on the segmentation of <phrase_Q=1.000>bones</phrase> from <phrase_Q=0.670>Computer Tomography</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.875>CT</phrase>) with the <phrase_Q=0.855>CSC</phrase>. In the <phrase_Q=0.816>postprocessing</phrase> step <phrase_Q=0.855>CSC</phrase> segments will be classified according to their <phrase_Q=1.000>average</phrase> hounsfield value. The classification is <phrase_Q=0.840>steered</phrase> by some <phrase_Q=0.893>application specific</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>topological</phrase> rules.
<phrase_Q=0.911>Illumination Insensitive</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Model</phrase>-Based 3D <phrase_Q=0.933>Object Tracking</phrase> and Texture <phrase_Q=0.821>Refinement</phrase>.
A common approach to <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> is to use a <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of the object to predict what will be observed, and then to compare that with real observations. For methods that make use of the object's <phrase_Q=1.000>photometric</phrase> properties (appearance) in their measurements, illumination inconsistencies between the modeled and actual scene can cause <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> problems. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we address one case: <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=0.814>tracking</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.866>Lambertian</phrase> objects under <phrase_Q=0.843>directional</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> sources. We present an <phrase_Q=0.865>iterative optimization</phrase> method that uses a <phrase_Q=1.000>Kalman filter</phrase> to simultaneously refine estimates of the <phrase_Q=0.778>object motion</phrase>, the illumination, and the <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> texture. We <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> the illumination <phrase_Q=1.000>variance</phrase> between the real and predicted observation using the intensity ratios of corresponding <phrase_Q=0.660>surface points</phrase>, which we then use to make <phrase_Q=0.841>model-based</phrase> image predictions consistent with the real lighting. To demonstrate the effectiveness of our method we present <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> using both synthetic (controlled) and <phrase_Q=0.633>real image sequences</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.851>Object Centered</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase>: <phrase_Q=0.770>Displacement Map</phrase> Estimation Using Texture and Shading.
We consider the problem of <phrase_Q=0.828>recovering</phrase> 3D surface displacements using both shading and <phrase_Q=0.882>multi-view</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> cues. In contrast to traditional disparity or <phrase_Q=0.946>depth map</phrase> representations, the <phrase_Q=0.851>object centered</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.770>displacement map</phrase> representation enables the recovery of complete 3D objects while also ensuring the <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> is not biased <phrase_Q=0.803>towards</phrase> a particular image. Although <phrase_Q=0.916>displacement mapping</phrase> requires a base surface, this <phrase_Q=0.612>base mesh</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.564>easily obtained</phrase> using traditional <phrase_Q=0.688>computer vision</phrase> techniques (e.g., <phrase_Q=0.775>shape-from-silhouette</phrase> or <phrase_Q=0.625>structure-from-motion</phrase>). Our method exploits shading variation due to <phrase_Q=0.597>object rotation</phrase> relative to the <phrase_Q=1.000>light</phrase> source, allowing the recovery of displacements in both textured and textureless regions in a <phrase_Q=0.530>common framework</phrase>. In particular, shading cues are integrated into a <phrase_Q=0.877>multi-view stereo</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.806>photo</phrase>-consistency <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> through the <phrase_Q=0.912>surface normals</phrase> that are implied by the <phrase_Q=0.770>displacement map</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.808>analytic</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>gradient</phrase> of this <phrase_Q=0.806>photo</phrase>-consistency <phrase_Q=1.000>function</phrase> is used to drive a <phrase_Q=0.842>multiresolution</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.970>conjugate gradient</phrase> optimization. We demonstrate the <phrase_Q=0.836>geometric</phrase> quality of the reconstructed displacements on several example objects including a <phrase_Q=1.000>human</phrase> face.
<phrase_Q=0.835>Flatness</phrase> and Orientation Signature for <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> and Matching 3D Objects.
This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> proposes a new technique for <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> and matching <phrase_Q=0.668>three-dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.899>rigid objects</phrase> by encoding the <phrase_Q=0.816>fluctuation</phrase> of the surface and the variation of its normal around an oriented point on the surface as the surface expands. The surface of the object is encoded into two <phrase_Q=0.650>two-dimensional</phrase> curves as the surface signature on each point, and then the collection of the signatures are used to <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> and match the object. The signatures <phrase_Q=0.646>implicitly encode</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>curvature</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>symmetry</phrase> of the surface around an oriented point. This <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> technique is <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> to scale, orientation, noise, patch <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase>, occlusion, and cluttering.
<phrase_Q=0.914>Large-Scale</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>Modeling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.833>Parametric</phrase> Surfaces Using <phrase_Q=1.000>Spherical Harmonics</phrase>.
We present an approach for <phrase_Q=0.914>large-scale</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.833>parametric</phrase> surfaces using <phrase_Q=1.000>spherical harmonics</phrase> (SHs). A standard <phrase_Q=0.740>least square</phrase> fitting (<phrase_Q=0.868>LSF</phrase>) method for <phrase_Q=0.884>SH</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.803>expansion</phrase> is not <phrase_Q=0.822>scalable</phrase> and cannot accurately <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> large 3D surfaces. We propose an <phrase_Q=0.836>iterative</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.833>residual</phrase> fitting (<phrase_Q=0.827>IRF</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>, and demonstrate its effectiveness and <phrase_Q=1.000>scalability</phrase> in creating accurate <phrase_Q=0.884>SH</phrase> models for large 3D surfaces. These <phrase_Q=0.914>large-scale</phrase> and accurate <phrase_Q=0.833>parametric</phrase> models can be used in many applications in <phrase_Q=0.688>computer vision</phrase>, graphics, and <phrase_Q=0.940>biomedical imaging</phrase>. As a simple extension of <phrase_Q=0.868>LSF</phrase>, <phrase_Q=0.827>IRF</phrase> is very <phrase_Q=0.550>easy to implement</phrase> and requires few machine resources.
<phrase_Q=0.795>Graph Cut Based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.860>Multiple View</phrase> Segmentation for 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Reconstruction</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we propose a novel framework for efficiently <phrase_Q=0.814>extracting</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>foreground objects</phrase> in so called shortbaseline <phrase_Q=0.949>image sequences</phrase>. At <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> a meanshift <phrase_Q=0.745>segmentation algorithm</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>partitions</phrase> each image of the <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> into a certain number of regions.
