Within the <phrase_Q=0.771>graph cut optimization</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> we define new <phrase_Q=1.000>energy</phrase> terms to increase the robustness and to keep the segmentation of the <phrase_Q=0.881>foreground object</phrase> coherent across all images of the <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.807>Finally</phrase>, a refined <phrase_Q=0.921>graph cut</phrase> segmentation and several adjustment operations allow an accurate and effective <phrase_Q=0.942>foreground extraction</phrase>. The obtained <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> are demonstrated on several <phrase_Q=0.639>real world data sets</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.804>Depth Images</phrase>: Representations and <phrase_Q=1.000>Real-Time Rendering</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.804>Depth Images</phrase> are viable representations that can be computed from the <phrase_Q=0.885>real world</phrase> using cameras and/or other scanning devices. The <phrase_Q=0.946>depth map</phrase> provides 2<phrase_Q=0.586>\frac</phrase>{1}{2}<phrase_Q=0.835>D</phrase> structure of the scene. A set of <phrase_Q=0.804>Depth Images</phrase> can provide <phrase_Q=0.827>hole</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase> rendering of the scene. <phrase_Q=0.927>Multiple views</phrase> need to <phrase_Q=0.829>blended</phrase> to provide smooth <phrase_Q=0.827>hole</phrase>-<phrase_Q=1.000>free</phrase> rendering, however. Such a representation of the scene is bulky and needs good <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> for <phrase_Q=1.000>real-time rendering</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.810>efficient</phrase> representation. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we present a discussion on the <phrase_Q=0.813>Depth Image</phrase> representation and provide a <phrase_Q=0.899>GPU-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> that can render large models represented using <phrase_Q=0.812>DIs</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.662>real time</phrase>. We then present a <phrase_Q=0.865>proxy-based</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.804>compression scheme</phrase> for <phrase_Q=0.804>Depth Images</phrase> and provide <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> for the same. <phrase_Q=1.000>Results</phrase> are shown on <phrase_Q=0.746>synthetic scenes</phrase> under different conditions and on some scenes generated from images. Lastly, we initiate discussion on varying <phrase_Q=0.685>quality levels</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.846>IBR</phrase> and show a way to create representations using <phrase_Q=0.812>DIs</phrase> with different <phrase_Q=1.000>trade</phrase>-offs between <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> size and <phrase_Q=0.621>rendering quality</phrase>. This enables the use of this representation for a <phrase_Q=1.000>variety</phrase> of rendering situations.
How Far Can We <phrase_Q=0.862>Go</phrase> with <phrase_Q=0.786>Local Optimization</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.662>Real-Time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Stereo</phrase> Matching.
Applications such as <phrase_Q=1.000>robot</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>navigation</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>augmented reality</phrase> require <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase>-accuracy <phrase_Q=0.935>dense disparity maps</phrase> in <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.837>online</phrase>. Due to time constraint, most <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> applications rely on local <phrase_Q=0.822>winner</phrase>-take-all optimization in the <phrase_Q=0.719>disparity computation</phrase> process. These local approaches are generally outperformed by offline <phrase_Q=1.000>global optimization</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.544>based algorithms</phrase>. However, <phrase_Q=0.743>recent research</phrase> shows that, through <phrase_Q=0.583>carefully selecting</phrase> and aggregating the matching costs of <phrase_Q=0.853>neighboring pixels</phrase>, the <phrase_Q=0.864>disparity maps</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>produced</phrase> by a local approach can be more accurate than those generated by many <phrase_Q=1.000>global optimization</phrase> techniques. We are therefore motivated to investigate whether these <phrase_Q=0.696>cost aggregation</phrase> approaches can be adopted in <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> applications and, if so, how well they perform under the <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> constraint. The evaluation is conducted on a <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>stereo</phrase> platform, which utilizes the <phrase_Q=0.681>processing power</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.801>programmable graphics hardware</phrase>. Several recent <phrase_Q=0.696>cost aggregation</phrase> approaches are also implemented and optimized for <phrase_Q=0.945>graphics hardware</phrase> so that <phrase_Q=0.662>real-time</phrase> speed can be achieved. The performances of these <phrase_Q=0.814>aggregation</phrase> approaches in terms of both <phrase_Q=0.701>processing speed</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.589>result quality</phrase> are reported.
A <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> Approach to <phrase_Q=0.810>Building</phrase> Footprint Extraction from <phrase_Q=0.774>Aerial LIDAR Data</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=0.814>Building footprints</phrase> have been shown to be extremely useful in <phrase_Q=1.000>urban planning</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>infrastructure</phrase> development, and <phrase_Q=0.827>roof</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.809>modeling</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.545>Current methods</phrase> for creating these <phrase_Q=0.847>footprints</phrase> are often highly manual and rely largely on <phrase_Q=1.000>architectural</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>blueprints</phrase> or skilled modelers. In this work we will use <phrase_Q=0.774>aerial LIDAR data</phrase> to generate <phrase_Q=0.814>building footprints</phrase> automatically. Existing <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> methods have been mostly unsuccessful due to large amounts of noise around <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> edges. We present a novel <phrase_Q=1.000>Bayesian</phrase> technique for <phrase_Q=0.775>automatically constructing</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>building footprints</phrase> from a <phrase_Q=0.671>pre-classified</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>LIDAR</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>point cloud</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> computes a boundederror <phrase_Q=0.836>approximate</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> footprint using an application of the <phrase_Q=1.000>shortest path</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase>. We then determine the <phrase_Q=0.588>most probable</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.810>building</phrase> footprint by <phrase_Q=0.802>maximizing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>posterior probability</phrase> using <phrase_Q=0.712>linear optimization</phrase> and <phrase_Q=1.000>simulated annealing</phrase> techniques. We have applied our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> to more than 300 buildings in our <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> set and observe that we obtain accurate <phrase_Q=0.814>building footprints</phrase> compared to the <phrase_Q=0.942>ground truth</phrase>. Our <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> is <phrase_Q=0.816>automatic</phrase> and can be applied to other <phrase_Q=0.860>man</phrase>-made shapes such as roads and <phrase_Q=1.000>telecommunication</phrase> lines with <phrase_Q=0.773>minor modifications</phrase>.
A System for <phrase_Q=0.816>Reconstructing</phrase> Integrated <phrase_Q=0.927>Texture Maps</phrase> for Large Structures.
We consider the problem of creating integrated <phrase_Q=0.927>texture maps</phrase> of large structures scanned with a time-of-<phrase_Q=0.815>flight</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.974>laser scanner</phrase> and imaged with a <phrase_Q=1.000>digital camera</phrase>. The <phrase_Q=0.545>key issue</phrase> in creating integrated textures is <phrase_Q=0.808>correcting</phrase> for the <phrase_Q=0.962>spatially varying</phrase> illumination across the structure. In most cases, the illumination cannot be controlled, and <phrase_Q=0.827>dense</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.822>spatial</phrase> estimates of illumination are not possible. We present a system for processing multiple <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> images into <phrase_Q=0.530>an integrated</phrase> texture that makes use of the <phrase_Q=0.974>laser scanner</phrase> return intensity and the captured <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase>, together with <phrase_Q=0.822>color</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.804>balancing</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.828>mapping</phrase> of illumination-corrected images onto the <phrase_Q=1.000>target</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>geometry</phrase> after filtering into two <phrase_Q=1.000>spatial frequency</phrase> bands.
<phrase_Q=0.889>Motion Editing</phrase> in 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>Video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>Database</phrase>.
As the <phrase_Q=0.686>next generation</phrase> of <phrase_Q=1.000>media</phrase>, 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> is attracting <phrase_Q=0.601>increased attention</phrase>. 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> is a <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.668>three dimensional</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.820>mesh</phrase> models, captured and generated for a real <phrase_Q=0.833>dynamic</phrase> object. In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase>, we present a simple framework of <phrase_Q=0.889>motion editing</phrase> in 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.803>re</phrase>-use 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase>. Our system is composed of two modules. In the <phrase_Q=0.817>first</phrase> module, a motion <phrase_Q=1.000>database</phrase> is automatically set up from original 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> sequences <phrase_Q=0.670>off-line</phrase> by <phrase_Q=0.803>analyzing</phrase> the <phrase_Q=0.904>feature vectors</phrase> of each <phrase_Q=0.801>frame</phrase>. It is observed that our original 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> sequences have a <phrase_Q=0.584>two-level</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.817>temporal</phrase> structure. A <phrase_Q=0.818>fine</phrase>-to-coarse method is proposed to extract such a structure. 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> is segmented into the <phrase_Q=0.818>fine</phrase>-level structure by a three <phrase_Q=1.000>reference frame</phrase> strategy and then is <phrase_Q=0.807>clustered</phrase> into the <phrase_Q=0.675>coarse-level</phrase> structure. In the <phrase_Q=0.806>second</phrase> module, users can synthesize the motions to edit a new 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.837>online</phrase>. A <phrase_Q=0.840>cost function</phrase> is optimized to <phrase_Q=0.801>transit</phrase> between two motions with the users' requirements. All the <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithms</phrase> in the system are based on the analysis in <phrase_Q=0.916>feature vector</phrase> space and the edited 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>video</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sequence</phrase> is played using <phrase_Q=1.000>OpenGL</phrase>.
The ASDMCon <phrase_Q=0.810>Project</phrase>: The <phrase_Q=0.802>Challenge</phrase> of <phrase_Q=0.802>Detecting</phrase> Defects on <phrase_Q=1.000>Construction</phrase> Sites.
Techniques for <phrase_Q=0.668>three dimensional</phrase> (3D) <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase> and analysis of as-built conditions of buildings are <phrase_Q=0.780>gaining acceptance</phrase> in the <phrase_Q=1.000>Architecture</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>Engineering</phrase>, and <phrase_Q=1.000>Construction</phrase> (<phrase_Q=0.840>AEC</phrase>) <phrase_Q=1.000>community</phrase>. <phrase_Q=0.882>Early detection</phrase> of defects on <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> sites is one domain where these techniques have the potential to revolutionize an <phrase_Q=1.000>industry</phrase>, since <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> defects can consume a significant portion of a project's budget. The ASDMCon <phrase_Q=0.810>project</phrase> is developing methods to aid site managers in <phrase_Q=0.802>detecting</phrase> and managing <phrase_Q=1.000>construction</phrase> defects using 3D <phrase_Q=0.817>imaging</phrase> and other <phrase_Q=0.803>advanced</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>sensor</phrase> technologies. This <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> presents <phrase_Q=0.591>an overview</phrase> of the <phrase_Q=0.810>project</phrase>, its 4D <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> environment, and the 3D segmentation and recognition strategies that are being employed to automate <phrase_Q=0.959>defect detection</phrase>.
<phrase_Q=1.000>High</phrase>-Performance <phrase_Q=0.754>Multi-View Reconstruction</phrase>.
We present a <phrase_Q=1.000>high</phrase> performance <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> approach, which generates true 3D models from <phrase_Q=0.927>multiple views</phrase> with known <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> parameters. The complete pipeline from <phrase_Q=0.946>depth map</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.801>generation</phrase> over <phrase_Q=0.813>depth image</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>integration</phrase> to the final 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.811>visualization</phrase> is performed on <phrase_Q=0.525>programmable graphics processing units</phrase> (<phrase_Q=1.000>GPUs</phrase>). The proposed pipeline is suitable for <phrase_Q=1.000>long</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.949>image sequences</phrase> and uses a <phrase_Q=0.919>plane-sweep</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.934>depth estimation</phrase> procedure optionally employing <phrase_Q=0.826>robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.881>image similarity</phrase> functions to generate a set of <phrase_Q=0.804>depth images</phrase>. The subsequent <phrase_Q=0.835>volumetric</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>fusion</phrase> step combines these <phrase_Q=0.926>depth maps</phrase> into an impicit <phrase_Q=0.808>surface representation</phrase> of the final <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, which can be directly displayed using <phrase_Q=1.000>GPU</phrase>-based <phrase_Q=0.859>raycasting</phrase> methods. Depending on the number of input views and the desired <phrase_Q=0.813>resolution</phrase> of the final <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>computing</phrase> times <phrase_Q=1.000>range</phrase> from several seconds to a few minutes. The quality of the obtained models is illustrated with <phrase_Q=0.885>real-world</phrase> datasets.
<phrase_Q=0.802>Multiple Camera</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.829>Calibration</phrase> Using <phrase_Q=0.826>Robust</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.829>Perspective</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>Factorization</phrase>.
In this <phrase_Q=1.000>paper</phrase> we address the problem of <phrase_Q=0.828>recovering</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.508>structure and motion</phrase> from a <phrase_Q=0.522>large number</phrase> of intrinsically calibrated <phrase_Q=0.829>perspective</phrase> cameras. We describe a method that combines (1) <phrase_Q=0.839>weak-perspective</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> in the presence of <phrase_Q=0.806>noisy</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.924>missing data</phrase> and (2) an <phrase_Q=1.000>algorithm</phrase> that updates <phrase_Q=0.839>weak-perspective</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> to <phrase_Q=0.829>perspective</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>reconstruction</phrase> by incrementally <phrase_Q=0.808>estimating</phrase> the <phrase_Q=1.000>projective</phrase> depths. The method also solves for the <phrase_Q=0.819>reversal</phrase> ambiguity associated with <phrase_Q=0.840>affine</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.825>factorization</phrase> techniques. The method has been <phrase_Q=0.699>successfully applied</phrase> to the problem of <phrase_Q=0.852>calibrating</phrase> the external parameters (<phrase_Q=0.564>position and orientation</phrase>) of several <phrase_Q=0.802>multiple-camera</phrase> setups. <phrase_Q=1.000>Results</phrase> obtained with synthetic and <phrase_Q=1.000>experimental</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>data</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.536>compare favourably</phrase> with <phrase_Q=1.000>results</phrase> obtained with <phrase_Q=0.824>nonlinear</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.814>minimization</phrase> such as <phrase_Q=0.976>bundle adjustment</phrase>.
Angle <phrase_Q=1.000>Independent</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.976>Bundle Adjustment</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.821>Refinement</phrase>.
Obtaining a <phrase_Q=1.000>digital</phrase> <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase> of a <phrase_Q=0.885>real-world</phrase> 3D scene is a <phrase_Q=0.648>challenging task</phrase> pursued by <phrase_Q=0.688>computer vision</phrase> and <phrase_Q=0.682>computer graphics</phrase>. Given an initial <phrase_Q=0.836>approximate</phrase> 3D <phrase_Q=1.000>model</phrase>, a popular <phrase_Q=0.821>refinement</phrase> process is to perform a <phrase_Q=0.976>bundle adjustment</phrase> of the estimated <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> position, <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> orientation, and <phrase_Q=0.605>scene points</phrase>. Unfortunately, simultaneously <phrase_Q=0.811>solving</phrase> for both <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> position and <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase> orientation is an <phrase_Q=0.712>ill-conditioned</phrase> problem. To address this issue, we propose <phrase_Q=0.552>an improved</phrase>, <phrase_Q=1.000>camera</phrase>-orientation <phrase_Q=1.000>independent</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.840>cost function</phrase> that can be used instead of the standard <phrase_Q=0.976>bundle adjustment</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.840>cost function</phrase>. This yields a new <phrase_Q=0.976>bundle adjustment</phrase> formulation which exhibits noticeably better numerical behavior, but at the expense of an increased <phrase_Q=0.737>computational cost</phrase>. We alleviate the <phrase_Q=0.533>additional cost</phrase> by automatically <phrase_Q=0.814>partitioning</phrase> the dataset into <phrase_Q=0.582>smaller subsets</phrase>. Minimizing our <phrase_Q=0.840>cost function</phrase> for these subsets still <phrase_Q=0.518>achieves significant</phrase> <phrase_Q=0.935>error reduction</phrase> over standard <phrase_Q=0.976>bundle adjustment</phrase>. We <phrase_Q=0.611>empirically demonstrate</phrase> our formulation using several different size models and <phrase_Q=0.949>image sequences</phrase>.
